PUB-DATE: November 12, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 3303 words

HEADLINE: Fear in the Mail -- A special report.;
Alarmed by Fund-Raiser, The Elderly Give Millions

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
"All the Social Security Trust Fund Money Is Gone!" screamed the official-looking envelope received by millions of elderly Americans earlier this year.
The letter inside called for emergency action to halt "the enormous fraud that has taken place at your expense" and asked for $5 in membership dues, and an extra $5 or $10 or $15, so the United Seniors Association could keep on "fighting hard in the nation's capital to insure the rights and benefits of America's seniors are protected." 
 It is the minimalist approach to public advocacy. United Seniors, to which hundreds of thousands of retirees have contributed millions of dollars over the last year, has no lobbyist and its directors are experts in fund-raising, not in the problems of the elderly. Nearly all its proceeds are used to send out still more letters seeking more donors, usually with language that critics describe as misleadingly frightening.
That letter was signed by George L. Murphy, former Republican Senator from California and, until his death in May, honorary chairman of United Seniors, a new nonprofit, tax-exempt advocacy group.
As those who sent money learned from the strident solicitations they have received monthly ever since, the actual chairman of this seeming bulwark of Social Security and Medicare, the largest Federal benefit programs, is the archconservative Richard A. Viguerie.
A leader of the New Right movement that helped put Ronald Reagan in the White House and has clamored for a balanced Federal budget, Mr. Viguerie remains a familiar source of stinging commentary. He is best known as a pioneer and master of direct-mail fund-raising, which he says he devotes to the conservative cause.
 
Master at Raising Money
 But a detailed examination of Mr. Viguerie's recent turn to the elderly for money shows him to be a master, above all, at generating new revenue for his cash-starved personal business, now called Viguerie & Associates.
Since 1989, in a pattern that experts in philanthropy say raises serious questions about Mr. Viguerie's motives, he has either created or worked for at least four different advocacy groups that have bombarded the elderly with tens of millions of solicitations, generating millions of dollars in fees for his private companies.
Twice he set up his own groups that competed with the organizations that bought his direct-mail services, possibly undermining his clients by soliciting many of the same retirees on exactly the same issues.
Mr. Viguerie did not respond to numerous requests over a two-month period for comment, including messages left with members of his staff by telephone and in person noting that his business practices were being criticized.
In his advocacy for the elderly Mr. Viguerie appears to have followed the letter if not the spirit of the generally lax Federal and state laws covering tax-exempt advocacy groups, which according to Internal Revenue Service regulations must be dedicated to a social purpose. Devoting most resources to mailing, for example, is legal because the I.R.S. allows advocacy groups to count the messages in their letters as public education.
But Mr. Viguerie's new dedication to helping old people appears to have been pursued in a manner filled with potential conflicts of interest, in operations that seem, above all, to generate money for his indebted private enterprises.
Mr. Viguerie's organizations use nearly all of the donations they receive to send out still more letters, and in the process spread large sums among list-renters, letter-writers, printers, mailers and other subcontractors, always including Mr. Viguerie himself.
In the case of United Seniors, Mr. Viguerie founded and directs an organization that takes advantage of the large postal subsidies available to tax-exempt groups to send what critics in Congress call fright mail. The group, in turn, spends hundreds of thousands of dollars a year to rent the mailing lists that his for-profit company compiles and maintains.
 
'It's a Sweetheart Deal'
 "It's a sweetheart deal," said Kenneth Albrecht, President of the National Charities Information Bureau, a watchdog group in New York. "He is using a nonprofit to make money for his own company."
Mr. Viguerie's activities show how easily charities and fund-raisers can tap popular passions and public subsidies for private gain by subtly manipulating the fund-raising operations in ways that are difficult for donors or government regulators to detect.
The examination of his activities, which included review of dozens of financial documents and contracts and records of lawsuits as well as interviews with numerous current and former employees, has also provided an unusually detailed portrait of the fund-raising tactics followed by Mr. Viguerie and several proteges, who make up a significant subsector of the fund-raising industry. Many direct-mail companies subscribe to a code of ethics that prohibits many of Mr. Viguerie's practices.
 
The Organization
Odd Mission For Conservatives
 United Seniors, Mr. Viguerie's latest group focusing on the elderly, raised $2 million in the last four months of 1991 and now claims 350,000 contributors. It is one of a handful of groups that are peppering the nation's elderly with ominous news of the latest "threat" to their Social Security and Medicare benefits, always with a request for money.
The United Seniors board and executives consist entirely of direct-mail experts and people active in conservative causes, almost all of them former Viguerie employees. The group says the alarms sounded by its mailings are its main contribution to political change.
Tying conservatism to the defense of mandatory spending programs for the elderly turns political tradition upside down. Conservatives have long derided Social Security and Medicare as bordering on socialism. As recently as 1983, Patrick J. Buchanan, whom Mr. Viguerie has championed for President, called for making Social Security voluntary; Mr. Murphy, as a Senator in 1965, voted against the creation of Medicare.
But in the last four years, as angry and frightened retirees were catalyzed by a Medicare tax and emerged as large donors, Mr. Viguerie emerged as a stalwart defender of elderly benefits. He links the fate of these programs to the more traditional conservative goal of slashing the rest of the Government, so there will be more money left for the elderly. Recently, he has also crusaded against applying any income test to receivers of elderly benefits.
 
Bipartisan Criticism
 Members of Congress from both parties and officials of the Social Security Administration say United Seniors and similar groups are preying on vulnerable old people with statements that distort the problems facing Social Security and Medicare, especially by exaggerating the threat to current retirees. Some charge Mr. Viguerie with cynical opportunism.
"If conservatism isn't selling very well, and the deadly Commie menace is dried up, then let's find some other trouble in River City," is how Representative Andy Jacobs, Democrat of Indiana, characterized Mr. Viguerie's motives. Mr. Jacobs's subcommittee on Social Security held hearings on United Seniors and several other groups this spring.
"The motive of these groups is to raise money," said Jim Bunning of Kentucky, a Republican on the subcommittee. Congress has acted to outlaw advocacy letters that mimic official Government correspondence, but cannot regulate the way they express their views.
Steven J. Allen, the editor of the United Seniors newsletter, who spoke on behalf of the organization, said, "These politicians from a corrupt Congress who criticize us are politically motivated, on a witch hunt."
He said it was the spendthrift Congress, not the statements of United Seniors, that people should be afraid of, and he portrayed his group as a harbinger of a new conservative movement.
 
The Business
A Lot of Money Is Churned Up
 Mr. Viguerie arrived at his dedication to the elderly by a roundabout path that started in 1980. That year Mr. Viguerie, who in the 1970's became famous as a fund raiser, joined forces with a politically ambitious, conservative school board president in Mobile, Ala., who wanted to take his appeals for traditional values in education, school prayer and money to a national audience. The official, Dan C. Alexander Jr., had formed a nonprofit group called the Taxpayers Education Lobby.
Both of them got something they wanted. With Mr. Viguerie's direct-mail help, the schools group received donations from hundreds of thousands of citizens over a decade. Mr. Viguerie, in turn, got a contract filled with exceptional advantages for a hired fund raiser.
Most charities rent lists of names and addresses from a wide variety of sources, and build a roster of members to whom they then turn for repeat donations. Groups often rent out their rosters to others, but try not to let their contributors be flooded with directly competing requests.
In this case, Mr. Viguerie gained total control over his client's donor list, which was gathered at the client's expense. The fact that these people had recently made a donation made their names valuable commodities in the mailing-list marketplace.
The education lobby could send repeat letters to its own donors, but under the contract could not rent out their names. Mr. Viguerie, in contrast, had the right to make any commercial use he wanted of the group's donor list. He could use it to replenish his company's lists, which he constantly rented out to other groups and businesses for profit. He could rent the lobby's member names to competing charities, or use them for mailings of his own. (Lists of people who make actually contributions are typically rented for about $8,000 for a single use of 100,000 names.)
 
Unusual Advantages
 In another unusual feature of the agreement, Mr. Viguerie owned the language in the letters themselves, which he developed at the group's expense, and he later gained control over selection of all subcontractors.
The list control and other provisions of this contract would constitute "a categorical violation of our ethical rules," said Robert Tigner of the Association of Direct Response Fundraising Counsel. That organization, to which many direct-mail companies, but not Mr. Viguerie's, belong, has set guidelines for the industry.
"This was a cash cow for Viguerie," said Denison Hatch, editor of the newsletter "Who's Mailing What" and a direct-mail expert.
Receiving fees for every letter sent, Mr. Viguerie benefited from large, expensive mailings even when there was little chance they would pull in donations. When the contributions fell short, as they often did, the education lobby fell into debt to Mr. Viguerie. The solution to this was more mailing.
It is common for new charities to go into debt initially, but in this case the debt reached $847,000 by 1989, after nine years.
In the strange economics of direct mail, such debts did not necessarily mean that Mr. Viguerie was losing money. Nor did it mean that the education group's chief, Mr. Alexander, was necessarily unhappy. His organization, though virtually under Mr. Viguerie's control, still received thousands of dollars each month out of the donations to cover salaries and expenses.
 
A New Issue
Fear Is Turned Into Contributions
 In early 1986 the Taxpayers Education Lobby, which was collecting $1 million or $2 million, depending on the year, moved from Alabama to Mr. Viguerie's offices in Falls Church, Va.
As it turned out, Mr. Alexander had reasons of his own for leaving Mobile. In late 1986, Federal prosecutors there indicted him for extorting kickbacks in school construction projects between 1974 and 1983. He was convicted and ultimately served 51 months of a 12-year prison sentence, leaving his wife, Fay, in charge of the education lobby.
In early 1987, just before Mr. Alexander entered prison, Mr. Viguerie, his own company struggling with a decline in conservative giving and disastrous investments, met with Mr. Alexander to amend their contract. Henceforth Mr. Viguerie was entitled to four debt-reduction mailings each year, in which the net proceeds would be used to pay off the education lobby's accumulated debt to his company.
In July 1988 Congress provided a plump new target that would draw Mr. Viguerie and Mr. Alexander's organization into a far more lucrative solicitation of elderly Americans. Congress passed the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act, creating insurance for major illness that was financed with a new, graduated surtax on the more affluent Medicare recipients.
As word of the new tax spread among the elderly there was an explosion of protest. Mr. Viguerie arranged for the Taxpayers Education Lobby to do a test mailing, with a letter that critics said was deceptive in its suggestion that all retirees, rather than a minority of the better-off, owed a large new tax. The response was excellent and the education lobby formed a new group, the Seniors Coalition Against the Tax.
With its new mission, the organization's income jumped in one year from $1 million to $4 million, according to its tax returns. But Mr. Viguerie, while managing that effort for large fees, formed a nearly identical, competing group of his own, sending similar high-pressure letters on the same issue and generating a second stream of donations, this time entirely in his hands.
 
Some in Congress Are Angry
 In October 1989, a chastened Congress repealed the new insurance and tax. Angry lawmakers lashed out at several groups for what they described as a campaign of misinformation conducted for profit. In a hearing, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, chairman of the Senate subcommittee on Social Security, condemned a new brand of fright mail that "can terrorize, even constitute an assault of sorts, on, say, the 80-year-old widow living alone who doesn't have anyone to tell her it isn't so."
Senator David Pryor of Arkansas, head of the post office subcommittee, said in a hearing that Mr. Viguerie and his associates "appear to be opportunists who may have acted on the very fringe of the law -- and at the expense of those for whom they claim concern."
 
A Network
A New Generation Of Fund Raisers
 The tax repealed, the schools group originally from Mobile, Ala., continued nevertheless. The Seniors Coalition raised $9 million in 1990 and $8 million in 1991, but large debts to Mr. Viguerie persisted.
"It was like the Wizard of Oz," recalled a person who was involved and spoke on condition of anonymity. "He kept the checks coming in, and he would say to pay no attention to that deficit, to that man behind the curtain."
In early 1990, Mr. Viguerie once again created competition for his client. Millions of elderly people, including Seniors Coalition members, began receiving letters from the Retired Americans Legislative Lobby, Inc.. "I need your immediate help to stop the Government from 'stealing' our Social Security Funds," pleaded its national chairman, George Murphy, whom Mr. Viguerie had hired.
This new organization led Mr. Viguerie to a different questionable maneuver. It was incorporated as a for-profit company, with Mr. Viguerie as sole owner, and intended to combine advocacy with programs like travel services. But little more than a year later, the retired Americans lobby was more than $1.1 million in debt, including $162,000 owed to Mr. Viguerie's business.
In 1991 the company's assets and liabilities were taken over by the United Seniors Association, a new nonprofit group Mr. Viguerie had started. Offsetting the $1.1 million burden of debt with which it was born, according to a United Seniors financial statement, was the transfer of the retired Americans lobby's mailing list, asserted to have a comparable market value.
This high valuation of the mailing list was unusual and open to question, especially since creditors held claims against the list, according to experts in philanthropy. What is definite is that donors to United Seniors have provided money to pay off some of Mr. Viguerie's debts, including to his own companies. "The nonprofit he heads is pulling his profit-making company's chestnuts out of the fire," said Mr. Albrecht of the charities information bureau.
 
Conflicts
Allegiances Hard to Pin Down
 The United Seniors Association in action is replete with conflicting interests.
In principle, tax-exempt advocacy groups are headed by independent directors who see that resources are devoted to the cause. Mass mailings generally hold the potential for abuse. They involve the frequent borrowing and spending of hundreds of thousands of dollars, and decisions about when, what, and how often to mail can easily be tilted to maximize income of list renters and mailers rather than the charity.
United Seniors does not have a standing contract with Mr. Viguerie's direct-mail company, but it does regularly rent lists of potential donors from the firm. Rental fees to Mr. Viguerie in late 1991 alone totaled $199,000, according to the group's financial statement.
All such transactions are conducted at arms' length, Mr. Allen said, and at market rates. But in this case the arms appear to be inherently short, raising questions about where loyalties would lie when the financial needs of Mr. Viguerie's nonprofit group and his for-profit company differed. The United Seniors board consists of Mr. Viguerie as chairman, and four close business associates or friends.
It also appears that at least one director of United Seniors has been paid simultaneously by that group and Mr. Viguerie's company. Speaking through Mr. Allen, the director, Sandra Butler, president and treasurer of United Seniors, refused to say whether she or other officers had dual financial allegiances. But in a Dec. 3, 1991, document dated Dec. 3, 1991, reorganizing Mr. Viguerie's private companies Ms. Butler, who had supposedly been working full time with United Seniors since its incorporation the previous May, signed as an officer of Viguerie & Associates.
 
Invented Direct Mail
 Asked about United Seniors' extensive reliance on lists owned by its chairman, Mr. Allen said: "We have available to us the person who invented direct mail. It would be foolish not to use those resources."
On Jan. 1, as United Seniors was expanding it operations, an angry Taxpayers Education Lobby/Seniors Coalition canceled its fund-raising contract with Mr. Viguerie. He responded with a lawsuit, asserting that under the 1980 contract the group owed him nearly $550,000, plus five cents for every letter it continued to send using ideas his company had developed.
In reply, the organization said Mr. Viguerie's company had "breached its obligation of good faith, loyalty and fair dealing" by "entering into direct competition" with it and "using and abusing the names" of its donors. But Mr. Viguerie, with a written contract, had the upper hand and under a private settlement he is receiving $600,000, according to people involved.
Now, as part of that settlement, donors to the Seniors Coalition are unknowingly sending $4,000 every week to Mr. Viguerie. He also received a copy of the Seniors Coalition donor file, updated as of March 31.
And now, Mr. Viguerie is apparently starting yet another nonprofit organization that will solicit the nation's elderly on much the same issues, churning more money through his companies. In a test letter recently prepared by Viguerie & Associates, former Senator Edward J. Gurney, a Florida Republican, warns on behalf of a new group called the 60/Plus Association that "the Government is now cheating seniors -- by taxing them on their Social Security benefits!"

Nearly all of the group's income has been used to send out more mailings. (Naum Kazhden/The New York Times); Richard A. Viguerie, a New Right movement leader, is chairman of United Seniors. PUB-DATE: November 12, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1960 words

HEADLINE: Mapping Out the Wireless-Phone Future

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
A multibillion-dollar telephone revolution that caught almost everyone by surprise is occurring in the United States, with a potential as great as that of the telegraph and transistor radio for changing communications.
Vigorous debate over how to apportion the benefits and costs appears likely to delay pending Government approval of the system and bring the issue before the Clinton Administration. 
 Millions of Americans are now buying cellular phones -- about 7,000 a day, many more than had been anticipated -- to carry around with them in cars, handbags and briefcases. And it appears almost certain that millions more Americans will flock to a new system being developed: shirt-pocket or even fountain-pen-size wireless phones smaller than cellular and not unlike the old Dick Tracy two-way wrist radio.
 
The Handheld Servant
 The system, called personal communications services, or P.C.S. in industry argot, is designed to be more versatile than cellular communications and may -- or may not, depending on the Government decisions ahead -- be much cheaper for everyone to use. The handheld phones will also work as wireless computers to send data to other computers or relay it for fax transmission.
"One thing we know about P.C.S is that it will provide people the electronic equivalent of butlers and secretaries," said James E. Katz, a staff sociologist at Bellcore, the research arm of the regional Bell companies. "It spreads to the middle class what only robber barons once enjoyed."
In less than a decade, the cellular business has grown larger than the McDonald's fast-food empire. And last week, A.T.& T., the world's largest telecommunications company, placed a $3.8 billion bet on its wireless future, saying it seeks to buy one-third of McCaw Cellular Communications, the nation's largest cellular carrier.
 
High Cellular Prices
 Nevertheless, cellular-phone users are finding that the price of making wireless phone calls has remained very high -- in some cases, as much as 80 times the price of a conventional call. And part of the excitement over the new P.C.S. system is its potential for changing that.
"Cellular calls are not cost based; they're insanity based," said Herschel Shostek, a telecommunications consultant in Silver Spring, Md. The history of the cellular industry should serve as a ready guide for what to avoid, others contend.
The cellular industry denies that prices are artificially high, arguing that the costs of constructing radio transmission stations and maintaining equipment have kept the business from being profitable.
The factors for the success of P.C.S. -- consumer cost, industry profit, the speed of putting the system in place -- all depend on how the Government views the cellular experience, on how the new markets will be organized, with how many companies, how many customers each and in what size geographic regions.
The Federal Communications Commission had planned to act as early as the end of the year. But with the change of Administrations and the likely replacement of at least two of the five commissioners, including the chairman, Alfred C. Sikes, the decision will no doubt be delayed.
 
The Prospect
A Portable Phone For Use Anywhere
 The new devices, like cellular phones, will in essence be battery-operated radios. They will communicate via receiving and transmitting stations that feed the calls into the world's network of wired telephones.
Cellular phones work best in open spaces. P.C.S. phones, however, will operate from a great many more locations -- from inside office buildings, elevators, trains and subway platforms, for instance.
Unlike a cellular phone, which can have a range of about 20 miles, a P.C.S. unit will be limited to perhaps a few thousand feet. But it will send signals to many more transmitter stations that themselves will be much smaller, cheaper and easier to install than cellular stations. Where a city might have a dozen cellular stations, a P.C.S system might have hundreds, permitting lower-power transmission and very small phones. It is because the user will never be far from a transmitter that the devices will work within buildings and tunnels.
The phones will be relatively cheap to manufacture because of advances in electronics miniaturization and computing power.
For the present, P.C.S. is not threatening to make cellular immediately obsolete, because P.C.S. has a short range. But in the future, as the technology moves forward, there may be a single wireless phone for each person that will work everywhere. People will carry their phones with them at all times, with one phone number that will reach them at home, office or golf course.
 
Lessons Learned
Cellular Theory Has Fallen Short
 Critics of the cellular-phone industry say it has been given control of a public resource, scarce radio frequencies on the electromagnetic spectrum, in a way that is a bit like deeding it the Brooklyn Bridge and letting it collect tolls from all who cross. Cellular executives counter that their use of the airwaves requires significant investments, and they are still not making any money.
Back in 1982, when the F.C.C. set up rules for the cellular markets, the agency divided the country into 734 territories and permitted no more than two companies to operate in each region. The theory was that competition between two companies in each market would eventually bring prices down, and that so few people would be interested in toting a phone around that no more than two companies per area could thrive. Not so.
The Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association says 10 million people now subscribe to cellular services, a level once forecast for the turn of the century. Industry revenue this year may well exceed $7 billion. Within a few years, the personal communication systems are expected to add $30 billion more annually.
The boom defies the high prices.
Lee L. Selwyn of Economics and Technology Inc., sees "no intrinsic reason why a cellular call shouldn't be priced at 10 or 15 cents a minute." But the prices range from 25 cents to more than 90 cents a minute.
Rates vary from region to region, but within each region they are invariably high compared to conventional calls. In Delaware, the lowest-price state in overall charges, a five-minute cellular call costs $2.50, or 80 times the 3.1-cent local call.
Within at least two-thirds of the regions, the prices charged by the two cellular carriers have been found to be almost the same or even identical. The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of the Congress, made that finding in July but said it could not learn why, in part because the industry was not required to provide detailed revenue and cost data.
Critics and industry analysts say consumers are paying for much more than the service they get, like helping one cellular company pay billions to acquire another. The industry does not deny this, but re-emphasizes its own high costs as factors in the fees.
"We have a competitive market today," said Brian D. Kidney, a senior officer at Pacific Telesis. No company, he says, is getting rich from the high prices.
 
The Rule Makers
Trying to Insure More Competition
 If the wireless-phone field is competitive now, the F.C.C. seems eager to make the new personal communications services more so.
A former senior official of the F.C.C, Albert Halprin, the nation's top telephone regulator in the mid-1980's, said: "The amount of competition is not what I would have hoped for. 'Mistake' is far from the right word to describe our action, but it was not perfect. With hindsight, we should have authorized a third carrier."
John Cimko, a longtime F.C.C. official who is the current chief of the commission's mobile services division, agrees. "Two competitors is not an optimal number of players," he said, noting that the commission is determined to mandate at least three companies.
After the F.C.C. divided the country into 734 territories, the companies subdivided these markets into smaller service areas, or cells -- hence "cellular." Each cell has a diameter of between one and 20 miles, depending on population and local obstructions like mountains and skyscrapers, and each cell contains one base station consisting of a transmitter and receiver.
The F.C.C. gave one of the two licenses in each market to the local phone company, in many cases a carrier owned by the GTE Corporation or a regional Bell company like the Nynex Corporation. By including the established communications company in each market, the agency thought the service would be established more quickly. It was.
In most markets, the second licensee was determined by lottery, and the plan led to a total of 120 different cellular companies -- Lilliputians in an industry dominated by Brobdingnagians. Ten carriers, seven of them Bell companies, served 95 percent of the population.
Because the country was cut into so many slices, national service has been difficult to establish, as if there were hundreds of little duchies, each with its own interests. To use a cellular phone while crossing from one market to another, a customer must enter into an expensive "roaming agreement" with the various companies.
The F.C.C. is considering four different plans for P.C.S.:
*Creating 487 territories, based on the Rand McNally Commercial Atlas and Marketing Guide and roughly similar to the cellular markets.
*Creating 194 divisions based on districts now used to determine long-distance calls.
*Creating 47 larger divisions, also based on Rand McNally.
*Creating one grand national market, to be served by a single company or consortium of companies.
 
The Players
Seeking to Secure A Marketing Edge
 The national approach is favored by MCI Communications, the nation's No. 2 long-distance company. MCI proposes a consortium of 5 to 25 companies to manage one national P.C.S. A larger number of regional carriers would handle the billing locally.
The General Accounting Office has urged the F.C.C. to ban current cellular carriers from the P.C.S. market. But the F.C.C. is unlikely to exclude these companies because of their expertise. The G.A.O. has asked, too, that the F.C.C. step up its monitoring of prices.
Established cellular carriers generally favor 487 territories because they could be grafted onto the system.
Start-up companies, like American Personal Communications, favor the 47-segment approach. It would organize cities and towns into the Rand McNally trading area defined by telephone traffic, commuting patterns and mail routes. This could make them profitable faster and more competitive with the big carriers. The District of Columbia, Northern Virginia and Delaware, would, for example, be in one market; they are currently separate.
Pacific Telesis, a regional Bell company, argues that 47 territories would be an administrative nightmare for the West, because it would create a single market embracing San Francisco and a huge diverse, swath of California east to Reno. "If you think Reno is a suburb of San Francisco, then you've got another think coming," Mr. Kidney said.
Under any plan, the consumer is not a guaranteed winner. Prices set by the giants working in the large number of territories might again end up, in the critics' view, higher than necessary, without proper monitoring. But building a convenient manageable system, one that small companies can manage, may take much longer than than necessary.
Still, if an effective, competitive new system is promptly agreed upon, you may soon be able to check in slyly with the boss from your rowboat in Central Park, to fax her your thoughts, say -- at a price you can afford.

GRAPHIC: Photo: New communications units are likely to be smaller than this pocket-size cellular phone. (Motorola)
 
Chart: "Evolution of Wireless Telephones"
 
PRECELLULAR -- Before 1983
 
Used a radio link between the phone and a single base station.
 
only 12 radio channels available in each city, so only 12 calls could be handled at a time. Subscribers often faced long waits for a free channel. Scarcity led to long waiting lists and high rates for service and for calls.
 
Because phone sets had to be able to reach a fairly distant base station, they were bulky and expensive.
 
Local obstructions such as tunnels, buildings and hills tended to make service spotty and unreliable.
 
CELLULAR -- Since 1983
 
Improves on precellular phnes by dividing the service area into dozens of sections (cells) 1 to 20 miles in diameter.
 
Computers automatically switch calls among different frequenceis and cells as users move about or frequencies become crowded.
 
A call ties up a frequency only within a cell, not citywide; more calls can be accommodated.
 
Since phones don't have to transmit as far, they can be smaller and less expensive.
 
Some problems with local obstructions remain.
 
PCS -- 1995?
 
Would improve on cellular by dividing the service area into hundreds of smaller cells, perhaps single blocks or individual building.
 
Could handle even more calls than cellular, using a different part of the radio spectrum.
 
Requiring only a very short range, phone sets could be small, cheap, and more portable.
 
Would work inside buildings and tunnels.
 
Short range may lead to problems handling fast-moving users (such as people in cars on a highway).
 
(pg. D6)

HEADLINE: In Trenton, Hopes Increase For a White House Payback

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
For reasons ranging from raw politics to philosophy of government, Gov. Jim Florio and some New Jersey lawmakers from both major parties believe the state will fare better with Bill Clinton in the White House than with George Bush.
New Jersey played an important role in Mr. Clinton's victory, going for the Democratic candidate in the Presidential election this year for the first time since Lyndon B. Johnson's landslide of 1964. In addition, Governor Florio's fund-raising machine raised $4 million for Mr. Clinton, the third-highest total for any state. 
 But Mr. Florio said in an interview this week that New Jersey could expect more than the return of political favors. The Democratic Governor believes that Mr. Clinton's government experience, which is exclusively at the state level, will make him more sympathetic to state problems.
"The Administration will be more sensitive to the needs of cities, mass transit and infrastructure," he said.
And Representative Robert E. Andrews, who was elected to his second term in the state's First Congressional District, says the makeup of the new Congress will also work in favor of New Jersey, where Democrats held onto their edge in the state's delegation.
 
A Mood of Cooperation
 Mr. Andrews, who was incidentally the first New Jersey Congressman to endorse Mr. Clinton, said the major difference will be a mood of cooperation.
"Instead of the White House crafting and shipping it over and starting the legislative fight, with vetoes, we can work out legislation beforehand," he said, and move it through Congress with less wrangling.
But he said he also feared a new form of gridlock -- this time between factions of the Democratic Party -- that could repel the electorate.
"The party must produce," he said. "Bill Clinton got a mandate to change, and if he fails, the Democratic Party will be in a deep political deficit for years to come. He could be Jimmy Carter, Part 2."
Mr. Florio said he was convinced that President-elect Clinton would not be wedded to the "big government" solutions that have characterized past Democratic administrations, and the Governor believes that dovetails nicely with New Jersey's plans for significant public-private undertakings.
 
'Very Impressed'
 "He was very impressed with New Jersey's job training program," Mr. Florio said, "and when I took him to Camden to the General Electric aerospace project, he favored that kind of approach."
The General Electric aerospace engineering studio, which will occupy abandoned manufacturing space in economically depressed Camden, is part of a $120 million state effort to revitalize industry.
"What he has talked about is what we have talked about and been doing in New Jersey," he said. "Government would not be the total answer, but it should have a constructive role, be helpful."
He also said Mr. Clinton was "very, very impressed" with the state's broad program to reduce welfare dependency both through job training and education and through denying increased benefits to mothers who have more children while receiving welfare payments.
"He has been very supportive of getting people off welfare and telling them that they have to take responsibility for themselves," the Governor said.
 
'An Obligation'
 A Republican legislative leader, Rodney Frelinghuysen, the majority budget officer in the State Assembly, emphasized the political debt he said the incoming President owes the state.
"We perhaps would not want it that way," he said, "but there is definitely a relationship between the ability to deliver electoral votes and the state's esteem in the eyes of the Administration. Clinton has an obligation to this state."
Mr. Frelinghuysen said he believed that the ability of the Democrats to deliver the state's 15 electoral votes for a Democrat for the first time in 28 years should mean, among other things, a favorable ruling on the state's request for $450 million in disputed Medicaid reimbursements. The Bush Administration has already agreed to pay $126 million of the state's claim, but the rest remains in doubt.
"I have no doubt that the Clinton victory will help the state's position," Mr. Frelinghuysen said.
 
'Good for the State'
 Cliff Zukin, a professor of political science at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University and a former director of the Eagleton Poll, said, "It's good for the state, better than if George Bush had been re-elected. I think Clinton will do some pump-priming, and that should benefit this state."
But Mr. Zukin said he did not think that Mr. Clinton's election, though favorable to the state, would make up for the loss in the Congressional delegation of four very senior members who chose not to run for re-election, among them Robert A. Roe, the Democrat who, as chairman of the House Public Works and Transportation Committee, was instrumental in funneling billions of dollars into the state.
"I'd rather have Roe and the others back, even if we picked up a friend in the White House," Mr. Zukin said.
 
An Imponderable
 What this means to Governor Florio's chances of re-election next year is an imponderable. Mr. Zukin thinks Mr. Clinton's election will have "marginal" benefits for Mr. Florio, who remains unpopular in the polls despite recent modest improvements in his standing.
Given the electoral boost that Mr. Florio and the Democrats gave to Mr. Clinton, Mr. Zukin said, "It's going to be very hard for President Clinton not to come to New Jersey next year and campaign in the gubernatorial race."
Just how much difference that will make remains to be seen, Mr. Zukin said. "It will certainly be more helpful if Bill Clinton has primed the pump for New Jersey by then."
But what is more important, he said, is how Mr. Florio himself is perceived, and whom his opponent turns out to be.
"The first question," he said, "is, do I like Jim Florio and do I want four more years of him, and the voters will probably say no. But the next question is, is the alternative more acceptable, and we don't have the answer."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Pay TV Is Looking To Score Knockout

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
Once again -- as in the days when Gillette's hyperactive parrot inquired "How are you fixed for blades?" -- Friday night is fight night.
This time, though, the fight -- the Evander Holyfield-Riddick Bowe heavyweight championship bout -- is not on free broadcast television, the way the "Gillette Cavalcade of Sports" ran on NBC, but on pay-per-view cable television. This means that those who enjoy watching two men beat each other up must spend $35 to $40 for the privilege. 
 The fight is being offered by TVKO, the pay-per-view boxing service owned by the media behemoth Time Warner Inc., which has been struggling to establish itself as an alternative to conventional cable networks.
Making TVKO's task particularly daunting is the erratic track record of pay-per-view sports in a weak economy, as typified by the fiasco suffered by NBC and the Cablevision Systems Corporation when they offered pay-per-view coverage of the 1992 Summer Olympics. Their Olympics Triplecast was unanimously derided as the Edsel of televised sports for its meager number of viewers and large losses.
 
Uncertain Enterprise
 TVKO has eliminated its financial risk by taking a flat fee from the fight's promoter instead of a share of any profit -- or loss. Still, the uncertainties over just how many people will watch tomorrow night's fight are indicative of the struggle that TVKO and other companies face in trying to establish pay-per-view as a profitable entertainment medium.
Not only have these companies experimented with events as disparate as boxing, wrestling, live opera and rock concerts, they are also trying many pricing, promotional and sponsorship strategies. At times, the results wind up stinging like a butterfly and floating like a bee.
To lure viewers to Holyfield's defense of his heavyweight title in Las Vegas against Bowe, TVKO and its partners will spend the equivalent of around $10 million for advertising and marketing, a hefty sum even for pugilistic promotions.
Seth Abraham, president at Time Warner Sports in New York, which formed TVKO in December 1990, believes that enough time has passed since the Olympics Triplecast debacle for another attempt at enticing viewers in the 20 million homes with access to pay-per-view into ordering a major sports event.
"The one beautiful thing about this business is that the viewer has a short memory," he said, "looking at it event by event. If an event warrants the time and the money, they'll order."
One who agrees is Marvin Sloves, chairman and chief executive at Scali, McCabe, Sloves Inc. in New York.
"When I was a kid, there were 15 places to watch professional boxing," said Mr. Sloves, a collector of boxing memorabilia. "Now, unless you live in Las Vegas, that doesn't exist. So television has become the only place you can see it."
The promotional campaign is centered on exploiting the fact that the fight is on Friday the 13th, by claiming "Anything can happen." Some might find this a dubious assertion considering that Holyfield's record is 28-0. However, it should be noted, Bowe, the challenger, is 31-0.
"Will Bowe be the next champion?" the advertising asks. "Or just next?"
"The story line is that the outcome of this fight is in doubt," Mr. Abraham said, "and Riddick Bowe can win."
"When people watch television, they give of their time," he added, "but in pay-per-view, you're asking people to give not only of their time, but of their money. So you're promoting the fact it is money well spent."
An added complication is the pattern among pay-per-view customers, he said, in which 75 percent of all orders come in the day before, or the day of, an event.
"No matter how many times we run spots saying 'Order early,' " Mr. Abraham sighed, "it's a nail-biting business. Friday night, at roughly 11:30 New York time, these two men will touch gloves, whether you've done a good job marketing this or a poor one."
The promotional campaign, on television and radio and in newspapers, is aimed as much at local cable system operators, to cajole them into participating in pay-per-view events, as it is at fight fans. (Pay-per-view is offered on a special channel with a signal that is unscrambled when a home orders an event.)
The problem, Mr. Abraham said, is skepticism among operators over pay-per-view's potential. "They wonder if the business is not here yet, if people like TVKO are trying to push the future into the present," he said.
"But you can't have that attitude," he added, "or Edison would have waited to invent the light bulb till 1960."
The best showing to date for TVKO, which had offered about 20 fights, was with its initial heavyweight bout, pitting Holyfield against George Foreman in April 1991. It brought in more than $50 million in pay-per-view billings from 1.45 million homes, "sort of the Roger Maris of pay-per-view events," Mr. Abraham said, mixing his sports.
But TVKO lost $2.75 million in June on its second heavyweight fight, between Holyfield and Larry Holmes, which was ordered by only about 735,000 homes. To avoid such risks, TVKO restructured this fight's financial arrangements; rather than purchasing all rights, TVKO is being paid an undisclosed production, distribution and marketing fee by the fight promoter Dan Duva.
Another risk-reducer was to bring in as a continuing sponsor Anheuser-Busch, which is spending about $1 million to promote its Budweiser beer. Mr. Abraham said he had hoped to enlist the Gillette Company as a second sponsor, but executives there decided against it, "much to my disappointment."
"Gillette is a real natural," he added, "because of its history, but it's very hard to get advertisers in boxing because it's such a violent business."
Appropriately for an event on a Friday the 13th, "we need luck," Mr. Abraham said, "and luck for us means bad weather." Bad weather keeps people home, he explained, close to their television sets, on which they watch pay-per-view boxing, and their telephones, on which they order pay-per-view boxing.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
President Clinton: Clean or Lean?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
GEORGE BUSH, scourge of Ozone Man and the spotted owl, is looking for a new job. So now the air and water will be entrusted to more sensible folk, right?
Maybe. President Bush actually played a better environmental game than he talked. He acted responsibly to protect -- dare one say it -- the ozone layer. He clamped down on acid rain. He even signed legislation to keep wetlands wetter at the expense of California's influential farmers. 
 If President Bush's record looks better on reflection, the challenges to President Clinton look more daunting. For decades, Washington has been setting environmental goals, whose bills are only now coming due. And while White House rhetoric on the environment will no doubt veer toward the warm and fuzzy, the behind-closed-doors debates over how much to spend and where to spend it are not likely to be any less fierce in the new Administration than in the current one.
On one side stand traditional environmentalists, who want to get on with the job of just saying no to polluters. On the other are economists and fellow travelers, who view a clean environment as a virtue -- but only one of many. And while some of the battles will be about how much crud is too much, others will be about the least-cost strategies for keeping it away from children and other living things.
Traditionalists like their regulation plain, if not always simple: do it, and do it now. Economics types are partial to market-based plans -- taxes or freely tradable permits to pollute -- that appall the old-timers because they imply that some level of pollution is acceptable.
The best guess is that President Clinton will choose an administrator for the Environmental Protection Agency who is not identified with either side -- Madeleine M. Kunin, the former Governor of Vermont, tops nearly everyone's list. And that suggests the big policy battles will be fought one at a time. Among those looming on the horizon:
Farm runoff. The Clean Water Act has taken a giant gulp from the sewage and industrial waste once dumped into rivers and lakes. Most of the muck still flowing is largely unregulated runoff from farmland. Robert Stavins, a researcher at Harvard's Kennedy School in line for the top planning job at the Environmental Protection Agency, predicts that these "nonpoint" sources will be Topic A in reauthorization of the law.
Traditionalists lean toward tough anti-runoff rules, possibly baited with grants to offset compliance costs. The economists' fix of choice would be effluent taxes or trading systems, in which polluters could buy the right to pollute from those who could cut runoff more cheaply.
Robert Hahn, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, has already designed a trading system for southern Florida, where farmers are under court order to prevent fertilizer runoff from corrupting the Everglades. Estimated savings over the brute-force approach run as high as 80 percent.
Infrastructure. For all the chatter about high-tech data networks and 300 m.p.h. trains, Congress and its suburban constituents are lusting for more money for highways. Dan Dudek of the Environmental Defense Fund thinks a scuffle is shaping over how big a slice of the infrastructure pie will go for environmentally benign mass transit. Perhaps more important, he sees a fight over whether new roads should pay their own way and whether Federal cash could be used as a lever to get cities to charge congestion fees for using roads at rush hour.
Superfund. The widely applauded idea of Superfund is to clean up abandoned toxic waste without first pinning down who is liable for the bill. But the law also demands "permanent" solutions -- restoration of the sites to pre-industrial condition. And that, argues Lester Lave, an economist at Carnegie Mellon University, often means a multimillion-dollar incineration of debris and soil, where a less fastidious scrub and a sturdy fence would keep people out of harm's way.
There will be a push next year for a standard that balances health risks with costs -- one that could save tens of billions of dollars. And as a portent of trouble to come, much of the opposition will come from businesses now making big bucks on the cleanup.
Active waste sites. While abandoned dumps are absorbing cash by the billions, Paul Portney, an economist at Resources for the Future, thinks toxic wastes stored on working business properties could prove an even greater drag on the economy. To add waste or change storage methods, companies must now meet exacting modern standards for the entire site -- even if the old waste poses little threat.
This rule could be modified without changing the law. But like much of the economists' agenda, it will not be altered without a sea change in the way Washington views the environment. And after decades of cleaner-is-better politics, that change will not come easily.

HEADLINE: World Bank War on Pollution Faces Ever Sharper Criticism

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
The World Bank's request for a special $5 billion grant for environmental projects is running into trouble from donor countries critical of the bank's environmental record.
Twenty donors are to meet Thursday and Friday in Paris to consider the grant, along with the bank's proposed three-year, $18 billion budget. The bank provides more than $20 billion a year to developing countries. 
 Officials in some donor countries argue that the $5 billion should be refused until the bank reconciles its development plans with the demands of conservationists.
A Bush Administration official familiar with the budget issue said the United States would vote against the special fund, which he said was unlikely to be approved in full, for economic reasons as well as environmental.
Critics of the bank's record point in particular to a decision to go ahead with a dam project in India that was condemned as environmentally unsound by experts hired by the bank.
The $10 billion project, in the Narmada Valley, which the World Bank began financing in 1985, has become a paradigm of the conflict.
Environmentalists and many Indians say the dam, designed to provide water and electricity for 80 million people in central western India, would flood forests and farms and displace 1.5 million people.
In response to the criticism, the bank commissioned a review of the dam in 1991. The report criticized virtually every component of the project.
The authors of the study say the bank distorted their findings to justify continuation of the project.
"What I find alarming were the misrepresentations," said Don Gamble, a Canadian who served as chief of staff for the review. "The bank twisted the report to say the opposite of what is actually true."
Bank officials deny that charge.
"We have listened to the report carefully," said Mohammed el-Ashry, the director of the bank's environmental department. "We feel that there has been good progress with the Government of India and we have to build upon it."
Mr. Ashry said the bank would send a team to India in April to monitor the progress of the dam. "If we see that things are going O.K., we will continue with the project," he said.
Mr. Gamble says the handling of the India project will have a direct bearing on the voting for the special fund. "The bank is very vulnerable now in terms of funding," he said.
Officials at the bank say they are not worried.
"We feel that the Indian Government is willing to take the issues raised by the review seriously," said Shawki Barghouti, staff member of the bank's India department. "If the Government in India is committed to its responsibility, there should not be a problem with funding."

HEADLINE: Stock of Nordstrom Surges

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Wall Street rewarded Nordstrom Inc. today after the retailer showed it could cut costs and deliver strong profits to investors.
Shares of the Seattle-based retailer, which reported healthy earnings Tuesday, gained strongly in Nasdaq trading. Nordstrom's stock rose $3.50 to close at $35.25 with more than 1.5 million shares changing hands. 
 The company posted stronger-than-expected third-quarter income of $23.4 million, or 29 cents a share, up 20 percent from a year earlier. It said sales increased by 7.3 percent.
Many analysts moved to raise estimates and ratings, saying the company's senior executives had made extraordinarily positive comments in a conference call after the earnings were released.
"You had four down earnings and now earnings have turned up," said Daniel Barry, a Merrill Lynch analyst. "I think they will continue to be up throughout next year."
Nordstrom confirmed in an interview that the company told the analysts it expects earnings for the year ending Jan. 31, 1993, to be flat to higher compared with last year's $1.66 a share.
"They suggested the possibility of an up year, they certainly didn't promise it," said Bill Smith, a Smith Barney analyst, who raised his share estimate by 10 cents, to $1.65 in 1993 and to $1.90 in 1994.
Nordstrom, which prides itself on the well-bred manner of its motivated sales force, had defied the economic downturn through the first half of 1991, when it posted solid earnings gains despite a glum retail environment elsewhere. But the retailer stumbled last fall when consumers reduced spending, particularly on higher-priced purchases.

HEADLINE: Steelworkers' Victory Is Bittersweet

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PROVO, Utah, Nov. 11

 BODY:
It was a dirty, sweltering job. But if Tony Pickering could hold on for one more year -- his 20th in the USX steel mill -- he would be fully vested in the pension plan.
He never made it. The steel giant shut down its mill in 1987. Unemployed and nearing 50, Mr. Pickering searched in vain for work. His wife, Andrea, took a minimum-wage job as a security guard. The Pickerings, who have a severely handicapped daughter, cut deeply into a lifetime of savings. 
 "I would look out the window and see my husband walking in circles on the front lawn in pain and frustration," Mrs. Pickering said. "But we were luckier than many. There were suicides. There were divorces. It was a horrible time."
There were hundreds of middle-aged workers like Mr. Pickering, just at the brink of qualifying for benefits, who seemed cursed by a terrible accident of timing. But a Federal court has ruled that it was no accident: that USX idled the 1,900 workers precisely to avoid paying millions of dollars in benefits.
 
Appeal Is Planned
 Damages have not been assessed, but lawyers for the steelworkers say their clients stand to collect more than $100 million. Lawyers for USX, which is based in Pittsburgh, said the damages were more likely to range from $5 million to $10 million.
USX, formerly United States Steel, has said it will appeal the ruling, which was handed down last week. In a statement, the company said it "continues to believe that it acted properly in all respects." The statement noted that the judge had ruled for USX on some charges, including age discrimination.
Lawyers for the steelworkers plan to appeal as well, contending that the ruling does not compensate the 300 workers they say were illegally induced to take early retirement.
The two sides may now negotiate to settle a damage award, but if they cannot agree, the judge in the case, Bruce Jenkins of the Federal District Court in Salt Lake City, has said that hearings will be conducted to determine the damages in individual cases.
In a similar case, the Continental Can Company was accused in 1990 of closing plants to avoid pension costs. In that case, the company reached a $415 million settlement with its workers.
For the steelworkers, it began as an almost quixotic battle, a legal fight between hard-hat workers in steel-toed boots and a corporate behemoth. And despite the times of doubt and despair for former USX workers over the last five years, their campaign was stoked by a righteous anger as hard-pressed men and women scraped together $700 apiece to pay lawyers' bills, never sure that as much as a nickel would come back.
"You know, I had felt kind of worthless when all this happened," Mr. Pickering said. "But I feel like I have gotten my dignity back."
More than 1,000 steelworkers and their families crowded into an auditorium at Provo High School on Tuesday night to listen to lawyers explain the ruling. One of them, Gerry Spence, a flamboyant Wyoming lawyer in boots and fringe coat, likened USX to "an invisible master who laughs and chortles" at the cries of its workers "in that pit -- that place of hell."
He added: "Right now, those scalawags and scoundrels are drinking their martinis and eating chicken cordon bleu, but they are not laughing."
Workers in mesh caps and jeans erupted in cheers. Husbands and wives smiled at one another through glassy eyes. And co-workers clapped one another on the back for enduring the long fight.
But the bitterness toward USX has hardly faded. "Those liars," sputtered Neil Ford, as he shook with contempt for the steelmaker. "They gave us their word they would not close us down. And then they lied."
Mr. Ford, 60, had been given a choice in 1986: retire now or take a 7 percent cut in pay. "We couldn't hardly afford that, so I quit and went to work as a mechanic," he said. But when the mill closed, the economy around Provo soured, and Mr. Ford was laid off from his mechanic's job.
His wife, JoAnn, 58, had never worked outside the home. But as the money ran out, and the days grew bleaker, she set out to find a job. Without skills or a college degree, she settled for a job cleaning houses.
"I had never worked before," Mrs. Ford said, "but you try living on $10,000 a year."
The shutdown of the Provo mill came after a six-month strike by the steelworkers' union. The strike, which the union says was actually a lockout, was settled in the spring of 1987, but USX decided not to reopen the plant; later that year it sold the plant to an investors' group that later named it Geneva Steel.
Many of the former USX workers were hired back, but at reduced wages. And their retirement benefits had to start from scratch.
At the time the mill was sold, USX said, the plant had simply become uncompetitive, running with inefficient machinery. During that era, major American steel companies were losing hundreds of millions of dollars in the face of foreign steel, low-wage competitors and sagging demand.
But the steelworkers sued, and after a nine-week trial in the spring of 1991, Judge Jenkins deliberated for 17 months. In his ruling, he said the company had violated the Employee Retirement Security Act, which prohibits businesses from dismissing workers to avoid paying benefits.
 
Retired Workers' Fate
 The judge said the retired workers were not covered under the Federal act. Lawyers for the steelworkers said they would appeal on behalf of retired workers on the ground that the USX was guilty of age discrimination.
On Tuesday night, Mr. Spence asked the workers for permission to reject any settlement that did not include the retirees. Every hand in the auditorium shot up in agreement.
For people like Don Ford, 37, who said he had endured a "dirty, stinking, filthy job" in the mill because it supported his family, the fight has been worthwhile -- "even if we never got a dime from them."
When he was laid off by the company in 1986, he and his wife, Launie, were within two weeks of closing on their first home. When he lost his job, the bank withdrew the loan. It took two years before the couple could get a loan. By then, interest rates had gone up. It cost them an extra $100 a month.
"But that wasn't the worst of it," he said. "We didn't have any medical benefits when we got let go. And we've got little kids. Do you know what it's like worrying that a kid is going to get hurt or sick -- and you won't have any insurance? It really works on your mind."
He added: "These big corporations have been muscling us labor guys any way they want. They've been beating us to death. Well this time, the little guys won."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tony Pickering and other workers have won a Federal case against USX to receive their pensions. He stood outside the Geneva Steel factory in Orem, Utah. (Tom Smart for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Leaves Clinging Like Lint

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 11

 BODY:
Jim Castagno's lawn vanished on Sunday, just as it has every weekend for the last month.
The fescue, ryegrass and Kentucky bluegrass that turned his yard into a fuzzy green blanket all summer has come under siege from a half-dozen century-old oaks and a neighbor's Norway maple -- the one with bright yellow leaves the size of catchers' mitts. 
 And once again the hoarse whine of the leaf blower is abroad in the suburbs, where the rake's progress has been blunted by a late-season fallout and a daunting pileup. It is enough to make even doughty homeowners yearn for the gypsy moth caterpillar.
"The oaks dry up nice and hard and crispy," said Mr. Castagno, who knows his enemy well and has chosen to battle it with elbow grease and good-humored resignation. "They curl up on top of the grass and blow right off. But the maple leaves have the consistency of a wet paper towel."
 
More Leaves, and Larger
 Bagged, blown, raked, shredded or still hanging from branches, the leaves city dwellers drive miles to see are the leaves suburbanites have grown to dread. Suddenly it seems as if the suburbs are filled with people whose necks are stiff from looking up and pleading, "How much longer?"
"Oh, a couple of weeks anyway," said Ronald Manning, Public Works Superintendent in Fairfield, Conn., pointing out that a wet summer and a mild early autumn kept leaves on branches a bit later than usual. This week is the start of Fairfield's seasonal pickup, when a contractor hired by the town collects homeowners' leaves, packed like laundry in biodegradable bags along 255 miles of streets.
"There are probably a few more leaves this year than usual," said Edward G. Corbett, a professor of plant science at the University of Connecticut. "We had a particularly good growing season, and that can mean more leaves and leaves that will be somewhat larger than if the season is drier."
But Professor Corbett could not be certain that leaves were falling later than usual.
"That's more a perception that people have, because we don't remember well from one year to the next," he said. "In fact, we were getting calls from people in September wondering why the leaves were turning color and dropping so early."
For Robert Rohl, Public Works Superintendent in Ridgewood, this is small comfort.
"The village concept of Ridgewood is suburbia in the woods," said Mr. Rohl, who scrambles his crews before dawn, sending forest-strength mechanical sweepers to push motley leaf piles toward intersections, where bucket loaders will toss them into dump trucks bound for the village compost heap.
In Briarcliff Manor, in Westchester County, vacuum trucks sweep through the streets for most of November, inhaling the leaf mounds along the curbs.
And in Hempstead, in Nassau County, where leaves must be bagged, any kind of bag is fine. The sanitation trucks pick them up on the usual yard-waste schedule and haul them to a transfer station. There, leaves from Rockville Centre are comingled with those of Valley Stream, Garden City and a half-dozen other places and eventually trucked to composting centers in New Jersey and Pennsylvania.
There are at least two reasons for all this raking and carting. The first is that civilization expects neatness. The second, Dr. Corbett said, is that a lawn will suffocate beneath a leaf blanket that deprives grass of sunlight. No lawn, no suburb.
And there is a potential commercial benefit, under a theory put forth by Joe Psota, co-owner of J. P. Home Arama in Hawthorne, N.J. In his view, there is a perceptible rise in do-it-yourselfers trying to overcome the cost of hiring yard crews.
Mr. Psota said he and his brother, John, sell about 2,000 plastic, metal and bamboo rakes a season. They also stock weed eaters, leaf eaters, leaf blowers, Vac 'n' Mulch machines and other shiny lawn gadgets. By the time the snow flies, if it ever does, Joe Psota estimates that he will have sold 450 motorized devices to chop, shred or vacuum, a modest improvement over last season's sales.
"It's the economy," he said. "I think more people are doing it themselves."
On Valley View Avenue in Ridgewood, where Mr. Castagno lives, leaves continue to pour down like cornflakes from a freshly opened box, They stick to pachysandra like lint and to rhododendron bushes like dandruff. Dogs and small children step off sidewalks and disappear in piles awaiting pickup. Curbside parking is impossible.
It's not as if Mr. Castagno and his neighbors haven't tried.
"If everything works, there's a system," he said, referring to his organized approach to efficient leaf removal: mowing, blowing, raking. "The problem is that sometimes the system breaks down, and you can't predict when that will happen. When they get to be really heavy, almost no system works. I guess you'd have to call it schlepping."
Clearly Mr. Castagno believes in mastering his property, and he is fully armed for battle: a gasoline mower with a rear bagger, several rakes and an electric leaf blower with a long extension cord.
"The little push mowers are adequate for a light leaf fall -- in Des Moines, with two or three trees," he said. "But here in the Northeast, where you've got large old oaks, it's not enough."
Mr. Castagno's teen-age children vanish when the lawn does, but he doesn't mind. "I have managed to muster them out on occasion," he said. "But I'm not someone who plays squash or belongs to the tennis club. I'm not a jogger. I'm accused of being a putterer and I plead guilty."
Mr. Castagno's arsenal, while functional, is really horse-drawn artillery compared with what some people can get from hired guns like Don DeVito, a landscaper from Hillsdale, N.J., and his crew of six.
"It'll take us about an hour and a half," he said, shouting over the din of leaf blowers attacking a 15,000-square-foot yard on Fairmont Road.
His squad had arrived at 8 A.M. and fanned out like mercenaries, each with a Ghostbuster-style backpack harnessing a gas blower capable of 200 m.p.h. gusts. An 11-horsepower blower on wheels -- the equivalent of a howitzer in the landscaping business -- stood silently on a lawn once strewn with oak leaves.
By 9:30, there was nothing left but grass and a stunned squirrel. Yet Mr. DeVito knew it was folly to think he had won. The leaves were still falling, like snow on the Donner Party. "We'll be back in about 10 days and maybe," Mr. DeVito said, "be a little fussier with the flower beds."
Roger Fulton of Briarcliff Manor is no lawn professional. Until he retired almost two years ago, he had hired yard crews for 25 years. But now, with the time and the inclination, he has acquired a leaf blower.
"Last year, I reseeded the lawn, so when it came to raking leaves, all kinds of shoots were coming up and I didn't want to hurt them," he said. Hence the blower.
"There's a six-foot pile of leaves out in my mulch pile," he said. "It'll be 12 feet when I'm finished."
But even suburban civilization has its discontents.
"I find that if I'm not careful," Mr. Fulton said, "I blow the leaves right back where they were before."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Northwest Air Unions See a Deal

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Unions representing Northwest Airlines employees expect to announce by the weekend an agreement about joint concessions in exchange for an equity stake in the company, state and union officials said today.
Financial advisers from some of the unions were meeting today at the company's headquarters with the airline's treasury department for briefings on Northwest's financial condition. They then plan to meet Thursday in Minneapolis with the top officers from each union. 
 "You can characterize these discussions as reactions to a crisis," said Bob Benner, an official in the Minnesota Department of Trade and Economic Development who is Gov. Arne Carlson's point man on issues involving Northwest Airlines. "Or you can look at them -- as we do -- as very prudent measures taken by a company."
 
No Specifics Yet
 The meetings come at a time when Northwest has less than $300 million on hand and no credit reserve. Two weeks ago the airline tapped the remainder of its $600 million credit line.
"I would expect what we'll see Friday," Mr. Benner said, "is a statement from the unions indicating their intent with respect to negotiating with the company."
Lisa Hirschman, vice president of Local 2000 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents Northwest flight attendants, said, "Hopefully, as of Friday, I think you can expect to see a general idea and philosophy rather than specifics."
Union officials said the meetings were not hastily arranged in reaction to any recent dire news, such as a trade journal's report Monday that a deal collapsed for KLM Royal Dutch Airlines to invest up to $500 million in new money in Northwest, union officials said.
A spokeswoman for KLM said there never was a deal, and Northwest declined to comment on the report.
"I don't think there's any new information; I don't think anything has changed over the last month or so," said Curt Kruse, a spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association.
A spokesman for the International Association of Machinists agreed.
KLM already holds a 49 percent stake in Northwest, having provided $400 million to back a $3.6 billion leveraged buyout of Northwest in 1989.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Zenith May Face a Credit Squeeze

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 11

 BODY:
The Zenith Electronics Corporation, the only television maker still based in the United States, warned today that it faced potentially "serious liquidity problems" that would require it to renegotiate its bank credit.
In a filing with Securities and Exchange Commission, Zenith said it was in talks with the Bank of New York to relax a credit agreement requirement that it maintain a net worth of $229 million at the end of every quarter. 
 "If the discussions do not result in the covenant being modified, the company is expected to be out of compliance with the credit agreement beginning as of the date fourth-quarter results are reported" in February, Zenith said.
 
 
'Full Range' of Plans
 A company spokesman said Zenith was considering "a full range of financing, strategic or other contingency plans."
The spokesman declined to say whether Zenith was considering filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy-law protection and said more details would be reported "when the time is appropriate to disclose them."
Dennis Moran, an electronics industry analyst at A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc., downgraded Zenith's stock to a hold from a buy and said he would recommend investors sell unless Zenith obtains "intermediate financing" within 30 days.
"By intermediate financing, we generally mean the sale of a major asset or securing an investment partner," Mr. Moran said.
Zenith's shares fell $1.125 today to close at $5.625. The 16.7 percent loss was the second largest on the New York Stock Exchange.
Last month, Zenith posted a larger-than-expected loss of $41.8 million for the third quarter, and the company had said it expects a loss for the full year, in part because of television price cuts by its competitors.
Mr. Moran said he expects Zenith to return to profitability next year, "depending on an improved consumer economy and the company getting additional and permanent working capital."
Zenith also said last month that it would eliminate about 15 percent of its 2,600 salaried work force in the United States and would cut its Mexican work force by an unspecified amount. Zenith, based in Glenview, Ill., assembles many of its televisions in Mexico.
 
 
Public Offering
 On Aug. 12, Zenith proposed a public offering of eight million shares of common stock, but the company withdrew the offer after it and its investment bankers reviewed the impact of third-quarter results, market conditions, October television price reductions and near-term business prospects.
In addition to televisions, Zenith, with 1991 sales of $1.32 billion, makes or sells picture tubes, computer monitors, videocassette recorders and camcorders.
The company is also involved in a high-stakes competition to develop a standard for high-definition television, or HDTV, a new technology that will produce movie-quality images for a variety of business and consumer applications.
The Federal Communications Commission is expected to choose next year between the standard developed by Zenith and that of several rivals.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bond Prices Higher Overseas

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Government bond prices moved higher yesterday in light overseas trading. The government-securities market in the United States was closed for the Veterans Day holiday.
In late London trading, the price of the Treasury's 30-year bond was up 3/32 point, or 93.75 cents for each $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, was 7.66 percent, unchanged from the closing yield Tuesday in New York. 
 Bond prices rose on Tuesday in New York following a solid auction of 10-year notes and a new report that showed inflation remained under control. The next test of the market will come today, when the Treasury is scheduled to auction $10 billion in 30-year bonds.
Other key events this week for bond traders will be Friday's report on consumer prices for October, as well as the latest retail and automobile sales figures.
 
Other Maturities Rise
 In the secondary market for Treasury bonds in London, short-term maturities rose 3/32 point and intermediate maturities were up 3/32 point, according to the Telerate Inc. financial information service.
The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, was not quoted because of the holiday.
The same applied to the Federal funds rate, which is the interest rate charged for overnight loans between banks.
