HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
Excerpts From President-Elect's News Conference in Arkansas

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President-elect Bill Clinton's news conference today at the Old State House in Little Rock, Ark., as recorded by News Transcripts Inc., a private transcription service.
Q. Governor, you campaigned on a theme of economic hope and a pledge of putting Americans back to work. Are you finding it increasingly necessary to scale back the expectations you might have raised? 
 And second, what do you think you'll have to accomplish in the early months of your campaign to keep alive the hopes you might have raised during the past year?
A. Well, I campaigned on a theme of economic hope and creating jobs and increasing income. I also told the American people repeatedly we didn't get into this business overnight and we're not going to get out of it overnight.
I think what I have to do is to present an aggressive plan to the United States Congress and pass it, and to put together a world-class economic team and to take whatever steps that can be taken without new laws being enacted by Congress to revive this economy.
I think all along the way I have to do my best at one of the most important jobs of a President, which is to communicate to the American people, to explain exactly where we are at this point in our history, how we got here and where we're going into the future. There is -- there has to be a short-term economic agenda, we've been in this deep recession for a long time now.
There also has to be a long-term economic commitment to increasing the productivity of the American economy so that we can not only create more jobs, but that we can begin to raise incomes of ordinary Americans again for the first time in well over a decade. And I expect that we'll be able to do that.
I expect to keep the focus on these economic issues, and I'm not trying to scale back, or scale down, or anything else. I think the American people understand that these problems are of long duration, and there won't be any overnight miracles, but I think they expect aggressive and prompt action, and I'm going to give it to them.
Q. Governor, along those lines, do you intend to propose a middle-class tax cut in January as you advanced through the campaign?
A. I intend to propose a tax package that is consistent with what I recommended in the campaign. I have not made any decision to change it.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Governor, the top savings and loan regulator says $50 billion is going to be needed to complete the bailout program and finance the deposit insurance fund. Do you intend to ask Congress for this money? If so, how quickly after you take office and will this hurt your ability to finance some of the programs you would like to see implemented?
A. Well, it's interesting, they came out with that figure, which is a bigger figure than they were using before the election, as soon as the election was over, but I have not -- I'm not in a position to accept the figure because I have not been advised about it.
Let me, let me tell you what I'm going to do. I'm going to devote a lot of attention to the condition of the S.& L. bailout, the R.T.C., as well as to the condition of the banking system in the country and the potential impact of the new capital requirements coming in on Dec. 19, and make a judgment on that, and as soon as I do I'll be glad to share it with you.
I'm just not in a position -- I don't have all that much confidence in all the decisions that have been made by the R.T.C. I don't know what our options might be. So I can't tell you precisely what I'll do. It is -- it concerned me that that announcement was made, when it was made and the way it was made, with the figure that was tacked on to it, and I think it probably came as kind of a jolt to the American people. But I will do what I think is best and responsible, but I can't accept the figure yet. Andrea.
Q. Governor, Bob Dole said that you're going to have a honeymoon and that he's going to be the chaperon. Do you anticipate that you're going to have a tough time with the opposition? And how do you respond to his comments that you did not have a mandate?
A. Well, I think -- let me say a couple of things about that. First of all, I think that I -- that the American people hope that I have a honeymoon, not for me, but for them. If a honeymoon means a break in partisan political behavior, and an honest attempt by people of goodwill to reach agreement on something that's good for the country.
I had a good talk with Senator Dole on the phone yesterday. I'm looking forward, when I go to Washington next week, to see President Bush. I am also looking forward to a meeting, a bipartisan meeting with the leadership in Congress, and I'm going to hold out the hand of cooperation to them, and I think that they will extend it in turn.
I think that the clear mandate of this election, by the way, from the American people was an end of politics as usual, and end to the gridlock in Washington, an end to finger-pointing and blame. I think there is no question that there was a mandate in this election.
In terms of whether I got a mandate or not, you know, having a 100-vote electoral majority more than you need is not too bad. There are only a couple of Democrats in this century who've gotten a bigger percentage vote. But arguably, the greatest President we ever had, Abraham Lincoln, was elected with under 40 percent of the vote.
So I think the American people will all now evaluate what I do and whether I do it well and whether they support it.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Governor, there's a lot concern abroad about what the Clinton foreign policy would be. I wonder if you could tell us what will be your first 100 days plan in foreign policy and what are the attributes you'll be looking for in a secretary of state and in a national security adviser?
A. Well, I think I've laid out my foreign policy in great detail and with clear specificity. I've certainly tried to, and I believe that I spoke more to foreign policy than anybody else running in the Democratic primary, at least, and arguably more than my opponents in the general election.
Q. What do you think will be your top priorities?
A. Well, my top priorities will be settling on a multi-year plan for a defense budget that I think keeps the defense of this country the strongest in the world and deals with the necessity to downscale; pursuing our continued efforts to reduce nuclear weapons with Russia and with other nuclear powers; working hard to stop the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction -- nuclear, biological and chemical; keeping the Middle East peace process on track and doing whatever I can to make sure there is no break in continuity; and doing what I can to strengthen global economic growth, in terms of resolving outstanding matters with Mexico, hopefully resolving the outstanding issues in Europe, and proceeding with a cooperative strategy with the other major economic powers to promote global growth, something which will help us very much.
Q. Governor, the second half of the question?
A. Well, I want a secretary of state who understands that we have obligations of continuity and obligations of change, and that basically the pillars of our national security and foreign policy ought to be a different but still very strong defense, a commitment to global growth and economic regeneration here, and the fulfilling of our responsibility as the world's sole superpower to try to promote democracy and freedom and restraint the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.
I want someone that I think really understands that and can relate well to those issues and to the people around the world dealing with that.
And in terms of a national security adviser, I want the same thing. I want people -- by the way, I do think that President Bush's group worked pretty well as a team in that area, and that's something that I want. I'm very much committed to picking a national security adviser, secretary of defense and a secretary of state who can work together on this agenda. I think that's what I ought to be doing.
Q. Governor Clinton, how quickly are you going to move on your pledge to allow gays and lesbians in the military? You're getting some heat for it now. You're getting pressure to do it in January, three days after you take office. How quickly are you going to move?
A. Well, I think that -- first of all, I am going to move forward on that.
Q. On your 100-day agenda?
A. Let me tell you what I'm going to do. My concern here is to do it in a way that is most appropriate for the management of the whole national security and military interests of the country. I want to consult with a lot of people about what our options are, including people who may disagree with me about the ultimate merits. And let me just remind you one more time of how this all came up.
This whole issue really came to light when Secretary of Defense Cheney was asked to comment on a study which said that there were many thousands of men and women who were homosexuals in the military forces who served our country with great distinction and never did anything in their conduct that was destructive of the morale or the purpose of the military.
And I think he referred to this rule as "an old chestnut" or something of that kind.
What I want to do is to come up with an appropriate response that will focus sharply on the fact that we do have people who are homosexuals who served our country with distinction, who were never kicked out of the military. Others, who are being kicked out of the military -- one of whom has just been reinstated by court. And the issue ought to be conduct. Has anybody done anything which would disqualify them, whether it's Tailhook scandal or something else. And so what I plan to do in an appropriate fashion, in a prompt fashion, is to put together a group of people and let them advise me about how we might best do this. But I'm not going to change my position on it.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. There are things that Presidents can do. Right now there is for instance -- there are two executive orders in effect, one of which bans abortion counseling by physicians at clinics, which use Federal funds. The other is an executive order that President Bush issued last May which effectively bars Haitian exiles from this country.
Have you made up your mind on what you're going to do with those two issues?
A. Yes. Well, I have made up my mind that I am going to change the policy in both areas. I don't believe in the gag rule and I think it should be repealed. And with regard to the Haitians, I think my position on that has been pretty clear all along. I believe that there is a legitimate distinction between political and economic refugees. But I think that we should have a process in which these Haitians get a chance to make their case. I think that the blanket sending them back to Haiti under the circumstances which have prevailed for the last year was an error and so I will modify that process.
I'm not in a position to tell you exactly how we're going to do it or what the specifics will be, but I can tell you I'm going to change the policy.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. On the economic summit, we're told that you're going to be bringing some of the top business leaders from across the country here to Little Rock to give you their views on what should be done about the economy. By almost anyone's standards, Ross Perot is one of the more successful business leaders. You agreed with some of his economic strategies during the campaign and you appealed to his supporters to be comfortable with voting for you. Would you be comfortable with having him come and be a part of that team?
A. I wouldn't be uncomfortable doing that. I have not made up my mind who's going to come.
Q. Will he be invited?
A. I've had no discussions on that. But I'm going to have business leaders here. We'll have some people from labor here who understand the changes that are going on. We'll have some distinguished economists here. We'll have a lot of people who were part of this campaign and some people who weren't. And it will be more in the nature of a retreat in that sense. I mean, I'm asking people to come here and go to work. You know, there's not going to be much posturing and show about this; it's going to be a lot of work.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Governor, are you satisfied with the way in which President Bush has handled the State Department probe into your background during the campaign, or do you think more needs to be done?
A. Well, I'm glad Ms. Tamposi had to leave her job about six weeks early -- I thought that was an appropriate thing to do. I don't know that I know enough to give you a final judgment. Let me just say this: If I catch anybody using the State Department like that when I'm President, you won't have to wait till after the election to see them gone. I don't want to talk about what happened in the past. The election is over, we don't have a minute to waste looking at the past.
I just want you to know that the State Department of this country is not going to be fooling with Bill Clinton's politics, and if I catch anybody doing it I will fire them the next day; you won't have to have an inquiry or rigmarole or anything else, because it is too important to me that the rest of the world see us as having a coherent and, as much as possible, nonpolitical foreign policy.
And let me say, you will see that I've gone out of my way since I was elected to support the idea that President Bush is our President, that he makes foreign policy, and that we're all going to stick with it until there's a change, and this is a part of that to me.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Little Rock is not Washington and you face increased security as President-elect -- -- and you also face increased media scrutiny. Will we see you on the streets of Washington a lot jogging and are you frustrated by the bubble?
A. Well, I'm a little bit -- you know, I'm a real sort of informal person. I live in an atmosphere that is highly personal and informal and I know my friends and neighbors, and my constituents can come up to me and talk to me on the street. But I would hope that both Senator Gore and I would be able to maintain some greater level of ongoing personal contact with folks than is typically the case. Now I know there are security concerns and we've talked to the Secret Service about that, and I have no criticism of them. I think they do a fine job.
But I think that one of the reasons we made this campaign a success is because we went out of our way to demonstrate, both of us together and separately, that we could be genuinely accessible to the American people and that we were interested in them, and I think that there are a lot of things you do in your own personal habits that send that signal out. So I hope I'll be able to do it. May not.

HEADLINE: G.M. Expects End to Losses By Next Year

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation's new management team told financial analysts and reporters in New York yesterday that cost-cutting in G.M.'s troubled North American operations was running ahead of schedule, prompting a forecast that losses would be plugged next year.
The financial forecast, which is unusual for G.M. or any auto maker, is significant because it suggests that new management, led by John F. (Jack) Smith Jr., is willing to put its credibility and performance on the line. 
 Mr. Smith said the return to profitability of G.M.'s North American operations would occur regardless of economic conditions. "We're not dependent on an economic upturn to turn us around," he said. "We're implementing fundamental changes and restructuring that will allow us to be profitable even in a downturn."
 
 
Bold, but Risky

Mr. Smith's promise was bold, but risky: Ford's financial executives made the same promise during the robust automotive market of the late 1980's, hoping to convince Wall Street the company's stock deserved a higher multiple; they were forced to eat crow when Ford posted a $2.3 billion deficit for 1991.
In light of G.M.'s $7 billion pretax loss in North America in 1991 and $3 billion of losses for the first nine months of 1992, a break-even performance -- before interest expenses and taxes are deducted -- would be a powerful harbinger of recovery for a company whose financial strength has been badly sapped.
Most automotive analysts could not be reached following G.M.'s all-day briefing. But one, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said, "They will have to work like hell to achieve this target." The analyst explained that he wished to speak to brokerage clients before being interviewed publicly.
G.M. was the third-heaviest traded issue yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $30.50, up 37.5 cents, on volume of 26.66 million shares.
In addition to comments by Mr. Smith, the analysts were also addressed by J. Michael Losh, executive vice president for marketing; J. Ignacio Lopez, vice president for purchasing; William E. Hoglund, in charge of new corporate affairs and staff support; Richard Wagoner, chief financial officer; J. T. Battenberg, vice president for parts and components; Harry J. Pearce, executive vice president and chief counsel, and other G.M. executives.
Mr. Smith offered evidence to reporters that cutbacks of white-collar and hourly jobs were proceeding faster than anticipated when they were announced last December. He also said they could go deeper. White-collar jobs will drop to 79,000 by the end of the year and to 71,000 by the end of next year, from 91,000 at the beginning of this year.
"That would put us on a level with Ford, adjusted for our greater size," Mr. Smith said. But after next year, he said, G.M. will try to reach white-collar efficiency established by Japanese auto makers, meaning a drop to as low as 60,000.
On the hourly side, employment will drop to 288,000 by the end of the year, down from 304,000 on Jan. 1. Afterward, the number will depend on how much work G.M. can bring in to its parts and components factories, which depends in part on agreements with the United Automobile Workers union to increase productivity.
Mr. Losh said G.M. forecasts increasing its sales next year to 4.7 million cars and trucks from about 4.4 million vehicles this year.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John F. Smith, the new chief executive of General Motors, answering questions yesterday after a news conference in New York. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Mercantile Exchange to Stay in New York City

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Ending years of indecision over whether the New York Mercantile Exchange would leave lower Manhattan for Jersey City, the exchange's board of directors voted late Wednesday night to remain in New York, exchange officials said.
Just last January, in the latest reversal in a long perils-of-Pauline melodrama, the Mercantile Exchange withdrew from a plan to build a joint headquarters on city-owned land in TriBeCa with the four other futures exchanges with which it has shared space for years in the World Trade Center. 
 But now, after considering a new offer of financial incentives to relocate in Jersey City, the Mercantile Exchange has decided to stay in New York, most likely by leasing space in a building owned by Shearson Lehman Inc. on Greenwich Street in TriBeCa, said R. Patrick Thompson, the president of the exchange. The Mercantile Exchange employs about 3,400 people.
The exchange, which trades futures and options contracts on crude oil, heating oil, gasoline and several other commodities, has been seeking a new home, with more space, since at least the mid-1980's.
Among the reasons for the decision to stay, said Samuel H. Lindenbaum, a lawyer representing the exchange, was a competitive package of incentives from New York City and State -- which city officials said was worth about $80 million over 15 years -- and the powerful lure of the tumbling cost of renting prime Manhattan office space.
 
2 Other Victories
 Retaining the exchange represents the latest in a recent string of corporate victories for the city and state. Among others, the Morgan Stanley Group and Prudential Securities, which together employ about 9,100 people in the city, have announced in the last three months that they would remain in New York. Both concerns were offered incentive packages by the city.
The New York Times said last week that it would move its Manhattan press and distribution operations to a new printing plant that the company plans to build on city-owned land in College Point, Queens. About 1,000 people are currently employed in The Times's Manhattan printing and distribution operations. Executives of the paper said they had also contemplated moving the operations to New Jersey and Westchester.
When officials of the Mercantile Exchange announced in January that they had decided to withdraw from the plan to construct a new building with the other exchanges, they said that the major premises on which the venture had been based -- including that the new center would also include office space for the exchanges' members -- had "evaporated," largely because falling rents in existing Manhattan buildings had made offices in an expensive new building much less attractive to the members.
The other four exchanges -- the Commodity Exchange, the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, the New York Cotton Exchange and the New York Futures Exchange -- remain committed to the joint center, city officials said. It is to be built three blocks north of their current quarters in the World Trade Center, in a lot bounded by Greenwich, Warren, Murray and West Streets, which is now primarily a parking lot.
After dropping out of the joint venture, the Mercantile Exchange, which is the largest of the exchanges, began searching for a new home, including in existing buildings in lower Manhattan and in Jersey City, which in 1990 had bid aggressively to become the new home for all five exchanges.
New Jersey offered a strong package of financial incentives in recent months, Mr. Lindenbaum said. New York City and State came up with incentives that were "competitive" with New Jersey's, said Mr. Lindenbaum, who declined to discuss details of the offers.
Carl Weisbrod, the president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said that the city and state incentives were worth about $80 million. He declined to provide a detailed breakdown of the financial package, saying that it would not be made public while the Mercantile Exchange was still negotiating with Shearson Lehman over the proposal to lease space in the Shearson building at 390 Greenwich Street, at the corner of Hubert Street in TriBeCa.
The elements of the city and state incentives are the same as those offered recently to other corporations, Mr. Weisbrod said. They include low-cost electricity from state-owned nuclear power plants, some relief from property taxes, exemptions from state sales taxes on construction and new equipment, partial relief from the city's commercial rent tax and a direct, though unspecified, grant from the city, he said.
The Mercantile Exchange generates a total of about $75 million a year to the city and state in tax revenues, Mr. Weisbrod said. He contended that those annual revenues justified the cost of the financial incentives.
Mayor Bret Schundler of Jersey City said he was disappointed that the exchange would not relocate to New Jersey. "What it means to Jersey City is that we have to keep on marketing for others," he said. "What it could have meant for Jersey City is that it could have expedited further the development of the waterfront. I think that's going to continue anyway."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
At Time Warner, Stock Is Stuck

BYLINE: By Geraldine Fabrikant

 BODY:
BY a number of key measures, Time Warner's stock should be thriving. Since Time and Warner merged in January 1990, the company has managed to pay down about 27 percent of its $11 billion in debt, attracted foreign equity investors and has seen its core businesses do well.
Wall Street has hardly turned a cold shoulder. The merger was touted as creating the world's largest media company, with all the leverage and synergistic mystique that such a combination would provide. And a number of veteran media analysts have aggressively recommended Time Warner, arguing that it is cheap relative to the value and earning potential of its wide array of assets: cable TV, films, records and pay TV. 
 The company has also bought the 18 percent of American Television and Cable that it did not already own, so that Time Warner could benefit from that company's entire cash flow. At the same time, operating earnings at its five divisions have grown even in a generally difficult economy.
The question of the company's future leadership appears to have been answered with Gerald Levin as the heir-apparent to Steven J. Ross, who is suffering from cancer.
Yet the stock, which split 4 for 1 in August, has lagged behind the Dow Jones industrial average since the merger, with the gap widening since May 1991. "It's been a real thorn in my side," sighed Jessica Reif, who follows the company for Oppenheimer & Company. At the time of the merger, Time Warner was trading at about 29, and it has not moved decisively past that level since. Two weeks ago the stock was down at 23; it has since moved higher, closing yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $26.875.
The stock was undoubtedly helped this week when top Time Warner executives met with analysts for four hours on Wednesday and explained the company's advanced cable system in Queens and its possibilities for the future.
Time Warner has more copyrights than anyone else in the world and is building the digital highway to distribute its copyrighted properties, said David Londoner, who follows the company for Wertheim Schroder & Company. Among the offerings would be home-shopping services such as How to Fix It, educational material and video on demand.
Meanwhile, a number of factors continue to weigh on the stock price, particularly the recently enacted cable reregulation bill, which could hurt revenues from the segment of Time Warner's business that last year accounted for 40 percent of cash flow.
Under this law, the Federal Communications Commission would have the opportunity to determine pricing for basic cable in communities in which subscribers say fees are too high. The F.C.C. has a lot of latitude for interpretation, and with a Democratic President, Ms. Reif believes more reregulation is likely.
But Richard Simon, a media analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company, believes that the passage of the cable bill was probably good news because it removed worries that an even more stringent bill might pass. The current bill is not particularly harmful. Mr. Simon believes.
"The growth in cable is basically going to be from ancillary services or a la carte services like pay per view and multiplexing," he said. "If that is the case, the industry will not be as dependent on basic cable rates.
"And despite the specter of the telephone company challenging cable, it is our view that the current technologies talked about by the phone companies to bring pay per view over phone lines is a less adequate delivery system than cable and has less longer-term potential."
This year the company's image has hardly been helped by the uproar over the lyrics on a recording by the rap artist Ice-T on Warner Records that dealt with violence against the police. And this has created a problem as well for some investment managers. "Some funds that run police money still can't buy the stock because of the Ice-T incident," Ms. Reif noted. And Mr. Londoner said one money manager who was handling police force pension money said the client did not want Time Warner in its portfolio. Moreover, despite its strong cash flow, Time Warner still is not generating earnings.
Oddly, few think that the publicity connected to Madonna's new book, "Sex," published by Time Warner, has affected the company much. "You kind of expect that kind of publicity from a media company," one analyst said.
Some other factors also make some investors a bit nervous. The company has filed a $1.5 billion shelf registration of securities. It has outstanding about $6.5 billion in preferred stock that generates high dividends that are not deductible for tax purposes. The fear is that Time Warner would issue debentures convertible into common stock that would be used to buy in the preferred stock. But Time Warner has denied that it plans to dilute its stock still further.
For analysts the persistent question is whether the stock is finally ready to make a strong move higher. "I've been waiting about two years," sighed one analyst yesterday.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Drop to a 2-Year Low

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for jobless benefits fell to a two-year low in late October and remained under 400,000 for the sixth consecutive week, the Government reported today.
Thomas F. Carpenter, an economist at ASB Capital Management in Washington, said the report was the latest sign that "the employment situation has at last stabilized." 
 "The claims numbers suggest that the hiring phase of the economic growth cycle is on the verge of kicking in," Mr. Carpenter said. "It won't kick in in a big way, but it will start kicking in."
 
 
Analysts Had Expected Rise
 The Labor Department reported first-time applications for unemployment insurance fell by 5,000, to 355,000, for the week that ended Oct. 31, the lowest since claims totaled 354,000 in the week of Aug. 4, 1990. Many analysts had expected claims to rise.
Initial claims, which peaked at 530,000 on March 23, 1991, at the depths of the recession, have numbered less than 400,000 since Sept. 26.
Not included in the report, however, were 20,869 new claims filed under a special emergency unemployment program. That total was down from 23,497 for the week ended Oct. 24 and the lowest since 20,754 applications were filed in the week of Sept. 25.
The emergency program numbers, unlike the national figures, are not seasonally adjusted.
Many analysts believe the unemployment rate should improve if claims hold below 400,000. The rate fell for the fourth straight month in October, hitting a six-month low of 7.4 percent. Others say the economy will have to grow faster than the 2.7 percent annual rate in the third quarter to generate substantial job growth. Only 27,000 jobs were created in October, for instance, less than half of September's 72,000 loss.
Still, the closely watched four-week average of new claims also dropped to a two-year low in the week ended Oct. 31. It fell from 371,500 to 364,500, the lowest since the average was 356,000 on July 14, 1990.
 
 
Less Volatility
 Many analysts prefer to track the four-week average because it smooths out the volatility of the weekly reports.
Twenty-nine states and territories reported decreases in weekly claims; 24 registered increases. States reporting the largest decreases were Ohio, 2,914; Missouri, 1,748; New York, 1,146; California, 894, and Iowa, 662.
Missouri attributed its decrease to fewer layoffs in the transportation industry, while New York said it had fewer seasonal layoffs in a variety of industries.
States registering the largest increases were Michigan, 2,666; Illinois, 1,354; South Carolina, 894; Kansas, 743, and New Mexico, 644.
The national figures are adjusted for seasonal variations, but the individual state figures are not.

HEADLINE: Mirage Resorts Offers Plan for Gambling on the Bridgeport Waterfront

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 12

 BODY:
Mirage Resorts today presented a plan for a casino and gaming center on this city's waterfront that, at first sight, looked no more implausible than the dolphins and rain forest at the Mirage desert resort on the Las Vegas Strip.
The center, called the Bridgeport Sporting Club, would be designed to look like a huge New England yacht club or oceanfront home, with clapboards and shutters, and would include attractions from a casino, dog track and parimutuel simulcast theater to an ice rink and an amusement area for children. 
 "It's time for people who love this idea or hate this idea to have something to criticize," Mirage's chief executive, Stephen A. Wynn, said in presenting the plans to business and political leaders at a luncheon at Bridgeport Jai-Alai, the proposed site for the center.
Mr. Wynn has been lobbying hard to open in Connecticut the first non-Indian casino outside Nevada and Atlantic City. Despite a vow from Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. to veto any legislation permitting a casino, he has proposed a convention center and casino in Hartford, as well as the Bridgeport casino.
 
Mashantucket Pequots
 Connecticut has one casino, Foxwood, on the Mashantucket Pequot Indian reservation in Ledyard. Federal law permits tribes to conduct gambling if a state allows it; the Pequots qualified because Connecticut allows churches and other organizations to sponsor Las Vegas nights.
In many minds, the Pequot casino made Connecticut ground-zero for a coming explosion of gaming across the country, as other tribes seek to emulate the Pequots' success and states starved for revenue begin legalizing casinos off the reservation so they can share in the profits.
The plan presented by Mr. Wynn today is Mirage's attempt to enter the New York day-trip market. The center includes only one hotel, with 350 to 700 rooms (the Mirage, in Las Vegas, has 3,044 rooms and suites). But it is next to the Connecticut Turnpike and the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, and could be linked to Long Island by hydrofoil ferries.
Mr. Wynn said the center would not be like Las Vegas: "There isn't a speck of neon on this building." And it would not repeat the mistakes of Atlantic City, with its concentration of casinos looming behind a deteriorated city.
He said the Bridgeport center, on the waterfront immediately off Exit 28 of the turnpike, would provide a "completely self-contained environment that can be safe, that can be well-lit, that allows people to come and go without upsetting residential neighborhoods."
 
Jobs and Taxes
 He said that he would expect the center to employ 5,000 to 7,000 people and that local residents would have the first opportunity to apply for the jobs. He estimated the center would produce $50 million to $100 million a year in local and state tax revenue.
He also said bluntly that the casino, by itself, was not going to solve Bridgeport's economic or social problems.
"Get it straight," he said. "I think I know how to bring people to Bridgeport, and keep them coming, but there is no reason on earth for any of you to expect for more than one second that just because there are people here, they're going to run into your store, or restaurant, or bar.
"That didn't happen in Atlantic City," he said. "It should never have been promised in Atlantic City. It is illogical to expect that people who won't come to Bridgeport and go to your restaurants or your stores today will go to your restaurants and stores just because we happen to build this building here."

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Expo for Pets and Their Companions

BYLINE: By Andrew H. Malcolm

DATELINE: UNIONDALE, L.I.

 BODY:
HERE'S the ideal weather report for this weekend by Rick Stuts: A 100 percent chance of overcast with a perpetual mist escalating to steady drizzle (but not a downpour), continuing without pause until 6:01 Sunday evening, give or take a minute.
What does Rick care, he's not raking leaves. He's cozy inside the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum, and he wants 80,000-odd others to pay $7 each to join him there over the next 60 hours. 
 Unless you've been in a coma since Sunday, you've seen the posters, read the ads, heard the radio spots or dodged the television promos for Pet Expo, the second annual extravaganza for animals who let us pay their rent or mortgage and all food and medical costs in exchange for several pounds of used hair per annum.
Pet Expo has 60,000 square feet of exhibits and sales booths offering everything from pony rides, animal adoptions, pet portraits and dog tricks to nutrition pellets for baby birds, jungle gyms for kittens, memorial parks for dead pets (rustic or formal services available) and, of course, carpet cleaners. This year Peter Orvis of Waxing Eloquent is here too with his new scented candles that address the problem of furry friends who never shower or flush.
Pet Expos are breaking out all over these days -- there's another in the Hartford Civic Center this weekend -- as thoughtful entrepreneurs help fill our dwindling leisure time and empty our wallets. Rick got the Pet Expo idea a few years ago from Hal Dunn, a friend whose wife, Maria, is really into parrots.
At first, Rick was so busy with his Long Beach company, Expositions Inc., and its twice-annual Coliseum home-improvement shows. But he did some research. You know, they even have successful expositions for people who relax by shooting defenseless ducks, which is a small, though fashionably dressed, and well-armed minority. Imagine what could be done with a convention for America's animal lovers, who spend more on pets than babies.
"Americans are crazy for pets," says Rick, who doesn't happen to have one himself. "You get people here who can't afford to eat well themselves, but they'll buy gourmet food for their pet. And you get North Shore folks who'll spend a fortune clothing their pet."
Rick gets more nervous for the Pet Expo, he says, than he did years ago playing bass guitar for Wilson Pickett. That may have something to do with the $145,000 he needs to see by Sunday night to break even. "It's fun," he says, cruising the floor with his crackly walkie-talkie. "I'm building a city of pets indoors." Interruptions, however, lurk everywhere.
"Hey, Rick. How many chairs you want in back?"
You might guess Rick is in sales. Rick's dad, Sidney, was a furniture salesman, a great one. Rick used to sell encyclopedias door to door, some people's image of eternal damnation. And Rick's son, Steven, hands out fliers at the Info Booth. Steven is 4.
Stuts salesmen are pros, of course; they believe in what they sell. And they believe all parties must feel good about any sale. Sidney's customers at Blumstein's just knew they got a good deal.
"Hey, Rick. Where d'ya want these cables?"
But how do you convince, say, the Tall Tails Pet Shop to rent basement exhibition space on a pleasantly dreary weekend? "In a brutal economy," says Rick, "some businesses play ostrich and get run over. The smart ones get aggressive. Now, how would you like Pet Expo to put your little shop on Hempstead Turnpike for 80,000 to see what they can buy from you? You'll see more people in five days with us than you get in your store in five years."
"Hey, Rick. The radio station's here with the balloon for the roof."
Rick is amazed at humans' mass dedication to animals. He donates free space to some adoption shelters. He offers a dog show and petting zoo. "Touching is very important in the pet business," he explains.
Now tell us, Rick, how do you sell expensive encyclopedias to a man who's six months behind reading Reader's Digests? "I understand," says Rick. "I don't want you to buy. I won't even tell you the price. But your wife made this appointment. Out of respect for her, I'm here. I'll tell you a few things. Then I'll leave. Fair enough? You've got, what, four children? You know education is more important every day. Books are a student's tools. You'd never send a carpenter out without a hammer. How could any parent deny their child the tools to build a fulfilling -- and profitable -- life? And when you divide the cost by four, that's not much for each future."
Will you take a check, Rick?

HEADLINE: Stocks Ease As the Dow Falls by 0.54

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Stocks ended slightly lower yesterday, under pressure from profit taking that halted a six-day rally on the Nasdaq over-the-counter market.
The Dow Jones industrial average ended down 0.54 point, at 3,239.79, after retreating from a high of 3,249.51. 
 Advancing issues led decliners, 922 to 875, on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume was 226 million shares, compared with 243.8 million on Wednesday.
The Nasdaq composite index, having rallied six sessions in a row, closed down 0.55 point, at 634.37.
"We finally took a little breather today," said Peter Coolidge, senior equity trader at Kidder, Peabody.
The Nasdaq had risen almost 5 percent in the six sessions after Gov. Bill Clinton won the Presidential election on Nov. 3, as investors viewed secondary stocks as likely to be favored by Clinton economic policies.
Analysts said the stock market had little reaction to President-elect Clinton's first news conference yesterday. He pledged to take "aggressive and prompt action" to get the economy moving again and announced the appointment of Prof. Robert Reich of Harvard as the head of economic affairs on his transition team.
 
Signs of Improving Economy
Stocks also received an initial lift on signs of an improving economy. The number of Americans filing first-time claims for state unemployment benefits fell for the third straight week to the lowest level in more than two years.
Analysts said the secondary shares were again the pacesetter for the overall market.
"What's affecting the market more than anything else today is that you're starting to see some profit taking in the over-the-counter market that is spreading into the listed area," said Harry Laubscher, market analyst at Tucker Anthony.
Analysts said blue chips, which had struggled to catch up with the gains in Nasdaq stocks, were again following the lead of the secondary shares.
Shares of Ford Motor gained 5/8, to 39, after the company announced that its president and chief operating officer, Philip Benton, would retire.
Upjohn lost 7/8, to 30 3/4 after a civil jury awarded $1.8 million in damages to the family of a former police officer who said his use of the company's sleeping pill Halcion had caused him to murder his best friend.
Shares of Lands' End lost 5 5/8, or 20 percent of their value, to close at 24 1/4. The mail order retailer reported lower net earnings for the third quarter and said softness in sales may continue through the Christmas season.
Some broader indicators showed gains. The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 0.67 point, to 422.87. The American Stock Exchange index gained 0.42, to 389.23.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite index of all listed common stocks rose 0.25, to 232.83.
For the second session, the Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of Big Board, American and Nasdaq issues -- closed at a record high, standing at 4,133.836, up 3.176 or 0.08 percent.

HEADLINE: New Talks On Europe Trade Set

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
The top American and European trade and agriculture officials will meet here next week in yet another effort to tiptoe back from the brink of trade war, American officials said today.
But both sides stressed today that they had not changed their basic positions in the dispute on farm subsidies. The United States contends that Europe unfairly subsidizes its grain farmers, which has the effect of denying billions of dollars of export sales to American farmers. 
 Unable to find a settlement, the United States said last week that it would impose a 200 percent tax on European white wines and some other goods, effective Dec. 5. The talks are now aimed at averting that sanction and whatever European retaliation might follow.
 
Key to World Deal
 And both sides say that resolving this dispute is the key to an overall deal in world trade talks that could reduce global trade barriers and stimulate economies in rich and poor countries alike.
Both American and European officials are under tremendous pressure from political and industrial constituencies at home, and they apparently feel they need at least to be talking.
And trade officials on both sides of the Atlantic have taken heart from the return to the negotiations of Ray MacSharry of Ireland, the European Community's Agriculture Commissioner and its top negotiator on farm issues until last week, when he quit in a huff, complaining that Jacques Delors, the French president of the European Community, had sabotaged negotiations.
Mr. MacSharry and the United States Agriculture Secretary, Edward R. Madigan, met in Chicago last week and nearly reached an agreement before Mr. Delors interceded, Mr. MacSharry said. He agreed to return to lead Europe's negotiating team on Tuesday after being assured of more independence.
Mr. MacSharry and Frans Andriessen, the community's External Affairs Commissioner, will come to Washington on Wednesday to open two days of talks with Mr. Madigan and Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative.
President-elect Bill Clinton has avoided any role in the dispute, emphasizing that President Bush remains in charge until Jan. 20. Today he said at a news conference in Little Rock that after his inauguration he hoped to strengthen the world economy by "hopefully resolving the outstanding issues in Europe and proceeding with a cooperative strategy with the other major economic powers to promote global growth, something which will help us very much."
American and European officials who insisted on anonymity said the United States had been calling for the European Community to limit its production of soybeans, rapeseed and sunflower seeds -- oilseeds used in animal feed and cooking oil -- to about eight million metric tons, while the community has offered to reduce acreage but not to limit total output. The community's offer on acreage translates into about 9.5 million tons by European estimates of yields per acre, and into 10.5 million tons by American estimates.
The two sides have secretly reviewed ways to find a compromise by agreeing on a reduction in acreage while each side uses a different forecast of yields. But American farm lobbyists have strongly urged the Administration to use a high estimate of yields, which means a bigger drop in acreage than the community is willing to accept.
"The problem is basically that our farmers have a lot of experience and know what the yields are," an American official said. "We could fudge it, but there'd be screams of outrage that we were fudging it, and there wouldn't be screams the next week, there'd be screams right away."
The United States is currently using a forecast of 2.31 metric tons a hectare (2.471 acres), which was the average yield for the European Community's 1990 crop. The community wants to use a figure of 2 or 2.1 tons a hectare. The yield rose last year to 2.44 metric tons a hectare, but is forecast to fall to 2.17 metric tons this autumn because of poor weather in Europe and a year-old revision of subsidies there.
The new subsidy system means that only the first couple of tons of oilseeds grown on each hectare are eligible for government money, which has discouraged farmers from using expensive fertilizers and pesticides to produce several tons per hectare. The European Community says this subsidy holds down yields, but the United States contends that technological advances will cause yields to resume rising soon.
French rapeseed farmers have been particularly vigorous in protesting the revision of the oilseed subsidies. As a result, France has tried to block an agreement with the United States that would further limit subsidies, and Mr. Delors, who holds thinly disguised ambitions to become president of France in 1995, has tended to support the French position.

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Bruce Weber

 BODY:

'Angels,' Downtown or on Broadway?
With the premiere of the two-part marathon "Angels in America" at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles on Sunday, the scramble is on to secure a home for it in New York. A longstanding agreement among the New York Shakespeare Festival, the New York Theater Workshop and the Center Theater Group in Los Angeles has the show arriving for an eight-week run at the Public Theater on Feb. 9, but the principals now say that a move directly to Broadway is very possible, if not likely. 
 General hopefulness that the seven-hour extravaganza, a visionary anthem for gay America, might prove to be a moneymaker has been building for some time, but it peaked this week after the premiere. As the actor Ron Leibman, who plays Roy Cohn, said: "When we went into it, it was because it was a beautiful piece of writing. Now it's like: 'It's commercial? Wait a minute. Is that possible?' "
Indeed, the competition to stage the show includes Broadway's most powerful producers and theater owners. The Shubert organization would like the play, possibly for the Plymouth Theater, though the Plymouth is temporarily being held for "The Song of Jacob Zulu." (That's to give the Steppenwolf Theater Company, which has taken over from the Shuberts as producers, a chance to raise the money to stage it.) The Jujamcyn organization has offered the Walter Kerr, which is smaller, but Jujamcyn's advantage is its relationship with the Taper; the last three Taper shows that have come to New York have shown at Jujamcyn houses. And there has been substantial interest from independent producers as well.
The competition, said Jack Viertel, Jujamcyn's creative director, "ought to be a donnybrook."
The show, set largely in the 1980's and strewn with magical theatrics, is divided into two parts. The first, "Millennium Approaches," was presented at the Royal National Theater in London this year; the second, "Perestroika," made its debut on Sunday, and Tony Kushner, the playwright, is still making changes in it. New material was added for the premiere as late as last Friday.
On Wednesday, Mr. Kushner will meet in New York with Gordon Davidson, artistic director of the Center group; James C. Nicola, artistic director of the theater workshop, and JoAnne Akalaitis and Jason Steven Cohen, artistic director and producing director, respectively, of the Shakespeare festival, to discuss their options. If the show, which Mr. Davidson estimated would cost $1.5 million to stage, bypasses the Public, the festival subscribers would be entitled to tickets elsewhere and the festival would still collect those revenues.
The issues to be discussed, Mr. Davidson and others said, include the size of the Public's stages, which are smaller than Broadway's and would require the show to compromise on the flight paths of its soaring angel and some of its other stagecraft; whether the show is better served in agrueling single-day performance or by alternate nights, and how a challenging show on a controversial subject should be marketed. It is not, the potential producers agreed, a sure-fire smash. "It's no layup," Mr. Viertel said.
Mr. Davidson and Mr. Cohen said the final decision would be largely in the hands of Mr. Kushner, who himself seems torn. Speaking from London, where he flew after the premiere to accept the Evening Standard Drama award for best play of 1992, Mr. Kushner said he had about a month of work left to do on "Perestroika" before New York.
"The second play is longer than the first, and it should be a little shorter, if not a lot shorter," he said. "I'm trying to hang on to my playwright's head and not get lost in the vagaries of producing." Nonetheless, he added, the choice of whether to go to Broadway or not was "a great dilemma to be in."
"The New York Shakespeare Festival has been the most important theater in my theatergoing life," he said. "And I think it's a play in the tradition of the theater that Joseph Papp created."
On the other hand, he said, he is attracted by Broadway's majestic proscenium stages and the lure of Broadway in general: "I do believe 'Angels' can play for a mass audience. It seems to play for straight people as well as gay people. It has crossover possibilities, I guess."
He added a note of conscience: "There is a community I want to be able to see the play in New York, if they want to. The downtown gay and lesbian community. I want them to see it. And we're in a recession. I don't want the play restricted to an audience with disposable income. Unless we do something about it, Broadway suggests inaccessibility in ticket prices. And if the people the play is about can't come and see it, something's wrong."
 
Helping to Keep a Secret Secret

 In the gossipy theater world it's tough to keep secrets, and in the case of "Solitary Confinement," the Stacy Keach vehicle that opened at the Nederlander this week, the secret -- revealed every night onstage -- is the whole point.
It's not just a secret, actually, it's a sting; the audience is willfully, playfully misled, and it would be impossible to pull it off without the help (or at least the benign neglect) of Playbill, the production-customized publication that provides the theatergoer with the show's vital info. What's bogus about the Playbill for "Solitary Confinement" won't be divulged here. A warning will suffice: Don't believe everything you read.
There's a history of Playbill's playing along, said Arthur T. Birsh, the publisher. He cited "Sleuth," Anthony Shaffer's 1970 thriller with two characters, myriad disguises and a whole list of made-up actors in the Playbill.
And then there was "We Interrupt This Program" in 1975. "This show had as its premise that 15 minutes into a very dull first act, armed and masked hooligans came in and hijacked the theater," Mr. Birsh said. "Then they gave out a totally new Playbill."
The fact is, Playbill doesn't necessarily know when it's helping to pull an audience's leg. The press agent for a show writes the production notes, and though the staff of Playbill edits the agent's notes, unless there's an unusual request -- printing the title page after the cast notes, for instance -- what they're given is largely what's published, no questions asked.
"I was fooled along with everybody else on 'Sleuth,' " Mr. Birsh said.
 
A Replacement for Tony Perkins
 When Anthony Perkins died of AIDS in September, he was preparing to direct "Together," a play about the stormy marriage of Eugene and Carlotta O'Neill. This week, the producer Curtis Roberts announced that Burt Brinckerhoff would replace Mr. Perkins, and that the play, which stars Lois Nettleton and Don Murray, would open at the Wellington Theater in Chicago on Feb. 24.

GRAPHIC: Drawing: "Doodles of the Stars": New Dramatists, a nonprofit organization dedicated to developing new plays, will hold its ninth annual celebrity doodle auction on Monday at 6:30 P.M. at the Russian Tea Room. Some two dozen drawings by theater notables (and others) will be for sale, including the self-portrait of sorts, above, by Nathan Lane. Tickets, which are tax-deductible, are $100. It ain't art, but so what?

HEADLINE: A Matisse Painting Sells For a Record $14.5 Million

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL

 BODY:
The art market got a stunning shot in the arm on Wednesday night at Christie's sale of Impressionist and modern paintings, drawings and sculpture. Much to even the experts' surprise, Matisse's "Harmony in Yellow," from 1927-28, which was being sold by Dr. Philip Sandbloom, a Swedish collector, set a record price of $14.5 million. The previous record for the artist, in 1989 at the height of the market, was $12.4 million when "Woman With a Red Umbrella Seated in Profile" (1919-21) sold at Sotheby's in New York.
But it wasn't just the Matisse that made the evening a success for Christie's. Another important work, Monet's "Waterlily Basin," from 1919, sold for $12.1 million, soaring way above the auction house's estimate of $7 million to $8 million. It was being sold from the estate of Ralph Friedman, a Manhattan philanthropist and former director of Bank Leumi Le Israel's North American operations. 
 Both sales proved that despite the doldrums the market has been in for the last two years, great works of art still command great prices.
The auction house refused to reveal the names of the buyers. These bids came over the telephone from the United States and Europe, as did most of the bids of the evening.
The evening totaled $70,694,100 in sales, well above the auction house's low estimate of $53.5 million. Of the 76 works up for sale, only 17 failed to sell.
 
Compared With Sotheby's . . .
 The auction stood in sharp contrast to Sotheby's sale of Impressionist and modern art on Tuesday evening. With the exception of one great price, $11 million, for "Asia," a Matisse that sold to the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, nearly half the works failed to sell and of those that did, many sold either at or well below their low estimates. The sale totaled $35.6 million, well below Sotheby's estimate of $59 million to $80 million.
"I'm extremely surprised," said Christopher Burge, Christie's president in New York, after the sale Wednesday night. "After Tuesday night we weren't quite sure what was going to happen."
Many experts said they knew Christie's sale would fare better than Sotheby's but no one said they expected that some of the prices would climb as high as they did in this economic climate. "Clearly we've hit bottom and we're on our way up," said David Tunick, a New York dealer. "Christie's got the estimates right this time. They also had the benefit of better pictures than Sotheby's."
The salesroom was packed with leading experts and collectors from around the world and the mood was immediately buoyant. What helped get the sale off to a positive start was that Christie's began the evening by offering the 24 works from the estate of Richard and Dorothy Rodgers. Not only was it a varied collection, with a wide price range of artworks, but clearly the reserves (the minimum price that is agreed upon by the seller and auction house) were kept low; the collection was 100 percent sold.
Picasso's "Guitar and Newspaper," from 1914, for example, was estimated to fetch $3 million to $4 million. It sold for $2.2 million to a private American collector. Another Picasso, "Spanish Dancer," from 1901, also went below Christie's estimate of $1.8 million to $2.5 million: it sold for $1.32 million. There was a lot of activity when Giacometti's sculpture "Falling Man," from 1950, sold for $1.5 million, way above the $600,000 to $800,00 estimate. And four bidders fought for Magritte's "Empire of Lights," from 1953, which was estimated to bring $400,000 to $600,000. It sold to a telephone bidder for $528,000.
 
'Buyers Were Very Focused'
 The sale was filled with more expensive works that the auction house had seen since 1990. A Degas, "Two Dancers in Green Dresses," from 1895, estimated to bring $4 million to $6 million, sold for $7.5 million to a European collector. Surprisingly, seven works sold for over $2 million, quite a change from last fall, when bidding tended to halt when an artwork reached $1 million. "There weren't people bottom fishing," said Michael Findlay, the senior director of Christie's Impressionist and modern painting department. "Nor did the room feel like one entity. Buyers were very focused on works they were interested in."
If any one artist dominated the two nights it was Matisse. It had been years since an important Matisse had found its way to the auction block and this season both by the coincidence of estate offerings and a hefty number of collectors trying to cash in on the success of the Museum of Modern Art's blockbuster Matisse retrospective. Christie's offered six Matisses for sale Wednesday night.
"Flowers From Nice," a colorful 1925 interior being sold by the Rodgers estate, fetched $528,000, just below Christie's estimate of $600,000. A Matisse drawing from the estate, "Lydia in a Romanian Blouse," from 1936, sold just above its high estimate, selling for $165,000.
"Still Life With Pitcher and Fruit," painted in Toulouse, France, in 1898, estimated to bring $500,000 to $700,000, sold for $451,000. "The Bridge From Sevres to St.-Cloud," from 1917, estimated at $550,000 to $650,000, failed to sell. Bidding stopped at $380,000. Still, the works fared far better than the Matisses at Sotheby's on Tuesday night, many of which never sold.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Assigning Blame and Taking No Responsibility

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:

A Nation of Victims
 The Decay of the American Character
 By Charles J. Sykes
 289 pages. St. Martin's Press. $22.95.
A Massachusetts man steals a car from a parking lot and is killed while driving it; his family subsequently sues the parking-lot owner for failing to take steps to prevent such thefts. A bicyclist in the Midwest compares disrespect toward bicyclists to "cross burning, swastika painting, gay bashing" and other "hate crimes motivated by the status of the victim." The University of Missouri School of Journalism issues a handbook of words and phrases that should be sidestepped "to avoid offending and perpetuating stereotypes": among those terms are "burly" ("too often associated with large black men, implying ignorance"), "white" (a product of the "racist power structure") and "community" ("implies a monolithic culture in which people act, think and vote in the same way"). 
 Such examples, Charles J. Sykes argues in his new book, "A Nation of Victims," are illustrations of a growing phenomenon characterized by a plaintive refrain: "I am a victim." "I am not responsible; it's not my fault." This "victim-ization of America," Mr. Sykes writes, "is remarkably egalitarian": "victim status is now claimed not only by members of minority groups but increasingly by the middle class, millionaire artists, students at Ivy League colleges, 'adult children,' the obese, codependents, victims of 'lookism' (bias against the unattractive), 'ageism,' 'toxic parents' and the otherwise psychically scarred." It has resulted in the imposition of "speech codes" at college campuses around the country; a flood of lawsuits charging bias or discrimination, and a proliferation of defense motions, intended to portray the defendant as another injured party.
Marion S. Barry Jr., the former Mayor of Washington, contends he is a victim of racism when he is convicted of cocaine possession. Dan White, who killed Mayor George Moscone of San Francisco, argues that his violent behavior was triggered by eating too much junk food. And Tawana Brawley, who fabricated a story about being assaulted by a gang of white men, is celebrated as a symbol of black women who have endured centuries of sexual abuse.
Of course, much has already been written about the victim phenomenon, and the book that Mr. Sykes -- the author of a widely praised study of American universities called "Profscam" -- has written remains heavily indebted to John Taylor's 1991 New York magazine article "Don't Blame Me!" and Time magazine's 1991 cover story "Crybabies: Eternal Victims." His book also superficially rehashes ideas raised by books like Christopher Lasch's "Culture of Narcissism," Jim Sleeper's "Closest of Strangers," Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr.'s "Disuniting of America," Mickey Kaus's "End of Equality" and James Lincoln Collier's "Rise of Selfishness in America."
As Mr. Sykes sees it, "victimism can be seen as a generalized cultural impulse to deny personal responsibility and to obsess on the grievances of the insatiable self." It stems in part, he suggests, from Americans' unwillingness to acknowledge the limitations and disappointments inherent in the human condition -- their tendency to see "the immemorial questions of human life as problems that required solutions."  As a result, he suggests, Americans have enshrined "the infinite expectation -- for psychological gratification, self-actualization, self-realization, and happiness -- not as a goal to be won but as an entitlement."
In the 1960's, as young people began embracing an adversarial stance toward authority, Mr. Sykes says, dissatisfaction became a permanent fixture in American life. Although he praises the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. for stressing self-reliance as a remedy to poverty, Mr. Sykes contends that the civil rights movement later underwent a decisive -- and, in his opinion, damaging -- change when it shifted its emphasis "from seeking equality under the law to a focus on the vague and volatile concept of racism." "Victimist" explanations were offered up to explain black crime and black drug addiction; "victimist" arguments were advanced to rationalize the academic failures of black students.
The grievances of blacks, Mr. Sykes suggests, were appropriated in the 60's by white radicals interested in "acquiring some of the moral standing of the genuinely downtrodden." Over the years, he argues, an increasingly wide array of groups -- including women, homosexuals, American Indians, the elderly and the disabled -- started to take advantage of "an elaborate array of programs, privileges, and entitlements that were specifically attached to various groups' victim status."
In describing the growing Balkanization of American society -- the competing (and often highly selfish) demands of different special-interest groups and the absurdities that can result from the dogmatic embrace of "political correctness" -- Mr. Sykes is eloquent and often convincing, displaying in these pages a healthy dose of common sense.
When it comes to the larger picture, however, he tends to grow didactic, callous and shrill, using extreme examples to dismiss or debunk entire trends, and making broad and often unsubstantiated generalizations. For instance, he blames Freud's "critique of the culture's emphasis on restraint and self-denial" for the lack of responsibility in today's society, although Freud actually underscored the importance of sublimating the unruly impulses of the id. He cynically predicts that the 1990 Americans With Disabilities Act will lead to a "starburst of victimist creativity." And he plays down the continuing problem of poverty and unemployment among blacks by selectively quoting a study that shows that the earnings of black women top those of white women with similar backgrounds.
How does Mr. Sykes propose to remedy the cult of victimization in America? He calls for a new code of personal conduct, emphasizing self-restraint, and he says he hopes that the "disrepute associated with dependency, illegitimacy and family breakup" will be reinstituted in minority communities. He wants to "sharply limit the definitions of victimization in the law itself -- civil rights legislation and protections of the handicapped included." And he wants Americans to re-embrace the family as "the crucible of character."
As flippantly delineated by Mr. Sykes, such proposals are simplistic in the extreme, as simplistic, unfortunately, as much of "A Nation of Victims."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
ALCOA UNIT CLOSING INDIANA PLANT

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday its Stolle Corporation subsidiary was closing a South Bend, Ind., plant that employs about 250 people. The plant's operations will be consolidated into Stolle's Princeville, Ill., plant in the first quarter of 1993. About 100 jobs will be added at Princeville. The plants make vinyl siding and accessories for the new-home, remodeling and manufactured-housing industries. The closing will result in an after-tax charge of about $30 million, or 35 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, Alcoa said.

HEADLINE: It's the Bully Pulpit Again;
The President-Elect: Leading by Explaining

 BODY:
Listening to Bill Clinton's news conference yesterday brought a surprising sense of relief and respect.
For 12 years, Presidential news conferences have often driven English teachers to slap their foreheads in despair. Yesterday Mr. Clinton not only spoke cogently and in complete sentences; he became a teacher. The bully pulpit has become a pulpit again. 
 For all his reputation as the Great Communicator, President Reagan, mellifluous with a prepared statement, often bumbled into incoherence when required to extemporize. In the last four years, parsing President Bush has become a competitive sport, turning up gems like, "I just am not one who -- who flamboyantly believes in throwing a lot of words around."
In his first news conference since the election, Mr. Clinton was no John F. Kennedy; he lackedthe signature flashes of wit. But he came out with an admirably limited and sensible agenda of priorities. And, equally welcome, he explained them.
For instance, he called anew for campaign finance reform, and embraced several key components of a decent plan: campaign spending limits, new curbs on PAC's and opening the airwaves to candidates.
Most notably, the President-elect spelled out his views of the economy. He took pains to make the fundamental distinction so often lost during the campaign between the short-term need for stimulus to get the economy growing again and the long-term need to reduce the deficit while making America more productive.
"All along the way," Mr. Clinton said yesterday, "I have to do my best at one of the most important jobs of the President" -- to communicate to the American people "exactly where we are at this point in our history, how we got here and where we're going in the future." He's right about the responsibility, and yesterday made a strong start on the content.

HEADLINE: Postal Service In Refinancing

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
The Postal Service and the Treasury said today that they had agreed to a refinancing of postal debt that will reduce interest costs by $2 billion over 20 years.
About $4.5 billion in debt was refinanced, reducing the average interest rate from 8.76 percent to 6.56 percent and providing the option to pay off notes early without penalty, the Postal Service said. 
The refinancing was handled by the Federal Financing Bank, an arm of the Treasury, which holds about $10 billion in Postal Service debt.
The Postmaster General, Marvin Runyon, said after he took office in July that he hoped to turn to the private financial market for lower interest rates.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Associations Form Brand-Equity Group

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
The American Association of Advertising Agencies and the Association of National Advertisers have joined nine media associations to form an organization to help make the case for building strong name-brand products.
The Coalition for Brand Equity is headed by Larry Light, who will continue as president at the Arcature Corporation, a marketing consulting company in Stamford, Conn. Others involved include the Magazine Publishers of America, the Network Television Association and the Newspaper Association of America. 
 "For the past couple of years," Mr. Light said yesterday, "we have been milking and exploiting brands."
"The key to profitability," he added, "is brand loyalty."
The coalition is being formed by organizations with a stake in the health of branded products, which are under unprecedented siege as economy-minded shoppers switch to lower-priced products and so-called value brands. Its plans include reviewing research on advertising's role in increasing brand value and sponsoring seminars on the future of brands.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: The New Team 1;
Clinton Selects Diverse Team of Advisers

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. Nov. 12

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton today named a transition team notable for its diversity in age, sex and ethnic background that will help Mr. Clinton shape the initial economic, foreign and social policies of his Administration.
The 48-person team includes a rich mix of white, black, Hispanic and Asian-American advisers, men and women, the youthful and the experienced, Gentiles and Jews, academics and business executives, politicians who worked with Mr. Clinton during the campaign and old friends. 
 The two most influential positions on the team went to Robert B. Reich, a professor of public policy at Harvard University, who will run the economic policy team, and Samuel R. Berger, an official of the Carter Administration, who will run the foreign policy team.
"I have pledged to the American people that my Cabinet will look more like America than previous administrations," said Mr. Clinton in a news conference at the State House here.
 
More Advisers Next Week
 The transition hierarchy is headed by Vernon E. Jordan and Warren M. Christopher. Under their direction, the advisers appointed today will deal with matters from health care to an office for Mr. Clinton's wife, Hillary.
The senior advisers heading each policy cluster will draw up detailed proposals for how to fulfill Mr. Clinton's campaign promises. They are also expected to prepare lists of prospects for lower-level appointments in their respective areas.
Another team of advisers, to be named next week, will work with agencies of the Bush Administration.
Mr. Reich, who lectures on political economy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, is known for his view that the two main factors in increasing a country's economic competitiveness are the quality of its work force and its roads, bridges and communications systems.
Mr. Reich is widely expected to be given a top economic post in a Clinton Administration. In the transition, he will be assisted by Ira Magaziner, an economic consultant who advocates a large government role in increasing economic competitiveness.
The national security post on the transition team will be held by Mr. Berger, who was a deputy director of the Policy Planning Staff at the State Department in the Carter Administration and is an old friend of Mr. Clinton. In recent years, Mr. Berger has been a law partner in the Washington firm of Hogan & Hartson, and his views on specific foreign policy issues lie in the mainstream of the Democratic Party.
In his news conference, Mr. Clinton was asked to describe what attributes he would be looking for in his Secretary of State and National Security Adviser.
"I want a Secretary of State," he said, "who understands that we have obligations of continuity and obligations of change, and that basically the pillars of our national security and foreign policy ought to be a different but still very strong defense, a commitment to global growth and economic regeneration here and the fulfilling of our responsibility as the world's sole superpower to try to promote democracy and freedom and restrain the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction."
Al From, president of the Democratic Leadership Council, the conservative Democratic Party organization that has influenced Mr. Clinton on both foreign and domestic policy, will head the domestic policy team. Judy Feder, who directed the Pepper Commission study of the nation's medical care system, will supervise health policy.
Other major appointments include Eli J. Segal, the Boston businessman who served as campaign chief of staff, as chief financial officer. He is considered a leading candidate for White House chief of staff. George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's longtime communications director, will take that post for the transition and is expected to hold it in the White House.
Doris Matsui, a public policy advocate who is married to Representative Robert T. Matsui of California, and Anne Cohn Donnally, executive director of the National Committee for the Prevention of Child Abuse, were added to a five-member transition board.
Supervising the inaugural will be Ronald H. Brown, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and Harry Thomason and Linda Bloodworth-Thomason, television producers and close friends of the Clintons.
On Friday, Mr. Clinton is to release the ethical guidelines for his transition team. They are expected to include a prohibition on transition advisers' lobbying the government on any subject related to their transition activities for six months after Mr. Clinton takes office and a prohibition on any contact by transition members with their private clients while working on the transition.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 14, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about President-elect Bill Clinton's transition team referred incorrectly in some copies to the law firm in which a Clinton adviser, Samuel R. Berger, is a partner. It is Hogan & Hartson, in Washington.
