HEADLINE: Without Dire Steps, New York Finds Air Is Cleaner

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

 BODY:
To meet clean air requirements, New York City officials have, over the years, considered banning trucks from midtown Manhattan, placing tolls on East River bridges and insisting on "no drive days," when commuters would be barred from driving into the city more than four days a week.
But in an unexpected turnaround, city officials now say they they won't have to do any of these things to meet carbon-monoxide standards. In fact, they say, they probably won't have to do anything at all, because the city's air is becoming cleaner without new restrictions. 
 New York City has not exceeded the federally acceptable levels of carbon monoxide on a single day so far this year, the first time that has happened since the standard was set up 20 years ago. Officials now predict they will have no trouble meeting the Federal Clean Air Act standards that go into effect at the end of 1995.
Environmental officials and other experts agree that the improvement in air quality is largely a result of better car-emission technology and of gasoline with fewer pollutants. As people buy new cars in the next few years, they say, carbon-monoxide levels will continue to descend.
"Until we saw these trends, we thought we'd have to demand some serious transportation-control measures," said Antonia Bryson, the city's Deputy Commissioner of Environmental Protection for air policy and programs. "We don't want to say we're completely out of the woods, but there is a good trend here."
New York's clean air estimates are part of a report to be submitted today to the Federal Environmental Protection Agency on how New York State plans to meet the 1995 standards. Elements of the state's submission are incomplete, officials say, but the city has made a persuasive case that it has met interim carbon-monoxide requirements.
The Federal Government had set a Nov. 15 deadline for the report because the seven-county area that includes New York City and Westchester and Nassau counties was designated a "moderate high" area for carbon monoxide levels in 1990.
At the highest reading of the last decade, one of the city's four monitoring stations found that carbon-monoxide levels exceeded Federal standards on 71 days during 1985. The four stations are at 59th Street and Third Avenue, on Canal Street in lower Manhattan, at Flatbush Avenue and Tillary Street in Brooklyn and at the entrance to the Queens-Midtown Tunnel at 34th Street and Second Avenue.
But New York's satisfaction with the air measurements is not without its skeptics.
 
Skeptics Are Critical
 Environmental experts criticized the city's method of collecting carbon-monoxide data, saying that relying on only four monitors was inadequate.
"There have certainly been reductions in carbon-monoxide levels, thanks largely to better controls on motor vehicles," said Eric Goldstein, a lawyer with the Environmental Resource Defense Council. "But to plop down a handful of monitors and say that the problem is solved goes too far."
And others cautioned that the city's report would make officials lax in giving their attention to mass transit, which they called the single most important factor in controlling air pollution.
"The biggest issue in air quality over the long term is mass transportation," said James Tripp, a lawyer at the Environmental Defense Fund. "Protecting the fare and the quality of the transit system is essential."
City officials said that the cleaner air readings were in part the result of tough new Federal vehicle-inspection rules in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut region that were promulgated last week and require stricter checks for pollution emissions.
 
Gasoline Regulations
 Maura Fitzpatrick, director of policy analysis in the Department of Environmental Protection's bureau of air policy and programs, said that perhaps the most significant change in carbon-monoxide pollution levels had come from a 1989 agreement among states along the Eastern Seaboard to adopt regulations for gasoline with a lower level of volatility, which produces cleaner emissions. Starting in 1990, all gasoline sold in New York State has had to meet this standard.
"The aim was to alleviate our ozone problem, but it had the second and unpredicted effect of lowering carbon-monoxide levels as well," she said.
New York State needs to meet Federal requirements for three kinds of air pollutants: carbon monoxide, ozone and small particulate matter. Around the United States, ground-level ozone is perhaps the most serious air pollutant, and the Clean Air Act also requires New York State to submit a separate plan on how it will try to reduce ozone levels in successive stages from now to the year 2007.
Another factor in lowering carbon-monoxide levels, Ms. Fitzpatrick said, is a Federal requirement that beginning Nov. 1 an oxygen additive be put in all gasoline sold in regions with high carbon-monoxide levels.
"The estimated effectiveness of this program is quite high," she said. "It's a lot of bang for the buck."
The recent recession did not significantly affect the carbon-monoxide levels, she said. While it reduced the number of daily commuters it also meant that fewer people were able to buy new cars, which produce less pollution than older ones.
To comply with clean air standards, a group of officials from different city agencies had drawn up a list of possible measures over the last year.
Among the more drastic were limiting truck access to parts of midtown Manhattan, charging tolls on all city bridges that are now free, extending bus-only lanes on major highways and designating "no drive days" for private vehicles.
Although such measures would have had to pass multiple political hurdles before they could be implemented, Ms. Fitzpatrick said many officials assumed that the clean air requirements would act as "a gun to our heads," forcing the city to get the measures approved. She noted that according to Federal clean air requirements, billions of dollars in transportation funds could be revoked if the air standards were not met.
If the Federal Environmental Protection Agency deems the state submission incomplete, and the state does not comply within 18 months, the agency can demand that other pollutants be reduced.
The Department of Transportation announced a series of measures earlier this week aimed at improving traffic flow and reducing air pollution by using Federal money earmarked for such purposes.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 18, 1992, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in The Metro Section on Friday about air pollution characterized the data incorrectly. The graphs showed only pollution from carbon monoxide, primarily a wintertime pollutant, and did not show smog, primarily a summertime pollutant. The adjoining article made the distinction between the two types of pollution, but failed to say that some of the same control measures, including limits on car traffic into Manhattan, could be required to combat smog even if the carbon monoxide problem was solved.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: News Analysis;
In Command Of Language

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Words are George Bush's enemies; President-elect Bill Clinton showed today that they can be his friends.
That was the dominant impression of a Presidential style in embryo as it emerged from Mr. Clinton's first full-dress news conference since his victory 10 days ago. Whatever one thought of the substance of what he said -- and there was plenty of room for argument, because he stated his view bluntly in some cases -- the man from Little Rock left not the slightest doubt that the White House will get its syntax tightened when he moves in on Jan. 20. 
 Mr. Clinton has no experience in the Federal Government, and Mr. Bush made much of that in his losing re-election campaign. But the Arkansas Governor showed a command of the details and nuances of a wide range of topics, from Haitian refugees and Washington lobbying to the savings and loan scandal. He sounded as if he had been dealing daily with such issues for a long time.
Of course, the trademark windiness, which the country experienced during the 1988 and 1992 Democratic conventions, made an occasional reappearance. And skeptics noted his tendency, displayed during the campaign, to rely on stagy mannerisms, like biting his lip and lowering his eyes in a show of modesty.
But where Mr. Bush often favored an elliptical approach, Mr. Clinton took most questions head on: Yes. No. I haven't decided yet. I've decided but I'm not going to tell you yet.
The President-elect made it clear that he would take his time making appointments, whatever his critics said, but he also made it clear that his would be an activist Administration, with the top man more deeply immersed in the minutiae of governing than any, perhaps, since Lyndon B. Johnson.
 
'Having a Wonderful Time'
 Asked whether he felt overwhelmed by his new responsibilities, Mr. Clinton, a real government-lover, answered, "No, I'm having a wonderful time."
All of this offers signposts to the future. An American politican's style, knowledge and composure when standing behind a lectern, fielding reporters' questions, can be every bit as important in this country as a European politician's ability to answer questions posed in parliament, or a corporate chairman's capacity to handle the queries of his stockholders.
The press conference is one of the few occasions when the nation gets a look at a President in a situation over which he has only partial control, at best, and his early outings help to form an impression that lasts and lasts.
Press conferences have helped make some Presidents and break others. The coltish charm and quick wit of John F. Kennedy, the easy familiarity of Gerald R. Ford and the effortless command of that old theatrical pro, Ronald Reagan, helped them put their ideas across. Richard M. Nixon's evident defensiveness and nervousness, President Johnson's chronic whining and exaggeration and Mr. Bush's spaghetti sentences all got in the way of effective communication.
 
Long but Clear Sentences
 Mr. Clinton manages, somehow, to put together long, involved sentences on the spur of the moment without tripping over his tongue. Here, unedited, is what he said today about the sort of person he wants to manage his foreign policy:
"I want a Secretary of State who understands that we have obligations of continuity and obligations of change, and that basically the pillars of our national security and foreign policy ought to be a different but still very strong defense, a commitment to global growth and economic regeneration here, and the fulfilling of our responsibility as the world's sole superpower to try to promote democracy and freedom, and restrain the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction."
Mr. Bush's sentences, on the other hand, often do not parse at all. Here, for instance, is the beginning of his reply to a question about tax cuts at a news conference a year ago, on Oct. 26, 1991:
"I think it's understandable, when you have a bad -- economic numbers come in from time to time, mixed, I must happily say, with some reasonably good ones, other people get concerned. I'm concerned. But I don't want to do -- take -- I don't want to say to them, 'Well, you shouldn't come forward with proposals.' "
 
A Picture of Youth
 The President-elect also indicated a preference for grander, more official settings than those favored by Mr. Bush, who liked impromptu sessions in the White House briefing room. Mr. Clinton is not yet in office, but he opted for flags and formality, like Mr. Nixon and especially Mr. Reagan, although the President-elect told reporters he was "a real sort of informal person."
Like President Kennedy, Mr. Clinton clearly intends to project a picture of youth and vigor, not least to differentiate himself from Mr. Bush and the Republicans. He told a friend last week that the President lost "partly because he seemed worn out." To reinforce his youthful image, he brought Vice President-elect Al Gore out to stand behind him, mute, during the entire news conference.
Like President Reagan, who also lacked a military record, Mr. Clinton wants to project a bit of the John Wayne, tough-guy swagger. Anyone riffling through State Department files on his watch, he said, will be fired the day after he or she is caught.
He claimed no broad mandate for any of his specific proposals, like the middle-class tax cut or slashing the military budget. But he did see in the pattern of election returns a public demand for an end to partisan squabbling and legislative gridlock. He heard that from individual voters and read about it in his private polls.
Which is why he turned the other cheek to Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the acerbic if able Republican leader in the Senate; why he pledged again to appoint Republicans to senior positions, and why he praised Mr. Reagan's skill at legislative packaging and Mr. Bush's success in keeping the National Security Council and the State Department on the same track.
While Mr. Clinton stated firmly his determination to change the Pentagon's policy toward homosexuals, which he can do with a mere stroke of a pen, it has always been his style to make a great show of consensus-seeking with a Legislature that often fought him. So it was not surprising that the President-elect pledged to explore the issue with the top brass and with others who strongly disagree with him before taking action. That way, no one can accuse him of heedless arrogance.
Similarly, on Haiti, he reaffirmed his intention to give asylum-seekers some sort of hearing before sending them home, but he showed an awareness of the trouble that could cause and of the important distinction between economic and political refugees.
It was in his answer to a question about unrealistic expectations, however, that Mr. Clinton most clearly set the tone for the months ahead.
"I expect to keep the focus on these economic issues and I'm not trying to scale back, or scale down, or anything else," he said. "I think the American people understand that these problems are of long duration and there won't be any overnight miracles, but I think they expect aggressive and prompt action and I'm going to give it to them."

HEADLINE: Federal Loans to Aid Nonprofit Theaters

 BODY:
More than 140 Off and Off Off Broadway nonprofit theaters may be able to renovate their theaters or purchase larger quarters with their shares of a $1.5 million low-interest loan program of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. 
 The program was announced by the Alliance of Resident Theaters/ New York, a membership organization of nonprofit theater companies; the New York City Economic Development Corporation, and the office of Congressman Bill Green, a Manhattan Republican.
Criteria for applicants are being presently decided upon by the alliance and the city agency. The first loans are expected to be granted Feb. 1.

HEADLINE: Our History vs. Clinton's Covenant

BYLINE: By Orlando Patterson; Orlando Patterson, professor of sociology at Harvard, is completing the second volume of his book "Freedom."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
It has taken two centuries of struggle for America to remedy the egregious compromises that made its Constitution possible. The election of Bill Clinton, along with his running mate, another young Southerner, may mark a watershed in this historic remedy, one that holds special hope for African-Americans, for women and for all who now feel insecure and alienated from the American dream.
One powerful theme ran through his speeches at the Democratic convention and on election night: the Puritan ideal of America as a covenanted society. 
 Stripped of its religious traces, this is a vision of society in which free, responsible agents work, in the President-elect's words, with "a new spirit of community, a sense that we are all in this together," toward the construction of a just society. It remains profoundly American in its introspective individualism. But it nonetheless insists that all rights are socially constructed, not inherent -- that, as Mr. Clinton said, there are no rights without responsibilities.
Liberty has to mean something more than brute escape from authority into selfishness, embracing, at the very least, care for the needs and aspirations of other covenanted individuals in the conscious pursuit of the good life.
It was the freest and most powerful of Southern aristocrats who, in leading our nation to independence from Britain, became not only our Founding Fathers but the source of a radically different conception of individual and society. The Southern aristocratic ideal of freedom as an inherited quality of the individual -- expressed through power over others in a hierarchical, paternalistic order -- joined with the old European notion of natural rights to fashion the distinctly American conception of the individual as a bearer of inalienable rights.
Under the impact of the evangelical doctrine of equality before God and the fraternal impulse of revolution, this aristocratic ideal was further democratized to the glorious belief that all men are created equal.
But however great in theory and promise, this was made possible only through the most horrible compromise, a "compact with death." That fifth of the nation comprising enslaved African-Americans and the half of white people who were women were not only left out of Madison's "workshop of liberty." Their exclusion became a required basis of solidarity and identity in the emerging polity of free, prosperous white men.
Those who voted for Bill Clinton now want to believe that what he said in his acceptance and victory speeches was not merely an adolescent echo of John Kennedy but the reclamation of something far more profound. This was a promise to reach back, with all of us, and to right the wrong that was done, by restoring to the alienated members of the nation the discarded vision of a covenant that now includes all.
In spite of his muted racial rhetoric, African-Americans are strongly drawn to the President-elect. After the dastardly symbolic use of Willie Horton four years ago, every African-American, except Jesse Jackson, understood the poisonous potency of the Republican "Southern strategy" and the need to checkmate it. Mr. Clinton's program, if it works, will encompass African-Americans as Americans rather than as blacks.
But they are also drawn to him precisely because, among whites, only a regenerate Southerner can truly empathize with the full horror of our racist heritage. Much has been said in powerful symbolic ways, such as his off-camera engagement with African-American congregations.
The brutal assault on his character, all the hypocritical talk about trust and fidelity, struck the memory of the African-American like familiar sermons from the great house. His cool survival of every adversity was almost a prototype of the collective African-American experience. And it meant a great deal that this promised agent of change gave his victory speech at the Old State House in Little Rock, not far from Central High, that secular Calvary of the civil rights movement.
But if Mr. Clinton's covenant message brings hope to dispossessed African-Americans and the even larger numbers of white poor, it also poses a serious challenge. To join the public household of this great nation is to share responsibility for its fortunes and for one's failings.
The single mother who, correctly, insists on her right to the best possible care and education for herself and her children must accept the entailed duty of responsible parenting. The same principle holds for farmers, Social Security pensioners and all others who benefit from entitlements and subsidies. Without such a moral and social contract, the President-elect's domestic plan is headed for disaster.
For women, generally, his victory has great meaning. The attempt to replace Willie Horton with a demonized Hillary Clinton points to the persistent evil that requires the joint exclusion of blacks and women in the construction of divisive unity -- "We who are Americans; they who are not." Its failure this time around sustains our hope that there is, at least, a remedying of that "compact with death" at our constitutional convention.
But the greatest reason for hope in this victory lies elsewhere. Because it was our Southern "Fathers" who first shattered the Northern vision of a covenanted society, it is only right, and perhaps only possible, that a Southern leader should return to that abandoned vision -- not simply to resurrect it but to refashion it so as to balance the vital, but potentially destructive principle of the autonomous individual in full pursuit of his or her own interests.
It is its dangers that now threaten us, caught as we are in a seemingly visionless society, a leaderless polity, and a faltering, uncoordinated economy. These become structural flaws only if unchecked.
What is required may already have been given some three and a half centuries ago by Thomas Hooker: "There must of necessity be a mutuall ingagement, each of the other . . . they should first freely ingage in such covenants, and then be carefull to fullfill such duties." This may not be all we need to know, but it is what we all must do.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC REPORTS ARE GIVING SIGNALS OF A QUICKER PACE

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
The path of economic recovery brightened today as the Government reported that retail sales rose nine-tenths of 1 percent last month and pollsters at the University of Michigan found consumer confidence soaring in the first half of November.
Combined with yet another decline in first-time jobless claims that was reported Thursday, today's findings raised hopes among many economists that the exceptionally sluggish business recovery may finally be gaining some momentum. 
 "This forced us to sit down and look at the models again," Raymond A. Warseck, chief economist for A. G. Edwards in St. Louis, said of today's retail data, which showed a fourth straight monthly gain and the biggest since July.
 
Faster Growth Is Seen
 One result was to raise by one-half point, to 4 percent, the firm's estimate of the pace of economic growth for the second quarter of 1993.
Tracy Mullin, an official of the National Retail Federation, called the figures evidence of "a sense of optimism and hope among the buying public" that bodes well for the holiday season.
Consumer optimism might also be seen in early November's auto sales, which were up 21.6 percent. [Page 35.] Still another report today found inflation at the consumer level rose four-tenths of 1 percent in October, a bigger-than-expected increase but one that most analysts dismissed as an aberration. [Page 43.]
Earlier in the week, the Labor Department said that prices received by producers in October declined slightly for goods at the intermediate and crude stages of production and that there was a decline for finished goods when the erratic food and energy components were excluded.
 
An Increase in Optimism
 The University of Michigan does not discuss current results of its proprietary consumer-confidence survey, but Wall Street subscribers said the survey's overall confidence index jumped to 83.6 in the first half of November from 73.3 at the end of October. Readings for expectations and for current conditions rose similarly, to 75.1 and 96.7, respectively, these sources said.
The overall index has regained all the loss of confidence registered since mid-1991, according to analysts at C. J. Lawrence.
One reason for the upsurge in confidence was said to be the Nov. 3 election, which presumably encouraged those who supported Gov. Bill Clinton while removing uncertainty, at least, for those who did not.
Officials at the university's Survey Research Center could not be reached late today to respond to inquiries on whether election questions were posed or whether tabulations were made of responses volunteered on the subject.
This week's upbeat news followed much anecdotal information of a business pickup during the last month or so. Among these, contributing to what Mr. Warseck called a mood shift, were increased traffic in auto showrooms and at model homes and people reporting unusual difficulty in getting taxis.
In late October, the Commerce Department reported that total national output for the July-September quarter climbed at a 2.7 percent annual rate, nearly twice what had been expected. This gain was powered mainly by increased consumer spending, which many thought unsustainable, but other data now suggest that the long period of retrenching by consumers may be on the wane.
Still, some indicators, including the October jobs report, have been lackluster, and even the more optimistic of economists said today that there were some regions, California being a prominent example, where business continued to worsen and others where conditions remained flat.
Although retail sales were thought to have benefited from the continued cleanup from Hurricane Andrew, the October gains were nonetheless considered solid. In addition, September's increase was revised upward to five-tenths of 1 percent and August now shows a tiny gain of one-tenth of 1 percent instead of no change.
"October started off the quarter pretty well," observed Kathryn Eickhoff, president of Eickhoff Economics, a consulting firm. She said she was particularly encouraged that furniture sales continued to rise.
Ms. Eickhoff also said that while incomes had been growing slowly, the steady decline in first-time jobless claims, to below 400,000, put them at a level associated historically with significant economic growth.
The Commerce Department's report on sales, considered a good indicator of current conditions even though revisions are often sizable, showed durable goods rising 1.7 percent and nondurables rising four-tenths of 1 percent.
Excluding the automotive sector, which Detroit reports every 10 days and thus comes as little surprise, retail sales rose four-tenths of 1 percent in both October and September.
Among durables, sales rose 2.9 percent at automotive dealers; 2 percent for merchants selling furniture, home furnishings and equipment, and seven-tenths of 1 percent for dealers in building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes.
For nondurables, which accounted for $103.4 billion of the $163.3 billion total, the gains were nine-tenths of 1 percent for general merchandise stores; 1 percent for food stores; 1.4 percent for apparel and accessory stores, and three-tenths of 1 percent for gasoline service stations.
Restaurants and bars, however, posted a decline of four-tenths of 1 percent while sales at drug and proprietary stores fell eight-tenths of 1 percent.
Michael P. Niemira, an economist at Mitsubishi Bank, observed in a recent market letter that nondurables had been much slower to rebound than durables. Today's report showed durables up 8.1 percent in the last 12 months while nondurables rose only 4.3 percent.
Mr. Niemira also pointed to a divergence within nondurables as general merchandise, apparel and gasoline have bounced back while food-related sales -- grocery stores, bars and restaurants -- have been weakening for three years.

HEADLINE: The Latest Party Zone

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER

 BODY:
It was time for another drink on the Upper East Side, which for Ronald Then involved pressing his lips against a sloped, two-foot slab of ice as two flavors of liquor, in this case tequila and Jagermeister, sloshed into his mouth. This is called a slalom shot. Mr. Then, a 22-year-old student from Washington Heights, said it was one of many reasons he traveled south to drink.
"When we go out drinking, we go for broke," he said after wiping his mouth dry at the Ski Bar, a popular club at Second Avenue and 94th Street with an Alpine motif and the nothing-can-be-this-fun feel of a beer commercial. "There is no limit to it. It's until you pass out." 
 People who live and drink on the Upper East Side describe the night life there as something distinct in this city of 4,875 places to have a beer. What they mean is that the opening of 25 new bars in the last few years has turned the area between 76th and 96th Streets, York to Third Avenue, into something of a party zone just one remove from a college dormitory.
The bars, each with themes and drink giveaways more reminiscent of campuses than cities, cater not only to an increasing number of young people in the neighborhood, but also to more young drinkers from around the city and the region. All of which has led residents of the staid Upper East Side to complain, though less frequently of late, that patrons are noisy and inconsiderate and urinate on the sidewalks.
Though similar to the crowd on the Upper West Side -- suburban, professional and white -- the East Side crowd is younger and less genteel, with no pretensions to hipness and a perhaps commendable lack of irony. There also appears to be a youthful determination, unhaunted by hangovers, to drink and get drunk (or else get a few telephone numbers).
"It is a mixture between preppies, like a preppie-yuppie mixture, and your hoods," said Robert Ryder, 21, a college student whose lacrosse jacket and oxford shirt placed him somewhere along the preppie-yuppie continuum. The difference, Mr. Ryder suggested, is that his type did not vote for Bill Clinton, and the rest "aren't out to make a good life for themselves."
Despite Mr. Ryder's observations, three recent nights of barhopping along the Upper East Side uncovered few major rifts between someone like Mr. Then, who commutes to drink, and Mr. Ryder, who lives there. If anything, bar patrons on the Upper East Side are more self-admittedly homogeneous than anywhere else.
"I like these bars because it's a young Republican crowd, which is what I like because that is what I am," said Jerry Miller, a 26-year-old investment banker, as he nursed a beer in Spanky's, a narrow sports bar on First Avenue and 75th Street.
Sondra Stallard, a 25-year-old account executive, complained that the Upper East Side, while safe and cheap, is almost exactly like college -- except that you do not see the same people every night. Which does not matter, because most everyone looks alike, either in Wall Street suits or crew-neck sweaters.
"They have this, like, polish," Ms. Stallard said in the Clubhouse, a popular bar with a fraternity-house atmosphere on York Avenue between 83d and 84th Streets. "They always shine. They are always so freshly showered." But this homogeneity carries an advantage: it provides a natural pick-up atmosphere in an area buzzing with pickup lines, which women said recently fell along the lines of "Who will you vote for?" and "Where are you from?"
"They act like they know you," said Kathy Scales, 22, from Woodstock, N.Y., who has lived in the city for three months. "They say, 'Didn't I go to college with you?' "
 
A Whiff of Notoriety
 There is, of course, not too much new about a lot of young people drinking a lot on the Upper East Side. In fact, the area has carried a whiff of notoriety at least since 1986, when Jennifer Levin, 18, was strangled in Central Park by Robert E. Chambers Jr. after the two met in Dorrian's Red Hand.
It is difficult to tell whether attitudes toward drinking have changed much since then, a time when the city, from financial markets to bars, seemed to be teetering on the edge of excess. Sam O'Connor, head of the East Side Bar Owners Association, said that young people seem to be drinking less these days, partly because of health, partly because of the recession and partly because of concern for their jobs.
"People can't go out because it affects their performance at work," said Mr. O'Connor, owner of Avalon, a bar at Second Avenue and 85th Street. "People don't write things off the way they used to. Remember the old martini lunch? That just doesn't exist anymore."
A bouncer at Spanky's said that the bar averages only about $4.50 per person a night when the total should be closer to $8.
But there is plenty of evidence that drinking is alive and well, especially among those right out of college.
"They are between the ages of 21 and 23," said Doug Torres, the manager of Name This Joint, on Third Avenue and 92d Street, "and they are working at their jobs during the week and they don't get paid very much. So on a Friday and Saturday they want to take what little they make and get as hammered as possible."
One woman, a 23-year-old Wall Street analyst, estimated how much she drinks each night out, two or three times a week. "Let's see, three beers, three bars; probably nine drinks," she said at Name This Joint as a waitress passed with a tray of Jell-O shots. "That's beer. Nobody drinks liquor."
 
Residents Complain
 Beer, liquor or slalom shots, the amount of alcohol consumed has an effect on behavior, and residents have complained that the behavior has been atrocious. At the Mill, a bar on York Avenue, residents pelted patrons with eggs on the street earlier this year to stop the noise and rowdiness.
"I do think young people today are rowdier," said Richard Murphy, the owner of the Clubhouse and the president of the Manhattan Restaurant Association. "I just think they are louder. And I don't think they are as respectful of other people's rights as young people were 10 or 20 years ago.
"This puts an extra responsibility on the bar owners and the staff of the places to work harder at educating about the rights of people in these neighborhoods," he said.
The situation got so bad that local politicians sat down with bar owners and demanded changes. More bars now have bouncers to stop under-age drinking and to police the sidewalks, there are signs in bars pleading for responsibility, and bar owners say they keep a closer eye on their customers.
These changes have apparently had an effect. State Assemblyman John Ravitz, Republican from the 66th District, said that since early summer, complaints from residents have trailed off dramatically.
One person who has not noticed a change, however, is J. R. Clay, a 49-year-old homeless man who panhandles in front of the Outback on Third Avenue. He complains that the young drinkers are loud and rude, much more than when he was growing up in Harlem, and occasionally try to humiliate him because he lives on the streets. But like the bar owners, he depends on them.
"I haven't eaten yet," he said, shortly after 11 P.M. on a recent Friday. "I have to wait until they get drunk."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The economic recovery appears to be gathering momentum. Retail sales rose 0.9 percent in October, and a University of Michigan survey found consumer confidence soaring in the first half of November. The findings raised hopes that the sluggish business recovery may finally be gaining strength. [Page 1.]
Sales of U.S.-built vehicles rose 21.6 percent in early November, with light trucks accounting for most of the increase. Car sales rose 7.9 percent, while light trucks advanced 44.6 percent. [35.] 
 Consumer prices rose 0.4 percent in October, an increase suggesting that some inflationary pressures exist. The increase was the largest since a rise of 0.5 percent in March. [43.]
 
 International
Fujitsu of Japan has arranged its first supercomputer sale in North America since re-entering the market. The machine is being purchased by a nonprofit Canadian consortium. [35.]
 
Companies
Humana plans to stop paying dividends next year, and investors rushed to sell their shares in the hospital and managed-health-care company. Humana shares plunged $4, to close at $19.875, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. [37.]
Hughes Aircraft appointed heads of two new overseas ventures charged with developing more foreign business. Hughes is seeking to broaden its customer list as military budgets decline. [37.]
Honda and Mazda reported sharply lower profits for the first half of the fiscal year. Honda's net income slumped 7 percent while Mazda's earnings plunged 85 percent. [37.]
Earnings at Berkshire Hathaway dropped nearly 60 percent, mainly because of insurance losses from Hurricane Andrew. Berkshire is headed by the noted investor Warren E. Buffett. [37.]
First New York Bank for Business was closed by banking regulators, and its deposits were sold to First Merchants Bank. The bank was founded in 1975 as First Women's Bank. [37.]
Los Alamos National Lab will develop a computer program to simulate chemical reactions in a refinery. [37.]
 
Markets
Blue-chip stocks fell modestly although technology companies and other smaller issues showed strength. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 6.76 points to close at 3,233.03. [36.]
Bond prices fell on the reports of stronger economic trends. Short-term Treasury bills were especially depressed. [43.]
Coffee futures prices surged to a seven-month high as worries about tightening supplies from South America intensified. [44.] The dollar was generally lower as interest rates declined abroad. [44.]
 
 Your Money
Valuables and documents may be difficult to locate when someone dies. A property inventory is an essential adjunct to a will, and without it, heirs may face large expenses and great frustrations in searching out the assets of a testator. [33.]
The Made in the U.S.A. fund appeals to investors' patriotism. But the company that is marketing the new mutual fund has been indicted for its handling of customers' money, and the fund's guidelines are vague about its standards for buying stocks. [33.]
It may be time to repay loans borrowed against life insurance policies. The interest is no longer tax deductible, and the returns from other investments are no longer attractive. [34.]

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: The Old Team;
President's Economic Stewards Defend Reputations and Actions

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
For the Bush Administration's economic stewards, these are trying times. Everyone knows the bad economy sank President Bush, and a lot of people are pointing fingers at those who steered the economic ship.
With their reputations on the line, the men who argued and fought over the economic policies of the last four years are now fighting for the white hats in the history books. 
 Last month, several articles in The Washington Post described a gallant struggle by Mr. Bush's director of the Office of Management and Budget, Richard G. Darman, to slay the deficit dragon and steer the nation clear of recession. The articles, relying heavily on statements from the budget director, were widely viewed here as Mr. Darman's parting shots at his colleagues.
On Thursday, the chairman of Mr. Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, Michael J. Boskin, took his turn, in his earnest, polite way. Without throwing any hatchets, he took to the morning talk shows to give his reading on the economy and to show that he had not been sitting on his hands when the economy fizzled.
With conservatives snapping that Mr. Bush's advisers should have been more aggressive about reviving the economy, Mr. Boskin explained that late last year he pushed for an economic stimulus package that included tax cuts as well as future spending cuts to reduce the deficit. The hope was this would pep up the economy in time for the Presidential campaign.
Appearing on the NBC program "Today," Mr. Boskin noted that the stimulus package he favored was somewhat larger than the one President Bush proposed last January.
"I think it would have been desirable to be more aggressive, but, you know, hindsight is seductive," he said. "It doesn't do anybody any good to go back and look at what might have been."
In interviews, other Administration officials said Mr. Boskin's call for stepped-up stimulus had been blocked because other policy makers had worried that it would increase the deficit, frighten financial markets and get mangled by the Democrats in Congress.
Congress did not approve the President's stimulus package, which called for tax credits for first-time home buyers and cuts in the capital gains tax. Mr. Boskin said the package "would have helped the economy grow more rapidly this year and create about a half million more jobs."
Some officials say Mr. Boskin failed to persuade the President to embrace a more ambitious package largely because he, Mr. Boskin, had been eclipsed in power by Mr. Darman, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and the former White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu.
Like the Administration's other economic policy makers, Mr. Boskin is eager to tell the world that he is not responsible for the nation's economic woes, or, if that does not work, at least argue that the economy was not as sick as many Americans think.
"The economy has been growing for a year and a half, starting in the spring of 1991, but too slowly to make any of us happy," he said on "Today." "But things are not nearly as poor as the campaign rhetoric and political hyperbole would suggest."
In recent speeches, Mr. Boskin has asserted that the economy had performed much better under President Bush than under President Jimmy Carter, when unemployment was higher, inflation was soaring to more than 10 percent and interest rates were rising to more than 20 percent. But many economists quarrel with this assertion, noting that growth under Mr. Bush has averaged less than 1 percent a year, the slowest rate under any President since Herbert Hoover.
 
Events Beyond Control
 Trying to put a favorable gloss on Mr. Bush's -- and his own -- economic stewardship, Mr. Boskin said that both inflation and interest rates were low and that "we're more internationally competitive than we've been in a long time."
Mr. Boskin blamed the economy's problems not on policy making but on events beyond bureaucratic control: overbuilding of commercial real estate, cuts in the military budget, banks' reluctance to lend, the huge amount of consumer debt developed in the 1980's and Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
President-elect Bill Clinton has not asked him for economic advice, Mr. Boskin said, nor has Mr. Boskin proffered any. But he added that he had told other lawmakers that a fiscal stimulus might be desirable if the economic recovery falters.
"If it looks like the economy is going to badly stall out and head back down to 1 percent or less for a protracted period of time, and unemployment is projected to rise rather than decline, then I think tying tax incentives and cuts in the short term with simultaneously enacted future larger spending cuts would be good," Mr. Boskin said.
In his view, this would provide some quick stimulus and allay the fear of financial markets that politicians were being irresponsible about the deficit.
"I think President Bush has done a remarkable job in difficult times, difficult situations, and history will treat him more kindly than the current discourse is, including on the economy," he said.
Seeking to rebut accusations that the Administration was out of touch on the economy, Mr. Boskin said he was the first head of the Council of Economic Advisers to predict a recession, even before the Commerce Department did. The department forecasts economic activity six to nine months down the road.
In a recent speech, he also said that his office had predicted exactly when the recovery would begin and that it had been more accurate in its forecasts than most private economists.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Health Plan Dips Into Unemployment Fund

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
With a Nov. 30 deadline bearing down on them, Republican legislators and Gov. Jim Florio have been unable to agree on how to restore New Jersey's system for financing health care for indigent patients.
If the Legislature and the Governor fail to act this month, hospital care for about 800,000 people will be jeopardized and millions of dollars in bad debts will create huge problems for hospitals across the state, threatening the survival of some. 
 The Republicans have proposed to use some of the state's $3 billion Unemployment Insurance Trust Fund, about $450 million, to finance health care.
"This is what is on the table now," said Senator C. Louis Bassano, a Republican from Union and the sponsor of the bill. "Unless the Governor has a different program, this is the area and the direction that the Legislature has gone in.
 
Florio May Have to Tap Fund
 "It's up to the Governor now. If he does not support the program that we are putting forth, I certainly want to know what his plans are, and we will await his plans."
Mr. Florio, a Democrat, may be forced to accept the use of the unemployment fund, which is based on taxes paid by employers and employees and which finances unemployment compensation, because it is the least onerous of the approaches he and the Legislature have considered in the six months since a Federal judge invalidated the state's 12-year-old health-care system for the poor.
Other proposals have included a payroll tax, an increase in the state income tax, an increase in "sin taxes" on tobacco, beer and liquor or raising the sales tax to 7 percent. Just four months ago it was rolled back to 6 percent.
"The Governor has not spoken out publicly on any plan," said Brenda Bacon, Mr. Florio's chief policy adviser on health care. "What he has been saying for three years is that what we are doing now is horrible."
 
System Thrown Into Chaos
 The existing system, the Uncompensated Care Trust Fund, financed health care for about 800,000 indigent patients through a 19.1 percent surcharge that has been added to the hospital bills of insured patients.
The system was thrown into chaos May 27 when Judge Alfred M. Wolin of Federal District Court in Newark, acting on a lawsuit brought by 14 unions, barred the state from imposing the surcharges on self-insured group health plans, which cover 40 percent of insured patients.
An additional 40 percent of insured patients are covered by Medicare, and they were not required to pay the surcharge. So the remaining 20 percent of insured patients in New Jersey, most of them individual policyholders, will have to pick up the $900 million annual bill for indigent care unless another system is approved.
Judge Wolin gave the Legislature and the Governor until the end of June to work out a new plan. But New Jersey officials bought extra time by appealing to the Federal Third Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia. The appellate court has not indicated when it will rule, but state officials have committed themselves to replacing the system by Nov. 30.
 
Talks Nearly Break Down
 The rush to do so has created unusual cooperation between the Legislature and the Governor. But a senior state official who has been involved in the negotiations said Mr. Florio balked at the plan to use unemployment funds, and when the Republicans refused to back down it nearly caused the talks to collapse.
"It is the only thing the Republicans have put on the table, the only thing they will discuss," the aide said.
The same official said Mr. Florio had softened his stance a bit and might be willing to support the plan if the Republicans agree to a clause that would increase the payroll tax if the fund shrunk to a certain level.
"We had to make a practical decision," said the aide, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "Either we do nothing and let the state health system slip into chaos or we try to make the best we can of the Republican plan."
Mr. Bassano, who is chairman of the Senate Health Committee, said today that he could introduce his financing bill as early as Monday. But he said that the Republicans would take no action unless Mr. Florio spoke out in favor of the legislation.
Mr. Bassano's bill is part of a package of health and hospital reform measures in the Legislature. Another bill, approved this week by health committees of both the Assembly and the Senate, would require private insurers to enroll all applicants or subsidize any losses suffered by Blue Cross and Blue Shield in providing such policies. This "open enrollment" plan would bar insurance companies from using age, sex or geography in establishing fees.
Under Mr. Bassano's financing proposal, $450 million a year would be diverted from the unemployment fund to finance indigent health care.
Proponents of the plan argue that New Jersey has one of the nation's healthiest unemployment trust funds. On July 1, the beginning of the state's fiscal year, the main reserve stood at $2.4 billion and a second fund had a balance of $400 million.
 
Saving Unemployment Fund
 But critics of Mr. Bassano's bill, including some within the administration, point to a sluggish economy and one of the highest unemployment rates in the nation as reason for worry. "The Governor is quite concerned that we do nothing to violate the solvency of the fund," Ms. Bacon said.
Projections show that the state will take in $1.2 billion in payroll taxes this year, Ms. Bacon said, but will pay out $1.4 billion in unemployment benefits, reducing the unemployment trust fund by $200 million.
Even with serious reservations about the Bassano plan, Mr. Florio might be locked into accepting it. Facing re-election next year, Mr. Florio may be extremely reluctant to be seen as advocating a tax increase.
The Governor incensed voters during his first year in office by pushing through a record $2.8 billion tax increase. The Republicans used it as a club in the 1991 elections, in which they won majorities in both houses of the Legislature.
 
Tax Rise Seen as Inevitable
 But avoiding taxes may not be easy. "No matter what three letters you come up with, the solution is going to spell tax," said Ronald Czajkowski, a spokesman for the New Jersey Hospital Association, which has lobbied for restoring the 7 percent sales tax. "It's just a matter of what's going to be most politically palatable.
"We are not proposing a new tax. What we are doing is take a regressive 19 percent tax, the surcharge on sick people, and coming up with a new tax basis."
But the Assembly Speaker, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, one of the leaders of the Republican fight nine months ago to roll the sales tax back to 6 percent, called an increase "the area of last resort."
"I have always said I would find it difficult in my caucus to get 41 votes," Mr. Haytaian said, "and I'm sure the Democrats would find it difficult to give any votes for a tax increase."

HEADLINE: European Community Finds Its Unity Plans Under Threat

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Nov. 13

 BODY:
A month before a summit meeting of the European Community that is intended to set the stage for ambitious expansion, the goal of economic and political unity among the existing 12 members seems farther away than it was a year ago.
Weaknesses of political leadership in France, Britain and Germany, and economic problems in all the major countries, are to blame for the malaise, in the view of many experts. 
 German business leaders have been openly denouncing French "chauvinism" for allegedly bringing Europe to the brink of a trade war with the United States, and German officials have been urging their counterparts in Paris to give in before the dispute plunges the world into depression.
Germany and France were united in expressing dismay at the surprise decision last week by the British Prime Minister, John Major, to put off a parliamentary vote on ratification of the treaty on European political and monetary union until after Denmark has had a second referendum on the accord. Danish voters rejected it narrowly last June, and their Government has demanded modifications before it submits the treaty to another popular vote next year.
A summit meeting planned in Edinburgh on Dec. 11 and 12 is expected to formally back reassurances by all the community leaders that the treaty does not mean that member countries will lose their sovereign national identities in a federal European melting pot. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany consulted with Mr. Major outside Oxford on Wednesday to prepare for that meeting, as well as to talk about the prospects of breaking the American-European impasse over trade.
 
Trade Prospects Improve
 These prospects have improved in the last few days, after public pressure by the Germans on the French to resume talks next week. The United States has threatened $300 million worth of trade sanctions on European exports if no compromise is reached.
The fate of the European union treaty, signed at Maastricht, the Netherlands, last December, is less clear. It was to go into effect on Jan. 1, but it cannot until all 12 nations have ratified it. The British and Danish delays are therefore expected to mean that negotiations on admitting Austria, Sweden and Finland, which have already applied to join the community, cannot begin as planned in January.
Switzerland may soon decide to apply, and Norway is expected to after a convention of its governing Labor Party decided narrowly in favor over the weekend. Poland, Hungary and both parts of Czechoslovakia would also like to begin preliminary negotiations on joining.
Until Britain's economic problems dragged him into conflict with his European Community partners, Mr. Major had said expansion would be one of the major goals of Britain's six-month community presidency, which expires at the end of the year.
 
Major Survives Narrowly
 But an anti-European rebellion in his Conservative Party nearly led to the Government's defeat in a preliminary parliamentary vote on the treaty last week. Mr. Major prevailed by a three-vote majority, but only by the grace of the opposition Liberal Democrats.
Over the weekend, President Francois Mitterrand of France said it was "unacceptable" for Britain to delay ratification, and on Tuesday Mr. Major said in Parliament that the action was none of Mr. Mitterrand's business. French officials have suggested that Mr. Major had been forced by domestic opposition to the treaty to hide behind the skirts of the Danes.
After consulting the main opposition parties last week, the Danish Prime Minister, Poul Schluter, said an agreement would have to leave Denmark out of any common European defense policy as well as a single currency, which now seems less likely than ever to come into effect by the end of the decade, as foreseen in the treaty. Denmark also wanted nothing to do with "supranational police cooperation," a euphemism for letting the German police pursue suspects across the border.
Initial reactions from the French and even some Germans indicated that these demands were unacceptable. "We haven't yet made up our minds," the German Foreign Minister, Klaus Kinkel, said the other day.
 
Major Is Hopeful
 Mr. Major, reeling from a stunning series of domestic political gaffes and economic setbacks, said after his talks with Mr. Kohl on Wednesday that they had agreed that a settlement on the trade negotiations was within reach.
"I think that is vital," the Prime Minister said. "What the world economic situation calls for at present is calm discussion and not saber-rattling."

HEADLINE: Delors Has Become the Odd Man Out in Europe

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Nov. 10

 BODY:
It has been a very bad year for Jacques Delors, the president of the European Commission, the executive body of the European Community. Lauded until recently as the man who galvanized Europe and put flesh on the frail outline of European integration, he has now become the squinting symbol of Europe's disarray, a focus of criticism, insult and ridicule.
"Delors equals chauvinism, protectionism and selfishness," Michael Fuchs, the president of the German Foreign Trade association, proclaimed this week. "We don't need another Sun King in Brussels. Once in Paris was enough." 
 Mr. Fuchs, angered by what he sees as Mr. Delors's role in blocking a world trade deal with the United States, was comparing the 67-year-old former Finance Minister of France to the vainglorious monarch Louis XIV (who actually ruled from Versailles).
 
 
Series of Attacks
 The unlikely comparison -- Mr. Delors is a Roman Catholic Socialist with a strong social conscience who lives modestly in a Brussels apartment -- was only the latest in a series of sharp attacks on the commission president. These have recently cast Mr. Delors in the roles of master bureaucrat enmeshing Europeans in a web of regulations, hapless chief executive disavowed by his senior colleagues and devious champion of France masquerading as a disinterested "Mr. Europe."
In the space of a few months, Europe's hero of recent years has thus been undone. He is now a much-questioned figure, just as his major achievement -- the Continent's frontierless market -- is about to come into effect in January. Lingering recession, the Danish rejection of the Maastricht treaty of European unity, and the monetary chaos of September that led Italy and Britain to withdraw their currencies from the Exchange Rate Mechanism of the European monetary system have all undermined Mr. Delors.
"In part, he is just the most convenient scapegoat for Europe's current problems," Nicolaas Wegter, a community spokesman, said.
 
 
Danger for Europe

But as Mr. Delors prepares to embark next year on a final two-year term as commission president, the danger is that Europe could find itself with a lame-duck leadership at a time of critical change and that Mr. Delors will be lastingly diminished by recent setbacks and insinuations.
Mr. Delors declined to comment. But his spokesman, Bruno Dethomas, rejected the criticism. "Mr. Delors is not divided between France and Europe; he always has the interests of the European Community at heart," he said. "Not for one second has he thought about resigning because his conduct has been irreproachable."
There are several reasons for the abrupt reversal of Mr. Delors's fortunes after years in which his dynamic leadership of European integration led to frequent comparisons between him and the chief instigator of the idea of the European Community, Jean Monnet of France.
As a Frenchman -- and one with thinly disguised ambitions to succeed President Francois Mitterrand when his term ends in 1995 -- Mr. Delors's role in the current trade talks held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade has been widely questioned. Some believe he has the interests of the politically powerful French farmers closer to his heart than he should.
These insinuations reached a crucial point recently when the community's Agriculture Commissioner, Ray MacSharry of Ireland, said he was dropping out of the GATT negotiations because Mr. Delors had undermined him. His decision came after another Commissioner, Frans Andriessen of the Netherlands, had openly criticized Mr. Delors's approach to the GATT talks.
Such squabbling among commissioners amounted to an extraordinary event in Brussels, and Mr. Delors has clearly been striving to paper over the differences. He coaxed Mr. MacSharry back to the negotiating team, and has suddenly expressed a new enthusiasm for, and optimism over, the GATT talks.
Still, it remains unclear whether he has regained the respect of the college of 17 commissioners he is supposed to direct until the end of 1994.
 
 
'Tenacious and Determined'
 "He is in the midst of a very difficult moment -- with the United States and with his European Community partners," Francois Hollande, a French Socialist who is close to Mr. Delors, said. "But if he's clearly preoccupied, he is also tenacious and determined."
Tenacity has indeed characterized Mr. Delors's work. As French Finance Minister in 1981, he pushed through a series of nationalizations of industry requested by President Mitterrand. When they proved disastrous, he persuaded the President to reverse course and left a relatively strong economy when he moved to Brussels in 1985.
Arriving at the commission, he refused to be daunted by inertia and setbacks, giving extraordinary new momentum to the European idea by setting the 1992 target of a "Europe without frontiers."
It seems clear, however, that Mr. Delors is in the midst of a period of uncharacteristic uncertainty. A passionate believer in the European idea, he has abruptly had to face the fact this year that a federal Europe with a single currency is not an idea that galvanizes many people at a time when European integration seems only to bring recession.
Dedicated to the notion that Europe's brand of socialism affords the best balance between a dynamic market and a social safety net, he has to come to terms this year with the rise of racist and far-right movements throughout Europe.
All this has taken a toll. He has been thin-skinned on several recent occasions, dismissing opponents of the Maastricht treaty in France as "having no place in a sophisticated democratic society" and attacking those who now contend that a bureaucracy in Brussels is about to take over Europe.
Moreover, he clearly has half an eye on France. Last month he founded a group within the Socialist Party knows as Temoin (witness), with a view to developing ideas on the renewal of the party. This event was described by the leading newspaper Le Monde as "the return of the Delors satellite from its European orbit to the French political stratosphere."
Mr. Hollande, who heads Temoin, said: "Mr. Delors does not exclude any possibility, and many people, including myself, hope this group will have an active political role supporting him. Obviously, with his Europeans mandate ending in 1994, he is beginning to apply himself more to French politics."
Whether Europe holds Mr. Delors's attention, and whether he can apply leadership, will probably be decided in the next six months. If the Maastricht treaty is ratified, the GATT impasse resolved and monetary stability recovered, analysts believe Mr. Delors will once more push vigorously for the federal Europe of which he dreams.
But if Denmark or Britain reject Maastricht, and other problems fester, he may feel his contribution to Europe has been made.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Earnings Are Down at Honda and Mazda

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 13

 BODY:
The Honda Motor Company and the Mazda Motor Corporation today joined the lengthening line of Japanese car makers reporting sharply lower profits.
Both said weak demand and the strong yen took big bites out of profits in the six months through the end of September. The fiscal year's second half does not look any better.
"The recovery in domestic sales will be slow and difficult, and the situation in the United States is similar," a senior Honda official said. "The upturn in new car sales may not come until the second half of next year."
Honda's parent-company net profit slumped 7 percent to 15.17 billion yen, or $123 million, from the comparable period a year earlier. Consolidated, or group, net -- which includes results from all the company's holdings -- plunged 39 percent, to 26.36 billion yen, or $214 million.
But those results were far better than the 85 percent dive in Mazda's parent net profit to 621 million yen, or $5.04 million.
Still, Honda and Mazda have avoided the fate of the Nissan Motor Company and Fuji Heavy Industries, maker of Subaru cars, both of which reported six-month net losses this month.
The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation also announced lower six-month profits this month.
Japan's once unbeatable auto makers have struggled as sales fell along with the economy. Vehicle demand fell 7.3 percent in the six months through September, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said recently.
Honda and Mazda have not escaped, with domestic factory sales of cars slipping 13 and 10 percent, respectively.
The yen's advance against the dollar also weighed them down. Honda expected an exchange rate of 130 yen to the dollar in the half just ended. The rate turned out to be 126.65 yen. Each 1 yen difference shifts group results by about 3 billion yen, or $24.3 million, a Honda official said, adding that the auto maker was expecting a rate of 125 yen in the current fiscal half.
Both companies have been struggling to streamline production and cut costs.
Mazda decided last month to scrap plans for a second sales network in the United States to market luxury cars and for two new luxury sedans aimed at the American market. It also decided to pull out of sports car races, including the Le Mans 24-hour endurance race in France.
Honda quit Formula One motor racing, in which its engines have been a dominant force for a decade, although it insisted the move was unrelated to the business slump.
One bright spot for Honda was motorcycles, whose combined domestic and export sales edged up 7 percent. Honda is the world's top maker of motorcycles.

HEADLINE: Struggle to Get Biggest Corn Crop In

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO. Nov. 13

 BODY:
From Nebraska to Ohio, farmers are battling drenching rains, high winds, early snowstorms and the effects of harvesting late in the season to bring in their largest corn crop in history.
"I've only had four days in the field this month," said Bob Johnson this morning after surveying the third blanket of snow his family's farm near De Kalb, Ill., has received in the last month. 
When snow has not stilled his combines, mud has.
To Mr. Johnson's west, at least some part of Iowa has received snow or rain every day since Oct. 31. Much of Ohio was hit by rains and winds last night, which will bring new delays.
Despite the obstacles and the fact that only 50 percent of the crop is in, farmers and the businesses that depend on them are predicting that almost all of the corn will eventually be gathered. The prospects of a bumper crop have already driven prices down to their lowest point since the mid-80's. Corn, much of which is used as animal feed, is the nation's single largest crop.
The record harvest should lead to plentiful and inexpensive supplies of meat through next year. Lower prices should also expand American exports and benefit processing firms that convert corn into everything from ethanol fuel to the raw materials for breakfast cereals, snacks, beer and soft drinks. And although converted corn is a small part of the final cost of such consumer products, economists say that the bountiful harvest should help hold down the prices of these goods as well.
But the huge corn crop, occurring in a year when farmers have also produced record yields per acre in spring wheat, sorghum, barley, oats and soybeans, may end up costing the Government hundreds of millions of dollars more than it had projected in farm subsidies.
The bounty sends a strong reminder to European trade negotiators that the United States is the world's low-cost producer of agricultural goods and may nudge them toward a compromise on the issue of subsidies, which has stalled efforts to reach a new international free trade agreement.
This year's large American harvest may lead as well to pressure for a re-examination of United States domestic policies. The policies are governed by a law that runs through 1995. "We can't wait until then to reopen it," referring to the law, said Representative Dan Glickman, the Kansas Democrat who heads the House Subcommittee on Wheat, Soybeans and Feed Grain. "I think we are headed into a new cycle of bumper crops that will require much more flexibility than we have now if we are going to avoid big deficiency payments."
The current corn policies require farmers to set aside a portion of their land to qualify for a subsidy that protects them against low prices when there are oversupplies. Farmers argue that keeping the subsidies but eliminating the set-asides would stimulate the entire agribusiness sector and increase pressure on higher-cost producers oversees.
 
Strange Weather Year
 The size of the corn crop reflects improvement in the plants themselves through selective breeding and freakish weather. Farmers say they cannot recall another year in which a dry spring, relieved just in time by rainfall, was then followed by such a cool and rainy July and August. This lead to a huge but late-maturing crop.
"You have to expect bad weather harvesting this late," said Mr. Johnson, whose family raises corn, soybeans and pigs. "Harvesting in November is like what a commuter faces driving to work through the first snowstorm of the year. You get it done but it's more dangerous because no one's really prepared and you end up grumpy and less productive."
Much of the resulting crop tended to produce somewhat lower-quality corn ears as measured by weight, but on the other hand the rains washed the corn borers away before they could cause internal damage. The rains resumed in late October.
Keith Bowden, a farmer in Williams, Iowa, said that he finished Saturday, later than normal. "Anything after the first of November makes me nervous, but I tend to be aggressive about this," he said. "I have neighbors who are still out there although this area is ahead of many others." Most farmers grow several different crops and the timing of their corn harvest can vary.
Mr. Bowden said his farm, about an hour north of Des Moines, had been in a pocket of relatively good weather compared with much of the state.
 
Crop Estimates Rise
 Each month since August, the Department of Agriculture and private analysts have been raising their crop estimates. This Tuesday's 3.3 billion bushel estimate from the department was an unusually sharp increase so late in the season. It briefly sent corn future prices on the Chicago Board of Trade Wednesday to a new low for the December contract of just over $2.04 a bushel.
The record output has had much less impact on prices than it would have in the mid-1980's because stockpiles are much lower and demand for corn and other grains has been rising. The Agriculture Department expects cattle, poultry and hog growers, who consume roughly two-thirds of the crop, to use 6 percent more corn as feed this year. Other domestic corn purchasers are projected to use almost 4 percent more. And exports are expected to edge up by 1 percent.
Low feed-corn prices not only reduce the costs of fattening livestock currently being prepared for slaughter but also encourage farmers to expand their herds in anticipation of growing consumer demand. In particular, low prices are seen as an incentive for countries like Japan to develop a taste for American meat. That, according to farmers, is the best way to increase demand for their crops and, eventually, raise the prices they receive.
"We have a saying there's no cure for low prices like low prices," Mr. Johnson said.
Outside of the feed-grain sector, lower corn prices have a minimal effect on consumer prices. Analysts say that corn, for example, accounts for less than 6 percent of the cost of a corn-based breakfast cereal.
"A company like Kellogg is much more impacted by advertising rates on Madison Avenue than corn prices on the farm," said John McMillin, an agriculture and food analyst for Prudential Bache Securities in New York..
Government price supports should help most corn farmers prosper despite lower market prices this year. About 75 percent of all corn farmers participate in the support program, which is linked to historic yields per acre. The record yields actually achieved may reduce the percentage of total production covered to as little as 60 percent in some areas, according to the National Farmers Organization.
The support level has not been fixed yet. The payment is a complex calculation based on the difference between the $2.75-a-bushel target price and the average market price in the five months from Sept. 1.
 
U.S. Bill Could Rise
 Agricultural economists are currently estimating that the support subsidy will end up between 55 cents and 75 cents a bushel. At the lower end of that range, the Government's projected $4.2 billion expenditure on corn subsidies in the budget running through next Sept. 30 might not be far off. At the high end, the Government's bill could rise by hundreds of millions of dollars.
Although individual farmers who had low production because of hailstorms or other local problems face financial ruin, farm incomes in general should be up, according to regional bank economists.
The farmers assured of doing better than average are those who used futures contracts or similar arrangements to lock in the price for a large percentage of their crops earlier this year. But the vast majority of farmers have been reluctant to use such techniques. They will have to hope that prices rise significantly next year to make the most of the huge corn crop.

HEADLINE: Salvation Army Learns Some Past Donors Are Needy Themselves

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
The Salvation Army, for the first time in memory, faces the holiday season unsure that it will have money to send out vans with hot meals to feed New York City's street people through the winter.
Local army groups in some areas, including New York, fear that they may not be able to raise nearly as much as the record $649 million raised by the army's 40 divisions across the country last year -- even as they confront more demands for help, including requests from people who have given money in the past. 
 The army's concerns this year go beyond the lingering economic slump. It made special appeals after natural disasters earlier this year, and it fears that people may not want to give again so soon. And like many other charities, it fears that there may be a chill on giving this year following disclosures about extravagant spending by the president of the United Way and his $465,000 salary.
"The last thing the army wants to do is cut services like feeding a thousand people a day in places such as the Bowery and the South Bronx," said Lieut. Col. Raymond L. Wood, divisional commander for the Greater New York area.
 
Letters of Regret
 The army recently sent out its seasonal appeal to past contributors, which typically brings in checks, money orders, cash and an occasional stock certificate. This year the return mail is notable for its letters of regret from loyal supporters.
A son writes for his parents, who were significant contributors, saying both are now jobless and ailing and asks, "What can you do for them?" Another writer said he was stopping his gifts because his union pension was cut in half. Another scribbled: "ill, old, alone and poor."
While the army does not discount the possibility that holiday spirit will still spur a wave of donations, it is concerned that there is a limit to what people can give.
Earlier this year, the army made a nationwide appeal for assistance for Florida residents who lost homes and businesses because of Hurricane Andrew in late August. New Yorkers, many with family or friends in the disaster area, contributed $600,000 for emergency relief.
But the help in September may create a shortage for local operations in November and December, Colonel Wood said. He estimated that collections for the year were trailing contributions at this time a year ago by at least $100,000. The army in San Francisco has a similar squeeze: donors there gave $382,000 after the California wildfires, and now the army faces soaring local needs.
 
Salaries Are Frozen
 In New York City the army is a partner in the local United Way campaign and will receive $2.7 million, a $200,000 cutback because of the shortfall in United Way fund raising in 1991. In October the New York organization froze salaries, which are already low when compared with other charitable groups. For instance, Colonel Wood and his wife, who is also an officer, receive $34,000 annually, plus a modest apartment in a building for the aged that is run by the army.
The army has ranked for decades among the 10 most successful charitable fund raisers. Nationally it was topped in 1991 only by the United Jewish Appeal, which ran a vigorous special campaign to assist emigrating Soviet Jews, according to the Chronicle on Philanthropy.
The Salvation Army began in 1865 in London and expanded to the United States in 1880. It is led here by 3,500 officers, all ministers and most from families with generations of involvement. Another 445,000 are church members, or Salvationists. The army also has 1.2 million volunteers of all faiths, and these ranks are slowly but perceptibly growing.
"There is a great American love affair with the Salvation Army," said Commissioner James Osborne, national commander of the army in the United States. "Americans do not know all the army is doing, they may not understand all about the army, but they believe whatever we're doing is to the good."
And if the mix of religious fervor, the uniforms, the marching bands and the zeal to rescue the downtrodden sometimes inspires satiric wit, the army's leaders seem unperturbed. "We're not sourpusses," the Commissioner said. "We should be able to laugh at ourselves a little."
 
Help From 'Guys and Dolls'
 The army will celebrate the opening of its Christmas fund raising on Nov. 24 in Bryant Park with musical help from the cast of "Guys and Dolls," the Broadway musical based on Damon Runyan's story about streetwise gamblers and a soul-saving missionary in Times Square.
Anticipating that fund raising will be tougher this year, some of the army's red kettles were put in place before the campaign's official start.
Last year collections from the kettles and direct-mail campaign netted the New York organization $4.4 million, helping to provide 500,000 meals and beds for 2,200 people each night in a Salvation Army shelter or residence, Colonel Wood said. The army also gives rent money to families on the verge of becoming homeless, a program that is now threatened.
The army is also one of New York City's major providers of foster care and day care for children, working under contract with the city. It also runs youth-training programs, group homes for teen-agers and the mentally retarded, residences for the elderly and projects with prison and parole agencies. The army's alcohol and drug rehabilitation programs are supported partly by selling recycled furniture and household items in thrift shops run by the army.
The army has already adopted austerity measures at the 34 community centers that it maintains in the New York area, which includes the five boroughs, Westchester County and part of the Hudson Valley.
 
Small and Symbolic
 At the army's largest center in the New York area, in Brownsville, Brooklyn, Capt. Raphael Jackson said he had eliminated bus trips for children and deliberately not filled staff positions -- turnover is high because army salaries are low. Some savings are small and symbolic: there will be no token gifts like chocolates for the staff at Christmas.
On Sundays Captain Jackson buckles on a 30-pound bass drum and walks a six-block circuit, picking up youngsters who follow him back to the center for Sunday school and luncheon. A few hours later the procession is reversed and he delivers them home, through streets where drugs are traded brazenly and violence is commonplace.
"On any day we see 500 children and they have unbelievable problems but also great potential, which will be used for good or bad," Captain Jackson said. "Our job is to guide them toward the good."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Capt. Raphael Jackson of the Salvation Army playing the drum, leading children through Brownsville, Brooklyn, to the Salvation Army building for Bible study classes, singing and storytelling. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)
