HEADLINE: Bond Prices Decline on Retail Gains

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Bond prices fell yesterday after the Government released some surprising inflation news and a separate report on retail sales that indicated the economy was gaining strength.
The new 30-year Treasury bond sold in Thursday's auction fell 5/32 percentage point. Its yield was 7.57 percent, compared with 7.59 percent Thursday. 
 Traders said short-term Treasury bills were especially depressed by the Commerce Department's report that retail sales jumped nine-tenths of 1 percent in October, the steepest rise in three months. The bills also fell briefly in reaction to Labor Department data showing a fourth-tenths of 1 percent jump in consumer prices in October.
"The short end of the market got clobbered today," Susan Talbot, senior money market analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said.
 
 
Secondary Market
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, short-term maturities fell between 9/32 point and 13/32 point, and intermediate maturities declined 17/32 point to 3/8 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value.
The economic reports gave support to speculation that the Federal Reserve would not ease interest rates further, analysts said.
The retail sales figure indicated consumer buying was picking up speed. Since consumer expenditures account for two-thirds of economic activity, that augurs well for the recovery.
Some traders dismissed the consumer price number as little more than a statistical blip, even though higher inflation generally erodes the value of bonds.
"The inflation report was not as good as expected but it was not bad enough to send the market down strongly," Michael Moran, chief economist with Daiwa Securities America Inc. in New York, said.
Economists said the inflation gain was caused by factors such as a record jump in airline fares.
Many traders were still focused on the Treasury's quarterly refunding auction, which concluded Thursday with a sale of $10.25 billion in new 30-year bonds.
Demand was brisk at that auction, meaning the Government was able to pay lower interest rates, keeping the cost of servicing the federal deficit down. The Lehman Brothers daily Treasury bond index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, was quoted at 1,247.9, off 4.46.
 
 
3-Month Bills
 Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 3.14 percent as the discount rose two basis points, to 3.08 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 3.43 percent as the discount rose 7 basis points, to 3.34 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 3.65 percent as the discount rose 10 basis points, to 3.52 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, fell to 213/16 percent, from 3 percent late Thursday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 9613/32 , up 1/16 point. The average yield to maturity was 6.46 percent, unchanged from late Thursday.

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Rise Brisk 21.6%

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built vehicles rose 21.6 percent in early November, with light trucks accounting for most of the increase.
The results follow on the heels of higher retail spending in October, suggesting that consumers may be gaining confidence to commit to bigger-ticket items. 
 A recovery in sales of light trucks typically precedes an increase in car sales because businesses are not able to postpone replacing a truck as long as some consumers can postpone a car purchase.
 
 
'Steady Recovery'
 Car sales rose 7.9 percent, to 126,127, while light trucks, which include mini-vans, sport-utility vehicles and pickups, advanced 44.6 percent, to 99,881, for the Nov. 1-10 period. The seasonally annual rate for cars was 5.6 million, down from 6.6 million in late October and 5.7 million for the corresponding period last year. Total vehicle sales were 226,008.
"It was a puny selling rate for domestic cars in early November, but I don't believe the overall industry is that weak," Tom Webb, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, said.
David Healy, automotive analyst for S. G. Warburg & Company, said, "We've got a steady recovery."
A spot check of car dealers found them reporting that sales had strengthened from last month and from a year earlier. Gary Martin, vice president of Leo Martin Chevrolet-Oldsmobile in Freeport, Tex., said: "We're seeing more people recognizing the value of domestic cars over imports. We're anticipating a very, very good year."
 
Some Caution Expressed
 But Michael Gorman, general sales manager of Nordic Ford-Toyota in South Burlington, Vt., said: "I sense there's still not a strong feeling of consumer confidence. We anticipated greater sales increases after the election. Now we sense people are waiting to see what President-elect Clinton does in his first 100 days."
The General Motors Corporation reported a 4.3 percent drop in car sales to 54,106, but a 32.9 percent increase in light trucks to 35,323. G.M.'s Oldsmobile division, which had been performing abysmally, suffered a 20 percent drop in sales.
The Ford Motor Company posted sales increases of 20.5 percent for cars, to 39,133, and 41.6 percent for light trucks, to 34,607.
Ward's Automotive Reports estimated that the Chrysler Corporation's car sales rose 18.9 percent, to 14,450, and light-truck sales rose 62.4 percent, to 25,500. Chrysler reports vehicle sales on a monthly basis.
The Honda Motor Company, whose sales had been declining, reported a 10.2 percent increase in sales of domestically built cars, to 7,694.
The Toyota Motor Corporation's sales of domestic cars fell 3.7 percent, to 4,535.

HEADLINE: Jails Switch May Prove Problematic

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
New York City said yesterday that it would stop using two prisons near the Canadian border by the end of the year, a move that officials said would save the city $51 million a year but would create a budget headache for the state.
The decision caps an effort by the city to turn over the prisons to the state and court efforts to compel the state to expedite inmates' transfers from city to state prisons. At issue is a dispute involving the city, the state and a prisoners' rights group over who has to pay for running the two upstate prisons, prison jobs upstate and finding room for inmates who should be in state custody. 
 A spokesman for the State Correctional Services Department, James B. Flateau, said the state would take over the prisons, at Ogdensburg and Cape Vincent, as soon as they were vacated and would use Ogdensburg to comply with a court order to clear up a chronic backlog of inmates held in city jails.
To relieve overcrowding in city jails, the city bought the prisons from the state for $113 million in 1988. Under the agreement the city paid the state to staff and operate the prisons, which this year will cost at least $51 million.
 
Changes in Overcrowding
 In the last two years overcrowding in the city prisons eased while state prisons became severely overcrowded. The drop in the city's inmate population prompted the city in March to notify the state that it intended to discontinue using the prisons, 300 miles from the city.
The medium-security prisons can hold a total of 1,500 inmates, and city officials proposed that the state use the buildings to reduce the backlog of inmates, called "state readies," who are scheduled to be moved from city jails to state custody. But state officials said there were contractual questions over the prison operating costs, including 809 employees of the Correctional Services Department.
Those jobs are considered essential to the local economies, and layoffs would almost certainly ignite political outcries. Mr. Flateau said the state would retain all the employees.
Nestled in bucolic regions near the St. Lawrence River, the two prisons acquired a reputation among inmates as "country club" institutions, especially compared with the grim landscape of Rikers Island. To transport inmates to and from the prisons the city spent $2 million a year for charter flights.
The Deputy Mayor for Public Safety, Fritz W. Alexander 2d, said yesterday that the city told state officials on Thursday that all inmates from Ogdensburg would be transferred to prisons in the city by the end of the month. He said all city inmates would leave Cape Vincent next month.
The two prisons had a combined inmate population yesterday of 870, according to the City Correction Department. Over all, city prisons yesterday held 20,190 inmates, 94 percent of the capacity of 21,369. Correction Commissioner Catherine M. Abate said she anticipated no difficulties in absorbing the transfers.
The state prison census yesterday was 62,154, or 128 percent of the intended capacity of 48,738.
 
Questions About Expenses
 State Criminal Justice Director Richard H. Girgenti noted that the city had a 10-year contract to pay for the two prisons. "There are questions that have to be negotiated as to whether the city gave us adequate notification and who pays for operational expenses," he said.
On the issue of removing "state ready" prisoners from city jails, state officials acknowledged that they had been unable to comply with a court settlement. The settlement, reached in August with the Legal Aid Society, required the state by Oct. 1 to transfer within 10 days all prisoners classifed as "state readies." Such inmates are mainly criminals sentenced on felony convictions and parole violaters.
The state is required to hold inmates serving sentences of a year or more. Justice Joan B. Lobis of State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday ordered Correctional Services Commissioner Thomas A. Coughlin 3d to end the backlog by Dec. 14. The City Correction Department said it had 825 "state ready" inmates awaiting transfers yesterday.
Mr. Flateau said the backlog had developed because of a surge in prisoners and the inability of the agency to expand its work-release program.

HEADLINE: Home Resale Prices Up 1.6%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
The weak economy continued to take its toll on home values during the third quarter, depressing prices in California and parts of the Northeast and curbing them in many other areas, a real estate trade group reported today.
The National Association of Realtors said the national median price of a previously owned single-family home edged up 1.6 percent, to $103,500, from the quarter a year earlier. The median means half the homes cost more and half cost less. 
 It was the smallest increase in home prices since they advanced 1.2 percent in the first quarter of 1991. Prices, which had jumped 7.5 percent from January through March, slowed to a 2.3 percent gain during the next three months.
Sales of existing homes actually fell during the third quarter, down 5 percent, to a 3.35 million seasonally adjusted annual rate, despite the lowest mortgage rates in nearly two decades. The realtors said sales rose only in the Midwest.
"Over the past quarter, the lower-priced segment of the market has continued to draw the most buyers," said Dorcas T. Helfant, the association president, explaining that "heavy demand has driven up prices." But she added that people in the upper end had been more apt to hold back until they received some positive news about the economy.

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Climbed 0.4% Last Month

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Consumer prices rose a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in October, the Government said today, in a report suggesting that some inflationary pressures still exist despite the sluggish economy.
The increase was the largest since a rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in March.
The October rise in the Consumer Price Index, adjusted for seasonal factors, reflected increases in housing, transportation and energy. The September index had risen two-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Core Rate Up 0.5%
 With the erratic food and energy sectors removed -- leaving the so-called core rate -- consumer prices were up five-tenths of 1 percent in October after rising two-tenths of 1 percent in September, the Labor Department said.
The pace of inflation in October was generally more vigorous than Wall Street had expected, but the rise did not appear strong enough to hamper President-elect Bill Clinton's plans to take steps to stimulate the economy.
Some people on Wall Street have been concerned that the new Administration might go too far, overstimulating the economy and setting the stage for higher inflation.
Such concern is affecting the bond market, where long-term interest rates have increased in recent weeks despite quiet inflation and low short-term rates.
Earlier this week, the Labor Department reported that prices received by American producers rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in October, with the core rate showing a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent.
Analysts say the weak increase at the wholesale level in October should eventually be reflected at retail outlets.
But October's figures on consumer prices were a different matter.
 Food and beverage prices rose only one-tenth of 1 percent, after going up by four-tenths in September. But housing jumped four-tenths last month, compared with a rise of one-tenth in September.
Apparel and upkeep rose three-tenths of 1 percent, compared with two-tenths in September. Transportation was up six-tenths after being unchanged in September. The surge in the transportation index mainly reflected a jump of 7.9 percent in airline fares.
Gasoline prices rose six-tenths of 1 percent; they had dropped seven-tenths in September.
Energy costs increased five-tenths of 1 percent, after being unchanged in September. Medical care was up six-tenths.
The Labor Department also reported today that workers' earnings, after adjusting for inflation and seasonal factors, rose four-tenths of 1 percent in October after falling 1.4 percent in September.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Coffee Prices Surge Again; Fear of Tight Supply Grows

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Coffee futures prices surged yesterday to a seven-month high on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange as worries about tightening supplies from South America intensified.
Coffee for December delivery rose 1.95 cents, to 69.2 cents a pound, the highest settlement of a near-term coffee contract since April 9. 
 It was the fourth straight daily advance for coffee, which has risen from recent 17-year lows in response to shrinking Brazilian exports and harvest forecasts, and a threat of terrorist-related supply disruptions in Colombia.
Another supportive factor yesterday was talk that Colombia, the second-largest coffee producer after Brazil, plans to announce next week that its new crop will be two million bags smaller than expected because of insect infestation.
Arthur Stevenson, analyst with Prudential Securities, said Colombia's political instability was at least as important a factor as the possibility of a smaller crop. He said a slowdown by dock workers at Santos, Brazil's main coffee port, had cut further into coffee exports that were already running 40 percent behind a year ago.
The new Brazilian crop is expected to total 18 million to 20 million bags compared with 24 million to 26 million last year.
Sandra Kaul, an analyst at Shearson, said coffee prices were likely to rise further.
Oil futures finished lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, extending a long-term slide associated with rising production and the sluggish global economy. Crude bounced off the key $20-a-barrel mark early in the session.
Light sweet crude oil for December delivery ended 13 cents lower at $20.08 a barrel; December heating oil fell 0.33 cent, to 57.7 cents a gallon; December unleaded gasoline dropped 0.33 cent, to 53.61 cents a gallon; December natural gas fell 2 cents, to $2.423 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Grain and soybean futures prices rose, supported by fresh export demand for United States wheat and talk of quality problems with Canadian oats. The strength in the wheat and oat markets spread to the corn and soybean pits, analysts said.
Wheat for December delivery rose 5 cents to settle at $3.73 1/4 a bushel; December corn rose 2 1/4 cents, to $2.12 1/2 a bushel; December oats rose 4 3/4 cents, to $1.46 1/2 a bushel; November soybeans climbed 2 3/4 cents, to $5.60 3/4 a bushel.
Livestock and meat futures finished narrowly mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Fails to Rally Despite Rate Cuts in Europe

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar failed to rally yesterday in the face of several favorable economic reports and lower interest rates abroad.
Gold prices advanced worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $335.30 an ounce, up $2.10 from Thursday. The Republic National Bank said gold had gained $2.30 an ounce, to a late bid price of $335.70. 
 The dollar headed lower in European trading despite interest-rate cuts in Britain, France and Italy announced Thursday. As European rates decline, United States yields appear more attractive to investors.
When trading shifted to domestic markets, the dollar got a momentary boost from a report showing a larger-than-expected increase in October retail sales.
A separate report showed consumer prices also rose more than expected. While generally negative because higher prices signal inflation, the report "dashed lingering hopes for a rate cut" by the Federal Reserve, said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the advisory firm IDEA.
Higher interest rates make dollar-denominated securities more valuable to investors.
"Despite the constructive data, the dollar's strong rally could not be reignited," Mr. Chandler said, referring to the dollar's steady upward climb in recent weeks, which began to stall a few days ago.
He predicted further profit taking early next week but noted that the underlying sentiment toward the dollar remained favorable.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 123.84 yen, down 0.29 yen from Thursday's close. Later, in London, the dollar was quoted at 123.90 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 124.05 yen, up from 123.95 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.5510, from $1.5240 late Thursday. In New York, it cost $1.5505 to buy one pound, more expensive than Thursday's $1.5290.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.5725 German marks, down from 1.5800; 1.4190 Swiss francs, down from 1.4285; 5.3055 French francs, down from 5.3365; 1,344.00 Italian lire, down from 1,356.00, and 1.2644 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2616.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
DISNEY SEES ENVIRONMENT HURDLES TO PROPOSED PARK

BYLINE: Reuters

 BODY:
The environmental impact costs from Walt Disney Company's proposed construction of a $3 billion theme park in Anaheim, Calif., raise new doubts about the feasibility of the park, a Disney executive said yesterday. A draft environmental impact report by the City of Anaheim on the proposed Westcot Center park found that most environmental effects could be mitigated but at a high cost, said Kerry Hunnewell, vice president of the Disney Development Company. "The economics are kind of marginal right now," he said. Environmental costs are estimated to represent about $750 million of the projected total cost of the park.

HEADLINE: The Romance of Boston

BYLINE: By Jane Holtz Kay; Jane Holtz Kay, the author of "Lost Boston" and the architecture critic of The Nation, is writing "Carbound: Ending the Auto Age."

 BODY:

CITYSCAPES OF BOSTON
An American City Through Time.
By Robert Campbell and Peter Vanderwarker.
Illustrated. 220 pp. Boston:
A Peter Davison Book/
Houghton Mifflin Company. $35.
 
PLANNING THE CITY UPON A HILL
Boston Since 1630.
By Lawrence W. Kennedy.
Illustrated. 314 pp. Amherst:
University of Massachusetts Press. $27.50. 
 POST-MODERN, post-urban: this would seem to be the era of the valley of despond in American cities. What lessons could Boston -- this urbane covey, this franchiser of lost literati and losing Presidential candidates -- offer a nation in which urban means apartheid? Does anybody really want to attend to cities other than to flee, fleece, privatize, butcher or decimate them?
And yet, for all our car-burb creations and post-Los Angeles Angst, the romance of the city dies hard. Not only romance. Ruminations on urban life reflect more than nostalgia: New York architecture is being chronicled in a hefty trilogy, Chicago recently earned a fascinating urban ecology ("Nature's Metropolis" by William Cronon) and even Los Angeles has writers who can evoke moody apocalypse from what we outsiders see as scourge or sprawl ("City of Quartz" by Mike Davis).
Cities, even shell cities, remain what they always were; what the root word "civitas" in "citizens" and "cities" suggests; what Lewis Mumford meant in the phrase "heart of empire" (an empire of mind and art and community) and, finally, what parochial romanticists (I among them) and even progressive time-motion economists maintain.
By these standards and by its size and design, its history and livability, Boston does deserve a place on some literary-geographic crest. The authors of two new books demonstrate why and how. They brandish the art of city making, describe buildings "dressed to kill," explore the artistic, the workaday and the wherewithal of creating a city of density, assembly and appeal. Surveying this time-bound city, once a peninsula about the size of New York's Central Park, they peel back the years to reveal the anomaly inside an enigma: a planned place in unplanned, placeless America.
"Cityscapes of Boston: An American City Through Time," by the architecture critic Robert Campbell, supplies a fascinating then-and-now photo primer on how Boston's lessons of design and urbanity work today and could work elsewhere tomorrow. "Planning the City Upon a Hill," by the historian Lawrence W. Kennedy, offers a close-up narrative of "Boston since 1630." They both record a city not only laminated by history but also one well trodden and visually vital despite its economic downslide.
MR. CAMPBELL, a critic for The Boston Globe, is the more episodic but acute voyager through the centuries of Boston architecture, or at least through the century and a half recorded by camera. "Cityscapes of Boston" presents a dynamic and engaging juxtaposition of images of times past and recent pictures shot from the same vantage point by the photographer Peter Vanderwarker. Amplified from a series that appeared first in The Boston Globe Magazine, the book could serve as a model text and approach to use in every city.
Often lyrical and always lucid, this is a portable book for a mutable city. Its then-and-now can be read on many levels: as a tale of successive cityscapes, as a polemic on caring in times past (and of mostly not caring in times present) and as an urban design guide with chapter headings like "Making the Public City" or "Strutting Our Stuff." Mr. Campbell's passion and prejudices enliven his story of city making. He delights in buildings that "turn the corner" of a street, those "ship's prow" shapes that swell toward the viewer; he favors "houses with hats and faces in a city of outdoor rooms," and offers comments at once quirky and instructive.
You may disagree with his opinions from time to time. (One man's "humane" Rowes Wharf is this woman's overscaled wall obstructing the waterfront.) You may admire his view that the flattening of the West End of the city, a classic urban renewal disaster, was "the product of well-meaning but idiotic control freaks, playing in their offices with zoning maps instead of walking out into the world to observe how cities really work," while also putting blame on developers, a myopic public and a pernicious era in urban history.
The rich, personalized nature of this book is a pleasure. Neither didactic nor high-style highbrow, Mr. Campbell's own aphorisms (Harvard Square "works because Harvard trusts it") blend with epigrams from people like Jorge Luis Borges ("after the age of 50, all change becomes a hateful symbol of the passing of time"). His polemic is invigorating. "Since World War II, American cities have been trashed by the invasion of marauding expressways that roar into town and slice up neighborhoods like raucous vandals," he writes. Shots of plain folks and idiosyncratic asides give the book a scrapbook air that like the city itself is intimate for all its elegance.
Mr. Vanderwarker's legwork unearthed the pictures of the original views and his adept photography captured today's scenes. If the photographic decks seem stacked against the present, that impression probably reflects the urbanity of 19th-century city builders and the beauty of the old photographs rather than any manipulation.
Lacking the depth or bite of that book, Lawrence Kennedy's straightforward, rather bloodless tale still fills a need. "Planning the City Upon a Hill" records the shaping of the city: the expansion and planning from Puritan arrival (1630) to wooden water-pipe expansion (1790); from the decapitation and embroidering of Beacon Hill to the invasion of South End, Back Bay, streetcar suburbs and the necklace of greenery Frederick Law Olmsted planned around the city. What is most useful, it updates Boston's tale of this century, charting the Depression epoch of Mayor James Michael Curley with its economic and architectural stasis, followed by the postwar urban renewal that both ransacked and rebuilt the city.
The author tries to translate Boston's conversion from mud flat and gravel to brick and greenery in terms of an alliance of the same kind of private-public cooperation promoted as a panacea today. In a book thrice its size and moral scope he would have trouble drawing conclusions. Each time slot, each segment of the city had its visionaries, its profiteers, its politicians. Shaping the Beacon Hill that emerged in the early 19th century with Charles Bulfinch, who was reigning architect and political chieftain at the same time, is not the same as creating the Back Bay, shaped by plan and commission after the Civil War. The desperate hours of the 1950's and 60's, when "New Boston" honchos flattened valued neighborhoods and raised architectural excrescences, are not the 70's and booming 80's, when Mayor Kevin White sold cherished landscapes to speculators for tax-abated towers.
Such comments may seem churlish. In the light of Boston's livability and the misery of many other cities, one cannot ignore the physical revitalization of the city. But by and large, this top-down history is too much the gospel according to the Boston Redevelopment Authority, the urban renewal agency where Mr. Kennedy once worked as a consulting historian. Although he tries to address issues of equity, Mr. Kennedy neglects urban or architectural criticism: labeling the abysmal, anti-urban new architecture of the opulent Copley Place or the insolvent Lafayette Place malls with the common and neutral phrase "larger developments" is more than lax prose.
His emphasis throughout on commerce and politics to the exclusion of civic or esthetic sensibility compounds the problem. Though his narrative is compact and up to date, it fails to explains old Boston's adroit patterning before planning became a profession, or modern Boston's capacity to make "recycling" and "festival marketeering" common coinage now. And by doing so, it slights the city's contribution to revitalization and preservation nationally.
"In the history of cities, private enterprise with public ambitions has created some of the best urban spaces," Robert Campbell observes almost offhandedly in "Cityscapes of Boston." Despite the search for large dreams and urban planning lessons, his corner-by-corner caring may say more about how a city is created than the pronouncements of the planners and politicians.
That is what the reader will find by studying the streetscapes or following the outline of their creation in the hub of Boston. Despite the fact this city on the hill still awaits a history that would combine the architectural and urban design approach of the Campbell book and the planning scope of the Kennedy one, the insights of the authors and the views of the photographer Peter Vanderwarker focus attention on the art and craft of urbanity at its most consistent in this country.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 29; Column 2; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: Journey to Isolation

BYLINE: By David E. Sanger; David E. Sanger is chief of the Tokyo bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
As our caravan of air-conditioned tour buses lumbered into Chongjin, a port town in the barren northeast corner of North Korea, housewives and schoolchildren -- most of whom had apparently been ordered off the streets before we arrived -- stared in amazement from their windows and schoolyards. For the inhabitants of the world's most hermetically sealed nation, we were, without doubt, an odd sight: a hundred or so Japanese businessmen, a few American academics and journalists, even a couple of South Korea's leading industrialists thinly disguised as "academics" and "consultants." But the biggest oddity was not us. It was our buses.
North Korea is so broke these days that buses are rarely seen. Not only are there virtually no tourists, but gasoline is so scarce there are few moving vehicles. Furthermore, conditions in the last few years have deteriorated so much that this notoriously secretive nation is doing the unthinkable. It is welcoming its traditional enemies, urging them to build megaports and factories in areas they would have been shot for entering a year ago. 
 For the North, this reflects the total failure of juche, the national religion of self-reliance. These days, the North Korean Government is busy amending its laws for international joint ventures and wooing many of those it has openly despised. Last month, it passed its first comprehensive foreign investment law, specifically aimed at drawing in South Korean investors and those from other "enemy" states.
"We want to develop our technology," Kim Dal Hyon -- the Deputy Prime Minister and a man believed to be in the vanguard of a tenuous reform movement -- admitted to us in a rare flash of candor in Pyongyang, the capital. "It is for our own survival."
Yet, with characteristic bravado, North Korea's officials also insist they can do what Eastern Europe could not: reform their economy without backing off an inch from the hard-line Communist ideology that has kept this nation tightly controlled since the division of North and South in 1945.
The harsh reality sweeping through this country is this: After 45 years, North Korea has been virtually abandoned by its longtime allies. Throughout the cold war, while the United States supported the South, the Soviet Union and China provided the regime of Kim Il Sung, who is now 80 years old, with food and fuel and technology. Every day freight trains rumbled across the single-track bridge spanning the Tumen River. But with the end of East-West hostilities, both Moscow and Beijing -- faced with their own economic problems and pragmatically preferring the capitalist South's steel plants and car factories to the North's Stalinist rhetoric -- have opened diplomatic relations with Seoul.
In late September, China -- the country that sent more than a million troops swarming over the border more than 40 years ago to crush the South -- welcomed South Korea's President, Roh Tae Woo, on a historic first trip. Roh brought what the Chinese wanted: news that this year South Korea's trade with the Chinese will double to more than $10 billion, and that even more South Korean-owned electronics factories and clothing plants would be built in the special economic zone of Guangdong Province, adjacent to Hong Kong. In a few days President Boris N. Yeltsin is scheduled to make his first visit to Seoul, and to talk about rebuilding Russia the way South Korea had transformed itself into one of Asia's industrial dragons.
No one knows for certain what kind of panic this is touching off in Pyongyang, but on North Korea's side of the Tumen, Li Song Pil, the spry stationmaster, can measure the country's isolation with precision. A few years ago, six or seven freight trains crossed the river every day. These days, he said: "Sometimes we see one. Sometimes, nothing comes."
But if this nation of 22 million is opening its door, it is opening it just a crack. The regime of the "Great Leader" and his son and heir apparent, "Dear Leader" Kim Jong Il, is determined not to let capitalists undo more than 40 years of rigid political training.
On our 10-day swing through the country several months ago, we were honored guests, even treated to a giant picnic on a beach along the northeastern coast near an area that North Korea hopes to turn into a thriving port. But an electric fence separated us from North Koreans living nearby. One morning, a group of us touring one of Chongjin's decaying shipyards wandered toward the shipyard entrance, hoping to get to the street and talk to people passing by. We never got the chance. As we approached the big iron gate, it slammed shut and armed guards emerged from their posts, shouting, "Seot! Seot!" ("Halt! Halt!"). One of our well-groomed guides, clearly annoyed by our temerity, explained that although the country is open, mixing with the populace "could be dangerous."
The regime seems equally insecure in its new international forays, alternating welcoming gestures with standard cold-war charges against the United States and its "puppets" in Seoul. Indeed, little that has happened in North Korea in the past year has eased fears that the regime might once again lash out, especially since it could soon gain nuclear capability.
There is far less of that fear than there was just a few months ago when the Central Intelligence Agency asserted that a 20-year effort by North Korea to build a crude nuclear device could be only months away from completion. American satellites had picked up a near-completed plutonium reprocessing plant, the last major hurdle before a bomb can be assembled. Under pressure from Washington, Tokyo and Moscow, Kim Il Sung was forced to let in international inspectors. Many believe that Pyongyang, surprised by the harshness of the West's reaction, may now have given up its nuclear card. Skeptics in the United States and Japan, however, note that the North Koreans are past masters of deception.
Oddly enough, among those who feel less threatened by Pyongyang's nuclear capabilities are the South Koreans, who appear confident that the end game in a four-decades-long conflict has begun. Even President Roh, in his last months in office, is talking like a general who sees victory on the horizon.
The North's "determination to develop nuclear weapons has become weaker," he told me in September at Blue House -- the giant new presidential palace on a hillside above Seoul, only about 35 miles from the border -- that is surrounded by elaborate defenses against possible North Korean terrorists. "North Korea is much more isolated this year than it was last year. Their economic situation is deteriorating, and their people are suffering from the lack of food. They have decided they must gradually open up. They have no choice. The waves of liberalization are rolling in."
In fact, the main fear in Blue House today is that the waves may crash in too quickly. Mindful of the enormous cost of creating an united Germany, Seoul still talks of achieving its dream of reunifying the Korean peninsula but seems in no rush to realize it. Some say that the price tag may be as high as $400 billion. And those who once argued for pressing the North to the wall are saying they want to avoid forcing a collapse.
South Korean companies are urging their Government to permit them to begin investing in the North, rebuilding its infrastucture and creating jobs and access to cheap labor, so that the South's economy will not be forced to absorb crippling costs when reunification arrives. Last month, even with the nuclear questions unresolved, the Government allowed a delegation of industrialists to visit the North to explore moving old textile factories and aging equipment to its industrial zones.
"We would like to encourage North Korea to change gradually, to change peacefully," one of Roh's most senior advisors says. "But this is not the kind of thing where you get to pick your timing."
Says Donald Gregg, the C.I.A.'s station chief in Seoul at the height of the cold war and now the American Ambassador there: "There is already a subliminal feeling of victory in the air -- that unification will come, and it will come on the South's terms. That is an enormous change. Three years ago, a Russian came to me here, one of the first who was allowed into Seoul, and he said with some surprise, 'You know, the South is scared to death of the North.' That was true then. It's not true anymore."
In the tightly ordered world of Pyongyang, North Korea's show city, every Government project is a "gift" from the Great Leader. This year, marking the 80th birthday of Kim Il Sung and the 50th birthday of his son, Kim Jong Il, there have been a lot of gifts. Some are buildings, like the Reunification Housing Project apartments, functional two-to-four-room units that would be welcome public housing anywhere in New York -- save for the speakers in most hallways constantly blaring Government propaganda.
With basic necessities in shorter supply than at any time in memory, the most prized gifts are food and clothes. China celebrated the senior Kim's birthday in April -- a few months before giving diplomatic recognition to the South -- by sending several hundred thousand tons of pork. When our group visited the Pyongyang High Middle School No. 1, Li Chun Ran, a 17-year-old, removed her lab smock to show us her new blue school dress. She wears it every day. "Kim Il Sung and the Dear Leader, Kim Jong Il, gave me the dress," she said.
The school, a Government showcase, boasts of classrooms filled with Japanese personal computers, advanced science laboratories equipped with up-to-date microscopes and even a room for driver's education, complete with a Chinese car and a screen projecting scenery racing by on the road. The only hitch is that almost no one in Pyongyang can buy a car. Indeed, the only cars on the streets are Volvo taxis (priced so that only foreigners can hire them), a few aging Mercedes limousines for V.I.P.'s and some modern-looking trams made in Eastern Europe. At night, the city is virtually pitch-black, with only a few buildings lit.
In a city of grandiose Stalinist-style monuments, the biggest one is the 105-story Ryu Gyong Hotel, designed to be the tallest in Asia. A bit more than half-finished, the pyramid towers over the city. No official would comment on the project, but rumors abound that it is out of money, and it is visibly in need of structural repair. But clearly utility is not an issue. Only about 100,000 tourists visit North Korea each year, all on group tours and most from the dwindling family of Communist or socialist countries. Most of them could not afford the Ryu Gyong if it were open.
What strikes a visitor to Pyongyang, a city of two million, is the total absence of spontaneity. It is perhaps the only Asian city without the chaotic, open markets that are plentiful in other Communist capitals, from Hanoi to Beijing. The department stores seem well stocked; there are few, if any, shoppers.
"Anything of value is rationed," explained a diplomat stationed in Pyongyang. "You might have coupons to get a few things, but almost no one buys in the stores."
When two of us asked on a Saturday to go to a restaurant where ordinary Koreans eat lunch, our guide had to take us on a 45-minute drive around town until he found one that was open. When colleagues visited an off-the-tourist-path apartment building and found it run-down and filthy, they were brought in for questioning.
Although officials take great pains to keep visitors from seeing any sign of poverty in Pyongyang, they are unable to do the same in the countryside. Early one morning, not long after our train began its journey up the coast, we saw women hoeing the hard earth by hand in the villages passing by our window. Oxen were few and far between. According to diplomats stationed in Pyongyang, malnutrition is widespread, with many people not getting their full allotment of 4.4 pounds of red meat and chicken a month. Earlier this year, the regime adopted the slogan "Let's Eat Two Meals!"
Every few months there are reports from ethnic Koreans living over the border in China about food riots breaking out in remote towns in the North. The stories are impossible to check, but with so many accounts most experts believe they carry at least some truth. "What we think happens," says Kim Chang Soon, the director of the Institute for North Korean Studies in Seoul, "is that people are supposed to receive rice every 15 days, but they get only enough for 10. So for the last 5 days they eat grass and vegetables and when the 15th day arrives, they go to get their rice. If it isn't there, they raid the warehouse."
Rice is not the only scarce commodity. From our train, we saw armed guards standing atop piles of coal at rail depots; later, North Korean officials conceded that theft had become a growing problem. Since 1990, Moscow has refused to deliver oil at what were called "friendship" rates, far below the market value. By some estimates, North Korea is getting only a third of the petroleum supplies it needs.
South Korean officials, who have an interest in painting a bleak picture, estimate that Pyongyang's economy shrank by 3.7 percent in 1990 and by 5.2 percent last year. Exports last year were about $1 billion -- roughly what the South exports in five days. Many economists, and the American intelligence community, estimate that things are actually much worse in the North. But because the North Korean Government guards most economic data as state secrets and because almost every economic "fact" is an extrapolation from anecdotes, it is easy for North Korean officials to issue blanket denials.
"We do not face any economic crisis that is not found in Russia or any East European country," one senior official insisted to us. The "only economic trouble we face," he said, was that "we cannot export or import any goods from the formerly socialist countries."
In most countries, sudden privation of the sort North Koreans are experiencing would be tinder for revolution. But North Korea is unlike most countries. So far, there is no sign of the kind of discontent that brought down Communism in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Unlike East Germans a few years ago, who knew -- from television and from a steady stream of visitors -- about life in the West, North Koreans seem to know almost nothing about the heady prosperity in the South. There is no television from the outside world, only a few shortwave radios in the hands of the elite, and endless propaganda about the abuse of workers, crime and homelessness in South Korea, Japan and the United States.
In short, after 35 years of brutal Japanese occupation, followed by 44 years of strong-arm Communist dictatorship, few North Koreans are in a position to question what they are told. And what they are still being told is that North Korea remains a "socialist paradise on earth." At the "mass games" for Kim Il Sung's birthday, where 100,000 schoolchildren performed precision gymnastics, a huge sign proclaimed "We Envy Nobody in the World!"
Public devotion to the Great Leader seems undiminished. If the South's economy was built on entrepreneurship and industrial policy, the North's has been built on a personality cult: a quasi-religious loyalty to the "great sun of mankind," Kim Il Sung. On the outskirts of Pyongyang, workers still line up to see North Korea's equivalent of Abe Lincoln's cabin -- the primitive thatched-roof house where the Great Leader was born.
When you ask North Koreans why they work so hard -- a national characteristic shared with the South -- the answer is predictable. "These buildings were made for us by the Great Leader, Kim Il Sung, who wants to give greatly to his people," Cho Ho Sun, a 35-year-old construction worker, said, pausing for a moment from his work planting trees around the just-completed Reunification Housing Projects. "They were built on rice fields," Cho continued. "By planting trees, we pay solicitude to Kim Il Sung and the Dear Leader, Kim Jong Il."
People in North Korea really talk this way. North Korean authorities -- unlike their counterparts in China, for example -- hardly blink when you walk up to almost anyone in the capital, where people seem accustomed to handling foreigners, and start a conversation. They have little reason to fear that something untoward will slip out.
Although the few people we managed to speak to -- always under the gaze of a Government functionary -- invariably spoke of the Great Leader and the Dear Leader almost as one, it wasn't clear during our visit if the succession from father to son was as certain as it once seemed. North Korean officials seemed hard-pressed to name even a few things the Dear Leader had done for his nation. We pressed one young official dining with us one night at the Communist Party's guest house in Pyongyang -- a 14-course meal, including quail soup and steamed piglet, followed by a Las Vegas-style floor show. He struggled for a few moments, said something vague about the Dear Leader's management of the economy, then came up with: "He is competent at many things."
In September, however, North Korea's Foreign Minister Kim Yong Nam, in New York to attend a session of the United Nations, reportedly told South Korean reporters that all power had been transferred to Kim Jong Il, and that the senior Kim, while he was still President, was playing only an "advisory" role. In a rare move, the younger Kim recently entertained a delegation of foreign businessmen on his yacht; until then, handling foreigners had always been his father's job.
Whether Kim Jong Il becomes the next Great Leader, though, depends largely on a segment of North Korean society about which little is known: the ruling elite. By most estimates, the 1.5 million or so members of the "intelligentsia" are the ones who have everything: education, social status, whatever wealth there is to go around. Within this group are 10,000 to 15,000 senior officials with access to the best medical care and special shops.
There is widespread speculation that many of the top military brass -- presumably the key figures in succession politics -- were deeply unhappy when Kim Jong Il was named head of the armed forces earlier this year. The younger Kim is reputed to be a spoiled playboy with a pronounced taste for liquor and women. (Japanese intelligence agents learn what little they can about him by seeking out the foreign "hostesses" he is said to import for "entertainment.") The most commonly discussed scenario for North Korea after Kim Il Sung is that the Dear Leader will be told that he can keep his cars and "entertainers" -- as long as he does what he is told.
NORTH KOREA'S Military ranks as the world's fifth- or sixth-largest, with about one million men, 710 ships and 850 combat aircraft (mostly older Russian-made MIG's) and a budget accounting for 21.5 percent of the country's gross national product. The military is also the country's most successful exporter: North Korean-made versions of the Scud missile are becoming a favorite among Middle Eastern nations.
American and South Korean commanders acknowledge in private, however, that respect for the North's military prowess is declining. Many of the troops spend their days putting up new buildings and rebuilding the fractured rail network. South Koreans, who for years based their enormous military budgets on the size and skill of their Northern enemies, are now cutting back the rate of growth.
Pyongyang's nuclear capability is quite another matter. Attention was suddenly focused on its bomb-building plans when post-mortems of the Persian Gulf war uncovered shocking intelligence lapses, chiefly the failure of the International Atomic Energy Agency to detect the scope or progress of Iraq's nuclear bomb project -- although Iraq had submitted itself to regular agency inspections.
Until a few months ago, North Korea had never let agency inspectors into Yongbyon, the sprawling, secret installation Kim Il Sung began building in the mountains north of the capital in the 1960's. The first part completed was a small, Soviet-supplied research reactor. A much bigger reactor opened in the mid-80's, capable of producing enough waste plutonium to build a crude bomb.
Around 1988, American satellite cameras began to pick up another giant building that seemed perfectly suited for reprocessing plutonium -- turning waste into bomb fuel. It is a complex technology that many thought was beyond North Korea's talents. But apart from satellite pictures, intelligence about the project was sketchy. "In Iraq we had oil people coming in and out, we had some scientific exchange, we had commerce," one American intelligence official with long experience in Asia said this year. "With North Korea, we had nothing. Zip."
Kim had long justified barring outside inspectors by saying he would not permit them as long as the United States kept nuclear weapons in the South. But last December the Bush Administration removed the remaining American nuclear weapons from South Korea. Under intense pressure from Washington, Seoul agreed to forswear any reprocessing of its own -- making it easier to demand that Pyongyang do the same.
Once the North Koreans allowed inspectors in, the atomic energy agency discovered a vast reprocessing center. But the C.I.A. had guessed wrong about the innards of the cavernous building. The reprocessor was less than half completed, the equipment unimpressive. The North Koreans admitted they had experimented with reprocessing tiny quantities of plutonium in laboratories -- far too little to make a bomb -- and insisted their work was part of an energy research project.
Early this year, however, before inspectors arrived, satellite photographs showed trucks pulling up to the reprocessing facility, perhaps to cart away equipment. Bolstering suspicions that critical equipment might be hidden, Hans Blix, the director of the atomic energy agency, noted in a report he circulated to several governments that the North Koreans may have built a "pilot plant" to process plutonium, out of satellite view, before taking the risky leap to the building at Yongbyon.
The United States and South Korea are still insisting on an agreement to allow South Korean teams to look around in the North, while North Koreans inspect sites in the South. Because South Korean inspectors speak the same language and share the same culture, it is hoped they might be able to uncover what the agency cannot. A nuclear-armed North could overturn the delicate balance that has kept the region in check for decades. If North Korea succeeds in producing a nuclear bomb, the South would be forced to build one of its own (it tried once in the 1970's, before the United States quashed the project) and Japan might be forced to rethink the wisdom of its own ban on nuclear weapons.
AS INSPECTORS WERE combing through the North's nuclear reactors in late July, a North Korean journeying to the South was escorted across the miles of tank traps and mine fields and barbed wire that make up the demilitarized zone and onto the highways that feed into Seoul. He was Kim Dal Hyon, one of the new breed of economic "pragmatists." He was the one who had told us in Pyongyang two months earlier that the openings were "for our own survival," that juche had been a philosophy of necessity, not of choice. "We have been isolated by the world community," he had said, "because of pressure from certain superpowers."
In Seoul, Kim was given a tour of everything from advanced electronics factories to noisy markets overflowing with consumer goods. He visited the country's industrial heartland. When he was finally escorted to Blue House, his message to President Roh was simple: South Korea, for its own good and the North's, should allow its giant chae bol -- the industrial conglomerates like Samsung, Daewoo and Hyundai -- to invest in the North.
"I know that without prospects for profit, they will not come," Kim said. "I promise that they will make profits."
The energetic North Korean knew precisely what he was walking into: a quiet but significant split between the United States and South Korea over how to deal with the North. Meeting with North Korean representatives at the United Nations early in the year, Arnold L. Kanter, a senior State Department official, made it clear that the North would get nothing -- not even mid-level talks with the United States -- until the nuclear questions were completely resolved. South Korea, with far more at stake, has gradually moved toward a different view.
Scores of economists sent to study the obvious parallel -- the integration of East and West Germany -- had come back with the message that if Seoul wanted to avoid economic disaster, it better start now. "The best guesses are that it would cost $250 billion to $400 billion," says Kongdan Oh, a Korean-born policy analyst with the Rand Corporation, a research institute based in Santa Monica, Calif. "So there are a lot of contingency plans under way. If the South can get management know-how and technology into the North and begin to train people, it will bring the costs down."
Bowing to United States pressure, until recently President Roh resisted negotiating with the North while the nuclear issues remained unresolved. But with an election approaching, the pressure is building for a major initiative with economic promise. During Kim Dal Hyon's visit, Roh agreed to allow a team to visit the North and explore business opportunities. According to South Korean press reports, when Roh met recently with the heads of the South's largest conglomerates, Koo Cha Kyung, chairman of the Federation of Korean Industries, used the one argument that he knew would strike a nerve. South Korea, he said, "should consider investing in labor-intensive and consumer goods industries in the North because Japan is showing great interest in North Korea's labor pool."
In fact, no one has been more heavily courted by Kim Il Sung these days than the Japanese. It is hardly a natural alliance. In his recently published reminiscences, Kim's hatred for the Japanese is writ large in almost every chapter, as he recalled his early days battling the nation's occupiers. "While visiting various parts of the world," he wrote, "I have had the opportunity of seeing many former colonial countries, but I have never seen imperialism so hideous that it deprived people of their language and surnames and even plundered them of their tableware."
Now, though, North Korea looks across the Sea of Japan (in Pyongyang it is called the East Sea of Korea) and sees a giant bank vault. For more than a year, delegations from the former colonizer and the former colony have been meeting regularly -- and getting no place.
"The meetings are very strange," says one Japanese official involved in the talks. "The North Koreans send maybe 15 people, but most of them don't speak at all." Although the negotiators claim to be diplomats, "most don't have any experience abroad," he says.
Pyongyang has also been making overtures to the business community of Niigata, one of Japan's major ports, which is a few hundred miles across the sea from the Tumen outlet. But even with the help of the United Nations Development Program, North Korea's initial presentations to potential investors in the Tumen have been rambling and vague. China and Russia are less than enthusiastic, because they view the project as competition for their own ports.
On our visit, Japanese executives who toured the region found that very little of the infrastructure had improved since the Japanese occupiers left in 1945. "The river is too narrow to carry ships," one executive of a major trading house said. "They are wasting our time."
WHEN ROH TAE WOO LEAVES office next February, he will go down in history as the man who brought the beginnings of democracy to South Korea. Just as remarkably, he brought about diplomatic independence. The "northern policy" that brought Pyongyang to the negotiating table was not hatched in Washington but in Seoul.
So far, though, the apparent progress is far greater than the reality. The "reconciliation and nonaggression" agreement signed nearly a year ago calls for regular exchanges of family members, air and mail links. But almost every effort to put specifics of the agreement into effect have failed. The North, for example, has blocked installing a military "hot line" until the United States and South Korea halt their joint military exercises. North Korea's rulers know that as soon as news and people move across the border the "paradise on earth" line will quickly wear thin. Meanwhile, diatribes and sometimes gunfire are still exchanged. Earlier this year, an apparently accidental incursion into South Korean territory led to the killing of three North Korean soldiers.
South Koreans have no doubts that managing reunification will be the task for the next decade. Managed well, it could turn Korea into the region's newest economic powerhouse, fusing the technology of the South with the eager, cheap work force of the North. Managed badly, it could bring chaos, with new battles along the DMZ -- a conflict that could involve China, Japan and the United States.
It is easy to forget that for all their common roots, North and South Koreans are virtual strangers to one another. They have grown up in different worlds, fought a war against each other and rebuilt vastly different societies. That has been driven home to South Korean negotiators who, visiting Pyongyang, have opened their hotel-room doors to long-lost relatives. Instead of a tearful embrace, they have gotten lectures on the wonders of the Great Leader's rule.

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Growing Down Grows Up

BYLINE: By William Safire

 BODY:
During the late political unpleasantness, Governor Clinton promised to "grow the economy." President Bush derided this promise not on the basis of its syntactical formulation but in regard to its object: he accused his opponent of intending to "grow government," and he pledged that if re-elected he would grow down the deficit.
"At first," writes a horrified Anthony Lanyi of McLean, Va., "I assumed these were slips of the tongue, since grow as a transitive verb is used only in an agricultural context, as in 'I grow tomatoes in my garden.' " In similar dismay, Esther B. Fein, a New York Times reporter reared in the tradition of fine distinctions, stopped me in the hall to say, "You raise cattle and rear children, but grow the economy and grow down the deficit?" 
 Grow to like it, because the transitive use of grow in a citified sense has deep roots in the language and is here to stay. "Whan David had regned vii yere in Ebron," William Caxton wrote in 1481 about Jerusalem, "he grewe and amended moche this cyte."
Fred Mish, editorial director of Merriam-Webster, says, "The transitive use of grow with inanimate objects like business is covered by the basic transitive definition, 'to cause to grow.' " The object of grow doesn't have to be limited to soybeans or a beard -- it can logically apply to growing a business, an economy, a government or a deficit.
But what about growing down? This term is an oxymoron, a jarring juxtaposition of opposites, with an honored place in English dialect; the English lexicographer James O. Halliwell reported in 1847 that "to grow downward, i.e. to get smaller" was "a common phrase in the provinces."
Down is not used nearly so often in verb phrases as up, but we pay down loans, dress down illiterates and bring down Presidents; in the case of grow down, we are influenced by the recent builddown of forces, which played off buildup.
Be not horrified at what seem like daring or extended usages, even by politicians under pressure. The unfamiliar should not be presumed to be mistaken; that's how we grow the language.
 
KINDER THAN WHO?
 WHEN GEORGE BUSH SPOKE of a "kinder, gentler nation" in 1988, I recently reported that Nancy Reagan turned to a convention boxmate and tartly asked, "Kinder than who?" I added, "She knew when the cord was being cut, despite her grammatical lapse."
Purist who-whomniks hit back. In the course of a thoughtful letter on values, Neil Rudenstine, the president of Harvard, writes: "If we are thinking about the nation, then 'Kinder than what?' would probably have been right. But if the comparison seemed rather more personal, then 'Kinder than who?' is maybe clumsily correct."
Hermione Wickenden of Weston, Conn., writes, "If the question had been completed, it would logically read: 'Kinder than who (or Ronnie!) is kind?' " David Carney of Sag Harbor, L.I., notes, "You obviously mistook than, a conjunctive adverb of comparison, for a preposition."
You bet I take than as a preposition, not a conjunction. The purists would ask "Kinder than who [is]?" and answer "Kinder than I [am]"; impurists, or non-stiffs, would answer "Kinder than me," using the objective case, and substituting the objective whom for me.
Nancy Reagan's friend Peter Hannaford takes no position on the who/whom controversy, but points out that Mrs. Reagan did not listen to the speech from a convention box and doubts the accuracy of my report. Maybe it's apocryphal, though my source says not; if Mrs. Reagan said it, she used the words "Kinder than who?" and I am prepared to concede she has a legion of who-whomniks to support her grammar.
 
SIGHTED SUPERSESSION, SANK SAME
 SOME SPOOKY CHARACTER answering a query about the theft of communication encoders and keys from the Department of Justice dumped a bunch of secret memos on my desk. I will mine the dump for news in another space, but cannot resist reporting immediately on the language of security bureaucrats.
Describing an inventory check, the man from DOJ COMSEC Central Office of Record writes "all items were physically sighted." Presumably this means the items themselves -- not pictures or descriptions or computer simulations -- were seen by the inventory-taker's human eye. Physically is sometimes used to mean "I was there"; sighted can have the sense of being seen from afar, or the sense of not being blind. In normal human discourse, physically sighted would be put as actually seen.
"The destruction of superseded key is accorded high priority with N.S.A.," the security official notes sternly. (N.S.A. stands for National Security Agency, nicknamed No Such Agency.) Key is, I assume, code material; superseded key must be "old codes" superseded, or replaced, by new ones. (Comes from the Latin supersedere, literally "to sit on top of.") Thus, if you look at an old code and want to impress your superiors about it in a memo, you write you are physically sighting superseded key.
"Custodian failed to destroy over 300 pieces of Top Secret operational and contingency STU-II key material," huffs the investigating officer, using over when he means more than, "within five days of supersession."
Although supersession was in use in 1790 to mean "the act of superseding," it has itself been superseded by the gerund superseding. He should have written "within five days of superseding"; a supersession, among the Ninth Street cognoscenti, connotes a fun time in the office of the Attorney General.
 
-AUTS, -ITES OR -IONS
 WILL THE FOLLOWERS OF BILL Clinton follow the practice of George McGovern, Richard Nixon or Ronald Reagan?
If the first, we will see frequent references to Clintonites, modeled on McGovernites.
Another choice would be Clinton ians, on the analogy of Nixonians.
A third would be Clintonauts, originating in Argonauts by way of Rea ganauts.
The only other possibility that comes to mind is Clinties, modeled on Bushies; that won't fly.

HEADLINE: RADIO VIEW;
Shock Jocks Shake Up Uncle Sam

BYLINE: By Jon Pareles

 BODY:
Whose problem is Howard Stern? The Federal Communications Commission thinks he's a government problem; it recently levied a fine of $105,000 on Mr. Stern and his Los Angeles radio outlet, KLSX, for 12 counts of verbal "indecency" during his morning show. But the real question is why his mixture of juvenile humor and hostility, his crusading vulgarity, draws such huge audiences, and that makes him everybody's problem.
Mr. Stern, the reigning talent among so-called shock jocks, is now simulcast to 10 cities, including New York, Chicago, Dallas and Los Angeles. The empire grows because he draws large audiences (his morning show leads the ratings in both New York and Los Angeles); he has also made forays into movies and television (his nationally syndicated show was recently canceled, but he will be doing an interview program for the Entertainment Channel). 
 On radio, "The Howard Stern Show" consists largely of Mr. Stern and his sidekick, Robin Quivers, talking sex, ethnic humor, the news and whatever else happens to come to mind -- mostly complaints, about wife, staff, celebrities, politicians and the F.C.C. Guests drop by; Mr. Stern elicits whatever they have to plug and then moves on to personal matters, like asking the broadcaster Maury Povich whether his wife, the newscaster Connie Chung, "bows a lot" (because she is Asian) and when he first slept with her. When offended listeners call in to complain, Mr. Stern and Ms. Quivers put them on the air and then laugh them off. As fans point out, the show is unpredictable; Mr. Stern may talk to celebrities, do sketch comedy, berate his producer at length or, as he did on Election Day with the comedian Gilbert Gottfried, do lengthy riffs of Amos-'n'-Andy-like black voices.
The shock-jock style has been imitated around the country. It's the herpes simplex of radio formats, contagious and incurable, though rarely fatal. One of the funniest things about Mr. Stern's show, perhaps unintentionally, is his sincere declaration of his own "bold and brazen" genius. When other radio personalities (for instance, Soupy Sales or Bruce Morrow) express reservations about Mr. Stern's tastelessness, he takes long stretches of air time to denounce them. His show constantly alternates self-deprecation (about his appearance: "a big-nosed idiot with freaky hair") and self-importance. "I liberated radio," he proclaimed the other day. "Talk radio is not interesting, I am interesting, and people imitating me are even interesting." There's also an endearing touch of paranoia; on one show, he insisted that the F.C.C. complaint was instigated by competing stations.
Mr. Stern represents free speech as loose talk, forever in search of the taboo-tweaking line that will jolt a sleepy listener out of bed or distract a commuter from the traffic. He's an insult comedian, an heir to Don Rickles, who invokes sexist and ethnic stereotypes as if by reflex. And he presents himself as an equal-opportunity insulter, although he is far more likely to pick on blacks and women than he is on WASP's. (Perhaps he feels immunized because Ms. Quivers, who sometimes chides him gently, is black.)
Told that a black South African won the New York Marathon, he asks, "Was he carrying a TV?" Complaining about drug-related violence created by "third-world people," he advocates building a wall across the California-Mexico border. He also stokes AIDS hysteria; commenting on the fears of infection that made Magic Johnson retire from the National Basketball Association, he said, "I wouldn't breathe the same air as Magic." Yet talking about Colorado's anti-gay referendum, he said it was "frightening" that voters refuse to accept homosexuals as people.
Mr. Stern is also a bawdy comedian, using the same vocabulary Dr. Ruth Westheimer does, though with non-therapeutic intent. The F.C.C. fined Mr. Stern for talk about masturbation, defecation and related topics, under laws against broadcasting "indecent material at times when there is a reasonable risk that children may be in the audience." At one point, according to a transcript, Mr. Stern said, "Hey, F.C.C.: penis." And indecency, a slightly broader category than obscenity, is judged by whether the terms are "patently offensive" by community standards. But given Mr. Stern's high ratings in his many broadcast markets, his lawyers might well argue that community standards are the ones he represents, since, as he has pointed out, no one forces people to listen.
Whether or not children are tuned in is not the problem. The stubborn fact is that adults tune in by the thousands. Listeners are attracted by someone who snarls blunt opinions, any opinions, and doesn't worry about being undiplomatic or politically incorrect. In a time of economic frustration and suppressed rage, it's fun to have a designated target, even if the listener feels slimy afterward.
Just as important, for Mr. Stern's listeners, it seems to be a big thrill to hear someone with the authority of a radio announcer talk about breasts and genitalia, hubba hubba. Apparently vast numbers of listeners are, like Mr. Stern's humor, suffering from a case of arrested development that elevates gross-out jokes to a full-fledged world view.
That's not Mr. Stern's problem; it's America's. Mr. Stern didn't invent the adolescent male's disgusted fascination with genitalia and bodily fluids; he only capitalizes on it. American mass media offer sexual discourse from the sniggers of "Studs" to the "steamy" romances of soap operas to the clinical-therapeutic tones of Dr. Ruth to the adolescent boasts of heavy metal and rap. Despite the F.C.C.'s presumptions, plenty of people prefer the locker room. Under pressure, Mr. Stern may switch from anatomical vocabulary to euphemisms like "rocket of love." But until his audience grows up, his style won't go away.
