HEADLINE: FILM;
Neither Dracula Nor Rumor Frightens Coppola

BYLINE: By JANET MASLIN

 BODY:
Francis Ford Coppola once offered to share a waffle with a friend. Then he cut the waffle into the shape of a bow tie and tried to divide up the pieces. "That's the trouble with you," the friend said. "You can't just cut the thing in half." It is still the trouble with Mr. Coppola, or at least an example of his chronic inability to do anything simply. Asked to devise a "Dracula" with mass appeal, he has come up with the fanciest, most faithful Dracula movie ever made.
"Bram Stoker's Dracula," an extravagant parade of strange visual effects and stunning costumes starring Gary Oldman, Winona Ryder, Anthony Hopkins and Keanu Reeves, is the work of a man who could make an interesting-looking movie out of a menu. But why not "Francis Ford Coppola's Dracula"? "Because I don't think of stuff like this," said the director with a little laugh. Ensconced in a hotel tower on the Upper East Side of Manhattan last week, Mr. Coppola was preparing for a screening that would unveil the film to visiting journalists and would perhaps silence the cynics who have been calling it "The Bonfire of the Vampires." He appeared remarkably unworried about what might happen next. 
 The reason is this: Mr. Coppola has been so often savaged by the rumor mill that by now, at age 53, he takes almost anything in stride. Nothing could be worse than the "One From the Heart" debacle in 1982, when an early review based on an exhibitors' screening sank the film before it ever surfaced and brought Mr. Coppola a financial crisis that has lasted almost to this day. Advance stories of trouble also greeted "The Cotton Club" in 1984 and "The Godfather, Part III" in 1990.
"I guess when I was in the Philippines," he said of making "Apocalypse Now," another rumor-plagued production, "people thought of me as a crazy person, and then it became the thing to do just to make fun of me.
"I'm so grateful for Oliver Stone," he continued, "because he draws all the fire. Or Spike Lee. I hear them, and I think: 'Great, keep sayin' that stuff. Because then they won't pay any attention to me.' "
Less familiar than Mr. Coppola's reputation for profligacy is the fact that he has quietly developed into a cinematic gun-for-hire, a reliable professional capable of finishing the $45 million "Bram Stoker's Dracula" on budget and on time.
The film was shot on sound stages, which eliminated the danger posed by bad weather. And Mr. Coppola was "particularly concerned to prove that he could be a good citizen in terms of his responsibility report card," said Mark Canton, chairman of Columbia Pictures, which is distributing "Dracula." Mr. Coppola even sent Mr. Canton weekly progress reports to assure him that all was well.
Said Sid Ganis, the president of marketing and distribution for Columbia: "I think more and more people understand that Francis is as interested in the financial side of his work as he is in the artistic side."
Mr. Ganis has known the director since he worked for the company that distributed Mr. Coppola's "You're a Big Boy Now," in 1966. More recently, as a Paramount executive, he had firsthand knowledge of the director's working habits on "Tucker: The Man and His Dream" (1988), which Mr. Ganis said was on time and on budget, and "The Godfather, Part III," which was financially successful despite delays brought on by Winona Ryder's last-minute withdrawal from the cast. Even so, "Godfather III" made enough money to allow Mr. Coppola to put aside some savings -- a first, the director said -- and to bail his company, American Zoetrope, out of bankruptcy.
"The truth is I'm pretty good at that," Mr. Coppola maintained on the subject of fiscal responsibility. "They would never hire me a second time if all those stories were true. There aren't a lot of people who can handle big, complicated movies. And I also think they feel that I'm a flexible director, 'cause I can do a comedy or a horror film or a gangster film. So that's my edge that's allowed me to keep going."
Where he wants to go is in the opposite direction from what might be expected. "It's ironic that I would love to work in a much more modest area, one where I can find myself a little better," said the director, who says his fondest wish is to "be like a bohemian, wake up and have my coffee and read the paper and write my notes." His ability to do that any time soon depends on the success of this Dracula film, which, if successful, could finance Mr. Coppola's frequently imperiled American Zoetrope. The film, which has opened in about 2,400 theaters, was always conceived by all concerned as a mass-market entertainment.
Maybe so. But how will Mr. Coppola's intense, romantic, multilayered horror film play to teen-agers at the ten-plex? What will they make of its historical data on everything from turn-of-the-century technology to Vlad the Impaler (Romanian protector of Christian Europe against the Turkish army in 1452)? "God help me!" exclaimed Mr. Coppola, but he still looked cheerful. Asked for a brief characterization of the finished product, he said: "Very authentic to the book. Unusual, a little experimental. For me, fun."
After the relative success of his "Godfather, Part III," Mr. Coppola was contemplating filming a version of Jack Kerouac's "On the Road" when Ms. Ryder asked him to read a "Dracula" screenplay. He had known Bram Stoker's novel from his days as a teen-age camp counselor but was otherwise not on intimate terms with the subject. "To this day, I think that nobody could tell you the second half of the story of Dracula," said Mr. Coppola, who points out that all the many movie versions have thrown out large portions of this 1897 epistolary novel.
He liked James V. Hart's screenplay, decided he was game and was apparently a bit surprised when the studio gave this "Dracula" the go-ahead shortly thereafter. Part of what made the movie sound marketable was the idea of emphasizing the sultry side of the story (Mr. Coppola says he intended part of the film to look "like an erotic dream"). Another part of the plan was to cast the film with attractive young stars, so Ms. Ryder became Mina Murray, the prim young beauty who is the reincarnation of Dracula's lost love.
Cast rather improbably as Jonathan Harker, Mina's English fiance, is Keanu Reeves. "We tried to get some kind of matinee idol for the part of Jonathan, because it isn't such a great part," Mr. Coppola said. "If we all were to go to the airport with Winona and Gary Oldman and I and anyone shy of Tom Cruise, Keanu is the one that the girls would just besiege."
It is Mr. Oldman who plays Dracula, often from under a mountain of makeup and a heart-shaped white hairdo. He looked nothing like this when he stopped by the hotel room to wish Mr. Coppola good luck with the imminent trial by fire. "I hope you like it," Mr. Coppola said twice to his star, who had not yet seen the finished film. "Tonight we're gonna get a beautiful print, and everything is going to be perfect."
Mr. Oldman did not seem apprehensive about being revealed as a nontraditional, nontuxedoed Dracula, appearing in bat mufti and performing one gravity-defying slither in a long, trailing red silk robe. Anticipating a barrage of interview sessions, he said drily, "When they ask me questions, I can say I don't know what the film looks like, but I was there."
Mr. Coppola cast this daring but unlikely actor as Dracula for the same reasons, he said, that he first offered the role of Don Vito Corleone in "The Godfather" to Laurence Olivier: because he wanted the best actor he could find and felt the rest would somehow follow. He made equally offbeat choices for "Dracula" in enlisting Wojciech Kilar, a Polish composer whose work Mr. Coppola felt had a suitably Eastern European feel, and the costume designer Eiko Ishioka, whose museum-worthy designs for the film have become the basis for a coffee-table book. Costumes do not get any more exquisite than this.
Perhaps the director's most audacious choice was to pour much of the film's budget into these costumes and very little into the sets, on the theory that his young actors, the "jewels" of this production, would thus be shown off to best advantage.
Such allocations left little money for special effects, but that was not a problem. The film's many visual tricks are generally achieved inexpensively in the camera itself, through clever reverse images, double exposures and other remarkably quaint methods. The film thus offered not just a homage to the magic of turn-of-century photography but a job opportunity for "my boy Roman," as Mr. Coppola referred to his 27-year-old son, who is the film's visual effects director. Though eye rolling greeted the news that the director would be employing another one of his children (complaints about nepotism dogged his daughter, Sofia, when she replaced Ms. Ryder in "The Godfather, Part III"), Mr. Coppola proudly predicted that his son's work would be well received.
Still, those effects are peculiar, as is so much else about this lavish, busy film. And today's movie audiences have been so encouraged to expect the predictable -- a sequel mentality Mr. Coppola traces in part to his own "Godfather II" -- that they can't be counted on to choose the bow-tie waffle over the square one. "It's like giving unusual food to kids," said Mr. Coppola, about the difficulty in winning general acceptance for anything strange. "Maybe they'll say, 'I don't want to try that.' And maybe years later those same kids will say, 'Oh, I remember when I had that. I loved it.' "

HEADLINE: Charting the Future Of the Waterfront

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
IN subtle ways and sweeping ones -- like a clock face 120 feet wide -- the future of New York City's waterfront will be charted in coming months, even though its actual rebuilding may be many years away.
Prospects for a major renascence in the near future grew much dimmer on Election Day, when voters rejected a bond act that would have authorized New York State to borrow $800 million for public works. Tens of millions of dollars were earmarked for projects along the city's 578-mile shoreline. 
 But the City Planning Department is looking into the next century. In its first comprehensive waterfront plan -- covering bays, beaches, docks, esplanades, factories, housing projects, marinas, marine terminals, marshes, parks, piers, ports, rail yards and wetlands -- the agency identified more than two dozen possible sites for residential redevelopment. It also proposed new zoning rules for these districts, setting caps on building heights, requiring public access through private projects and limiting development rights from underwater lands. These rules must be approved by the City Planning Commission, which is to consider them early next year.
"We've tried to give clear signals on what we believe is appropriate on the waterfront and in what places," said Richard L. Schaffer, director of the City Planning Department and chairman of the City Planning Commission. "We're trying to get away -- by laying out a clear set of regulatory instructions -- from pitched battles over mega-developments on the waterfront."
Even as the rezoning measures are being drafted and debated, a number of projects advanced -- on paper, at least. Stephen Muss's Brighton-by-the-Sea development in Brooklyn won approval from the City Council in September. Donald J. Trump's Riverside South proposal was approved by the City Planning Commission last month and is to be voted on by the Council next month.
Another enormous project, Queens West, on the Hunters Point waterfront, took a small step forward in August, when the state Urban Development Corporation said it would review a proposal by a development team that includes affiliates of the Tekken Construction Company and Tobishima Corporation of Japan, the Dreyfus Corporation and the Zeckendorf Company.
TEN days ago, Venturi, Scott Brown & Associates and Anderson/Schwartz Architects won the competition for a new Staten Island Ferry terminal in Manhattan, a $112 million project by the city's Economic Development Corporation and Transportation Department. Already the talk of the town, the proposal calls for a giant illuminated clock above the ferry slips and a smaller clock as a gateway to Peter Minuit Plaza.
Meanwhile, a lease is being negotiated between the state and an operating company that plans to turn the Chelsea Piers, from 18th to 22d Streets in Manhattan, into a combination marina, skating rink, gymnasium, running track, golf driving range and movie and television studio. The partners in the operating company are Roland W. Betts, Tom A. Bernstein and David A. Tewksbury.
"I think it will be the first beat of the heart, if you will, that we hope will start pumping along the West Side," said Tom Fox, president of the Hudson River Park Conservancy, a subsidiary of the state Urban Development Corporation whose mission is to fulfill a 1990 plan for the West Side waterfront, between Battery Park City and 59th Street.
The plan includes a waterfront park, with an esplanade, public piers, bicycle and pedestrian paths. Along this park would be four major development sites: Pier 40, at Houston Street; the Chelsea Piers; Pier 76, at 36th Street, and Piers 81-84, around 42d Street.
Critics wonder whether development will stop there, however. Marcy Benstock, executive director of the Clear Air Campaign, said, "We remain afraid that if they did succeed in building infrastructure to support development in isolated nodes sticking out into the water, the nodes would be eventually connected and obliterate an environmentally critical stretch of the river."
The Clean Air Campaign, the New York Public Interest Research Group and other civic organizations have filed suit to overturn the formation of the Hudson River Park Conservancy and to halt any implementation of the plan until an environmental impact statement has been prepared.
But Mr. Fox said that it was premature to prepare an impact statement because the plan was still in a "conceptual" stage.
"We have all intentions of complying with all environmental requirements," Mr. Fox said. "We're committed to doing it. We're not trying to get around the process. We're trying to do it in a logical way."
The first parcel over which Mr. Fox's organization is to take control is the right-of-way through the Hudson River, from Battery Park City to 35th Street, where the landfill was to have gone for the Westway highway. But the city and state would have to repay $80 million that the Federal Government spent to acquire the property, unless local officials either obtain a waiver or scale back their riverfront plans significantly.
Another hurdle to development scenarios was the recent defeat of the $800 million bond act. Among the losers was the Harlem waterfront, which was to have benefited from $4.2 million for repair of the bulkhead, roadway improvements and other work.
Donald J. Cogsville, president of the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, said that while there were other encouraging signs, such as the plans by Circle Line to begin operating at 125th Street, the loss of the bond money "really has a huge effect."
"The public improvements that we would have been able to do would have accelerated development of the waterfront," he said.
The president of Circle Line and World Yacht, August J. Ceradini Jr., said the company remained committed to its project and expected to begin offering sightseeing trips and dinner cruises operating from a floating pier at 125th Street by April.
In dollar amounts, one of the biggest losers was a project to stabilize Piers 1 through 5, at the foot of Brooklyn Heights, which was to have received $11 million under the bond act.
These piers command some of the most spectacular views in New York City and a struggle has gone on for years between those who see them as a harborside park and those who imagine their potential as a residential enclave. Last July local officials and community leaders drew up a set of principles to guide development, in what they hoped would be a major step forward.
NOW they are less sure where they stand, since the piers must be shored up before anything else can happen. "The $11 million would have given us a leg up on any future development planning," said Marilyn Gelber, executive assistant to Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn. The defeat of the bond act, she said, "doesn't cancel out our plans and dreams, but it makes it more difficult."
Some delays seem to serve the city's purposes. For example, the badly stalled River Walk project on the East River, between 16th and 24th Streets, was officially pronounced dead this year as city officials removed the Related Companies as the developer.
River Walk, a residential and commercial complex, was to have been built on a platform and, Mr. Schaffer said, "We did not believe that it was appropriate to be building new piers or platforms over open water for the purpose of building new apartments or office buildings." However, new piers and platforms would be allowed for water-dependent uses and recreation.
The comprehensive plan pinpoints vacant land and manufacturing districts in which 25,000 to 50,000 housing units might be built, in addition to the 25,000 units in projects already approved. But planners also set aside six areas to be preserved for maritime and industrial use: Brooklyn, from Pier 6 to the Red Hook Containerport and from the Erie Basin to Owls Head; Staten Island, from Howland Hook to Snug Harbor; Port Morris and Hunts Point in the South Bronx; the Queens and Brooklyn shores of Newtown Creek and the Brooklyn Navy Yard.
"We're putting out the word that we want to hold the zoning in these areas," said Wilbur L. Woods, director of waterfront and open space at the planning agency.
In the areas that might be rezoned, planners have proposed limits on building heights, from 110 to 280 feet. They would also require that at least half of a building's total area be packed below a fixed height.
"We wanted to encourage low- to medium-rise buildings, avoiding walling off the waterfront with wide and tall buildings," said Marilyn Mammano, director of zoning and urban design at the planning agency.
In mid- to high-density residential and commercial projects, as well as large low-density residential developments, planners would require that 15 to 20 percent of the open space on the zoning lot be set aside for public access. This space would include a public area at least 40 feet wide running along the shoreline.
To make its case, the planning agency drew contrasting hypothetical buildings at a site overlooking Pot Cove, on the East River in Queens. The example given for existing zoning rules shows high slabs set apart from one another, with little access to the waterfront. The example of proposed zoning shows shorter buildings that cover much more of the property, with an ample esplanade.
As another key part of the zoning proposal, owners of property between the bulkhead line on shore and the pierhead line in the water would no longer be able to shift the development rights from those underwater parcels to their upland development sites, as Mr. Trump would have done for the Television City proposal that preceded his Riverside South plan. Owners would still be permitted, however, to exploit the development rights attributable to existing pier structures.
The public access requirements and the limits on development rights were "enthusiastically" endorsed by the private Parks Council, said the chairwoman of its waterfront committee, Jeannette G. Bamford.
BUT the Real Estate Board of New York said the rules would be crippling.
"The city must recognize that mandating public open space on private property, severely restricting the design of buildings and removing lands that generate floor area all have major implications on the feasibility of any development on the waterfront," said Michael Slattery, senior vice president of the board. "This radical approach is so extremely costly that without an up-front commitment of public funds to secure the public benefits, any development would prove unlikely."
He also took exception to the choice of potential redevelopment areas. "It seems that they went to sites that were noncontroversial or in existence," he said. "One wonders if they pushed harder whether they could have found more sites."
On the other hand, Ms. Benstock said planners created too many development opportunities. She believes that, contrary to their stated purpose, the new rules would encourage -- not discourage -- new piers and platforms, which would be built under the exemption for water-dependent uses and then converted to residential or commercial space.

HEADLINE: Talking: Investments;
Buying Rental Property

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
WITH interest rates lower than they have been for 20 years and foreclosures still glutting the market, could this be a good time to buy rental property?
An informal poll of about a dozen brokers suggests that only a few brave souls agree. But for contrarians willing to take the plunge there's a whole new universe of expectations and strategies compared to the high flying days of the 1980's. 
 Gone are many of the tax incentives and the wild expectations of quick appreciation and the notion that it's possible to consider a relatively short holding period -- say, three to five years. Gone, too, is the expectation that it can all be accomplished with very little upfront cash.
What can make it really worthwhile this time, say those who are investing, is the positive cash flow, or yield.
Either the property can generate a higher return on capital than is currently available from other investments, such as certificates of deposit or stocks, or -- by the time the investor retires or has children going off to college -- the rental income will have grown to the point where it can serve as a pension or a welcome boost to earnings.
This has been the approach of Bob Kirkland of Virginia Beach, Va. He has been buying condominiums whenever he can pick them up at a price that more or less covers his monthly overhead, at least to start out, he said. He uses any profit he can generate to pay off the mortgage as fast as possible.
Thus, by the time he retires he expects the properties to be virtually debt-free and able to provide him with a comfortable pension.
Most of the current breed of savvy investors say it is imperative to become a bottom-fisher. As a protection against a possible further dip even more, "they want something that's not going to drop even farther," said Rita Cohen, president of Prudential Rita Cohen Realty in White Plains.
The potential investor may be well served by seeking out those larger regional estate agencies that sell a substantial number of foreclosed properties. Another good source are real estate agencies that deal heavily in the relocation market. Dozens of corporations, and their representatives, have also been stuck with an unacceptably high number of unsold homes and are better able to accept a low price than are most private sellers.
An even better deal, say investors, is to seek properties that lenders are unwilling to finance under any circumstances -- such as certain New York City co-ops or a condominium in an association that already has a large number of investor-owned units. These have already been marked down to substantially below market as a consequence of their status as pariahs.
But to make it work may mean paying all cash. Yet doing so may not turn out to be that much of a deterrent. Consider Patrick Mitchell of Hamden, Conn., an apprentice with United Technologies. His preference has been for condominium units that have been repossessed by the banks, since he maintains they go for the lowest prices.
To find them, he has developed a close relationship with several lenders in the area that handle a large number of foreclosed properties. Mr. Mitchell has also focused on large, three-bedroom units. Proportionate to the cost, he finds they generate higher rents.
The secret of good bargaining, he says, is being able to walk away ("never fall in love with anything"). He insists he has also learned the value of patience and persistence.
"I start out with a very low offer," he said, "even if I know I will be turned down. But then I wait. And I wait. And I go back with the same offer, sometimes months later."
Using this approach, and with help from his family, he has bought three three-bedroom condominiums in a modest-income neighborhood in Hamden for under $30,000 each over the last six months. Being able to offer all cash was definitely an advantage, he maintained.
INDEED, certain units eventually sell for such rock bottom prices because of the reluctance of lenders to provide financing. Though most lenders maintain they are willing to make loans on virtually any property, their strict criteria end up excluding not only many of the units but also the bulk of the potential buyers, too.
Today, most lenders require a down payment of at least 30 percent for an investor loan, said Paul Havemann, vice president of HSH Associates of Butler, N.J., a company that monitors lending policies nationwide. They also charge a higher interest rate and more points than for a property being occupied by the owner.
Take Arbor National Mortgage of Westbury, L.I. It requires investors to put down a minimum of 30 percent and pay an extra 1.5 percent in points. It has a loan limit of $202,300 on one-family homes and $388,800 on a four-family. No co-ops are allowed. Similarly, the Dime Savings Bank of New York will not lend on a condominium if more than 50 percent of the units in the complex are already owned by investors.
At Arbor, the borrower's income is also being tightly scrutinized to see how much of the debt load the person could carry, irrespective of the rental income. And approval is taking twice as long as a loan for a personal residence, or about six to eight weeks.
Even so, a lender who may have been holding a property in inventory, following a foreclosure, might be persuaded to offer slightly more attractive terms just to get the property off its list of nonperforming loans. So you should always attempt to negotiate better terms, said Mr. Havemann.
Even accepting those terms may not be all that bad. Anthony Girardi, an ophthamologist in Glen Cove, L.I., is using one of these kinds of investor loans to buy a two-family house in Lynbrook, L.I., lessening the burden by going into partnership with his brother and doing the repairs himself.
Though it will mean that the brothers will not have a positive cash flow at first, he said, they will not be generating a loss. Moreover, they are buying for the long term, he added, in an area where they believe values have bottomed out and rentals are strong and on the rise.
But he said they were careful to take out a 15-year loan so his mortgage will be paid off by the time his children are ready for college. At that point, he said, the brothers plan plan either to use the income to help pay tuition or refinance the property and use the money thus freed for their tuition.

HEADLINE: Horticulture Gaining as a Career Option

BYLINE: By ELISABETH GINSBURG

 BODY:
TWO years ago, Carole Anderson of Florham Park was a travel agent. Elizabeth Staley of Morristown was a housewife who spent every spare moment in her garden. Now both are studying for two-year degrees in landscape design.
When she is not in class, Ms. Staley works as an assistant horticulturalist at a large garden center, and Ms. Anderson has already begun as a consultant on residential landscaping projects. Both are eager to move ahead into their new lives. "I want to get out and do this now," Ms. Anderson said. 
 The two women are part of a green wave -- people who have turned their backs on established careers or redirected their lives to enter the world of horticulture. Many are women, and what makes them different from other career changers is the emotional satisfaction they derive from their new lives.
By turning a hobby into a vocation, these new horticulturists have found a calling. "This is something I can do until I'm 90 years old," said Barbara J. Palmer, a journalist turned landscape designer.
Even in the midst of a recession, these career changers are finding jobs. Many students in the landscape management and design and agribusiness programs at the County College of Morris receive job offers before they finish their courses. Maureen Heffernan of the American Horticultural Society's garden information service described a nationwide shortage of horticulturalists and said, "If you have a B.S. in horticulture, the jobs are there."
 
More Than Growing Flowers
 Even fields like landscape architecture and the commercial nursery business, which have suffered along with the construction industry, may soon see a resurgence. The Federal Department of Labor has identified landscape architecture as a growth area for the 90's.
As a vocation, horticulture is an umbrella term covering fields like landscape architecture, agriculture, environmental work and gardening as therapy. The variety of educational programs that prepare students for these careers is equally wide. Two-year institutions like the County College of Morris and Cumberland County College offer degrees in "green" subject areas like agribusiness and landscape design.
Career changers lacking the time or inclination to earn a degree can enter certain fields by taking specific courses at the two-year schools or by earning certificates at institutions like the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Other horticultural career fields require four-year degrees or graduate work.
Cook College at Rutgers University is the only accredited college in the state that offers degrees in landscape architecture. Students at Ramapo College of New Jersey can earn a bachelor's degree in biology with an emphasis on plant science.
Adults are entering these institutions in significant numbers. Prof. Phillip Edgecombe of the County College of Morris says that the total enrollment in its horticultural courses has almost doubled over the last five years, to about 100 students. About 40 current students at the college are career changers over 30 years old, and 25 of those are women.
Last year, New Jersey residents accounted for about 14 percent of the New York Botanical Garden's 6,000 registrations. Susan Greenstein of the garden's adult education department said most registrants were probably career changers.
At Cumberland County College, which had a record enrollment of 43 day or evening students in horticultural subjects in 1990, 7 of the 12 students now taking the required fundamentals of horticulture course have come from other career fields. In Rutgers's landscape architecture program, 10 to 15 percent of the students are what Prof. Roy Deboer calls "second degree people."
In some cases, it is possible to start a horticultural career without going near an ivy-covered wall.
Two years ago, John Horwath of Wallington was a self-employed commodities broker caught in the general economic slump. His cousin was dating a landscaping contractor, and Mr. Horwath asked if the landscaper had any openings.
Now, with 24 months' experience, the Wallington man is the foreman of a landscape construction crew that is making a park and wildlife habitat out of a former landfill in the Hackensack Meadowlands.
Though he has taken a 75 percent pay cut, Mr. Horwath said the healthy outdoor life "gets into your blood after a while." When the economy improves, he said, he may even combine his old and new careers, installing greenery by day while trading commodities at night.
Career changers sometimes find permanent jobs through on-the-job training, which some institutions also require as part of a degree program. Barry Yinger, superintendent of horticultural services for the Somerset County Park Department, called such hands-on experience "an excellent way to enter the horticultural field." Students who have done field work have an edge in the job market, because they have a proven track record, Professor Edgecombe said.
Pay for on-the-job training is usually low (from $4.25 an hour, the minimum wage, to $8 an hour). Also, because of budget cutbacks, New Jersey horticulture students may have trouble finding such jobs in public parks and gardens and state-supported institutions.
Joanne DiLorenzo, a landscape architect with the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission who apprenticed at the commission, said, "If we had money, we would always have a trainee, but right now, finances are terrible."
Mr. Yinger said his Somerset County department offered four paid training jobs last summer, but he was unable to say whether any would be available in 1993. For those with other sources of income, Mr. Yinger noted that unpaid apprenticeships are always an option.
Why do people abandon steady paychecks for a return to the classroom, a low-paying or volunteer apprenticeship and a future full of dirty fingernails?
"I was burned out," said Ms. Palmer of Maplewood, the former journalist. Trying to balance her family's needs with the demands of freelance writing at home ended up being unworkable for Ms. Palmer. Now, with certificates in commercial horticulture and landscape design from the New York Botanical Garden, she runs a landscape consulting business, writes a garden column for a local newspaper chain and teaches gardening at a local adult school.
Many career changers, like Ms. Staley, began as recreational gardeners. Ms. Anderson and her County College of Morris classmate, Pat Mills of Long Valley, also worked on volunteer projects in their hometowns. Ms. Mills, an art historian and housewife, was working with her town's shade tree committee when she first looked through the trees and saw a forest of career possibilities.
Some career changes come to horticulture looking for the freedom and flexibilty of self-employment. Others, like Ms. DiLorenzo, a former computer software designer, fell into various occupations after high school or college. With years of work and life experience behind them, many are ready to make a living at something closer to the heart.
Women making the change also have more role models now than in years past. All three landscape architects at the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission are women. The enthusiastic women in the County College of Morris program are taught by an equally enthusiastic associate professor, Jan-Marie Traynor.
Nine of New Jersey's 28 individual members of the American Association of Botanical Gardens and Arboreta are women. Women also hold top executive positions at seven of the nine New Jersey institutions belonging to that group.
 
Seen as a Lasting Trend
 It is possible that horticulture will be to the 90's what financial services were to the 80's -- a hot career field -- but New Jersey experts think the trend will be more lasting.
Dr. Joseph Dallon, professor of biology at Ramapo College, says that when people become fully aware of the possibilities in horticulture, the field will become even more attractive. Students looking for the ultimate creative act can take part in saving endangered plant species by culturing tissue from a lone surviving plant. Landscape architects like Ms. DiLorenzo can work environmental alchemy by transforming landfills into wildlife habitats.
Rhonda Daidone of Netcong is typical of many of the career changers who have found a sense of vitality and renewal in their new occupations. After surviving two bouts with Hodgkin's disease, the former American Telephone and Telegraph Company employee is studying horticulture with the goal of working for the Environmental Protection Agency.
She spoke for more than one of her green colleagues when she said, "Horticulture definitely helps keep you healthy."

HEADLINE: Port Chester Seeks An Earlier Last Call

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: PORT CHESTER

 BODY:
AT 2:10 A.M., traffic inches south on Route 1 heading into this village on the border with Connecticut. Just 15 minutes earlier, "Last call" had been issued in bars throughout Connecticut, and now hundreds of cars were joining the Sunday morning exodus to Westchester, where bars remain open until 4 A.M. On summer nights and during holidays, the police say they have often counted more than 2,000 cars coming down Route 1.
These young, affluent residents of Stamford and Greenwich are heading for places like Marty's, the Beat and 7 Willow Street, already filled with Westchester County residents. In 7 Willow Street, which throbs to the melodic funk sound of the Groove Tubes, strobe lights sweep over a bar dispensing Jell-O shots, a mix of vodka and Jell-O. A barmaid here, wearing a skin-tight outfit revealing her midriff, pours Jack Daniels over a three-foot-long "ski bar," or slide, made of ice. Patrons waiting with cups below receive a whisky slush.
 
Like Fort Lauderdale in Spring
 But now, the village that claims both the highest number of bars and the most drunken driving arrests per capita in the county wants to call a halt to the party scene, which the police say has turned downtown Port Chester into a scene reminiscent of spring break in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. 
 In a move led by Mayor Peter Iasillo and unanimously endorsed by the village's six trustees, Port Chester has proposed that all Westchester municipalities require bars to close at 2 A.M., thus matching Connecticut's closing hour. Under state law, bar hours must be uniform in each county, and although bar owners may close as early as they want, individual municipalities do not have the power to set their own bar hours.
Since the proposal was announced last June, it has been endorsed by 13 municipalities, and several other communities have scheduled hearings, including one next week in Hastings-on-Hudson. Communities already in support include Larchmont, Pelham, Pelham Manor, Lewisboro, the village of Mamaroneck, the town of Mamaroneck, Somers, Rye Brook, Bedford, Tarrytown, North Tarrytown and New Rochelle.
 
Municipal and County Support
 The movement appears to be gaining momentum, and municipal officials and tavern owners are scheduled to meet next week with the Housing and Community Affairs Committee of the Westchester Board of Legislators to discuss the issue. Legislators Audrey G. Hochberg and Martin L. Rogowsky, both Democrats, have co-sponsored a resolution calling on the Board to support Port Chester's effort. The measure has already received strong support from the Board's chairman, Stephen P. Tenore, and Katherine S. Carsky, both Republicans.
But municipal and county pressure is unlikely to get bar hours changed. Under state law, any decision to change bar hours in Westchester requires the unanimous consent of the local Alcohol Beverage Control Board, the body that issues and renews liquor licenses on behalf of the State Liquor Authority. One of the two commissioners on that board has already commented unfavorably on the proposal.
"Drunk driving is not controlled by closing two hours earlier," said Thomas G. McSpedon, the Democratic representative appointed by the New York State Liquor Authority. Calling Port Chester's problem "a local issue which police should handle," Mr. McSpedon said the board planned a public hearing on the matter shortly. "I'm keeping an open mind," he said.
 
Reduced Hours Would Hurt Business
 Mr. McSpedon, the retired chapter manager of the Westchester County National Electrical Contractors Association, is completing his 15th year on the board. He said the issue had been reviewed in 1985, prompted by problems in New Rochelle. He opposed any change at that time, Mr. McSpedon said, adding that tavern owners had argued that reduced hours would force many out of business.
Support for the Port Chester proposal is "a minority viewpoint," Mr. McSpedon said, adding that the county's southern cities, other than New Rochelle, are reluctant to support a plan that would encourage young residents to go to New York City to drink. "This is not a countywide problem," he said. "Why penalize everyone?"
John Nanna, former Mayor of Dobbs Ferry, is the Republican appointed to the Commission by Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke. "We understand community concern," he said, adding that he wondered if an earlier closing "would drive our young people to New York City." He has not made up his mind on the issue, Mr. Nanna said, adding, "Both of us are flexible."
With 30 bars concentrated in the heart of this village of 24,750, Port Chester has long attracted youthful partygoers from Connecticut and Westchester, especially in the days when the drinking age in New York was 18 while Connecticut's legal drinking age was 21. The overcrowded bar scene made national headlines in 1973 when 24 patrons died in a fire at Gulliver's, a popular night spot
But a recent crop of new establishments catering to an even younger crowd has produced problems that residents, merchants and Mayor Iasillo agree cannot be ignored. "They come out of these places in a drunken stupor, rip branches off the trees, urinate in front of our retail shops and destroy property," Mr. Iasillo said. "Our retail merchants are rightfully outraged."
 
From as Far Away as Hartford
 While he is mindful of the impact on tavern owners who are providing needed economic stimulus to the village, Mr. Iasillo said: "They say 2 to 4 A.M. is when they make all their money. I may agree, but they don't understand 2 to 4 A.M. is when we have all our problems."
Port Chester police made 210 arrests for drunken driving during the first six months of this year, with 164 arrests being made after 3 A.M., said the Police Chief, Carl P. Verrastro. Half of those arrested were between the ages of 21 and 29, and half drove cars with out-of-state licenses, some from as far away as Hartford and New Haven.
Because the village police department does not have the manpower to run sobriety checkpoints, most of those were arrested, Chief Verrastro said, "because we bump into them on the street" or because they are involved in automobile accidents.
The large number of arrests has "crippled our court system," Chief Verrastro said, forcing overworked judges to accept an unusually high number of plea bargains. Pleading to a lesser charge of "driving while ability is impaired," he said, is "less than a misdemeanor," a plea that can be entered an unlimited number of times. A second charge of driving while intoxicated can be treated as a felony.
"Some of these kids have rap sheets eight feet long," Chief Verrastro said, adding that he sympathizes with judges. "A village court should not have a court calendar with 100 cases a day," he said, adding, "How can the court properly dispense justice under these conditions? This is not the way suburban Westchester is supposed to be."
The police chief could find just as many drunken drivers leaving a wedding, said Martin Kasmarsky, the owner of Marty's on Adee Street. "He should sit in front of a place where they are having a reception, and he would get just as many D.W.I.'s," Mr. Kasmarsky said, adding that he doubts that police statistics on the amount of traffic coming to Port Chester are accurate.
"I don't see a huge influx after 2 A.M.," Mr. Kasmarsky said, adding that although he doesn't depend on the last two hours, "it makes a difference." Reducing hours, he said, will have a domino effect on Port Chester's economy, throwing area musicians and late-night restaurants out of business.
Port Chester's current problems are caused by a few "badly managed places that are giving the rest of us a bad name," Mr. Kasmarsky said, adding that recent state cutbacks have prevented the Alcohol Control Board from timely enforcement of drinking laws in those establishments.
The village has "two categories of bars," said another owner, who refused to give his name. "If I let people do what they wanted, I'd make a lot more," he said, adding, "There's a lot of money to be made, especially if I.D.'s aren't checked and if drug dealing is going on."
If such places exist, they are few in number, said Scott Wexler, executive director of the United Restaurant, Hotel, Tavern Association of New York State, which represents 2,000 members, including 250 in Westchester. "One or two bad places," he said, "make problems for all," adding that his association has lobbied for more money for enforcement.
"We are adamantly opposed to the 2 A.M. closing hour," Mr. Wexler said, adding that better enforcement procedures would separate "the good guys from the bad." "We should focus on the specific problem and reject greater restrictions on the entire industry," Mr. Wexler said.
Imposing more restricted bar hours in Westchester, he said, won't solve the county's border-crossing problem, Mr. Wexler said. "If we change to 2 A.M., we will just move the problem to New York City. Closing earlier won't change the behavior of people -- it will only change the time in which they behave that way."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Small Stocks Are Loved, but For How Long?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Stock prices in America have been surging upward since bottoming this summer, and to some it looks as though the bull market is back.
To those who focus on the Dow Jones industrial average, the above statement looks downright absurd. Rarely has the action on the Dow seemed more boring than it has in recent months, and 1992 is bidding to be the year with the smallest moves in that index of any since World War II. 
 But in the wild land of small stocks, the speculative juices have again started to flow. The Nasdaq composite index is up 16 percent since it hit bottom on June 26. Over the same stretch, the Dow is off a bit. Nasdaq daily volume often exceeds turnover on the New York Stock Exchange, and on Wednesday 273 million shares were traded in the over-the-counter market. That is the highest level in years, and not far from the record of 288 million set during the 1987 crash.
"Everyone knows that small stocks are the place to be," commented Robert Farrell, the chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch and a man who feels nervous when he sees such unanimity of opinion.
Wall Street is always good at explaining moves after they occur, and there are plenty of reasons offered for this one. Bill Clinton's election is one. "In both 1960 and 1976, Democrats replaced Republicans in the White House," noted Robert B. Ritter, a technical analyst at Ladenburg, Thalman. "Both times, small growth stocks did very well."
It is not clear why Bill Clinton should be good news for small stocks. His election may eventually break the Congressional logjam and allow the capital gains tax rate to be reduced, but he has shown more sympathy for investors who start companies than for those who buy shares in public trading.
Others say that with European economies weak and a trade war looming, it is a good time to avoid larger stocks, which are more likely to have international operations.
One clear factor was the negative sentiment of recent months. Money managers let cash build up in aggressive growth mutual funds, and short-sellers borrowed a record number of shares traded on Nasdaq, each betting that prices would soon be lower. Both groups have scrambled for cover, helping to push prices up.
The move has not been universal. Industrial stocks have lagged, but high-technology stocks and those that have growth stories to tell have been leaping. And enthusiasm is growing, with hopes that buyers will seek to take advantage of the so-called January effect, which calls for small stocks to soar early in the new year.
"Secretaries, friends and relatives are calling and asking what my favorite idea is, and how much I think it will rise in the next several months," said Kurt Feuerman, who watches emerging growth stocks for Morgan Stanley. But valuations for quality growth stocks are now very high, he said, and last week he recommended that investors in such stocks take some profits.

HEADLINE: Beyond the PC: Apple's Promised Land

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

DATELINE: CUPERTINO, Calif.

 BODY:
JOHN SCULLEY wants to become the apostle of the information age. From Japan to Hollywood to Germany, the chairman of Apple Computer Inc. has been preaching about a post-industrial promised land where four giant industries -- computers, consumer electronics, communications and information -- will converge. Picture an affordable electronic personal assistant that fits in your hand and works anywhere. It not only has all the functions of a computer -- calculating, word processing and tapping into data bases anywhere in the world -- but also acts as a television, telephone, note taker (you can use a pen or your voice), fax machine, mailbox, appointment calendar and even a sketch pad for artists and designers.
Cerebral and soft-spoken, sounding more like a college professor than an evangelist, Mr. Sculley describes an emerging industry that he says will be a $3.5 trillion business within a decade. It will, he says, be more than half as large as the combined economies of the United States, Canada and Mexico are today. 
 Instead of fire and brimstone, Mr. Sculley uses technology to dazzle his audiences. He surrounds himself with tools he says will make Apple the company that defines this emerging industry. There is a prototype of the first generation of the electronic assistant. There is Powerbook, Apple's hot-selling four- to seven-pound portable computer that next year will offer telecommunications features (answering phone calls and storing messages). There is the new Macintosh that can now play movies and music as well as display text, and combine the different media in educational and entertaining presentations.
"We're on the threshold," he tells his listeners.
 
The Risks Ahead
 It is a vision that leaves some industry people skeptical. Here, after all, is a man who was trained as an architect and made his name selling soft drinks. They wonder: Will he create an unwieldy conglomeration of divisions that end up stealing business from each other, as happened at I.B.M. and Digital Equipment, or that stretch the company too thin, as happened at Sun Microsystems before it refocused itself? And, they wonder, will Apple's coming products really reach Mr. Sculley's goal? Will the company persuade enough software developers to accept its vision, as it did with the Macintosh eight years ago?
Finally, will Apple lose this market to other tough competitors, including Microsoft, the company whose software gives computers the same functions that the Apple Macintoshes do and that has proven adept at imitating each Apple innovation and then capturing most of the market.
Indeed, the Cupertino, Calif., company's stock sells at a price-to-earnings ratio of just 12.9, far below rival Compaq's 18.7 and Dell's 20.2, partly because many investors think the company will not be able to differentiate itself enough from others to maintain comfortable margins.
"What they're doing is unbelievably gutsy," said Paul Saffo, a consultant at the Institute for the Future in Menlo Park, Calif. "The PC industry is dead and the only thing you can do is aggressively cross the chasm into the next world. But Apple could have the right vision and still fail."
Nevertheless, Mr. Sculley, who was ridiculed upon taking the title of Apple's chief technology officer two years ago, is being taken a lot more seriously now. His success recently in turning around Apple has made him hard to ignore.
Surprising many industry executives who thought the company could not survive the brutal personal-computer price wars, he has overseen a comeback so strong that this year Apple will pass I.B.M. to become the market-share leader in the United States PC industry.
Apple's Powerbook line of notebook PC's, introduced just a year ago, has become the hottest product in the industry; sales have already exceeded $1 billion. Apple now leads the notebook market in the United States, making inroads in corporate America, where the company had never succeeded. And after steep price cuts in the past two years, sales of the desktop Macintosh have taken off.
While Apple's gross profit margins -- revenue minus cost of goods sold as a percentage of revenue -- have been slashed from the mid-50 percent level two years ago to just over 40 percent in recent quarters because of the price cutting, Apple's unique Macintosh software has helped it avoid the worst of the PC industry price wars, where margins for competitors like Compaq and Dell have plunged below 30 percent.
Holding employment at just below 15,000, Apple has added almost $2 billion in revenue in three years, to $7.08 billion in the year that ended Sept. 25. And Apple is now sitting on $1.5 billion in cash.
Finally, Apple appears at last to be building a management team that can function without turmoil. In particular, Mr. Sculley has established a strong partnership with Michael Spindler, Apple's president and chief operating officer.
 
A View of the 90's
 But Mr. Sculley has only just begun. At the age of 53, nearing the end of a full decade at Apple, he has been widely reported to be a candidate for a post in President-elect Bill Clinton's Administration. In fact, Mr. Sculley was briefly considered for the Vice Presidential position on the Democratic ticket.
Mr. Sculley, however, says he has no interest in politics -- the Vice Presidential talk was "ridiculous," he said -- and focuses instead on his vision for Apple. The marketing wizard who oversaw the resurrection of the Pepsi Generation is now doing the same for coming generations of Apples.
Looking into the later 1990's, Mr. Sculley paints a picture of winners and losers very different from those in the past decade. He sees the personal computer industry no longer growing rapidly, and thinks the next generations of machines will be so versatile that people will think of them not as computers but as appliances.
Once the company has an electronic umbilical cord to its customers, it can generate additional revenue by offering telecommunications services like travel information, home-shopping services and a variety of business services like electronic mail. It is a logic understood by A.T.&T., which Mr. Sculley thinks is well positioned to capitalize on the coming together of the computing, telecommunications, consumer electronics and information fields. (A.T.&T.'s plans, page 5.)
With this in mind, Mr. Sculley is changing Apple Computer from a company with a single focus on desktop computing to a cluster of related businesses. "We believe that we will be an entirely different kind of company in two years," he said.
The resulting Apple Computer will be selling from three principal divisions. One is the current Macintosh Systems division. The second, whose products will begin appearing this winter, is Enterprise Systems, selling more powerful computers known as servers that effectively replace mainframes in performing company-wide computing. The third is the Personal Interactive Electronics division, also known as Apple PIE, which will produce portable products, starting in the middle of next year with the Newton.
Mr. Sculley describes Newton as a personal digital assistant. Selling for what analysts expect will be between $700 and $1,000, it is a palm-sized electronic calendar and organizer into which notes can be entered using a stylus and from which facsimiles can be sent and received. Later in 1993, Apple expects to introduce a wireless version of the Newton.
Apple PIE is working on two other kinds of products. One is multimedia products, about which the company has said little, that will allow the viewing of entertainment and educational programs. The other is data services that will allow Macintosh users to tap various Apple data bases and to shop through electronic catalogues. The idea is that Apple will derive significant revenues from services providing information.
Apple executives say they realize that the new strategy will succeed only to the degree that the company can do a better job of making its products from its three divisions easier to use and better at communicating with each other than those of rivals.
The risk, said Jonathan Seybold, an industry consultant and publisher, is that Apple awaits the fate of almost all the computer companies that have attempted to make the jump from one generation of technology to the next. They have either lost their focus trying to sustain a variety of incompatible systems or have been unwilling to let the new generation cannibalize sales of the earlier one. During the 1960's, mainframe companies failed to become minicomputer makers; in the 1980's, minicomputer companies were overwhelmed by the rise of the personal computer. Only I.B.M. has been able to span generational changes in technology, and now even the world's largest computer maker appears to be foundering on the rapid developments brought about by the computer-on-a-chip called the microprocessor.
Apple "may wind up trying to ride two horses," said Mark Stahlman, an industry consultant at New Media Associates in New York City. "The problem they face is controlling both horses so they don't fall off or lose control of either or both."
Furthermore, Apple could face confusion and disappointment with its coming products. For example, after announcing its new hand-held machines, including the Newton, at the giant consumer electronics shows in January and May, the company now realizes that it created confusion in its choice of consumer shows for the unveilings. The choice led to expectations in the industry that Apple was pressing to build consumer electronics products that would sell for under $500 and show up under the Christmas tree.
But in September Mr. Sculley told industry executives that Apple had no intention of entering consumer electronics markets with its electronic assistants just yet. The shift led to consternation among Apple watchers, many of whom concluded that the company had decided it had promised too much with the Newton and was now backpedaling.
Although Apple has licensed its Newton technology to two Japanese consumer electronics giants (Toshiba and Sharp), and despite the forum that Apple chose for the Newton announcement, Mr. Sculley insists the company intends to target its first Newtons at the business market.
 
Possible Misjudgment
 But three factors -- the confusing shift in strategy, a delay in introduction (the first Newton was originally scheduled to be available early next year, rather than mid-year) and the possibility that the product might not perform well enough or have enough features to attract a large market -- have led some executives in the industry to suggest that Apple has misjudged the difficulties of expanding beyond the PC market.
"To me it's a bust," said Daniel Farber, editor of PC Week, a weekly computer industry magazine. "They rolled it out too soon and it's just going to be an electronic note taker. That's not going to satisfy anyone."
Finally, Apple faces the challenge of creating an environment that encourages other companies to endorse its vision. It succeeded at that when it introduced the Macintosh in 1984, encouraging software developers to write programs for its new machines.
This time, there is a debate within and outside Apple over how accessible to make Apple PIE products like the Newton to other developers whose support will be crucial to their success. Mr. Sculley knows that to succeed such products will require many kinds of attractively priced software, like electronic books, interactive videos and digital reference materials.
Indeed, Mr. Sculley has been spending time in Hollywood, looking for deals with entertainment companies. Michael Ovitz, chairman of the Creative Artists Agency, is a friend who spends time with Mr. Sculley discussing the coming transformation. "We both know that we're on an inevitable course of computing moving toward the entertainment business, and entertainment moving toward computing," Mr. Sculley said.
But Apple has not had an easy time persuading traditional publishers to ally themselves with the Newton effort. Not only are publishers still timid about the risks of new electronic media -- including potential piracy problems -- they are increasingly concerned that Apple will jump into the publishing business itself, competing with them.
The recent arrival of Gaston Bastiaens, who left Philips to head the Apple PIE division last summer, has evidently extended the controversy to Apple itself. He has reportedly pressed the notion of owning entertainment and information software.
Mr. Bastiaens was not available for comment, but several people inside and outside the company said he has argued for a strategy similar to Philips's and Nintendo's, under which the computer maker would largely control the content for Newtons.
 
Controlling the Content
 Mr. Sculley said Apple may not need to own such content but should play a role in its packaging and presentation.
Some multimedia experts say such a strategy could backfire.
"I think it would be a gigantic mistake for Apple to attempt to control content," said Denise Caruso, editor of Digital Media, a San Francisco-based industry newsletter. "It could drive the publishers out of digital media completely, or even worse, it will drive them right up to Microsoft," which is trying to build a similar business on top of its Windows software.
Mr. Sculley agrees that there will be much uncertainty and even chaos as his industry changes. But he says Apple, more than almost any other company, will be able to gain in this environment. He cites its recent success against price-warring rivals.
"The best thing that ever happened to Apple," he said, "is the crisis in the computer industry."
 
 
 
SCULLEY COMES INTO HIS OWN
 APPLE COMPUTER, at about $7 billion in revenue, has reached the size that Pepsico was when John Sculley left that company almost a decade ago. It is a size, Mr. Sculley says, that enables him to do a lot more of what he's good at.
"I'm starting to have the impact on this company that a C.E.O. should have," he said. "During the 1980's, I would have never thought of putting the kinds of management structure in place that I am now."
Mr. Sculley has brought in veteran managers, implemented a standard development process for every Apple product, and pushed autonomy downward by giving lower-level managers budget responsibility.
Evidence that Apple's new organizational structure is delivering was best seen earlier this year in the company's ability to quickly develop an unplanned version of its Macintosh LC for the educational market on just five months' notice. The machine, the LC II, has sold more than 460,000 units at about $1,500 each since its introduction last spring.
There's another way that Apple may just now be becoming the kind of company that its co-founder, Steve Jobs, hired Mr. Sculley to run. "I was hired because the belief was that Apple was going to be a home computer company," Mr. Sculley said. But once he arrived the company found there was no home market. Apple instead scrambled to grow in the education and small-business markets. "I was incredibly unprepared," he said.
Today, Apple is finally ready to enter the home market. In October alone, Apple doubled the number of retail outlets through which it sells, to 4,000 from 2,000, and the company says its home-targeted Performa machine is selling strongly.

HEADLINE: An Economy That Will Test Clinton's Pledge on Jobs

BYLINE: By JOEL KURTZMAN

 BODY:
It sounded like a promise from the campaign stump. President-elect Bill Clinton told a news conference last week that "I will ask the Congress to adopt an investment tax credit that I have been advocating for well over a year now to give the private sector incentives to go out and invest in new plant and equipment and to increase their capacity to hire." That one proposal, Mr. Clinton said, could create half a million new jobs in the first year alone. Even more jobs could be created, he said, by accelerating investment in the infrastructure.
At first blush the logic seems straightforward enough: tax credits from Washington create incentives for entrepreneurs to start companies and hire workers and for existing companies to buy equipment. Spending on the infrastructure leads to more hiring. The unemployment rate -- now 7.4 percent -- falls as more people find work. 
 But economists caution that creating a new-jobs bonanza in a sluggish economy -- even with the use of incentives -- may not be as easy as Mr. Clinton suggests. Economists further warn that the incentives Mr. Clinton has proposed -- an investment tax credit for businesses, increased government spending and tax credits for education and training, and $20 billion a year over four years in spending on the infrastructure -- may simply not be enough to perk up a sagging $6 trillion economy. And with the economy awash in debt and consumers watching their wallets, the incentives may not be sufficient to jog budding entrepreneurs into action. "The animal spirits of the entrepreneurs are very damp right now," said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company.
Further, because much of the money Mr. Clinton has proposed to stimulate the economy and provide jobs will be taken from other programs -- the military, principally -- rather than from new sources of revenue, the impact on growth from the spending may be minimal. "Clinton's program was the most growth oriented of the candidates', but it's not a big macro event," Mr. Sinai said.
That may pose problems for Mr. Clinton on the employment front. Economic growth, economists say, is the main engine behind job creation. "If the economy is growing rapidly it is going to create a certain amount of new employment anyway," said Bennett Harrison, professor of political economy at Carnegie Mellon University. "That's what Reagan had. You can build on that base. But the problem Clinton faces is that with the continuing long-term sluggishness of the economy, there's no base on which to build."
Mr. Clinton also faces an economy in which one major employment sector -- the military and its suppliers -- is cutting back drastically. According to estimates by Lawrence Chimerine, senior economic adviser to DRI/ McGraw Hill, more than a million jobs could be eliminated from the military and its suppliers alone by mid-decade. If those jobs are not replaced by new jobs in other sectors, they could add as much as a percentage point to the unemployment rate.
But the military is not Mr. Clinton's only problem area. He must also contend with the continued shrinking of many of America's largest corporations. "Layoffs at the Fortune 500 companies have slowed, but they haven't bottomed out and in some sectors they will go on for years," Mr. Chimerine said.
The weakness of the economy has already had a chilling effect on hiring. In the ebullient 1980's, "the economy was a prodigious job-creating machine, creating 19 million new jobs, almost two million a year," said Samuel Ehrenhalt, a regional Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. But from October 1991 through last month, "only 150,000 jobs were created in the economy as a whole, and in the private sector, zero were created."
In every job category except health care, according to Mr. Sinai, job creation has been below average for post-recessionary periods. Employment in construction, retailing, manufacturing and the military are all down. And while the employment ranks have been expanding somewhat, "virtually all of the job growth in the last 17 months can be accounted for by temps," Mr. Sinai said. While some people choose to be temporary workers, most would rather work full time, he said.
With this grim backdrop, some economists are arguing for a deficit-be-damned approach of more spending early on in the Clinton Administration. During the campaign, the Harvard economist Robert B. Reich, now assistant director for economic policy in the Clinton transition team, argued for what he called "frontloading" -- spending more than the $20 billion earmarked for infrastructure investment in the first year of the Administration. Mr. Clinton, in his remarks last week, indicated that some spending programs could be accelerated.
Other economists agree with the fix-the-deficit-later approach. "If the economy flattens to no growth, I would advocate a $50 billion stimulus package," Mr. Sinai said. "If the economy were growing in the 2 percent to 3 percent range, then they could proceed with the program," he said.
While spending on the infrastructure is a pump primer for business, using tax incentives to create jobs comes with a caveat. Most of those incentives won't really affect the entrepreneur, economists say, and it is the nation's entrepreneurs who create the jobs. "I'm skeptical about tax credits," said Mr. Harrison of Carnegie Mellon.
In an article in the upcoming issue of the Harvard Business Review, Amar Bhide, an assistant professor at the Harvard Business School, argues that the vast majority of the nation's 600,000 or so startups begin as concerns with no income to benefit from tax incentives. For these companies, "the incentives are completely irrelevant."

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
The Theory of Relativity for the London Market

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
IN Britain, it looks like the London stock market has been surging. In Frankfurt, that same stock market looks dull. In New York it looks like a disaster.
The fate of British stocks since Britain was forced out of Europe's Exchange Rate Mechanism in mid-September shows that currencies do matter. Since the end of August, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100 index has soared 17 percent measured in pounds, but only 2 percent measured in marks. 
 That reflects the integration of European economies. Many British companies make a lot of their revenues and profits in francs andmarks, and for them the devaluation of the pound just meant that foreign income would translate into more pounds.
During the same period, the dollar has been rebounding from depressed levels, reflecting a growing consensus that European interest rates were likely to fall while those in the United States had hit bottom and were rising. In dollars, the British stock index has fallen 9 percent since the end of August.

HEADLINE: Balancing the Power at the Corporate Top, British Style

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
AFTER ousting Robert C. Stempel as chairman and chief executive, the board of the General Motors Corporation created what for companies in the United States is an unusual management structure. It appointed John F. (Jack) Smith Jr. as chief executive from within the ranks of management but gave the chairman's title -- and ultimate authority over the company's direction -- to an outside director, John G. Smale.
Only a handful of other corporations in the United States have installed an outside director as chairman. But the practice has long been common in Britain. And with boards in the United States becoming more assertive, and occasionally imposing greater control, as in the case of G.M., analysts and executives said the British experience might hold lessons for companies in the United States. 
 Companies here, partly out of tradition and partly as a result of growing pressure from shareholders and from regulators, tend to avoid giving full control to any one executive. They prefer to subject their top managers to stricter board oversight than is common in the United States.
Analysts said there were some risks in splitting the jobs, not the least of which was possible confusion both inside and outside the company about who was really in charge. Nevertheless, the separation of the chairmanship from management is becoming even more common in the wake of corporate scandals like the collapse of Robert Maxwell's media empire, in which there was virtually no board monitoring Mr. Maxwell, who was chairman and chief executive.
But analysts said that the practice should not be limited to extreme cases, and that it had proved helpful to many companies when shareholders perceived a chief executive as needing more oversight, or when a recession-battered company needed all the help it could get.
Earlier this year, for example, John S. Kerridge stepped down as chairman and chief executive of Fisons P.L.C., a large pharmaceuticals company. Mr. Kerridge resigned for health reasons, but his stewardship of the company had drawn considerable criticism from institutional shareholders, who said he had failed to fully disclose problems Fisons was having selling two of its products in the United States.
Under prodding from the shareholders, the board of Fisons named an outside director, Patrick Egan, as a nonexecutive chairman, and brought in a new chief executive, Cedric Scroggs. Industry executives said the new management structure was set up primarily to assuage the concerns of shareholders about too much power resting with a single executive who did not seem inclined to keep shareholders fully briefed on the company's difficulties. Analysts said they now receive a much clearer picture from the company of its prospects.
Only 24 percent of public companies in Britain have a combined chairman and chief executive, according to Proned, a research organization in London that lobbies on behalf of institutional shareholders and other groups for increased use of nonexecutive directors. In the United States, according to various estimates, 75 percent to 80 percent of companies combine the jobs. At General Motors, for example, the two jobs have been treated as one for the last 34 years.
"It can be very dangerous when the person at the top of a large organization takes too much power onto his shoulders," said Colin St. Johnston, the managing director of Proned. "Companies on both sides of the Atlantic have suffered as a result of that kind of situation. So we need to find a way of building a good system of checks and balances."
The structure of corporate management has become a topic of considerable debate in Britain over the last year. Last year the London Stock Exchange, the Confederation of British Industry, a trade group, and the Institute of Chartered Accountants set up a task force to study corporate governance.
The task force concluded in a draft report issued earlier this year that more should be done to promote a separation of powers at the top of the corporate hierarchy. Some members of the task force have also suggested limits on terms for service for outside executives to keep them from becoming so close to management that they fail to exercise independent judgment. In the United States, shareholder advocacy groups have been calling for similar changes.
"There should be a clearly accepted division of responsibility at the head of the company, which will insure a balance of power and authority, such that no one individual has unfettered powers of decision," the draft report said. "Where the chairman is also the chief executive, it is essential that that should be a strong independent element on the board, with an appointed leader."
British industry has objected to portions of the draft report, particularly the suggestion that outside directors have an appointed leader. The final report may back off on that point, people involved with the task force said.
 BUT the task force's chairman, Sir Adrian Cadbury, said in a speech to the Confederation of British Industry that companies should not risk a public backlash and the imposition of tighter regulatory controls by failing to make managements more accountable, particularly at a time when recession is claiming many victims among shareholders, employees, suppliers and customers.
"Hard times have had a part to play in putting the matter on the public agenda, but the basic issue is one of trust," Sir Adrian said. If companies and their boards do not take action on their own, he added, "others who understand business less well and are more doctrinaire in their approach will surely do so."
Yet while some managements continue to resist, the notion of greater board oversight is increasingly accepted even at companies that have long combined the roles of the chairman and the chief executive.
"The chairman and chief executive are two separate jobs," said Blenyth Jenkins, the director of corporate affairs for the Institute of Directors, a trade group based in London. "One of the major functions of the board is to supervise management. If the chairman of the board is also in management, then he is in effect marking his own exam papers."
Take the case of British Petroleum P.L.C. The company had long combined the chairman and chief executive jobs, and under Robert Horton, who was given those titles in 1990, virtually all authority over the company seemed to rest in them.
But when rising debt levels, falling oil prices and what some outside directors viewed as Mr. Horton's unwillingness to change strategies left the company staggering earlier this year, outside directors put pressure on Mr. Horton to resign. He was replaced by another member of management, David A. G. Simon, as chief executive, and by an outside board member, Lord Ashburton, as chairman.
"It was seen as a solution to the problem of having too much power concentrated in one person," said an industry executive who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
