HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Ogletown, Del.;
An Office Park Just for Credit

BYLINE: By Maureen Milford

 BODY:
A CREDIT-CARD company that began modestly 10 years ago in a converted strip-shopping center here has bought a 235-acre office park in nearby Stanton for its expanding business.
The company, MBNA Corporation, calls itself the nation's third-largest lender through bank credit cards, after Citibank and Chase Manhattan. 
 Last month it bought the Westgate Corporate Park, where for two years it has been leasing two three-story buildings as satellite space. The purchase price was $56 million.
The company plans to begin constructing two more three-story office buildings early next year in the park, half a mile northeast of its headquarters here.
Construction has already begun on a 17,500-square-foot day-care center to accommodate 200 children of its employees. The two new buildings, with a total of 240,000 square feet, will double the space of its satellite buildings.
The architects are Victorine & Samuel Homsey of Wilmington. Design plans are not final, but the site and zoning of the property permit MBNA to construct highly visible buildings facing Interstate 95.
MBNA came to Delaware in the early 1980's with dozens of other out-of-state banks. It was then known as Maryland Bank NA, but has subsequently been spun off as a pure credit-card operation. The state's favorable banking and credit-card laws, enacted during the runaway inflation years of the early 80's, created a haven for financial institutions that did not want interest-rate ceilings.
MBNA set up shop about seven miles southwest of Wilmington in this crossroads community mostly of middle-income suburban housing developments. From its start in a former local shopping center it has grown to occupy nine buildings, totaling 593,000 square feet, on 31 acres and to employ 5,200 people. It plans to add more than 4,000 jobs in the next five years at the Westgate Corporate Park, according to David W. Spartin, senior vice president. The park will be developed for MBNA's use only.
The parcel had been part of a 950-acre land bank owned by the nonprofit Welfare Foundation Inc., founded in the 1930's by the late Pierre S. duPont to preserve land for institutional use.
In the early 80's the foundation donated 191 acres to the Medical Center of Delaware, which built a regional medical center. A few small parcels were sold to commercial developers and the rest was given to the University of Delaware in Newark.
At one time the university planned to build an office and research park on the site, but in the 80's it sold the land to a development joint venture of Bell Atlantic Properties of Philadelphia and Bellevue Holding Company and EDIS of Wilmington. Its Westgate Corporate Park never progressed beyond the two buildings.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
BMW Puts a V8 Under the 740's Hood

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
TRADITIONAL wisdom used to tell us that high-end cars were bulletproof in a recession. The idea was that folks with money continued to have money, and they didn't worry about where their next Rolls-Royce was coming from.
That notion has had some holes poked in it in recent years, however. Falling stocks, a Federal luxury tax, the weakening dollar and ever more bearish conditions have made the car business a bit more egalitarian when it comes to taking lumps, and the makers of fancy cars have been hurting just like the rest. 
 BMW is one of those that has had its ups and downs, but the German manufacturer's full line of automobiles -- ranging from the 3-series that appeals to young buyers with healthy cash-flows to the 8-series of 12-cylinder supercars -- has kept the Bavarian Motor Works factory in Munich reasonably busy of late.
So far in 1992, American sales are up 27 percent over last year, and construction has begun on a $300 million plant in Greer, S.C., that will produce as many as 70,000 cars a year for the world market by the end of the decade. In addition, BMW has continued to upgrade its line, introducing a 525i station wagon last spring and a V8 version of the 7-series just last month.
That car, now dubbed the 740, replaces the six-cylinder 735, and it is what BMW calls its "base luxury sedan." As such, the 740i carries a minimum sticker price of $54,000, while the longer-wheelbase 740iL begins at $58,000. With options, we could be talking real money here.
But the car is undeniably gorgeous, even if its rather conservative four-door styling fails to turn heads. And, for what it's worth, the notes that I dictated into a tape recorder while cruising in a silver 740i say, among other things, that this is what an automobile ought to be about.
It is one of the tautest, quietest cars you are likely to find. It swaths you in sweet-smelling leather and it gives you mirrorlike walnut trim to smile at. There are antilock brakes, of course, and standard dual air bags, with automatic tensioners to tighten the front seatbelts in case of a crash. And despite other manufacturers' protestations that a passenger-side bag forces the elimination of the glovebox, the 740 has what may be the biggest glovebox anywhere.
With 10 power adjustments for the front buckets and a switch to make the four-spoke wheel move in and out, driving position is superb. Room in back is good, as is trunk space, given that the 740 is not a particularly large car. Unfortunately, the trunk's liftover is high, posing the possibility of a sprained back for someone loading cargo. But the compartment does hold a full-size spare tire, and the lid, as usual in a BMW, contains a complete set of tools.
The car is, in fact, laden with nice touches. Up front, the intermittent wipers are keyed to the car's speed, and the washer fluid sprays from heated jets. The driver's doorlock also is heated to prevent freezing, and the key in that lock allows simultaneous closing of the windows and sunroof.
The "halogen ellipsoid" headlamps may be the best in any car, putting a carpet of sun on the road. There is a high-pressure headlight-foglight cleaning system and a rearview mirror that dims automatically when hit by high beams from the rear.
The right sideview mirror automatically positions itself to show the curb when you are backing up, and a memory system recalls your preference for adjustment of the driver's seat, the steering wheel, the heated sideview mirrors and the front seatbelt height.
It is fine to talk about these magical gizmos, of course, but it is what's under the skin that makes the 740 a driver's car. And for those of us who grew up with V8's, the sound and smoothness of a 90's version is . . . well, a thrill.
With the 740, BMW revives a tradition that began in 1954 when the company became the first European manufacturer to build a V8, putting its 2.6-liter and 3.2-liter aluminum engines into 501 and 502 sedans, the 503 coupe and convertible, and the 507 roadster. In 1965, the eight-cylinder yielded to the six that previously powered the 7-series cars.
Like those earlier eights, 1993's four-liter powerplant is made mainly of aluminum, but it now has four overhead camshafts, 32 valves and today's electronics. And while the earlier engines produced as much as 160 horsepower, the new V8 puts out 282 horses and 295 foot-pounds of torque.
It also has "knock control" that allows it to run without stumbles on less than its preferred premium fuel, and its high-tech innards include such things as a lightweight thermoplastic intake manifold and a fuel-injection system that employs a hot-metal-film sensor in the incoming stream of air to determine exactly how much gas is needed.
Instead of steel cylinder liners in the aluminum block, the walls of the cylinders are hardened with a layer of nickel deposited by galvanic action. The system, called Galnikal, is a first for automobiles, although it has been used previously in BMW motorcycle engines.
Power from the V8 flows to the road through a new five-speed automatic transmission whose electronic controls offer three shift modes.
In the "Economy" position, early upshifts provide the quietest and most efficient operation, yielding a miles-per-gallon rating of 16 in the city, and 22 on the highway. Shift-points are raised with the "Sport" button pushed, creating 0-60 acceleration on the order of 7 seconds. The third button, a snowflake symbol, indicates "Winter" mode, which reduces the tendency to wheelspin by providing third-gear starts.
Traction control, which further aids driving in slippery conditions, is available as part of a $1,795 "inclement weather package." Heated front seats (which by themselves cost $360) and a ski bag with a trunk-to-interior pass-through also are part of the package. The only other necessary or possible expenses are the $1,300 gas-guzzler tax, $405 for delivery, and a $1,470 damping-control system that puts electronics to work in the suspension.
That would add up to something like $58,970 plus tax for the silver 740i that I was so happy with. Still, according to Karl Gerlinger, president of BMW of North America, 7,000 of the 7-series cars are expected to be sold in the coming year.
Traditional wisdom may have a point.

HEADLINE: To The Mat;
Now Clinton Decides Which Promises Came First

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.

 BODY:
WHEN President Franklin D. Roosevelt was addressing a rally at Madison Square Garden during his re-election campaign of 1936, someone up in the rafters held up a sign that read: "We love him for the enemies he has made."
Indeed, Presidents are defined as much by the promises they keep as by the enemies they are willing to make by breaking or postponing campaign vows. The intriguing question about Bill Clinton is: now that he is President-elect, which of his campaign promises will he push and which will he push aside? 
 One thing is clear. Mr. Clinton simply cannot ram through Congress in the first 100 days, or even in the first year, anything more than a fraction of his campaign pledges. But this is not only because he would choke the Congressional committees. More important, it is because the consensus at the center of the political spectrum -- which he will need to get his most important programs, health care and economic renewal, through Congress -- almost certainly would not hold if he tried to take too many controversial steps at once.
It is an axiom of American politics that Presidents govern at the center -- by nudging it in one direction or another. The fun in the coming year will be watching Mr. Clinton juggle in the center ring -- juggling Democratic supporters who will be alienated by the special interest promises he fails to keep and juggling Republican and Perot conservatives who will be outraged by the special interest promises on which he delivers, while all the time trying to hold together a center coalition for what really counts: healing the economy and reforming health care.
President John F. Kennedy promised during the 1960 campaign that he would "end discrimination with the stroke of a pen on his first day in office," recalled the Presidential historian Michael R. Beschloss. But when Mr. Kennedy got into office, not only did he not fulfill his civil rights pledge, he appointed a slew of conservative judges opposed to civil rights in order to hold the support of conservative southern Democrats in Congress for other issues he held more dear. Instead of acting on civil rights in January 1961, he waited until June 1963 to submit a civil rights bill.
What happened in the interim?
"People sent him a lot of pens," Mr. Beschloss said.
It is hard to know what Mr. Clinton will get in the mail, but the White House post office better be prepared, because something is going to have to give.
Consider just last week. Mr. Clinton declared on Veterans Day that once in office he would move to lift the 48-year-old ban on gay men and lesbians in the military. Just that act alone, a relatively small item in his overall agenda, would involve the most radical change to the social fabric of the American military since President Harry S. Truman ordered the army integrated in 1948.
 
Colin Powell's Against It
 The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin L. Powell, has already declared that lifting the ban would be "prejudicial to good order and discipline."
Now, imagine that on top of fulfilling just that one campaign promise, Mr. Clinton also fulfills his promise to adopt a more aggressive posture toward humanitarian relief for Bosnia, even if it requires American military intervention as part of a United Nations operation. The Pentagon, under General Powell, has vigorously opposed such intervention. Will President Clinton, who will come into office with his own baggage of having avoided the Vietnam War draft, want to overrule the military on two highly controversial issues in his first few weeks or months in office?
For interest's sake, add one more promise that Mr. Clinton has made -- that he will move quickly to make it easier for Haitian refugees to gain political asylum in the United States. That could stimulate a flood of Haitian refugees to already overburdened Florida, setting off all sorts of fireworks.
Just those three initiatives could get a Clinton Presidency tied up in knots before it even takes up the explosive questions that will probably be involved in economic restructuring -- gasoline taxes, deficit reduction, entitlement trimming, free trade, middle-class taxes and the like. Taking on those issues will aggravate many in Mr. Clinton's Democratic constituency.
Mr. Clinton, of course, is no fool and he did not get where he is without being able to juggle. His actions during this first week since the election provide a lot of clues as to the techniques he will employ.
One is that he may announce his intentions to take certain steps on social policy -- like lifting the ban on homosexuals in the military or the ban on abortion counseling at Federally funded clinics -- without necessarily doing it right away, but instead by convening a commission to study the matter first and make recommendations on how to proceed. As Governor, Mr. Clinton was a master at using study groups to buy himself time for difficult political decisions, and to give him political cover when the decision was made.
On Wednesday, Mr. Clinton told reporters flat out that he intended to lift the ban on homosexuals in the military. But at his news conference on Thursday he soft-pedaled his commitment and stressed instead the careful manner in which he would approach this delicate issue, saying: "What I plan to do is to put together a group of people and let them advise me on how we might best do this."
 
The Balm of Rhetoric
 Another of Mr. Clinton's techniques will be to use the balm of rhetoric. He clearly has an innate ability to explain things in terms that the average person can understand, speaking in sentences and paragraphs -- in contrast with the fractured prose of George Bush, whom it was virtually impossible to quote in a coherent sentence without the aide of ellipses and parentheses to patch his thoughts together.
Mr. Clinton's abilities in this regard were most apparent in his carefully crafted answer on why he supported homosexuals in the military. First he cited a study by President Bush's Defense Secretary, Dick Cheney, noting that homosexuals who have served in the military did so with distinction. Then he observed that the Army needs every man or woman ready to serve -- who can argue with that? -- and closed by saying that it is behavior on the job, not sexual preference, that should determine eligibility.
This was a series of rapid fire arguments, seamlessly woven together, that might have given even the most homophobic American something to think about. In an era of scarcity of both resources and tolerance, having a President who can heal with his words and not just his wallet could be a great asset. But even Mr. Clinton's masseur's touch with the English language, which recalls Lyndon Johnson's ability to soothe angry constituencies, is something he will also have to balance. Quite simply, sometimes he can seem too smooth, too eloquent for his own good. Sometimes you want to check your wallet when he's done talking -- just to make sure all your credit cards are still there. He is obviously aware of this tendency, and seems to be feeling for the right balance in his voice.
Finally, it appears that Mr. Clinton will look to pay off different groups in different currencies. The trick, said Norman Ornstein, an expert on the Presidency at the American Enterprise Institute, "is finding ways to placate constituencies without giving up resources you cannot afford or political capital you don't want to expend."
For instance, he will probably engender a lot of good will from traditional Democratic constituencies early on through executive orders lifting the gag rule on abortion counseling and, as a payoff to labor, imposing restrictions on union-busting.
"If Clinton is clever, he can find a few things that have great symbolic weight for certain interest groups," said Mr. Ornstein. "If dispensed judiciously, they will not fracture the center."
Another interesting act to watch will be Mr. Clinton taking on his own party by putting in place what he vows will be the highest ethical standards imposed by any Administration on its staff. On Friday, his transition team announced guidelines restricting post-inauguration lobbying by transition officials or their involvement in transition affairs from which they might benefit.
 
The Clamor for Jobs
 The delicate balance here will be between the clamor for jobs, especially from those tied to the Democratic party Washington establishment -- the Clinton transition chairman, Vernon Jordan, is as Establishment as you can get -- and the very real public demand to break the hold of the three-martini lobbyists on Congress. On the one hand, Mr. Clinton clearly seems committed to being an agent of change, but on the other he wants to tap into the networks of power and influence, from the think tanks to the top law firms and investment banks. It was precisely his link to that network in years past that kept him, the Governor of a small backwater state, from being marginalized. In formulating and, more importantly, in applying his ethics rules, he will have to confront those two sides of his own politics.
"People will say that fixing the economy or fighting drugs is what's really important and ethics can be taken for granted," said Dennis F. Thompson, who runs an ethics study program at Harvard. "But I say that ethics is the most important issue. Nothing will do more to restore lost confidence in government than higher than normal ethics standards and nothing will paralyze an Administration more quickly than an ethics scandal."
Strict ethics guidelines, added Mr. Thompson, are not some liberal indulgence, but rather "a precondition for getting on with the business of addressing the major public policy issues."
That is certainly how Mr. Clinton has approached ethics in theory, where he has made a sharp departure from the past. But practice will be the real test. This is one area where he cannot afford to play the juggler.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Whose New Health Plan Is This Anyway?

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

 BODY:
AS a Presidential candidate, Bill Clinton astutely diagnosed the malaise of the nation's health-care system. But to cure its problems, in one year or even four, he will need to combine the skills of an emergency-room doctor, an economist, a faith healer and a miracle worker.
Health care was one of Mr. Clinton's strongest campaign issues, and doctors, hospitals, private health insurers and drug companies now see profound changes as inevitable. But they are girding for battle over the right to direct those changes. Last week they were mouthing conciliatory words, offering to work with the new Administration, promising not to obstruct the changes envisioned by the President-elect. At the same time, they were refining plans for sophisticated lobbying to define the public interest in a way that will coincide with their own. 
 "Clinton has a clear mandate for reform, but does not have a national consensus on any specific plan," said Drew E. Altman, former Commissioner of Human Services in New Jersey, who is now president of the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation, which studies health policy.
Congress has considered a huge variety of proposals ranging from tax credits for buying private health insurance to a publicly financed "single-payer" system of universal insurance like Canada's. To control costs, Mr. Clinton said in the campaign that he wanted to impose annual limits on all health-care spending, public and private. As a step toward universal coverage, he would also require employers to provide health insurance for their workers.
To revamp the health-care system, Mr. Clinton must "make health one of his top two or three personal priorities and invest tremendous time, energy and political capital," Mr. Altman said. "It is by no means certain we will see comprehensive reform that controls costs and covers all the uninsured."
Mr. Clinton designated health care as one of his top priorities when he announced last week that there would be a separate transition team to address it. It is headed by Judith Feder, co-director of the Center for Health Policy Studies at Georgetown University. Dr. Feder was staff director of a Federal advisory panel that, in 1990, recommended that employers be required to provide health insurance or buy coverage for their workers through a Government program.
 
An Issue So Complex
 Mr. Clinton has a reasonably good chance of reviving the nation's economy -- if nothing else, the business cycle works in his favor. By contrast, the problems in the nation's health-care system are chronic and seem intractable. Rising economic fortunes lift all boats, but effective controls on health spending will adversely affect some groups. Consumers may benefit from stringent controls on health costs. But doctors, hospitals, private health insurers, drug companies and manufacturers of medical technology all fear they will lose money.
The issue is so complex, the interests so diverse, that it will be a major feat if Mr. Clinton can, as he promises, simply draft a comprehensive bill in his first 100 days in office.
Thomas A. Scully, who has worked at the Office of Management and Budget for the last four years, offers an admonition: "If Clinton tries to push through one big health-care reform package in the first 100 days, he'll get creamed by eight zillion interest groups. Even if one party controls the White House and both houses of Congress, you'll still have massive fights."
Democrats in Congress have widely divergent views about the extent to which Government should regulate health costs and insurance company practices.
The Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, the American Hospital Association and the Washington Business Group on Health, which represents 175 big corporations, held a news conference last week to promote the idea of health maintenance organizations and other networks linking hospitals, doctors, employers and insurers. Their announcement was a pre-emptive effort to gain a voice in the new Administration, to strike a cooperative tone and dispel the impression that they would block change.
In a move that signals new ferment in the health insurance industry, two of the biggest companies, Metropolitan Life and Aetna Life and Casualty, announced this month that they were withdrawing from the Health Insurance Association of America, the powerful lobby for the nation's commercial insurers. With the future of their business at stake, some of the bigger insurance companies seem willing to accept major changes in the health care system that would fundamentally transform the role of private insurers. They increasingly find themselves in conflict with smaller companies that want to continue business as usual.
John D. Moynahan Jr., executive vice president of Metropolitan Life, said, "Our role has changed dramatically from providing the standard type of health insurance to being a manager of care" delivered to large employee groups by networks of doctors and hospitals.
 
Persuasive Donors?
 Those in the health care industry are trying to buttress their arguments with the persuasive power of campaign contributions. From January 1991 through June of this year, the health and insurance industries contributed $18.6 million to Congressional candidates, according to a study by Citizen Action, a nationwide consumer group. The political arm of the American Medical Association, the biggest donor, gave more than $1.1 million. A.M.A. officials like to project an altruistic image as learned guardians of public health, but they refuse to discuss details of their campaign contributions.
Robert M. Brandon, vice president of Citizen Action, said: "Toward the end of the campaign, Bill Clinton seemed to rely more and more on the idea of public-private health partnerships, managed care and managed competition. But that alone will not solve the problem of soaring health costs. There is no evidence that such arrangements dampen health costs. And they defy people's desire to maintain freedom to choose their own doctors."
The two-year-old, free-form debate over health care has not produced concrete results, but may have laid the groundwork for action. Democrats in Congress and their leaders, Senator George J. Mitchell and Representative Richard A. Gephardt, are on trial too. Having raised expectations, they will be judged severely if they do not pass legislation to control health costs and protect the 35 million people lacking insurance.
It is probably unrealistic to expect major changes to take effect in Mr. Clinton's first 100 days or even in his first year. Dr. Paul M. Ellwood, president of InterStudy, a health policy research group in Jackson Hole, Wyo., suggests that the people take an even longer view. "In the next four years," he says confidently, "we will see the most significant changes in the American health system in 50 years."

HEADLINE: The Riot's Ashes/A special report.;
Separateness Grows in a Scarred Los Angeles

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Among the lasting casualties of the Los Angeles riots is Julius Butler's faith in the future, his belief that with good will and hard work the competing ethnic groups of this fast-changing city could find a road to harmony.
"We've been saying for years to the younger generation, 'Hold on, there's hope,' " said Mr. Butler, a 60-year-old black lawyer who is active in church affairs and youth counseling. "What do we tell them now? 
 "I ask myself many times, 'Have I been responsible by saying that? Have I been responsible by continuing to advocate Martin Luther King's dream? Is it a dream or is it a fantasy?' "
Half a year after the worst urban American riots of the century, Los Angeles seems to be a city coming apart rather than coming together. Though there are some signs of progress and hope, there are others that the violence and destruction served only to intensify competition and mistrust in this most diverse of major American cities.
Black, Hispanic, Asian and white communities have withdrawn into themselves, more aware than ever of their differences, competing for scarce resources, aid, jobs and political power.
"The violence of last April and May has laid bare the city's inter-ethnic competition and hostility," said Halford Fairchild, a past president of the Association of Black Psychologists who studies social issues in Los Angeles. "I think the potential exists for urban warfare where the battle lines are drawn according to skin color, language and ethnicity."
The tensions are evident in recent violent black-Hispanic confrontations within Los Angeles County's schools and prisons and at construction sites where black groups have held noisy demonstrations demanding post-riot rebuilding jobs.
They are evident in the successful lobbying of the City Council by a South-Central Los Angeles group to limit the reopening of scores of liquor stores, mostly Korean-owned, that had been looted and burned. In addition, a black-Korean alliance that struggled for years to prevent conflicts has been all but disbanded, city officials say, as the two communities focus on their separate concerns.
 
An Issue on the Sidelines
 The scramble for power and resources almost paralyzed the city's main reconstruction effort as interest groups, rather than setting aside their differences at a time of need, jostled angrily for months to be represented on the main umbrella organization, Rebuild L. A., headed by Peter V. Ueberroth, the former commissioner of baseball.
In a city with a weak mayoral system and diffuse power structure, there has been no clear leadership to bring the groups together. With Mayor Tom Bradley retiring and an election for his job set for next November, some analysts fear that politics will overwhelm constructive action in the months to come.
"There is very little talk about coming together these days," said Larry Aubry, an official with the Los Angeles County Commission on Human Relations. "People are focused on getting their own stuff together. Human relations has always been peripheral as an issue, and that's where it stays."
 
Blacks
Little Hope In a Grim Setting
 At the intersection of Florence and Normandie avenues, where the rioting erupted last April 29, a young man, James Hrue, was recently selling homemade T-shirts showing a Florence and Normandie street sign above a movie marquee reading, "COMING SOON at a corner near you."
All around him in this mostly black neighborhood, the empty lots of burned-out businesses stood as symbols of the city's unhealed wounds. Outside the Tom's Liquor store, where the looting began, the usual crowd of drifters lounged, holding bottles concealed in paper bags. On the side streets were groups of gang members, also with bottles in their hands.
"This is a symbolic place; this is history," Mr. Hrue said, reflecting on the convulsion of violence that took more than 50 lives and caused nearly $1 billion in damage.
Four white police officers acquitted of assault in the videotaped beating of a black motorist, Rodney G. King, face a Federal trial in the same beating next year, and many people here worry that new riots are possible.
"Basically the problem now is time," Mr. Hrue said, voicing a widespread restlessness among many blacks here. "I know things are getting done, but we don't see it here. Why don't they act like this is an emergency?"
Inside the liquor store, the Korean proprietor spoke angrily about the failure of the police to protect him, about the Government's slowness in reconstruction aid and about live television coverage of the looting that he said seemed to advertise, "Hey, free beer!"
"This is a stupid country, man, I'm telling you," said the owner, who refused to give his name.
On the street outside, Pete Douglas, 45 years old, described a drab routine here in which jobless men shuttle between the liquor store and the service station where they hustle for tips.
"We go pump gas across the street in the morning: that's breakfast," said Mr. Douglas, who once worked at a sewage plant. "Then again at lunch hour and then the evening rush."
He said the men and women who make this corner their home know Gary Williams, who was arrested for picking the pocket of Reginald O. Denny, the white truck driver who was severely beaten at the start of the rioting.
"He was just a hungry guy out here trying to make ends meet," Mr. Douglas said. "He probably just saw an opportunity. If he did do it, he probably did it out of hunger and frustration."
That, Mr. Douglas added, is still the mood of South-Central Los Angeles, an area where, the 1990 census found, 30 percent of the people live below the poverty line.
"They've cleared the land" after the looting and fires, he said, "but we don't see no businesses going up."
On 71st Street, one block away, a group of tough-looking young men, mostly unemployed, said they had also returned to their routines, to empty lives enlivened by brushes with the police.
"I just got out of jail two days ago," said one of the men, Mark Williams, 30, who is the older brother of Damian Williams, one of those accused of beating Mr. Denny and a dozen other people at the start of the riots.
Mr. Williams said he had been jailed for "running off at the mouth" when he challenged an undercover policewoman who was watching him and his friends from across the street. He said he also faced charges of assaulting a police officer and trying to disarm two police officers during the first confrontation of the riots.
"We're the weed part," Mr. Williams said, referring to the Federal Government's new "weed and seed" program for reviving urban America in which troublemakers are to be removed from the streets and social programs provided in their place.
Mr. Williams, who has been struggling to start a car-stereo-installation business, said he might save the Government the trouble. "I'm just waiting to get these court cases over with and sell the house and get out of here," he said.
Mr. Butler, the lawyer, said he had been in Los Angeles during the Watts riots of 1965 and understood the frustrations of angry young men like these.
"I know the hurt, the pain and the outrage that they feel," he said. "If I was 19 years old, I probably would have been in the streets with them."
 
Whites
Bitter Farewell To Isolation
 For James N., a 40-year-old white man, the nagging thought is how much he might have had in common with the black man who threw a brick through his windshield as the violence erupted at Florence and Normandie.
"If he had only asked me, I would have told him I was as angry at the verdict as he was and we could have walked away," James N. said, referring to the officers' acquittals that sparked the rioting.
James N., a delivery man who was passing through the area as the verdicts were announced, refused to allow his last name to be used because he feared becoming a participant in post-riot controversies.
"I don't know who it was, but the guy who threw a brick through my windshield changed my life," he said, adding that his left cheekbone was shattered and that his body trembles uncontrollably whenever he talks about the riot.
"I carry a gun now, and you know why? Not because of what those people did to me but because of what I have turned into.
"I grew up in this town. My father grew up in this town, and I never had any trouble getting along in the world. Now when I come up on a stop light, I look around to see who's there. That's what has become of me. Now I'm a guy who says, 'Next time it's going to be different.' I've got a gun and I'm an excellent shot and I'll use it."
The city's white population, while largely untouched by the riots, was shaken by the uprising it witnessed.
While some whites joined cleanup brigades, many others hurried to buy guns. Whatever an individual's response, there was a shared sense that the city's more affluent residents could no longer feel insulated from the poverty and anger of the inner city.
"When I grew up here, it was like a small town, with basically white middle-class neighbors," James N. said. "Now we've got Asians, Koreans, Vietnamese, Latin American countries from Argentina to Mexico. I live in one of the strongholds of white people in this area, along the coast. The rent keeps out minorities."
The riots have only underscored the difficulties of this diversity, he said, alienating him because of race from people like his assailant, with whom he might have found common ground. He has retreated into his mostly white enclave and carefully maps his delivery routes to avoid minority neighborhoods.
"I think this is a big country," he said. "There's room for everybody. But the system we have still isn't prepared to deal with providing services for all these people. The pie is only so big, and everybody wants a piece, and they're fighting over it."
 
Hispanics
Looking for Ways To Gain Power
 One group that is reaching out for political power in the wake of the riots is the city's fast-growing and increasingly vocal Hispanic population. But even here, a challenge is to find common ground among diverse elements.
As the long-established Mexican-American residents of East Los Angeles looked on nervously from across the paved banks of the Los Angeles River, Hispanic neighborhoods in South-Central Los Angeles and the Pico Union district, largely populated by Central American immigrants, were among those torn by rioting and looting.
"There were people who were saying, 'That's not us. They're not Mexican,' " said Frank Villalobos, an urban planner who is a community leader in East Los Angeles. But he said a decision was made by leaders in East Los Angeles not to divide the Hispanic community and to accept responsibility for the actions of fellow Hispanic residents.
Since the riots, Mr. Villalobos has helped organize focus groups among the city's Central American population to help integrate their needs into a common Hispanic political agenda that will become a force in Los Angeles's future.
The old, mostly black-white coalition formed during Mayor Bradley's 20-year-tenure is already fading. "I think there will have to be a new leadership coalition in the city," said Sergio Munoz, news director of the Spanish-language television station KMEX.
"But this coalition will have to recognize the new reality," Mr. Munoz said, "which is that 38 percent of the city is Latino, that a very important Asian population is growing, that the African-American population is diminishing and that there is a white Anglo-Saxon population that is no longer as powerful as it used to be."
 
Shopowners
Waiting for Aid For Rebuilding
 Six months after the riots, the owners of the burned-out Family Chiropractic Services finally found an organization to represent their needs. With the help of the American Civil Liberties Union, they joined nearly 2,000 other riot victims two weeks ago in filing suit against the city, claiming that the police discriminated against them during the riots.
"This is the first place we've gotten any action," said Priscilla Feldsher, who with her mother, Wenefrette Conner, owns Family Chiropractic Services and the adjacent M.F.I. Skin Care Clinic. The two businesses were among hundreds that were burned in the riots, and their owners' complaints of inaction are repeated increasingly around the city.
Political leaders agree that the reconstruction of businesses, with all the economic ripple effects they offer, is a vital part of reviving the area and preventing future unrest. But frustration has grown as bureaucratic delays, ignorance and broken promises have slowed the rebuilding.
There are bright spots. Ben Mayo, owner of a print shop that burned in the same fire that destroyed Dr. Feldsher's clinics, has opened a new shop with the aid of Rebuild L. A.
Mr. Mayo said his new shop was even better than the one he lost. "The help is available," he said. "You just have to go after it."
Like many other black owners of small businesses in the area, Dr. Feldsher and her mother did not have insurance. They were among the first riot victims to apply for Small Business Administration loans. But even then they were not sure how much help they would be eligible for because most of their financial records had been destroyed in the fire.
"It's just been a big rat race," said Dr. Feldsher. She said she had gone from the Mayor's office to her Councilman to Rebuild L. A. to black organizations. "They just kept giving us numbers we had already gotten through our directory."
The two women spent weeks assembling documents for the Small Business Administration but so far no loan has been approved. They hear from their former employees only indirectly now, when they receive requests from the unemployment office for confirmation of claims for benefits.
Creditors have given Dr. Feldsher extensions on house and car payments, on her credit cards, on most of her utilities payments and even on her children's piano lessons. But she said this simply meant that her debts were accumulating at a time when she was surviving mainly through the help of friends.
"My husband and I are scared to death, to be honest with you," Dr. Feldsher said. "And my mother's feeling real bad."
So it was a relief last month to march into City Hall with documents prepared with the A.C.L.U.'s help and to demand restitution from the city, the county and the state.
The suits may be difficult to win, but they make a statement about the sense of disenfranchisement among the city's minorities. The claim they make is that the police and other city officials, in that moment of greatest need, made a conscious decision to abandon the city's poor and minority neighborhoods to the flames.
"It's true," Dr. Feldsher said. "When there was trouble in Beverly Hills, they responded immediately. But for us they didn't do anything. Nothing at all."
 
Koreans
Persistent Anger Fuels Involvement
 Ho Jun Sin filed a claim against the city, too. His shop, Leimert Park Liquor, was the target of a firebomb during the riot, and the flames spread down the block, engulfing Dr. Feldsher's clinics and other businesses.
"It cost me my business," Mr. Mayo said, adding that Mr. Sin's store, like a number of other Korean businesses in the area, had experienced conflicts with its black customers and had therefore been singled out in the rioting. "He apologized and he admitted it. He knew it was him."
About 2,000 Korean businesses were damaged or destroyed in the riots, and that has been a turning point for the local Korean-American community of 145,000 people.
The riots in effect created a new ethnic interest group as the Koreans realized that they needed to stand up for their own rights in the city's multiethnic competition. Shopowners associations and riot-victims groups have multiplied, marches and demonstrations have been held and Korean voices have been newly raised at public meetings.
"In the past I would be the only Korean-American and the only Asian-American at different meetings," said Jerry Yu, executive director of the Korean-American Coalition, a community advocacy group. "Now I see more and more Korean-Americans coming there."
The Korean community was stunned by the absence of police protection in the busy retail enclave called Koreatown as their stores were looted and burned, and Koreans have filed the largest number of discrimination claims against the city.
Now Mr. Yu is angered by what he sees as the local government's continuing treatment of the Korean-American community as foreigners. "Many government agencies keep asking us how many Korean-American victims, how many stores," he said. "But it is not our job to have this information. It is their job. So these questions are an insult."
In addition, blacks in South-Central Los Angeles won passage of a city ordinance that requires a public hearing before any damaged liquor store in the area can be reopened.
Advocates of the measure say that there are too many liquor stores in the neighborhood and that alcohol contributes far more than drugs to the area's crime.
But many Koreans, who own 70 percent of the liquor stores and markets in the area, say the ordinance is really intended to keep them away. So far, only three approvals for reopening, all of them to Koreans, have been granted.
Mr. Sin is not one of those few, and he is supporting himself with a Small Business Administration loan.
"The process is not fair," he said, and for once it was a complaint that might be endorsed by any of the city's fractious groups. "I thought there was equal opportunity for everyone in America, but it is not true."

HEADLINE: You Can Go Home Again, Even to China

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHUN SHUI, China

 BODY:
"My son, are you from this village?" Liu Jiuyou asked Henry Doong as he walked toward the village's ancestral hall. "Come. See how we've expanded."
Stooped and fragile, the 87-year-old Mrs. Liu walked slowly with the help of her cane and pointed to a small clump of homes whose wobbly walls seemed in far worse condition than she. Her pride in this insignificant accomplishment reminded Mr. Doong that if history were slightly different he could have been standing in her place, barefoot with muck between the toes, pointing to the same cluster of mud huts. 
 The 68-year-old Mr. Doong, who was born in a mud hut here, is one of tens of thousands of Chinese-Americans whose roots are somewhere among the rice paddies, villages, rolling hills and valleys of this region in southern China called Taishan.
 
To 'Old Gold Mountain'
 The peasants of Taishan were among the first to flee to "Old Gold Mountain," as San Francisco was known, in the 19th century, and a large share of the 1.8 million Chinese-Americans in the United States are from this area. The Taishan dialect used to be the patois of American Chinatowns, although in recent years Cantonese and to a lesser extent Mandarin have become more common.
Many of the one million residents of Taishan have relatives overseas, especially in Hong Kong, the United States and Canada. Now, as China's economy continues to blossom, many of the Chinese-Americans are coming back with their checkbooks and skills, along with a mixture of guilt and affection, to invest in their poor homelands. And if they do not come back in person, they send money.
In the village of Pan Shi, about an hour's car ride down the narrow bumpy roads from the nearest city, about three-quarters of the 440 residents have relatives overseas, and some of them seem more familiar with the streets of Queens than with those in Guangzhou.
Jiang Xiaomei, a 58-year-old woman whose blue-black sweater, high heels and lipstick make her look like a movie star in a mock run-down rural set, says her daughter is studying in New York. Other relatives overseas sent money to help build her a two-story tiled-wall home, which she locks up every time she leaves, unlike most villagers.
Many schools, factories, roads and homes here are built with money from overseas Chinese, and although Taishan people earn on average about $550 a year, officials say they spend more than that because of money sent from relatives. Overseas Chinese frequently return for vacations, and their sheer numbers fuel the local industries and drive up the prices of taxis and restaurant meals.
To encourage these contacts, the local government has established a special office that helps make arrangements for visiting overseas Chinese. Government officials also offer advice to the local people on American immigration law and explain procedures for emigrating to North America.
As a result, the outflow of Taishanese keeps growing as people here emigrate to join their parents, siblings or children in "the beautiful country," as the United States is known.
According to Chinese statistics, up to 6,000 of the more than 26,000 Chinese who immigrate to America each year come from Taishan. On top of that, a fair number of Taishanese living in other parts of China also obtain permission to emigrate.
 
Luxuries at Age 100
 Those who stay reap the benefits, though they may be decades in coming. For more than 60 years, Liang Jingzhen strapped her children to her back and headed to the fields alone to pluck rice from the paddies while her husband struggled to make a living abroad. Though he sent her money every once in a while, it is only now, at the age of 100, that Mrs. Liang can afford the luxuries of silk and a refrigerator and a color television, thanks to her 80-year-old daughter, now retired in Canada.
The overseas connection has helped broaden the attitudes of peasants here, although not always for the right reasons. Boys are still favored, but girls are increasingly valuable -- in part because they can marry Taishanese men who live abroad but come back to get married.
Mr. Doong, a retired engineer who lives in Washington,plans to spend next year teaching engineering at a nearby university here.
"I could have bought a home in Fort Myers and taken it easy for the rest of my life," he said. "But I'm coming back here to teach for a year. Why would I want to do that? It's the attachment."

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: The New Team;
Long Bottled Up, Advice From Democrats Flows

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Bruce Reed, an assistant to President-elect Bill Clinton, was buttonholed on a stairway at the transition headquarters in Little Rock, Ark., the other day by a stranger from Finland with a long, handwritten list of policy recommendations.
Toss it on the pile, Mr. Reed thought at the time, not even wondering how the man from Helsinki had managed to get past the security guards. 
 Like most others around Mr. Clinton, Mr. Reed, who was issues director in the campaign and who was named Thursday to be deputy director of the transition for domestic policy, has become numbed by all the free advice.
All the Democratic ideas that have been pent up for the last dozen years are now overflowing like lava from a long-dormant volcano.
Here is some of what happened just this week:
*The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and the Institute for International Economics submitted a report (on 100 percent recyclable paper with inks containing no lead or cadmium) listing the recommendations of dozens of former Government officials on how to organize the White House. ("Reorganizing the Government for the post-cold-war world is a necessity, not a luxury.")
*A group called the Citizens Transition Project headed by Mark Green, the New York City Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, sent the transition office a four-inch-thick loose-leaf notebook with the liberals' wish list on topics ranging from tax policy to the Peace Corps. ("The next Administration must first and foremost reaffirm the importance of the social policy mission and should lead a collective effort to articulate that historical mission in the context of 21st Century needs and capacities.")
*Women's organizations touted 79 Democratic women for top Government jobs (ranging alphabetically from Madeleine K. Albright, a expert in foreign policy, to Lynn Yeakel, an unsuccessful Democratic candidate for a Senate from Pennsylvania.)
* A group called America Talks Issues released a report, based on a public opinion poll, entitled "What the Public Wants in the Federal Budget." ("When confronted with 8 major revenue items and 20 major spending items, the public backs down to a smaller net deficit cut of 23 percent, but still does far better than Congress, which has increased, not cut, deficits throughout the Reagan-Bush years, despite the fact that 19 out of 20 Americans wants to cut the deficit and virtually all political leaders say we should do so.")
* Foreign Affairs magazine distributed advance copies of an article called "The 100-Day Economic Agenda," part of the issue of the magazine to be published this month. ("In recognizing the inescapable link between economic strength at home and influence abroad, the President-elect may not only improve the lives of millions of Americans but help many nations abroad that are counting on renewed and confident leadership from Washington.")
 
One Week's Total
 And that was this week alone.
On Monday, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's Commission on Competitiveness is releasing "America's Agenda," billed as "a book-length blueprint for the next Administration."
The week after next, the American Enterprise Institute, a moderately conservative research organization here, is holding a two-day seminar called "Advice to the New President."
And in early December, the Progressive Policy Institute will publish "Mandate for Change," 14 chapters on the main issues of the day, like economic growth, health care, international affairs and the environment. This institute is home base for many Clinton advisers and is thus probably the most influential of the dozens of nonprofit organizations here that devote their days to writing papers on Government policy and filing 401(c)(3) tax exemption forms.
Each of the organizations would no doubt like to fill the role played 12 years ago by the Heritage Foundation. About this time in 1980, Heritage published "Mandate for Leadership: Policy Management in a Conservative Administration." It became the Bible for the new Administration. Many of its policy precepts, like supply-side economics, became Reagan Administration dogma. And many Heritage scholars joined the new Government.
 
Series of 'Mandates' Wanes
 In 1984, Heritage published "Mandate II: Continuing the Conservative Revolution," and in 1988 it put out "Mandate III: Policy Strategies for the 1990's." Neither was as successful as the first one.
This year, smelling the coffee, the conservative foundation decided not to publish a new "Mandate" but to confine its effort to individual papers on such topics as health care, trimming the size of the civil service and foreign and military policy.
"In 1980," said Herbert B. Berkowitz, a Heritage vice president, " 'Mandate for Leadership' was the only game in town. This time around, virtually everyone is hitting the ground running with their advice."
Politely, Mr. Clinton's staff says the President-elect welcomes advice and has actually read a draft of the Progressive Policy Institute's book. "He has a voracious appetite for policy," Mr. Reed said. "He really is curious about these big questions."
 
What Experts on Experts Say
 But experts in the field of advice say they are not sure all this paper is worth the staples that hold it together.
Reached by telephone, Ann Landers said Mr. Clinton "would be wise to ignore all the advice that's coming at him from all directions and do what he thinks is right for the country."
And Judith Martin, who writes the syndicated "Miss Manners" column, said: "The first rule of giving advice is you only give it when it's sought. It's rude to go around giving advice to people who haven't asked for it. And it's futile, too, because they won't take it. It's more than a rule of etiquette. It's a rule of practicality."

HEADLINE: Panamanians Will Vote Today On Changes That Ban an Army

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Panamanians vote Sunday in a constitutional referendum that many view as a verdict on the fragile Government that took office during the American invasion three years ago.
Some Panamanians believe a yes vote would help consolidate democratic changes introduced by President Guillermo Endara, the reluctant and easygoing leader of the coalition that won elections in May 1989 but could not take office. 
 He was installed after United States forces landed in Panama in December 1989 to apprehend the country's militaqry strongman, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who had been indicted in the United States on drug-trafficking charges.
Still, many Panamanians predict a huge no vote today, one that would amount to a firm rejection of Mr. Endara's Government. The President and aides are widely accused of ignoring Panama's social problems and hesitating to make decisions except under strong prodding from the American Ambassador, Deane R. Hinton.
Although Panama's economy is expanding rapidly, unemployment remains in double digits in many areas. Many citizens are also dissatisfied with the lawyerly style of Mr. Endara, a sharp departure from the passionate language of past leaders.
 
59 Changes Proposed
 Voters are to approve or reject with a single yes or no vote a package of 59 changes in the 1972 Constitution, including an amendment prohibiting Panama from having an army.
The prohibition would be a constitutional recognition of the de facto situation that has existed since United States forces forcibly disbanded the Panamanian Defense Forces and captured their leader, General Noriega. Since then, Panama has had only a police force.
But those lined up against the packing, including many who supported General Noriega's ouster, say the Government deserves a no vote regardless of the substance of the changes.
"We are voting no because the politicians who got into power with our help have turned out to be a total failure," said Tomas Herrera, a lawyer who was part of the public campaign against General Noriega and is now part of a group organizing a new political party.
A poll published Friday suggested that more than a third of the voters were still undecided and that the rest were almost evenly divided. But opponents of the constitutional package seem much more confident of victory than the supporters.
 
Frustration Is Cited
 Even the country's First Vice President, Ricardo Arias Calderon, whose Christian Democratic Party was the main architect of the constitutional proposals in the Legislative Assembly, suggested that a big no vote would signal that "the majority feel enormously frustrated for what the Government of Endara has not done."
Mr. Arias, who has been excluded from executive decision-making since last year after a dispute with the President, said a yes vote would reflect a national consensus on shifting Panamanian politics away from dictatorship.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: Campaign Finances;
With Gifts From All Sides, Who Gets Clinton's Ear?

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
From his convention address in July to his victory speech last week, Bill Clinton vowed to change the political landscape by reducing the role of big money and powerful special interests.
But now that he has won after raising more private money for a Presidential campaign than any contender in modern times, his biggest financial backers are preparing to call in their chits. And one difficulty for the President-elect is that many contributors are seeking laws and regulations at odds with one another. 
 Labor contributors clash with big business contributors, banking interests oppose those in the insurance and securities industries, and a wide array of donors in the health care business have competing ideas on the best way to change the nation's medical system.
"Clinton's challenge will be to successfully confront those who have put him in office," said Ellen S. Miller, executive director of the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan organization that studies the influence of money in politics. "He faces the questions of what to do for all of those who have played in the pay-to-play system."
Mr. Clinton's fund-raisers took in more than $70 million in the general election campaign, shattering the record of $52 million set in 1988 by Michael S. Dukakis. Mr. Clinton also raised $26 million for the primaries, not counting matching money from the Government. He and his opponent, President Bush, also received $55 million each from the Federal Election Commission after their party conventions.
 
Disappointments Loom
 Federal election laws limit how much money can be given directly to campaign organizations. But donors can easily circumvent the limits by directing the money instead to the political parties and to state and local organizations that also work on behalf of the Presidential candidates. Likewise, limits on how much campaigns can spend are easily circumvented through the "soft money" loopholes, which permit unlimited spending on activities like voter drives and advertising that does not specifically use a candidate's name.
Even the people who raised the money have begun to acknowledge a fundamental truth that was generally unspoken before the election: taking so much money from so many interests makes it inevitable that many corporations and wealthy people who gave will wind up disappointed.
"There will be some who express the attitude that, gee whiz, me and my industry helped out and we're not getting better attention," said Donald R. Sweitzer, a Clinton fund-raiser who was the finance director for the Democratic National Committee in 1988. "But what I tell people is that what you get for your contribution is an ear. The candidate will listen to you, but then he will make a decision based on what he thinks is good for the public."
Many contributors, of course, give money precisely because they are seeking such access. Mr. Sweitzer added that it is a political fact of life that victorious candidates must balance the interests of competing contributors. But what makes Mr. Clinton's situation different is the unusually large number of groups expecting his help, particularly on economic and health care issues; his appeal worked to get dollars from a wider array of contributors and industries than most candidates.
"So many people got on the bandwagon as they saw that he was winning," said Gerry Klepner, legislative director of the American Federation of State County and Municipal Employees, one of the largest unions to support Mr. Clinton. "Everybody on both sides of virtually every issue ultimately decided to support him."
The President-elect has supported calls for stricter rules on lobbyists: establishing more rigorous requirements on disclosure of clients and stipulating a much longer waiting period between the time officials leave Government jobs and the time they can begin lobbying it. He has also said he supports legislation that would change the campaign finance rules and diminish the influence of big money in politics.
[On Friday Mr. Clinton issued guidelines for members of his transition team that imposed a six-month ban on lobbying after Inauguration Day and prohibited involvement in decisions that could affect a member's interests.]
 
Where Money Came From
 But over the last year, he and his senior campaign aides relied on money from many interests with issues before the Government. Indeed, Mr. Clinton's largest groups of contributors have been lawyers and lobbyists, who by some estimates have given more than $5 million. Many contributors do not identify themselves by occupation, but various research organizations match computerized lists of donors against lists of people in various industries and professions to make estimates of industry-by-industry donations.
Of those groups able to be more precisely identified, the biggest donors were unions and Wall Street concerns. Interestingly, the American Trial Lawyers Association, which Mr. Bush accused of having undue influence over the Clinton-Gore campaign, has been identified as giving only $550,000 out of a total of $12.9 million given by lawyers and lobbyists to both parties as of Aug. 31.
Of the 10 top contributors to the Democratic Party this year, four were union groups representing steel workers, educators, sheet metal laborers and government employees. By some estimates they gave more than 14 percent of the party's revenue, in the hope of shaping Mr. Clinton's legislative plans and having a say in the selection of his Cabinet and other top Government officials.
For the unions, which have been essentially frozen out of the White House for more than a decade, the trick is not to ask for too much at once but to focus on just a few issues.
 
A Position Evolves
 Top union employees met in Washington earlier this month to consider strategies to obtain legislation they have been seeking for years. They have already made it plain that they want the new President to endorse legislation that would extend and control health care costs and prevent employers from hiring permanent strike-replacement workers. They have also pushed for an economic package that would create more jobs by emphasizing spending on things like rebuilding bridges and roads.
Mr. Clinton was embraced relatively late in his campaign by many unions and has said he would support many of their proposals, particularly on creating jobs. But he has disagreed with them on some issues, too.
For instance, he said in the past that he would support repeal of a Federal provision that permits states to adopt anti-union work laws. But in a recent television interview he said he was satisfied with the law as it now stands, although he added that if Congress insisted on repealing the provision he would go along.
Health care interests have also sought to influence Mr. Clinton's plans. He and the Democrats have received more than $2 million from drug company executives, insurers and medical groups, each with differing views on how to overhaul the system.
The drug companies are against price regulations. The insurers are generally against Federal standards on private health insurance, including coverage and rates, as well as any attempt to restrict their ability to withhold insurance from sick or poor people. The American Medical Association has sought to make it mandatory for employers to cover all workers. And casualty insurers and doctors' groups favor limits on malpractice lawsuits, a move strongly opposed by the trial lawyers.
Mr. Clinton has proposed forming a new governmental body, composed of consumers and health care providers, to establish national limits on health spending. He has recommended that the Government guarantee insurance coverage for people who are not working and give tax credits to small employers to help offset the cost of health insurance. But many of the most important details of his plan remain undecided.
The investment interests on Wall Street, which Mr. Clinton courted with more success than any modern Democratic Presidential contender, are also nervously awaiting the new President's views on changing the financial system. Big banks are hoping he does away with the Depression-era laws that have made it hard for them to underwrite corporate securities. Investment houses would like to see them left in place. The insurance industry would like to see the new Administration retain the restrictions that prevent banks from branching into the insurance field.
And many of Mr. Clinton's Wall Street contributors are hoping he was not too serious when he made an issue of excessive executive pay. During the campaign, he said he hoped to discourage high salaries by limiting the ability of corporations to deduct as business expenses all salaries above $1 million.
"I told him he would do much better with the Wall Street crowd if he went a little easier on them," said one executive who would speak only anonymously because he did not want it known that he had switched allegiances and raised money for the Democrats. "He didn't listen. He raised a lot of money and got elected, but it's not too late for him to take it a little slower on us."

HEADLINE: Clinton's Promise of Cleaning House Worries Some Career Civil Servants

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
As a senior official of the Social Security Administration, Louis B. Hays staunchly defended Federal efforts to halt payment of disability benefits to tens of thousands of people.
More recently, he made concessions to California officials resisting Congressional efforts to set strict standards for nursing homes. Mr. Hays has carried out Reagan and Bush policies so vigorously, in fact, that Toby S. Edelman, a lawyer at the National Senior Citizens Law Center, said she had been astounded to learn that he was a career Government employee. 
 "He seemed to take a special delight in carrying out the policies" of the last 12 years, said Mrs. Edelman, who challenged many of those policies as a lawyer for nursing home residents and other elderly people.
Mr. Hays has worked for the Federal Government since 1973. He and many other career Government employees now worry about their fate under a Clinton Administration that has pledged to dismantle the Reagan-Bush legacy the employees helped create.
 
Possibly an Obstacle
 In theory at least, Civil Service laws protect the career employees against political reprisals. But the success of the new Administration will depend, in part, on its ability to enlist their support for Mr. Clinton's efforts.
Since those men and women are entrenched in Government because of their status as civil servants, "they may present quite an obstacle to the incoming Clinton Administration," said David C. Vladeck, a lawyer at the Public Citizen Litigation Group, a nonprofit law firm.
The career employees exist at crucial spots throughout the Government. As deputy director of the Federal Office of Population Affairs, Gerald J. Bennett has repeatedly tried to halt abortion counseling at family planning clinics that get Federal money.
As a top official at the White House Office of Management and Budget, James B. MacRae Jr. has tried to roll back Federal regulation of health, safety and the environment. As a senior member of the Foreign Service, Joseph G. Sullivan helped design and carry out Bush Administration policy in Central America, especially Nicaragua.
 
An Elite Corps
 The 7,400 career members of the Senior Executive Service form an elite corps of Government officials, supervising space shuttle flights, cancer research and the collection of economic data, among other tasks. In theory, they are insulated against the political shock waves of a Presidential election. They are not supposed to be demoted for any reason except poor performance or misconduct.
Indeed, the new Administration is not even supposed to shift such senior executives to new jobs until the end of a 120-day "get-acquainted period," during which the career employees have an opportunity to show their mettle to the political appointees. After that, the career executives can be assigned to other jobs in the same agency.
The purpose of these guarantees, as explained by a political appointee at the Bush White House, is to "prevent the new Administration from abruptly getting rid of members of the Senior Executive Service regarded as collaborators with the ancien regime."
 
Some Opposition
 Some longtime Federal employees quietly resisted Reagan and Bush policies. Others embraced those policies so enthusiastically that they were seen as full-fledged members of the Administrations.
Mr. Hays, the Social Security official, declined to discuss the work he had done over the last 12 years. "As a career civil servant," he said, "I believe it is inappropriate for me to comment during this transition period."
Mr. Vladeck, the Public Citizen lawyer, said that Mr. McRae, in his position at the budget office, "has been a zealous advocate for deregulation, has carried out the agenda of the Reagan-Bush Administration with unparalleled fervor and has a staff of young men and women who are true believers in that policy."
Carol A. Bonosaro, president of the Senior Executives Association, said that career employees who are seen as "cheerleaders" for one administration often pay a price when the other party takes office.
Despite protections in the Civil Service law, she said: "There is a real danger that a career executive will be sent to the turkey farm -- given a job with few responsibilities, few staff and no access to the boss. It is an incredible waste of talent and of taxpayers' money."
 
Doubts Expressed
 Within days after voters rejected President Bush, some civil servants acknowledged publicly for the first time that they had had doubts about Reagan and Bush policies they had tried to enforce.
Mr. Bennett, for example, said in an interview that he believed the ban on abortion counseling was "not good policy." But he said: "President Reagan and President Bush had ordered us to issue that regulation. Our private views become irrelevant once we get directions like that."
A Federal appeals court blocked enforcement of the rule on Nov. 3. Aides to President-elect Bill Clinton predict that he will rescind the ban on abortion counseling.
Mr. Bennett has worked at the Department of Health and Human Services and its predecessor agencies since 1967. "There is a risk in working closely with political people, especially if one is identified with controversial policies," he said. "But as a civil servant, I can carry out policies that I don't necessarily agree with."
 
Roles Carry Over
 Mr. Hays was closely identified with a Reagan Administration policy under which the Social Security agency ignored Federal court decisions it disliked. "We have a policy of either acquiescing in court decisions and following them, or nonacquiescing in court decisions and not following them," he explained to Congress in 1984.
After Federal judges, governors and members of Congress denounced this policy as lawless, Social Security officials ultimately agreed to abide by Federal court rulings.
No person has been more instrumental in efforts to curb the growth of Federal health and welfare programs than David K. Kleinberg, a 24-year employee of the Office of Management and Budget. Over the last decade, he has drafted hundreds of unpopular proposals to trim Medicare, Medicaid, Social Security and welfare spending.
But he is a member of the Senior Executive Service, responsible for preparing the President's budget each year, and in the Clinton Administration he is likely to have the same responsibilities.
 
Praise From Bosses
 At the State Department, Mr. Sullivan served as director of the Office of Central American Affairs and as a Deputy Assistant Secretary. Paul S. Reichler, a Washington lawyer who represented the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua in the 1980's, described Mr. Sullivan as "a true believer, a willing implementer of Administration policy, who had a visceral hatred of the Sandinistas."
Mr. Sullivan, a Foreign Service officer for 22 years, said he could not respond without permission from the State Department, and the department did not give permission. But a department official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, praised Mr. Sullivan, saying: "The duty of a Foreign Service officer is to serve the Administration. Our foreign policy had great success in bringing peace and democracy to Central America."
In February, Mr. Bush nominated Mr. Sullivan to be Ambassador to Nicaragua. At least two lawmakers raised questions about Mr. Sullivan's efforts to aid Nicaraguan politicians opposing the Sandinista Government. He never had a chance to answer those questions because the Senate held no hearing and the White House withdrew the nomination in September.
Mr. Sullivan is now working on several short-term projects, waiting for a new assignment from the new administration.

But he said: "President Reagan and President Bush had ordered us to issue that regulation. Our private views become irrelevant." (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)
