HEADLINE: Surge in Home Foreclosures and Evictions Shattering Families

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
The number of homes in foreclosure in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut has almost doubled since the middle of last year, rising to levels not seen in decades.
The sudden surge in foreclosures, after a steady climb since the late 1980's, reflects the region's job losses, falling real-estate values and a growing backlog of cases that have clogged the courts, delaying some foreclosures for months and even years, lenders and lawyers say. 
 Moreover, these experts say, some lenders, facing closer scrutiny from Federal regulators, have become quicker to foreclose, or begin legal proceedings to take property, particularly in areas where home sales have rebounded. "They are clearing the books as soon as they can," said Doug Duncan, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association in Washington.
On the front lines, the impact is huge. "We used to have 10 foreclosure sales a year -- now we have 10 a week," said Capt. Mary A. Tierney, who handles the sales for the Hudson County Sheriff's Department in New Jersey.
 
Evictions 6 Days a Week
 Foreclosure-related evictions are also rising. In Hudson County, there were 217 by Nov. 5, compared to 189 for all 1991 and about 15 a year in the 1980's.
"I am scheduling evictions for March and April right now -- that's how backlogged we are," said Deputy Sheriff Michael Geerlof of Hudson County. "We also started doing them six days a week."
The emotional trauma for the families who lose their homes to foreclosure is incalculable. "It's devastating," said the owner of a three-bedroom condominium in Secaucus, N.J., who was evicted Monday.
The owner, who spoke on the condition that his name not be used, said that he bought his apartment for $350,000 in June 1989 and six months later lost his $300,000-a-year job with a corporate relocation firm. His monthly mortgage payment, including maintenance and taxes, was $3,500. "At the time, with the money I was making, $3,500 a month was nothing," he said. "But things change."
Now, at age 53, he makes $14,000 a year running his own small moving company; his wife is paid about $30,000 a year working for an airline. The couple is renting a two-bedroom apartment for $1,000 a month in the same complex where they owned a condominium.
Their former home will probably be sold by the Fortune Bank of Clearwater, Fla., which held the mortgage on it and bought it back for a nominal fee at a foreclosure auction earlier this year. The bank's asking price, according to a broker familiar with the property, may be "under $200,000."
 
A Glimmer of Good News
 "I got taken for a ride," the former owner said about his original purchase, adding that he hoped to relocate to the South. "Now, I just want to be a nice quiet old man."
Some economists see in the foreclosure data a glimmer of evidence that the worst of the recession may be behind New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. They note that the percentage of home loans that went into foreclosure in the three states dropped between the first and second quarters of 1992, as did the percentage of loans that were delinquent for 90 days or more.
"Foreclosure rates lag the economy," said Rae D. Rosen, the vice president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York. She noted however that bottoming out should not be equated with a quick upturn. "Our economy may just be hitting bottom, though it's more likely that it will happen next year," she said.
The foreclosures involve everything from million-dollar suburban properties to low-priced condominium units. "We are talking about the middle class, even bankers -- people that have never been in this position before," said Leanor Clarke, a counselor at Westchester Residential Opportunities in White Plains, a nonprofit organization that advises people in financial distress.
"They are slow to react to problems, and when they do it is often too late," she added. "They can't accept that they are living in a different income class. They don't take it well."
Ms. Clarke said her organization's caseload of foreclosed mortgages has increased from about 50 in 1987 to about 500 today. "That's all I do nowadays," she added, "people in trouble with their mortgage."
 
New Jersey Has Worst Rate
 Figures from the National Mortgage Bankers Association for the quarter ending June 30 show that New Jersey had the nation's highest proportion of mortgages in foreclosure, 2.36 percent. That means that one in every 42 home loans was in foreclosure. A year earlier, the figure was 1.40, or one in every 71. For the second quarter of 1987, just before the stock market crash, the figure was 0.71, or one in every 141.
In Connecticut, which was surpassed only by New Jersey, Massachusetts and Oklahoma, the second quarter foreclosure rate was 1.59 percent, or one in every 63 loans. The rate for the same period in 1991 was 0.86, or one in every 116. For the second quarter in 1987, it was 0.20, or one in every 500.
In New York, which ranked eighth nationally, behind New Hampshire, Florida and Kansas, the figure was 1.43 percent, or one in every 70 loans. The rate for the same period a year earlier was 0.85, or one in every 118. For the second quarter of 1987, it was 0.46, or one in every 217.
Nationally, 1.04 percent of mortgage loans, or one in every 96, were in foreclosure in the second quarter, and that figure has deviated little since 1986.
 
Court Is Bank's Last Resort
 The statistics do not include foreclosures on cooperative apartments, which exist throughout the region but are concentrated in New York City. Co-op loans, which finance the purchase of stock rather than real estate, are subject to different regulations than mortgages and are not tallied by court clerks, bankers or bar associations.
The region's foreclosure figures -- which are more than double those recorded in the recessions of 1981-82 and 1973-74 -- also do not include loans that are more than 90 days delinquent but are not in foreclosure because lenders have worked out repayment agreements with the borrowers.
"Every bank is different, but, generally, going to court is the last thing you want to do," said Theodore J. Doll, the president of Washington Savings Bank in Hoboken, N.J., where 50 of its 2,000 home loans, or 2.5 percent, are in foreclosure and an additional 24, or 1.2 percent, are being repaid under "work-out" agreements.
Bank foreclosure policies vary widely, but usually the process does not begin until a borrower is at least 90 days delinquent. Once foreclosure is started, it may take several months before a judgment is reached in court. Then it may take several more months before the home can be seized or sold. These days, the property is usually sold at auction to the bank that made the mortgage, which usually pays only a nominal fee. Other bidders, if they succeed, are required to pay off the borrower's mortgage.
 
6 Months Before Summons
 The process is so lengthy that only one in seven loans that go into foreclosure result in judgments. And of those, only about one in seven result in evictions. Most borrowers who are subject to foreclosure sell their homes, especially if they have equity in the properties. If they cannot sell, a common problem these days, or if they have little or no equity, they often seek revised payment schedules or obtain stays through legal motions or bankruptcy protection.
"In New Jersey, it takes six months just to get a sheriff to issue a summons and two years before you can evict," said Dr. Paul S. Nadler, a professor of finance at Rutgers University in Newark. "There are judges out there who say, 'I don't want to make someone homeless.' "
In some cases, the length and complexity of foreclosure is an incentive for delinquent borrowers to remain in foreclosure; they can often continue to live in their homes free for months -- even years -- before they are evicted. "For those who have no intention of paying, they are getting a nice long free ride," said Sheila R. Shemtoz, the foreclosure clerk for the Sheriff's Department in Monmouth County, N.J.
When the foreclosed property is an apartment building, the tenants may have no knowledge of their landlord's problems. In late October, the Hudson County Sheriff evicted four tenants from an apartment building in Union City, N.J. The owner was still collecting rents, Deputy Sheriff Geerlof said, though the property had been in foreclosure since February. "One tenant even paid his November rent two days ago."
 
Vicious Circle With Taxes
 Job losses are a critical factor in foreclosures, lenders and lawyers say, because many borrowers in the mid-1980's who bought at inflated prices and had high-interest mortgages needed two incomes to make their payments. When one income disappeared through a job loss or divorce, they were unable to continue.
Some struggling borrowers also faced higher property taxes, sometimes as a result of a decline in a town's total assessed value. "It's not only killer mortgage payments some of these people face, it's killer taxes," said David M. Fleisher, a lawyer in White Plains who has represented lenders. On Long Island, for example, the total assessed value of property is declining because of lower home-sale prices, a wave of challenges to assessments and new rules removing some property from the tax rolls.
The impetus to foreclose may also be greater these days because in many parts of the region it is easier than it was in the late 1980's for a bank to sell a foreclosed home, largely because of the lower interest rates and appraised prices.
Some lenders have also been delaying foreclosures in the hope that the economy would improve and bail out delinquent borrowers. Today, though, many of those lenders say they see little economic improvement soon.
 
'Disaster for Everyone'
 Bankers also say that borrowers who made very low down payments and whose properties have lost value have little or no equity in their homes. In many instances, particularly involving condominiums and low-priced urban properties, the owners simply abandon them, lenders say.
Whatever the owner's attitude, foreclosure is "really a disaster for everyone involved," said Douglas Panetta, the owner of Bids-for-Barristers, an 18-month-old company in Tenafly, N.J., that has represented banks and lawyers in bidding at 2,500 foreclosure auctions. "Everyone loses -- the lender, the owner."
"Everyone but me," he added. "I'm thinking about franchising."

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: The President;
Friends Describe a Melancholy Bush

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOCA GRANDE, Fla., Nov. 14

 BODY:
Stoic and reclusive, President Bush has been steeling himself for his final weeks in power by driving golf balls and angling for snook and redfish through a vacation that his family and friends hoped would revive him from what they say is a state of despair.
The four days in this sleepy enclave, where he came to make peace with the nation's decision to replace him, were a needed respite for Mr. Bush, a trip suggested by his son George. 
 Friends and relatives say the President left the White House on Wednesday depressed and second-guessing his campaign. Mr. Bush has told some friends that he remained convinced through the final days of the race that he could pull off an upset victory, that he was bitter over how poorly his campaign had been run and that he believed the result had not been inevitable, despite the economy's disappointing performance.
Even as the polls in the final months consistently showed him trailing, Mr. Bush was described as having convinced himself that he would ultimately prevail. By one telling account, he dismissed the advice of Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, who in a campaign swing late in the race pleaded with Mr. Bush about campaigning harder. "Al, relax," the President is said to have told Mr. Simpson. "We're going to win this thing."
 
Candid Talk of Friends
 And in one of his last meetings with strategists, Mr. Bush is said to have looked up at one point and said to the pessimistic gathering: "Am I the only S.O.B. who thinks I'm going to win this thing?"
Supporters have been surprisingly candid about Mr. Bush's melancholy. Marilyn Quayle has told friends that Mr. Bush was shocked at the election result and that he was "having difficulty dealing with it."
The President's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, has told some supporters that the loss had hit Mr. Bush "very hard" and that he "has been feeling dreadful." And a brother, Jonathan Bush, said the President "is very disappointed."
Thomas Ashley, a friend in Washington who has spoken to Mr. Bush several times since Election Day, said: "He's gone through a real suffering period. He went to Florida bone tired and physically and emotionally spent, with the feeling he could've done better."
Mr. Ashley recalled a telephone conversation with the President before the vacation.
"I said to him, 'The way I look at it, with the economy what it was, you couldn't win,' " Mr. Ashley said. "He said, 'I think if I had run a good campaign, it would not have been that way at all.' " When Mr. Ashley told the President that he must have felt as if his insides had been kicked out, Mr. Bush responded: 'Present tense.'
Mr. Ashley said that it was not in Mr. Bush's nature to blame his campaign advisers for the defeat, but that he personally bore the weight of the loss.
 
Gloom of a Funeral
 Others said Mr. Bush felt as bereft as someone who had lost a close relative and was having difficulty even talking about it. In the few public comments about the defeat, the President has spoken in funereal terms, challenging what he said was the talk about "the demise" of the party and raising concern that a Republican dinner earlier this week would resemble "a wake."
He has tried to conceal his disappointment with humor, comparing his fate to that of Winston Churchill, who in defeat spoke of being granted "the Order of the Boot."
Mr. Bush's post-election blues have stood in marked contrast to the upbeat mood of Vice President Dan Quayle, who still believes he could have a future in politics if he so decides, and who was described by friends as feeling good about himself and his performance in the campaign.
Barbara Bush, meanwhile, has told friends that she is angry, particularly at the White House chief of staff, James A. Baker 3d, whom she believes frittered away several chances of turning the race around.
While Mr. Bush still occupies the Oval Office for 66 days after he returns to Washington on Sunday, an aide says he has become so demoralized that for all practical purposes he is already in semi-retirement. Unless there is some crisis, he is expected to maintain a low profile.
In another sign of the dismantling of the Administration, the President's office of legal counsel last week circulated a memorandum on ethical rules to be followed as officials move back into private life.
Mr. Bush has not decided what he will do after he leaves office, although he appears headed for Texas, where Mrs. Bush will soon be searching for their new home. The Bushes had listed their official residence as a hotel suite in Houston, but they are expected to give that up. Their vacation home in Kennebunkport, Me., is not fully winterized.
Aides say the President's remaining days in Washington will be mostly ceremonial. One of his last decisions will be whether he will personally deliver a State of the Union Message in January or simply send a written report to Capitol Hill.
 
Maintaining Vigorous Schedule
 It was a sign of his new life as a lame duck President that one local newspaper, The Sun Herald, noted his arrival here with the front-page headline "The First Snowbirds." The reference is to retirees who come to Florida in the winter and go back north in the summer. The Bushes have been staying at the waterfront compound of Bayard Sharp, an heir to the Du Pont fortune and a relative of Mr. Bush's friend Will Farish.
Mr. Bush tried to maintain his usual vigorous schedule, rising some mornings at 6 o'clock to jog through the banyan-lined streets of a town that was once the Gulf Coast gathering place for the likes of the Astors and the Vanderbilts and the Du Ponts. Later he would bounce briskly from one sport to another.
Still, there were signs of detachment. When the President returned from a fishing excursion with Brent Scowcroft, his national security adviser, his mood seemed to match the sentiment expressed in the names of three neighborhood streets: Dam If I Know, Dam If I Care and Dam If I Will.

HEADLINE: Progress Is Slow In New Efforts To Find Bombs

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Nearly four years after the bombing of a Pan Am flight over Scotland started a search for better ways to find hidden bombs, the widespread use of more advanced detectors is still years away.
Both the families of victims of the bombing, which killed 270 people, and top aviation security officials say there are signs of progress but the prototype bomb detectors being tested in airports have not been developed as swiftly as they had hoped. 
 Adm. Clyde Robbins, retired, the Transportation Department's top security and intelligence official, said in an interview that he had hoped to have high-performance detectors in place at "the most sensitive airports" in two years. He said it would probably be four or five years before they were widespread.
Admiral Robbins was in Albany today to meet with relatives of those who died in the Pan Am bombing to discuss a research program on which millions of dollars are being spent each year, largely as a result of political pressure from the families.
 
Never Happen Fast Enough
 "Of course these things never happen as fast as you like," he said in an interview before the meeting. "It has taken us longer to get the equipment on the street than we would like, but it is very developmental, and much of this equipment is state of the art."
Elizabeth Philipps, whose 20-year-old daughter Sarah was killed in the Pan Am bombing, said the victims' relatives were monitoring the Federal Aviation Administration's research programs closely, sitting in as observers on research committees.
"We feel that progress has been made, but that the pace has been far too slow," she said. "We feel that the airlines have had a much louder voice in the economics of the improvements than airline passengers have."
Shortly after the bombing, the F.A.A. said it would require all big airports to install a new kind of bomb detector, known as a thermal neutron analyzer, which bombards luggage with radiation and analyzes the atomic particles that are emitted in reaction. Six were built and tested, but their performance fell short of expectations. In 1990 Congress told the F.A.A. not to require any detectors until they had been tested and proven reliable at detecting small quantities of plastic explosives.
Since then several new approaches for detecting bombs have been explored by various companies, with financing from the F.A.A.
 
Standards to Meet
 This month the F.A.A. for the first time told prospective manufacturers of new equipment what standards their machines would have to meet to be certified for use at airports.
The performance requirements call for equipment to be automatic, sounding an alarm to alert an operator when bomb material passes through. That way, an operator's judgment would not be needed, as it is with existing X-ray equipment used at airports, which cannot reliably detect plastic explosives.
For security reasons, the agency did not disclose the reliability rate required of new equipment and the size of explosives that must be detectable.
The agency said that since it was unlikely any single technology would meet the performance requirements, combinations of existing technologies will probably have to be used until some breakthrough is made.
In the next two months, according to F.A.A. documents, the agency will begin testing one promising combination of technologies at the terminals of Delta Air Lines and American Airlines at Miami International Airport, using both advanced X-ray machines and vapor-detection equipment that mechanically sniffs out bombs. The trials will include both F.A.A. test baggage and actual passenger baggage.
 
Tests Being Planned
 Other tests are being planned at airports in Newark, San Francisco and other cities.
Many devices being assessed have their origins in medicine.
Invision Technologies Inc., for example, has developed the CTX-5000, a compact unit that could be used at airline check-in counters. It uses advanced computer-assisted tomography scanning, like the CT scan technology widely used in medicine.
The device scans a piece of luggage from all sides, draws a 3-dimensional cross-section and pinpoints the location of explosive material.
Another company, Vivid Technologies Inc., uses an X-ray analysis technique first developed by Hologic Inc. for measuring bone densities.
And Scan-Tech Security Inc. has developed a way of recognizing the spectra emitted when certain chemicals are bombarded with X-rays, using an advanced computer processing technology known as artificial neural networks. Put simply, this is a way of stringing electronic circuits together like brain cells, so that a computer can in effect learn to recognize patterns rather than being programmed.
Experts said one advantage of these approaches is that the bomb detectors could also search out other substances, like illegal drugs.

HEADLINE: Taxpayer Revolt in Colorado Vote Raises Alarm About Lost Services

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DENVER, Nov. 14

 BODY:
It was potentially the most radical change in any state government this year, and it did not involve a candidate.
Colorado voters approved a measure that stripped the power of state and local governments to increase taxes. Any increase in taxes -- from the state income tax to a school district's mill levy -- now requires approval of the voters. 
 "This was the most important ballot initiative in the country," said David Keating, executive vice-president of the National Taxpayers Union, a conservative anti-tax group.
The measure, known as the Taxpayer Bill of Rights, has alarmed state and local governments, who warn that services could be deeply cut and schools left in the lurch.
Gov. Roy Romer, a Democrat, who campaigned against the measure, has predicted that schools could see a 12 percent drop in financing.
 
Hope for a National Model
 "This takes the issues of taxation away from representative government," said Mr. Romer, who added that "it's very difficult" to win voter approval for tax increases.
Colorado has been a harbinger before, as a leader in the move to limit the terms of officeholders, an effort that passed in 14 states in the recent elections. And groups that seek to limit government's taxing power say the state measure will serve as a model for similar efforts around the country.
With a few exceptions, voters around the country this year voted soundly against new taxes.
South Dakota rejected a state income tax. California repealed a tax on snack foods and rejected a proposal to increases taxes on the wealthy. Voters in Colorado also turned down a proposal to increase the sales tax by a penny. And Arizona voted to require a two-thirds majority of the Legislature to increase taxes, joining 20 other states with tax limitation measures.
 
Measure Defeated Twice
 The exceptions came in Idaho and Michigan, where voters rejected curbs on property taxes.
The Colorado measure, which was led by Douglas Bruce, a Colorado Springs real estate investor, had been defeated twice before. The amendment won 54 percent to 46 percent.
"It's our money, and if we want bigger government, we'll pay for it,"Mr. Bruce said. "But we don't want it to be crammed down our throat."
He said he was outspent 3 to 1, and he complained that opponents had tried to scare voters.
"I'm no anarchist," he said. "I'm a short-haired, middle-aged bachelor with a paunch living in the suburbs with a puppy. I'm not a threat. I just don't like government paternalism. Can't we decide for ourselves what taxes should be? Does Big Brother know what's best for us?"
The measure is more comprehensive than California's Proposition 13, the 1978 measure that cut property taxes but did not remove the power of the Legislature to pass increases in sales and income taxes. The Colorado measure does not impose a tax cut.
"This is the best tax and spending measure that we have seen -- period," said Mr. Keating of the Taxpayers Union.
The measure requires that the state save 1 percent of its budget for three years to be used for emergencies. But the Legislature must declare an emergency before it spends the reserve.
In addition, it puts a cap on spending. Governments can spend no more than they did the previous year, with an adjustment for inflation and population growth. And the measure forbids any special elections to decide tax increases. Votes on new taxes can only be held during the general elections.
Local governments officials say the measure would effectively keep them from accepting state or Federal grants, in some cases, since the money would exceed the spending cap.
The tax measure threatens to put the state's tourism agency out of business. The tourism board, which has been financed by the Legislature with a tax that expires every five years, runs out of money in July. And the next general election will not be held until November of 1993.
"We would be the only state without a national tourism promotion campaign," said Deborah Milo Cornelius, a spokeswoman for the tourism board. Tourism, the second-largest industry in Colorado, after manufacturing, generated $5.6 billion here last year.
For local governments, the tax measure could stop projects in mid-stream. Mike Gay, the director of public works in Fort Morgan, said the town's new sewer project cannot continue without a tax increase. The current system is out of compliance with standards set by the Environmental Protection Agency.
And Jim Collard, the city manager in Brush, said the measure could thwart the ability of towns to negotiate tax incentives with new businesses.
"This thing has a catchy slogan, but it's bad government," he said. "When you've got to wait a year for a vote on taxes, you'd have to delay negotiations with a new business. And they won't wait. They'll go somewhere else."

HEADLINE: U.S. Team in Hanoi Studies Relics of the Missing

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Up a musty stairwell in a museum commemorating the triumphs of the People's Army of Vietnam, a team of American investigators sit hunched over laptop computers and a camera tripod, trying to end what for many American families is the continuing torment of the Vietnam War.
Every half hour or so, a group of Vietnamese museum workers slowly make their way up the steps, lugging another assortment of relics collected from the enemy, the United States, in that long-ago war. 
 The relics examined by the Pentagon investigators one morning this week included an American-issue military parachute, a pocket flare gun, an airman's helmet with the wearer's name on it, a blue-felt Air Force captain's cap, a plastic flap from the fuel tank of an American military jet, a single pink cotton handkerchief and a pair of red-and-white socks -- all of it hidden away for years in unlit storerooms in the Museum of the People's Army, the national war museum in Hanoi.
 
2,265 Still Missing
 This, the American investigators say, is what they have been waiting for.
If they are correct, these bits and pieces of metal, rubber and cloth -- along with thousands of black-and-white photographs stored elsewhere in the museum -- will allow the United States to determine the fate of many of the 2,265 Americans who are still officially listed as unaccounted for from the Vietnam War.
It was only last month, after an American researcher alerted the Pentagon to the treasure trove in the museum, that the Hanoi Government agreed to allow a Defense Department team to come in to study the full collection.
 
Breakthrough Is Seen
 The commander of the American investigators now working in Vietnam, Lieut. Col. Jack Donovan, described Vietnam's new open-access decree as a breakthrough.
"I've heard this described as the central biggest development since 1973 in terms of accounting for missing Americans," he said. It was in 1973 that United States ground forces pulled out of Vietnam.
Until last week, Americans investigators had only guessed at what might be found in the war museum, three blocks from Ho Chi Minh's mausolem in the heart of the Vietnamese capital. Only a small fraction of the articles were actually on public display in the museum, which draws a steady stream of visitors. Now they know it contains personal items and military gear taken from scores, and perhaps hundreds, of American soldiers, pilots and sailors who were captured or killed in North Vietnamese territory.
"My gut feeling is that our work is going to be very valuable," said James Minihan, a 26-year-old Navy petty officer from Jacksonville, N.C., who spends his days at the museum tapping away on the keyboard of a laptop computer, cataloging the relics as they are placed on the floor on a white sheet of paper and photographed. "The Vietnamese have kept very complete records on this material."
Vietnam is eager for normal diplomatic relations with the United States and is desperate for Washington to lift the economic embargo it has imposed since the end of the war. Since 1988, it has allowed Pentagon investigators into the country to search for the remains of Americans missing from the war. The Defense Department opened an office in Hanoi last year.
 
No Single Depository
 There is no single repository in Vietnam for wartime army records and artifacts gathered from American soldiers. Instead, records and relics are scattered throughout the country in dozens of war museums and archives, some built by individual provinces and cities to commemorate their local contribution to the war against the Americans and, earlier, against the French.
The Americans, who until last month had been granted access to only a few museums and archives in Vietnam, are now discovering how meticulous the Vietnamese record-keeping was.
In the Army Museum in Hanoi, the well-preserved relics range from military penknives and wristwatches to bicycle-sized chunks of jagged metal from the wings of B-52 bombers shot down over North Vietnamese territory. Virtually all of the items inspected so far have been carefully tagged to show where and when they were found.
The artifacts may help the Pentagon determine exactly where individual soldiers died and how, or where American planes went down and whether their pilots survived. That in turn will help American search teams decide which areas of the Vietnamese countryside should be combed for human remains.
 
'Pieces of the Puzzle'
 "The end result of work does not take place here in Hanoi," said Chief Warrant Officer Gary Fulton of West Des Moines, another of the investigators working at the museum. "We're getting pieces of the puzzle that will take us back out into the field."
As he spoke, a Vietnamese museum worker carefully laid an American aviator's helmet on the paper-covered floor so it could be photographed from several different angles.
"That could be valuable," said Chief Fulton, motioning to a small, worn name tag that had been affixed to the outside of the helmet, apparently by the airmen who had once worn it. Mr. Fulton showed the helmet to a reporter on condition that the name not be used.
Some of the relics inspected by the investigators will be of no use in determining the fate of missing Americans. They were taken from prisoners of war who were freed by the Vietnamese years ago, or they are so innocuous that it will be impossible to link them to any one person.
"We were given a brown leather wallet -- empty, no identification, no pictures inside," said Petty Officer Eric Frandsen, 28, of Lansing, Mich., the team's photographer. "I photographed it. I don't know how valuable something like that would be."
 
Many Bear Identification
 But many other artifacts turned over so far by the Vietnamese do bear a name, a serial number or some other notation that could help American investigators tie them to a missing soldier or pilot, or to a particular battle, crash or ambush.
The Pentagon team has inspected American-issue military parachutes and life vests in recent days that, while they have no name tags, are stamped with a series of inspection dates, which should make it possible to determine with some accuracy when the survival equipment was used by a serviceman.
The names and other details can be checked against information stored in the laptop computers carried by the American investigators. The computers hold a detailed electronic dossier on each of the 2,265 Americans -- 2,262 men, 3 women -- who remain missing in Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia. Of these the vast majority are assumed to have been killed in combat, and are listed as missing because circumstantial evidence of death has yet to be backed up with physical proof.
The Pentagon investigators are still in the very early stages of their work, and they are reluctant to guess how long the inspections in Hanoi and elsewhere in the country will take.
 
Wary of Raising Hopes
 They are even more reluctant to estimate how many of the 2,265 cases of missing Americans might be solved by their work. They say their optimism, which is palpable here, might raise false hopes among the families of the missing,
"This work is going to help us answer questions concerning the fate of a number of missing Americans," said Robert J. Destatte, a Defense Intelligence Agency analyst whose career has been dedicated since 1979 to the search for missing Americans. "I'm confident we're moving in the right direction. But it's going to be a long process."
Some of his colleagues say the search for missing Americans is likely to continue for years.
The Vietnamese Government has already provided the Bush Administration with the thousands of photographs of dead Americans taken by Vietnamese military photographers during the war and stored in the People's Army Museum.
 
Librarian Was the Key
 The exact sequence of events that led Hanoi to turn over the photographs and to announce last month that it would grant the Pentagon full access to the war archives remains a mystery, although it is one clearly linked to the unusual relationship between the Vietnamese Government and an American researcher, Ted Schweitzer, who was given access to photographic archives at the Army Museum earlier this year.
According to the Vietnamese, Mr. Schweitzer, a 50-year-old librarian, was allowed to rummage through the museum's collection after he told museum directors that he was writing a book about the war. Vietnamese officials say they were later surprised and irritated when he turned over the results of his research to the Pentagon.
During a search of the archives, Mr. Schweitzer found thousands of photos of American servicemen who had been captured or killed by the Vietnamese. Last summer, after telling associates that he had failed to interest New York publishers in a book, Mr. Schweitzer turned the photographs over to the Defense Department.
Mr. Schweitzer is now back in Hanoi, this time as a Pentagon consultant. But the other American investigators here say they rarely see him and know almost nothing about him. He did not respond to repeated requests for an interview.
 
Hiding Material Denied
 Mr. Schweitzer's disclosure of the photos raised new questions about whether Hanoi has been hiding information that might have resolved the fate of missing Americans years ago.
Le Van Bang, director of American affairs at the Vietnamese Foreign Ministry, said that material in the museums had always been available to the United States, but that Pentagon investigators had chosen to conduct their investigation on a case-by-case basis -- requesting information about a specific soldiers instead of requesting access to everything in the museum archives. "We were not hiding anything," he said.
But Pentagon investigators working in Vietnam say the recent disclosures prove that they have been misled for years by the Vietnamese. They add, however, that the new Vietnamese pledge of cooperation is so important that there is nothing to be gained by attacking the Vietnamese publicly.
"If there was a misunderstanding with the Vietnamese, it is not so important now as the fact that we have an agreement that pleases everybody," Mr. Destatte said. "Certainly it pleases everybody on our side."

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
A New Director of Legislative Traffic

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
Bernard R. Sullivan will take on in January what is in many ways the ultimate political-insider job at the Connecticut State Capitol: chief of staff in the office of the Speaker. Mr. Sullivan says he's had a lifetime of career preparation: as a policeman.
Mr. Sullivan, who is 49 years old and a Democrat, was chief of police for Hartford, state Police Commissioner and director of security for the Hartford Insurance Group. 
 He has never worked for any legislative body, but he'll probably be feeling the heat soon enough. The newly elected Speaker, Thomas D. Ritter, a Democrat from Hartford, said recently in announcing the appointment that one of Mr. Sullivan's main duties would be to act as point man on whether to expand legalized gambling in the state to raise tax revenues.
Lawmakers say that gambling will be one of the big questions facing the state next year. Mr. Sullivan said it is a course the state might have to take if no new economic engine emerges to pull Connecticut out of its long slump.
But he promises no rough stuff.
"I'm not a tough-guy cop," he said. "I've never thought of myself as a tough-guy cop. Certainly there are times in my life when I have been in combat positions, but that's not me, that's not my life. I've been a consensus builder."
 
Raise for Legislators?
 Could New York's lawmakers, already the highest paid in the country, possibly be angling to give themselves a raise during this recession? The answer in the State Capitol is no, no, no a thousand times no . . . well, maybe.
Both the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Republican, and Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, a Democrat, say they are vigorously opposed to a pay raise, especially since they have had to cut billions of dollars from the state budget and eliminate 10,000 jobs. But neither side would rule out consideration of a pay raise at a special session proposed for next month.
Under the constitution, lawmakers can only raise salaries for a subsequent two-year legislature, meaning that if they did not act in December, there could be no pay raise until the next legislature convenes in January 1995. Lawmakers' pay was last raised in July 1987, from $43,000 to the current $57,000.
Lawmakers who might -- if their arms were twisted -- support the pay raise suggest that passing it now, soon after the election, would at least give constituents lots of time to get over it, or forget about it, before the next election. Or, as Assembly Minority leader C. D. (Rapp) Rappleyea said regarding a dead-of-night pay-raise vote in December 1984: "If you're going to walk the plank, you might as well do it in shallow water."
 
Money for the Shore?
 The political infighting between Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat, and the overwhelmingly Republican legislature has become such a staple of New Jersey government that even when the two sides agree, they disagree. The most recent squabble involves a $15 million appropriation for repair of shore areas devastated by coastal storms. The appropriation whisked through the Legislature this week but the Governor, who is a big booster of shore tourism and a keen advocate of repairing storm damage, might veto the bill anyway.
The reason is that the Republicans, while stipulating that the money would come out of real-estate transfer fees, have not said what, if anything, they would cut to free up that money.
Earlier this year, over the Governor's veto, the Republicans cut $608 million in revenues out of his proposed budget by reducing the sales tax a penny, forcing deep spending cuts and reducing the unappropriated surplus to almost nothing.
Since the $15 million now goes into the general fund, taking it for shore protection will mean cutting something else, or raising some more revenue elsewhere. The Governor says the Republicans should figure out where to get the money; they say he is being needlessly stubborn.
 
A Loser's Lessons
 Chris Powell, managing editor of The Journal Inquirer, an irreverent tabloid in Manchester, rose from the trenches this spring to run for the State Senate as muckraker-turned-politician.
Although ostensibly a Republican, Mr. Powell often had as many unkind words on the campaign trail for his own party as he did for Democrats. He lost. Now he's back at his newspaper job, lessons learned, but anger toward the system alive and well.
"It confirmed my impressions of everything I thought was wrong," Mr. Powell said.
One of Mr. Powell's main problems as a candidate, he said, was that he refused to be pigeonholed. On the issue of abortion, for example, he gave a typically complicated response: yes on a woman's right to have an abortion, but also yes on whether parents should be notified if their teen-age daughter sought an abortion.
Even on what some might consider minor issues, Mr. Powell refused to give the desired answer. A political action committee for librarians, for example, sent a questionnaire to candidates asking if they promised to support the budget for the State Library Board.
Mr. Powell wrote back saying he could promise nothing, and that every appropriation would have to be considered in light of other budget requests.
"Even they wanted you to take a mindless pledge," he said.
Still, Mr. Powell has learned the politician's answer when asked if he would run again for public office. "I don't expect to again, but I would never say never," he said.

HEADLINE: Court Overrules a Public Shaming

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Indiana's second-highest court has ruled that the judge of a lower court overstepped his bounds in ordering an unemployed man who had failed to pay child support to stand on a courthouse lawn and hold a sign that said, "Need Job to Support Children."
The decision, issued Thursday by a unanimous three-judge panel of the Indiana Court of Appeals, said the order had exposed the 45-year-old unemployed father, Clarence William Epley 3d, to public humiliation and therefore constituted abusive discretion by the sentencing judge, Eugene N. Chipman Sr. of Marshall County Superior Court. 
 The case dates from September 1991, when Judge Chipman found that Mr. Epley had fallen $1,475 behind in support payments for his three children. Mr. Epley was jailed until he could come up with $1,000 of that sum and was then ordered by Judge Chipman to find employment by holding the sign outside the courthouse.
Mr. Epley did carry the sign for a few days and then found a job, and so Thursday's decision carried little practical effect for him. But a lawyer who was a friend of Mr. Epley's father decided to appeal the order and got support in that appeal from the Indiana Civil Liberties Union.
In striking down the order, the appeals court said it was "a throwback to the days of stockades and conjures up images of Puritans who fell from grace and were forced to wear scarlet letters upon their chests."
Writing for the court, Judge William I. Garrard said that the evidence showed Mr. Epley to have been "less than diligent in securing employment as a means toward meeting his support obligations" and that in such cases trial judges have freedom to fashion a remedy.
But requiring Mr. Epley to wear the sign went too far, the court said. "Although the measure was ostensibly imposed to coerce Epley to obtain employment," Judge Garrad wrote, "it also improperly subjected him to public ridicule, embarrassment and humiliation."

HEADLINE: A Company Move That Hasn't Irked the Neighbors

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WHITE HOUSE STATION, N.J., Nov. 11

 BODY:
In an era when states and municipalities fight winner-take-all battles for corporate investment, the story of Merck & Company's plan to move its headquarters from gritty Rahway to rural Hunterdon County is working against the script, and leaving everyone smiling.
Merck, a pharmaceutical giant that likes to remind visitors that it has been judged "America's Most Respected Corporation" for six years running by Fortune Magazine, is orchestrating the move with an all-absorbing finesse. It has deployed long-range planning, careful diplomacy and a heavy dose of corporate munificence to soothe the familiar fears of abandonment that factory towns express when a corporate citizen makes a move. 
 Far from abandoning Rahway, Merck planned its headquarters move to coincide with a reassuring spate of new investment in the city.
"As you can well imagine, when a move like this is planned, I think the community might feel initially some uncertainty as to what happens to them," John M. Bloomfield, a Merck spokesman, said. "We have worked very hard to reassure Rahway and Union County that Merck intends to remain an integral part of their community."
 
A Popular New Neighbor
 As for this tiny municipality in Readington Township, in the soft foothills of the Appalachian chain, the arrival of the nearly completed Merck heaquarters on a secluded hilltop, once a dairy farm, has meant nothing less than having a quiet, clean and very rich neighbor move in.
It is a neighbor who not only keeps to itself, in the sense of requiring few municipal services, but also promises to provide a few million dollars for housing for low-income residents and old people and a new truck to the volunteer fire house and to pay about a third of the township's annual tax bill to boot.
"This is a win-win situation for everyone," said Theresa Martin, Readington Township mayor.
The railroad depot that gave White House Station its name is now a picturesque library. Still, that's where the New Jersey Transit train to and from Newark stops four times a day, and it is the name that Merck has chosen as its address.
Josie Weber, the librarian, has seen to it that at least one of the commuters has a key to the former station so that if it is raining, travelers can let themselves into the juvenile section to wait for the train.
 
Going-Away Presents
 Merck's 1.8 million square-foot building already houses nearly 500 of the 1,500 employees, including all of top management, who will have moved from the Rahway corporate headquarters by the end of March.
But in Rahway, new research labs will be installed in the old executive suites, into which Merck plans to move most of the 1,100 technicians now occupying rented laboratory space in Woodbridge.
In addition, in Rahway Merck will build a 65,000-square foot pilot plant, where research ideas are translated into manufacturing processes, a new biological support laboratory, and a new day-care center for about 120 children of employees, to match the child-care center installed at Whitehouse Station, Mr. Bloomfield said.
The new investments in Rahway will add $20 million in taxable property to a corporate tax bill that already amounts to $3.2 million annually, equal to 10 percent of the city budget, said Rahway's Mayor, James Kennedy.
In addition, Merck donated $40,000 to fund a study on improving Rahway's downtown business district, it paid $126,000 to help cover the cost of paving some roads adjoining its complex, and it put new scientific equipment in Rahway High School, the alma mater of Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, the corporate chairman.
 
Not Losing Any Sleep
 The departure of the executive will not empty Rahway's residential areas either, Mr. Kennedy said. Ten percent of the firm's 4,200 employees in Rahway live in the city, he noted, but few of those residents are among the executives moving to White House Station.
"Headquarters doesn't add much to our local economy, so we're not really losing any sleep over the move," Mr. Kennedy said. "Realistically, most of the executives already live west of the first range of the Watchung mountains. They'll just have an easier commute."
Mr. Kennedy also credits Merck executives with helping to persuade New Jersey Transit, the state-owned commuter system, to put a new $15 million train station in Rahway.
"They have always had a good community conscience," he said.
In Readington Township, 45 minutes west of Rahway on Interstate 78, Merck officials spent a year attending planning board hearings before presenting their first development plans. A year later, in 1989, the plan for a project the township values at about $220 million was approved.
 
Company Did Its Homework
 "One of our local developers came up to me and asked, 'How come Merck got its permits through so quickly?' " Mayor Martin recalled in an interview. "Part of the answer is that this is exactly the kind of project the town was looking for, but another part of the answer is that they really did their homework."
In the end, the corporation needed only two zoning variances, Mrs. Martin said: one for the height of the mountain-hugging complex, and the other for the helipad.
The taxes that a town's biggest taxpayer pays are subject to negotiations, Mrs. Martin said. Still, she said, Merck will probably pay between $2 million and $3 million a year into an annual township budget that is now $7 million, most of it for schools, and local residents are hoping that the new money will mean a tax cut for everyone else.
"I don't know if we will be able to do that," Mrs. Martin said, "but if it turns out that we could reduce taxes, believe me, we would."
Anyone looking for the down side of a major corporate move to a small rural setting can usually rely on someone at least to object to the added traffic, and a study of the traffic impact from the new project did indeed conclude that the the county road access to Merck's driveway would have to be widened.
 
Mass Transit Stressed
 But the two sides are trying something else first. "We didn't want the road widened and they didn't want to pay for it," Mrs. Martin said, "so we worked out a plan with Merck and New Jersey Transit that stresses mass transit for the Merck people. If we find out that doesn't work, Merck will still have to widen the road."
If anyone is disappointed, it may be real estate brokers like Georgean Babey who hoped the Merck move would bring new demand for local housing. It hasn't, she said.
"I moved in two vice presidents two years ago, but I don't see much else coming from them," she said. "Most of the Merck people already own homes close enough for a commute."
Meanwhile, Barry Clark, the Readington town manager, has a hope that when Merck brings foreign executives to visit its new headquarters, they will leave a new sense of the country.
"I go into the New York City all the time, and I see a lot of foreign visitors there," he said. "I hope they will start coming out here, and realize that America is more than Times Square and oil refineries along the New Jersey Turnpike."

HEADLINE: Regulators Tell Utilities to Cut Spending

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 14

 BODY:
State utility regulators have ordered Connecticut Light and Power and United Illuminating to reduce spending on conservation to slow down increases in utility bills.
The State Department of Public Utility Control cited the poor economy, higher rates and a surplus of electricity in its decision on Friday. 
 The regulators ordered $5 million to $10 million cut next year from Connecticut Light and Power's $53 million budget for programs that help commercial and residential customers use less electricity.
For United Illuminating, the regulators approved conservation budgets of $12.1 million for next year and $14 million for 1994, less than the company had requested.
At least one environmental group chided the decision. Deborah Smith, a staff lawyer with Conservation Law Foundation, called it "bad policy" and "regressive."

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
N.Y.R.A. Feels Sting Of a Critical Audit

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO

 BODY:
The state's confrontation with the New York Racing Association escalated yesterday when the details of a state audit were made known that disallowed some expenditures by the association and questioned others at a time of dwindling profits.
The audit was prepared by Edward V. Regan, the state comptroller, who sharply reminded the management of N.Y.R.A. that the law "states that a nonprofit racing association shall operate in a sound economical, efficient and effective manner so as to produce a reasonable revenue for the support of government." Regan charged the N.Y.R.A. with "management judgments and accounting decisions that we assert are unreasonable, excessive and inconsistent" with state law. 
 The audit will be sent to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who has been challenging the association's role as the operator of the Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga race tracks. The Governor recently created a nine-member commission to overhaul racing in the state, especially by the time N.Y.R.A.'s franchise ends in the year 2000. Last Tuesday, he berated the association's executives for high salaries and bonuses, in particular the combined $261,000 paid in 1990 to the association's president, Gerard J. McKeon.
 
Profits Go Down
 The Regan audit, covering the years 1988 and 1989, says that N.Y.R.A. reported a net profit of $1.5 million for the state in 1988 and no profit in 1989. But it notes that $120,164 was spent by the N.Y.R.A. in those two years to buy or lease automobiles for executives, and that $320,100 was allotted for cash bonuses for seven executives.
The bonuses ranged from $4,600 in one case to $43,400 in another. The audit urged that they be disallowed by the state.
The report says that at the same time that bonuses were being handed out, income was dropping, "continuing a trend that began in the early 1970's with the advent of off-track betting." According to the audit, in a period extending from 1985 to 1989 attendance dropped 15.6 percent, from 4.6 million in 1985 to 3.9 million; betting dropped 8.8 percent, from $951 million to $867 million, and expenses increased 11 percent.
In a letter to Regan, McKeon defended the N.Y.R.A. expenditures as reasonable and said that the salary scale "fell at the lower end of range for the larger racing jurisdictions."
"N.Y.R.A. is a privately financed stock corporation, organized as a nonprofit racing association," McKeon wrote, "not a governmental agency or public authority."
"Your office," he said, "has chosen to ignore, perhaps because it has failed to understand the nature of N.Y.R.A.'s business, that its racing is the object of $2.5 billion of parimutuel wagering annually, approximately 25 percent of all such wagering on thoroughbreds in the United States."

HEADLINE: From the Economic Doctors, Diagnoses and Some Cures

 BODY:

ALLEN SINAI
Chief economist, the Boston Company in Boston 
 There are several important statistics to watch, according to Mr. Sinai, and none of them give much comfort. Though the employment rolls are growing, they are increasing at only 30 percent to 40 percent of the average rate after a recession, with temporary workers accounting for most of the gains. "The economy is still underperforming," Mr. Sinai said. "Payrolls in particular are growing at an unsatisfactory rate." Though new business incorporations have increased since the depths of the recession, they are also doing so at about half the rate normal after a recession, Mr. Sinai said. As a precaution, the new administration should be ready to put off balancing the budget to concentrate on growth. To do that, first-year spending on the infrastructure should be increased to $50 billion "if the economy flattens out."

LAWRENCE CHIMERINE
 
Senior economic adviser, DRI/McGraw Hill in Philadelphia
President-elect Bill Clinton has a tough road ahead, said Lawrence Chimerine. To get the economy moving, Mr. Clinton's proposed $20 billion investment in the nation's infrastructure next year should be increased to about $50 billion. But Mr. Clinton is not the only one with a difficult future. Workers have been losing ground and will continue to do so. Real wages did not grow in the last two years and will fall further. That has hurt consumers, who, rather than spending, have been sitting tight.Without spending, the economy will remain sluggish. Though hiring is expected to creep up, layoffs haven't hit bottom yet. And there is likely to be further downward pressure on wages as military suppliers cut back. "Clinton's plan has to be a massive defense conversion plan."
 
MICKEY D. LEVY
 
Chief economist, CRT Government Securities in New York
For Mr. Levy, even without any new proposals from Washington, the trend is up on the job front, albeit modestly. The "numbers are clearly pointing to a turnaround, with most of the losses in employment behind us," he said. The wrenching restructuring undergone by corporate America since the recession began has resulted in big increases in productivity. That has boosted bottom lines with five quarters in a row of steadily increasing profits. Mr. Levy forecasts profits will continue to increase through the end of 1993. But while cost cutting has made businesses leaner and more competitive, painful memories of layoffs will serve to keep companies' optimism in check. "Companies will continue to keep a lid on expenses. I don't expect any hiring sprees."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
When Index Funds Make Sense

SERIES: First of two articles on index funds./Next: which ones are best.

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
While some mutual fund investors try to squeeze out the last dollar of return, most are satisfied with building value over time. About the only way to do that is to invest in stocks, and the simplest way to go is to buy a fund that tracks an index like the Standard & Poor's 500.
A combination of simplicity and assured market returns has made winners of index funds lately. For the last decade, the average stock fund has underperformed the S.&P. 500, leading some experts to say indexing is the only way to go. 
 But others insist the 1980's were an aberration because the restructuring of S.&P. companies through corporate raids and leveraged buyouts caused big stocks to be priced higher than earnings warranted, and foreign buying focused on those stocks. And while it is true that fund managers have lagged behind the index almost every year since 1983, they beat the index the previous seven years.
In any case, index funds are proliferating, and this breeds confusion -- more than half of today's 40 index funds have not yet celebrated their third birthday. And even seemingly simple index investments must be assembled in ways that make sense.
Index funds own all the securities in a market index, or a representative sample, and thus have several edges over regular actively managed funds.
Since they use a buy-and-hold strategy -- buying and selling only to stay fully invested in the indexes -- the funds should have extremely low transaction costs. And a low turnover means fewer taxable distributions for people who invest outside 401(k) plans, Keoghs and other tax-deferred accounts.
Management fees should be low, too, because fund managers do not have to research investments or come up with an investment strategy, just buy and sell securities.
And, by design, index funds are fully diversified, not biased in favor of a particular market segment. While some funds can and do move into cash when the markets look dicey, index funds always stay fully invested.
Conventional wisdom today holds that indexing makes sense only in particular markets, and most experts say the case for indexing is most persuasive among large-capitalization stocks. Since many analysts follow the bigger stocks, it is difficult for an investor to unearth information not already reflected in the company's stock price.
Still, some analysts disagree. While the average large-capitalization fund is not likely to beat the S.&P. 500 because of expenses and trading costs, investors who analyze track records and research fund managers' strategies can find funds with better-than-average long-term performance, said Kenneth E. Gregory, editor of the L/G No-Load Fund Analyst, in San Francisco.
The case for indexing small stocks is much less clear. Because small stocks are followed by fewer analysts, "a good, active manager is likely to find inefficiencies among small-capitalization stocks, so you have a greater chance of exceeding an index," said Sheldon Jacobs, who edits the No-Load Fund Investor, in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.
When it comes to overseas investing, many experts say indexing is a bad idea. Domestic funds have been successful because American markets are so efficient, but international markets largely are not, said Lori Lucas, an analyst with Morningstar Inc., mutual fund researchers in Chicago.
What is more, index funds in foreign markets are not diversified in the way American investors have come to expect.
For example, the Vanguard International Equity Index: Pacific Portfolio is really a Japan index fund, with 86 percent allocated there. The fund increased its already-large allocation to Japanese equities as the market there inflated, and took a harder spill when the Japanese market finally crashed.
The Vanguard European portfolio is only slightly more diversified. Two-thirds of its assets are invested in just three countries: 40 percent in Britain, 14 percent in Germany and 14 percent in France.
Probably the best approach for individual investors is to follow the core approach used by institutional investors, said Maria Crawford Scott, who edits the American Association of Individual Investors' Journal.
This approach divides a portfolio into two parts. The passively managed portion would be filled by index funds, letting you spend more time on the actively managed part.
One possibility is to buy funds that you think will perform strongly under current market conditions -- funds that focus on value investing, for example, tend to do well during economic recoveries. Using this method lets you "make small bets on the market's direction without making major changes in your overall portfolio," Ms. Scott said.

LENGTH: 635 words

HEADLINE: The New White House Order

 BODY:
President-elect Clinton promises to focus like a laser beam on the economy. The effort is likely to begin with creation of a high-level adviser to head a new White House "economic security council." That's a powerful idea. In this new world order, after the cold war, economic problems loom at least as large as military threats. This new council could do for economic policy what the National Security Council does for diplomatic and military policy: bring coherent views to the President's attention, every morning.
But the proposed council also poses risks that are evident just by thinking for a minute about the name economic security council. The parallel with national security invites the belief that America is still at war, only this time over foreign investment and trade rather than missiles. That's not just misguided but dangerous, inviting a quick descent into the worst protectionism. 
 America's economic problems start at home: untrained and undereducated workers, slumping investment, sluggish productivity. By fastening on these real problems, the new council would do immense good. If it focuses instead on foreign "enemies," it will invite dangerous distraction.
The other day, the Commission on Government Renewal, a bipartisan study group of 30 senior officials from the last eight administrations, published a memorandum for the President-elect offering an admirable outline for Mr. Clinton's economic council. It proposed three equal White House councils to deal with national security, economic and domestic affairs.
No whiff of protectionism here. The emphasis is on coordination and access. Each council would consist of Cabinet officials and would be managed by an assistant to the President with a small professional staff. The three council heads would meet daily with the President, coordinating input from every corner of the Administration.
The daily briefing is key. Now, only the national security adviser gets automatic access. This proposal would put economics on an equal footing. That's important because issues increasingly cross traditional boundaries.
But while the commission's proposals on access and coordination are right on target, it made a disquieting proposal for refocusing Administration attention on the issue of "competitiveness." That's an unfortunate focus, especially if measured by the imbalance between exports and imports -- and if it invites bailouts for particular industries.
What's wrong with the American economy is a 20-year slowdown in the growth of living standards. But that's a reflection of slow productivity growth, not of some export-import imbalance. A trade deficit reflects nothing more than that Americans spend more than they produce, and therefore have to import the difference.
Economic growth reflects productivity. And productivity will follow from combining well-trained workers with state-of-the-art equipment. That means better educating the 50 percent of high school students who don't go to college; it also means consuming less, investing more.
Those will be difficult changes. Presidents Reagan and Bush wanted to leave them entirely to private decision. Mr. Clinton brings to Washington a promising confidence that the Federal Government also has a role to play.
Some people equate any such promise with the ugly specter of arrogant bureaucrats deciding which industries will grow, which will shrink. But what Mr. Clinton has actually proposed -- and what the proposed economic council could promote -- is putting Government behind entrepreneurs willing to risk their own fortunes.
If the new council, renamed, can keep its eye on productivity, not competitiveness, and on living standards and not producer bailouts, the new order in the White House can keep up with the new order in the world.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Putting America First

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
"By bringing to Washington a government determined to govern," Arthur Schlesinger Jr. wrote of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, "[he] unlocked new energies in a people who had lost faith, not just in government's ability to meet the economic crisis, but almost in the ability of anyone to do anything."
Voters wanted their faith renewed in 1992. So, many once again set aside their mounting cynicism about governmental activism and selected Bill Clinton. 
 They gave this young question mark of a Governor from a poor and unremarkable state a mandate to do "something," though nothing in particular, to fix the economy and provide broader health care coverage and better education.
But candidate Clinton neither sought nor received a mandate for national security policy. Therein lies the problem. Unaddressed, it could lead to creeping isolationism and, worse, backfire on his commitment to domestic priorities.
Mr. Clinton did speak his piece about foreign affairs. He presented himself, reassuringly, as an internationalist who would guard old and new U.S. interests.
But the Clinton thrust was decidedly and correctly inward. Politically, it had to be. With the cold war over, Americans chafed under the heavy burdens of world leadership. They felt that President Bush had paid too much attention to foreign problems. Mr. Clinton repeatedly picked at that sore. Ross Perot went much further, often sounding isolationist. Even Mr. Bush fell virtually mute on foreign policy for fear of reminding voters of his once proud strong suit.
Separately and collectively, the three candidates pledged to reverse cold war practice and focus on America.
This message was not only good politics, it pointed to sound priorities. Presidents have shortchanged domestic problems throughout the cold war. The country is falling apart. It cries out for Presidential energy and imagination and for a larger share of the Federal pie.
Even foreign leaders have come to empathize with those needs. They have started fretting about Mr. Bush's apparent indifference to stimulating the U.S. economy. They have begun to admire Mr. Clinton's domestic activism. It could help regenerate America and pump up the market for their exports.
At the same time, they wonder and worry what America's new priorities will mean for U.S. presence and leadership abroad. And not without reason.
Putting America first makes sense -- up to a point. Beyond that point, Mr. Clinton could fall into the traps of unintended isolationism and policy passivity.
First, his preoccupation with the U.S. could go too far and take on its own wind in American politics. The U.S. could float much further inward than intended. But those around Mr. Clinton say that he is alert to this danger and will undertake the political combat necessary to keep the U.S. involved abroad. Foreign leaders will see this soon and calm down.
Mr. Clinton is more likely to fall prey to the second and far more insidious trap of passivity. World crises will occur no matter what he does, but his chances of containing them will improve if he is constantly trying to head them off. It is not enough for the U.S. simply to be engaged overseas; it must be engaged actively and imaginatively, and with dollars. Otherwise, crises will explode and devour Mr. Clinton's time and political capital.
Without active American leadership, the Bosnian nightmare could escalate into a Balkan war. Iran and others will surely acquire nuclear arms unless the U.S. mounts active opposition. Arabs and Israelis will inevitably drift back toward war without constant American mediation. China and Japan could start down the road to confrontation without a major U.S. presence in Asia. The ex-Soviet Union will have no chance to escape new dictatorship and militarism unless Washington actively reassures reformers and organizes world assistance. Any of the above could become a domestic political bombshell.
Often during the campaign, Mr. Clinton wisely argued that domestic policy is foreign policy is domestic policy. In a few short weeks he must come to terms with the paradox of his own wisdom: If he wants to devote the maximum time and resources to his domestic agenda -- as he should -- he will have to engage in active and creative diplomacy.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: More U.S. Support for Russia

BYLINE: By Robert S. Strauss; Robert S. Strauss, who has resigned as Ambassador to Russia, plans to rejoin his Texas-based law firm.

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
Returning from 16 months as Ambassador in Moscow, first to the Soviet Union and then to Russia, reminds me again that people change their minds. This is true in the United States and in Russia.
In my lifetime, Americans have changed their minds about Prohibition, isolationism and racial and sexual equality. They have changed their minds several times about the role of government in the economy and society. The ebb and flow of changing minds is what politics and government are all about. 
 Agendas are being reordered in Moscow and in Washington. Change is the basis of a historic opportunity between us and the Russians. But to exploit it, we will need more change in our thinking about ourselves, the Russians and the world.
During my time as ambassador, the Russians have transformed their thinking about themselves, the West, their former ideology, the erosion of centralized state power, the free market and their relations with former Soviet republics.
The character of future Russian government and democracy is an open question. Will they be authoritarian and limited? Broad and open? Presidential or European parliamentary? Centralized or fragmented? Stable or unstable?
Russia's instability holds our attention. The country is important for us as an engine of our own economic transformation, and it can assist the West in dealing with all of the "isms" in this volatile, dangerous part of the world.
Russia is weak, impoverished and unsettled, but we should have no illusions that it will or should remain weak or that a weak Russia somehow serves our interests.
We have an opportunity to make an important contribution to securing democracy and market reforms in Russia and assist as it rebuilds its society. Our selfish interests demand we grasp it firmly.
Over the past year, we have laid a foundation for a new relationship with Russia. I have come to appreciate the depth of President Boris Yeltsin's commitment to democracy and his role as a product of the old system and yet on the cutting edge as a visionary for the new. He told Congress on June 17, "The Russian people have made their choice in favor of liberty and democracy." The majority certainly have but many remain undecided. We must reinforce that majority and help encourage the undecided.
The choice is not between a strong or weak Russia but between a strong, inward-looking authoritarian state or a strong democratic state that participates in the world community.
While our help cannot preordain Russia's success or failure, it can help shape the character of the outcome. This is partly because we matter to the Russians as the prosperous democratic society Boris Yeltsin and the vast majority of Russians would like to more closely resemble.
We need to understand what we are all about in Russia as well as what they are all about -- that we will always have our differences, that it is the Russians who must rebuild the new Russia, not us, and that we and they have a long way to go but both have also come a long way.
In setting our priorities for attention -- not necessarily money -- support to deepen the roots of democracy must be raised to a far higher level than it has been so far on the national agenda.
The Congress, executive branch and the American people must come to grips with the fact that our effort must not lapse with the modest first steps we have taken.
Given the global economic problems, the justification for this modest response is certainly understandable, but it's misguided and certainly not in our own self-interest.
If the agenda and commitments required in coming years are substantial, so are the U.S. interests and values that are at stake. Let's not lose this historic opportunity.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Believe It, Women Elected This President

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The women in this country played a major role in the Clinton election victory. According to your Nov. 5 analysis of the demographics, 46 percent versus 37 percent of women preferred the Clinton-Gore ticket, yet you say that the abortion issue was a factor for only one out of eight voters. 
 Perhaps by the time women got to the polling place, this major issue was overshadowed by all the other pertinent reasons for rejecting the Republican candidate, but the overwhelming majority of the female electorate was unwilling even to consider a candidate with a strong antichoice position.
Women are by nature pragmatists. It has always been their role to keep the home fires burning and the children fed. Some of us have chosen additional roles; many more have had additional roles thrust upon them. Their resolve to vote for the pro-choice Clinton ticket was fortified by their determination not to have the largely white male middle-class Republican Party explain "family values" to them, not to have the fanatical religious right determine the reading material permitted in their children's schools, not to have mandatory school prayer. Women voted for the candidate with the articulated economic plan, the vision for health and education reform, the resolve for a better future for their children.
As for the character issue, politicians should be reminded that women have a built-in falsehood detector. The Republican character assassination of the Democratic candidates fell on deaf female ears. They made a determination of character a year before, when President Bush looked into the television camera and proclaimed that Clarence Thomas was "the most suited person in America" for the job of Supreme Court Justice and when this most suited person proclaimed he had never discussed Roe v. Wade with anyone.
More than ever before, women made their importance in the electorate felt this year. We are not a minority; we are the majority in this country, making up slightly more than 51 percent of the electorate and controlling more than 50 percent of the wealth of the country. We are a force to be dealt with, as a group that votes its conscience first. We are strongly pro-choice, pro-child, pro-social tolerance, pro-education, pro-health care. If the Republicans keep avoiding these issues, we are going to keep the Democrats in the White House a long time.
 
PATRICIA WARBURG CLIFF
New York, Nov. 5, 1992

HEADLINE: Believe It, Women Elected This President;
Making Taxes Fairer

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Experts are flocking to Little Rock, Ark., and Washington to urge Bill Clinton to tone down any suggestions of social reform in the program he will present to Congress and the nation. Political pundits urge the middle and working classes not to hope for improvements, but to prepare for more sacrifices. 
 The most concrete Clinton proposal of change from the Reagan-Bush policies is to increase taxes on the very rich. The top rate for those with incomes over $200,000 would go up from 31 percent to 36 percent, and there would be a 10 percent surcharge on those with incomes over $1 million.
Based on 1990 figures, the latest available, this would affect 835,000 taxpayers, .7 percent of all taxpayers, and would raise their total tax bill by $16.1 billion, or 16 percent. Most of the increase, $11.8 billion, would be paid by the 61,000 taxpayers with incomes above $1 million. This would be a minimal reform, a beginning, but would leave little for middle- and lower-income tax relief, not even considering the financing of infrastructure, advanced research and development and deficit reduction.
Real tax reform should return at least to the pre-Reagan tax structure of 1979, which would yield an increase five times greater, or $82 billion, from those with adjusted gross incomes of more than $200,000.
While still less than a really radical "tax the rich" program, this is a necessary primary financial step to keep the President-elect's promise of change, if that is to be benefical to most Americans.
 
VICTOR PERLO
Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., Nov. 9, 1992
 
The writer is an economic consultant.
