HEADLINE: Believe It, Women Elected This President;
Why Bush Failed

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Peggy Noonan's "Why Bush Failed" (Op-Ed, Nov. 5) fails to grasp both why and, to some degree, how President Bush lost. 
 The Reagan-Bush economy was never worse than today's because, along with unemployment, has come the stunning news for hundreds of thousands of able, motivated former workers that their last employers will never rehire them or anyone else in their place. Bill Clinton and Al Gore perceived the urgency of hope as more than campaign rhetoric and spoke to unemployed and uncertainly employed America in a time when the word "unemployed" took on an ominous meaning unknown since the 1930's. If Mr. Bush's speechwriters never saw this, they may be a reason why Bush failed.
He also failed because the President's advisers and at least one speechwriter believe the war against Iraq was "masterly diplomacy." On Nov. 3, Saddam Hussein, the cause of that "war," was still there, perhaps stronger than ever and certainly a larger thorn in our side.
As volunteer co-director of a private homeless shelter, I further refute claims that 1982 was worse than today because 1982 saw but the beginning of homeless America. New York City churches and synagogues were assured in 1982 that food and beds for the homeless would be necessary for just six months. By Nov. 3, 1992, this city's homeless population topped 150,000 and was increasing, as is the case in most United States cities.
Citizens watching milk or gas prices, uneasy about Saddam Hussein, passing the begging homeless daily, know better than White House aides or speechwriters why George Bush failed, and they spoke keenly on Election Day.
 
BRYANT HAYES
New York, Nov. 5, 1992

HEADLINE: Criminal Charges Make Outlook Grim for Collor

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 14

 BODY:
President Fernando Collor de Mello's political prospects grew bleaker this week as Brazil's Attorney General formally charged him with corruption for a criminal trial and the Senate promised a verdict by Christmas in a parallel impeachment trial.
A conviction in either trial would cause Mr. Collor to be permanently removed from office. On Sept. 29, a congressional vote forced him to surrender his powers to Vice President Itamar Franco for six months to allow the first impeachment trial in Brazil's history. 
 "The only person in Brasilia who thinks that Collor will get off is Collor," said a Brazilian newspaper editor who recently visited the President at his lakefront estate in Brasilia where he lives in reclusion.
Within a month, the Chamber of Deputies is expected to vote to authorize the Supreme Court to try Mr. Collor on the criminal charges.
 
'Passive Corruption' Charged
 Trying to stave off a criminal indictment, Mr. Collor wrote to the Attorney General late last month to say he had not benefited from "one little penny snatched from the public treasury."
But on Thursday, Aristides Junqueira, the Attorney General, formally charged the President with "passive corruption" and "criminal association." The 55-page indictment charges that Mr. Collor and his relatives accepted $8 million from an influence-trafficking ring that netted $55.3 million.
"According to the verified facts, it seems to me that the big boss was the President," Mr. Junqueira said at a news conference on Friday.
Eight others accused of being members of the ring were indicted, including Paulo Cesar Farias, Mr. Collor's former campaign treasurer. The Attorney General charged that Mr. Farias, the ring's reported mastermind, pocketed $21.5 million of the proceeds.
In his letter to the Attorney General, Mr. Collor asserted that the last time he communicated with Mr. Farias was around June 1990. But a check of telephone bills discovered that, since Mr. Collor's inauguration in March 1990, 479 calls were made from the President's residence or offices to Mr. Farias's residence or offices and 137 calls were made the other way round.
 
'Like a Concubine'
 In a parallel trial, Brazil's Senate plans to vote on Dec. 22 on whether to convict Mr. Collor on corruption charges stemming from the same scandal.
In a summation, prosecution lawyers charged on Tuesday that the President had committed 20 corruption-related crimes and had lived "like a concubine kept and maintained by a private patron."
In another setback for the presidential family, a prosecutor in Mr. Collor's home state, Alagoas, has formally accused Rosane Malta Collor, Brazil's First Lady, with embezzlement and with "heading a criminal gang." Citing the misappropriation of assets from a federal charity run by Mrs. Collor, the prosecutor also asked a judge to freeze her assets.
Police investigators, who devoted the summer to tracing the destinations of Mr. Farias's millions, recently turned to studying the sources.
Studying a computer seized last June from Mr. Farias's Sao Paulo office, the police reportedly discovered that the password to an electronic spreadsheet was "Collor." The program listed 128 federal projects and commission percentages ranging from 3 to 15 percent.
 
Immunity Is Offered
 Prosecutors are now offering immunity from prosecution to representatives of 25 businesses that supposedly made payments to the ring. On Thursday, a lawyer for Mercedes Benz do Brasil told the police that his company paid $1.1 million to the ring over the last two years because Mr. Farias threatened "to shut the company down."
The president of a trade association for Brazil's interstate bus companies said he paid $225,000 to a company controlled by Mr. Farias because he threatened to freeze bus fares -- financial death in an economy with 25 percent monthly inflation.
Cement companies reportedly contributed hundreds of thousands of dollars after Mr. Collor made a tough speech in May 1990 threatening to open the sector to competition from imports.
"Collor used his power to create problems, and P.C. Farias sold the solutions," Jornal do Brasil, a Rio newspaper, wrote last week.
Pressed by the mounting revelations, Mr. Collor's tightknit group is disintegrating into a festival of finger pointing.
"If everything they say about P.C. is proven, I will have the most complete repugnance for him," Mr. Collor told one Sao Paulo newspaper.
In return, Mr. Farias's lawyers vowed not to let their client be "a punching bag."
Taking another tack, Brazil's besieged President attributed the unaccounted millions passing through accounts controlled by him to "leftover campaign money."
 
'No Way to Explain It'
 But the man legally responsible for the President's 1989 campaign finances retorted, "There never was any money left over the from the campaign."
"He has no way to explain it, and it would have been better if he had resigned," Daniel Tourinho, the president of Mr. Collor's political party, continued in an interview with Veja.
When the time came for members of Mr. Collor's Government to testify in his defense before the Senate, several vanished. Marcilio Marques Moreira, the former Economy Minister, flew to Europe without leaving a forwarding address.
In a final defection, a member of the Mr. Collor's campaign team gave Brazil's scandal the Watergate touch that it has lacked since it first erupted in May. The disillusioned insider, Octavio Ramos, told the press that electrical specialists working for the Collor campaign wiretapped telephones at the headquarters of the President's opponent, Luis Inacio da Silva.

LENGTH: 1749 words

HEADLINE: Speaking the Language of Business on Behalf of the Mayor

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
After nearly two years of negotiations, the Dinkins administration had by last spring offered the Morgan Stanley Group what even the investment bank called very attractive incentives to keep it from moving its headquarters to Stamford, Conn.
But to the frustration of city officials, Morgan Stanley held out throughout the summer. Staying might be too big a gamble, given New York's long history of raising business taxes, its leaders said. 
 Then along came Barry F. Sullivan, the new Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. He persuaded Mayor David N. Dinkins to commit himself to a four-year freeze of the general corporate tax rate. That did it: Morgan Stanley decided last month it would keep its headquarters, and 4,100 jobs, in New York.
"Barry was critical in getting the last pieces of our arrangement in place," said James M. Allwin, a managing director who headed Morgan Stanley's negotiating team. "He thinks like a businessman. We speak the same language."
 
Business More Optimistic
 After 34 years as a banker, including 11 as chairman of the First Chicago Corporation, he should. Mr. Sullivan, who is 61 years old, knows how crucial stable government policies are for companies trying to carry out long-term plans.
In his six months at City Hall, Mr. Sullivan has helped to rekindle optimism in the city's business community, an especially remarkable feat considering that New York remains mired in a severe recession.
Besides the Morgan Stanley agreement, he was instrumental in persuading Prudential Securities Inc. to keep its headquarters, and 5,000 jobs, in New York and in clinching deals that kept the city's five commodity exchanges and their 11,700 jobs.
Mr. Sullivan's team also used path-breaking incentives to persuade Bradlees Inc., a discount retailer, to offer to buy six stores closed by the bankrupt Alexander's Department Stores. The Caldor Corporation has since outbid Bradlees and has not asked for city incentives.
And this month the city and state prevailed over New Jersey when The New York Times decided to build a printing and distribution plant in College Point, Queens, to replace its midtown Manhattan press operations.
Mr. Sullivan also helped devise the tactics that nabbed the 1998 Goodwill games for the metropolitan area. And he has begun programs to help smaller businesses.
 
Ending Another Cold War
 Undoubtedly one reason Mr. Sullivan has been so successful is that he ended the cold war that had been raging between Mayor Dinkins and big business. The thaw began when he got the Mayor to make a spring trip to Europe with corporate executives to promote the city.
Now the Mayor can sit through breakfasts with executives -- as he did one recent morning -- without gripping his chair as they speak their minds. While the Mayor and corporate leaders may not yet be bosom buddies, now there seems at least a cordial, constructive relationship.
"To the extent that there was any gap -- and there was for some people -- it has been closed," said John F. McGillicuddy, chairman of the Chemical Banking Corporation.
So far, the only big defeat on Mr. Sullivan's watch involved First Chicago, his former employer. This fall, it decided it would move most of a shareholder-service subsidiary, and 1,000 jobs, to Jersey City from Manhattan.
But when the loss is mentioned, business and political leaders not only defend Mr. Sullivan -- who kept out of the talks because of his $780,000-a-year consulting contract with First Chicago -- they praise him. The city and state, they say, would have had to pay too much in incentives -- more than $50,000 a job. The First Chicago and Morgan Stanley cases show the city is more disciplined than before in its approach to retaining companies, they add.
 
Interest in Theology
 Mr. Sullivan, who spent 23 years at the Chase Manhattan Corporation before going to First Chicago, took early retirement from the latter in December. His tenure got mixed reviews: once a formidable money-center bank, First Chicago is now more of a regional bank.
Insisting he was not pushed out, Mr. Sullivan said the bank, unlike others, not only survived but "is really in good shape." He said he just wanted to devote more time to community service and to his family -- his wife Audrey, five children and four grandchildren.
It hasn't exactly worked out that way.
He light-heartedly complained that because of the new job, he is only halfway through the second volume of Jaroslav Pelikan's five-volume history of Christian theology, a going-away present from the University of Chicago, where he had served as chairman of the board of trustees. He also took a course this year on Christian theology until Thomas Aquinas.
Mr. Sullivan says he plans to give his $112,000 salary to worthy causes.
Mr. Sullivan insists that a government should be obsessed with listening to and serving its "customers" -- whether they be businesses, residents, commuters or tourists -- just like a successful company does. He also has been trying to get the city government to act like a business by setting goals, assigning responsibility and holding people accountable.
 
An Understanding of Business
 Howard A. Knight, a senior executive vice president at Prudential, said that the city might have lost his company had it not been for that attitude. Once Mr. Sullivan got involved, he said, "All of a sudden things moved on a very definite time line with certain milestones." The 20-year deal was signed in August.
Mr. Sullivan also understood Prudential's desire to respond to market forces. While the city had been insisting that Prudential would lose municipal benefits if Prudential jobs fell below a threshold, Mr. Sullivan agreed to make the job level an average over two or three years. "He didn't cause the city to get a materially smaller commitment in terms of jobs, but he gave us flexibility to run our business," Mr. Knight said.
As part of his customer focus, Mr. Sullivan has called on some 160 of the largest employers in the city, and he frequently walks through neighborhoods to visit smaller businesses.
Recently, he was in the Broadway area of Bushwick. Fifteen businessmen and community leaders told him about their struggle to revive the poor area. He listened sympathetically to their laments -- things he has heard all too often before.
Maybe he could get some empty city-owned land for a parking lot, he said. He talked about an insurance fund the city was creating to encourage banks to loan to small businesses. But he yet again delivered the bad message about tax relief. "If you're saying a general tax reduction, it ain't gonna happen," he said with a Bronx accent that survived years in Washington, London and Chicago.
 
New Incentives for Retail
 How did he go over? "It's nice to have the visit, but he's doing it on behalf of a mayor who's trying to regain lost ground politically," said Gary Schneiderman, a supermarket owner.
Most, though, seemed encouraged. "I think something will be done," said Stanley Henry, owner of a hardware store, adding "we've got the Mayor's attention."
These kind of visits led to the offer of incentives to Bradlees. Mr. Sullivan and some staffers toured Washington Heights the day after last summer's disturbance to see how badly shops had been damaged, and he was, he said, struck by the role small shops play in creating a vital neighborhood.
Then he learned how on Fordham Road in the Bronx, the closure of Alexander's original department store -- where his mother had taken him shopping as a boy -- had reduced the flow of shoppers, causing the sales of small shops to plunge.
"We had never, as I understand it, as a city done incentives for retail," he recalled. After learning that Kmart planned to open its first store in the city -- in Fresh Meadows, Queens -- he also phoned the chain's chief to say the city might offer incentives if Kmart opened more.
 
Search for a Vision
 He has also embarked upon other initiatives for smaller businesses -- like the loan-insurance fund and streamlining the process for granting city loans. He is exploring the idea of a city venture-capital fund to provide small businesses with equity capital.
Mr. Sullivan strongly believes that the city needs a long-range "economic vision" aimed at improving conditions for industries deemed vital to the city. Ultimately that could mean having to cut fewer special deals to keep or attract jobs.
Starting with a draft written in June on a plane ride back from a meeting of the University of Chicago's board of trustees, he has honed a two-page plan that reflects a range of views solicited from inside and outside City Hall. The first page is the vision. The second is the policies for realizing it.
In its current form, the strategy sees New York as a global corporate headquarters city, the world's leading cultural center, a vibrant place for small and growing businesses, the center of the regional economy and a global city of opportunity.
In that context, the draft says, New York must strive to strengthen its position as an international center for financial and business services, communications industries, design industries like fashion and jewelry, tourism, biomedical science, and manufacturers serving the local economy.
Looking to small business to be the engine of job creation, the strategy calls for much more emphasis on helping people to begin and expand them.
Mr. Sullivan hopes is now working with Mr. Dinkins on the final shaping of the vision. "I don't believe we ought to have a Barry Sullivan economic vision of New York City. I believe we ought to have a Mayor Dinkins vision," he said. .
Norman Steisel, the First Deputy Mayor, says of Mr. Sullivan, "He clearly is a team player."
 
 
 
PROFILE
Barry Francis Sullivan
Born: Dec. 21, 1930, the Bronx.
Education: Regis High School in Manhattan; attended Georgetown University 1949-52; bachelor's degree from Columbia University, 1955; master's in business administration from University of Chicago Graduate School of Business, 1957.
Career: Chase Manhattan Bank, a series of executive position, 1957-1980; chairman and chief executive of First Chicago Corporation, 1980-91; New York Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, May 1992-present.
Family: Married for 36 years to the former Audrey M. Villeneuve; four sons and one daughter; four grandchildren.
Interests: Theology; reading; sports, especially basketball.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1949 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
Malcolm X: The Facts, the Fictions, the Film

BYLINE: By SHEILA RULE

 BODY:
He was Malcolm Little when he was born on May 19, 1925, in Omaha, and El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz when he fell in a fusillade of bullets on Feb. 21, 1965, in New York City. In the relatively few years in between, he was Detroit Red, Satan and Malcolm X. Now, 27 years after his assassination, his complicated life has been refracted through the prisms of history and myth, confirming him as a compelling political presence but leaving conflicting interpretations of his legacy.
In his new film "Malcolm X," which opens on Wednesday, the director Spike Lee traces the black leader's dramatic evolution, from impoverished child, hustler and thief to convict to angry spokesman of the Nation of Islam contemptuous of "blue-eyed white devils" and, finally, after a pilgrimage to Mecca, to the powerful humanist who used his rhetorical gift to repudiate racial exclusivity before being gunned down at the age of 39. The film stars Denzel Washington as Malcolm X, Angela Bassett as his wife, Betty Shabazz, and Al Freeman Jr. as Elijah Muhammad, leader of the Nation of Islam. 
 "Malcolm X," 3 hours and 21 minutes in length, takes its audiences from the rural poverty of 1920's Nebraska to the tough streets of Roxbury in Boston and Harlem in New York, inside the strict world of the Black Muslims and to the holy land of the Middle East. The screenplay, which embodies Mr. Lee's vision of Malcolm X, is based on an adaptation of "The Autobiography of Malcolm X," written with Alex Haley and published in 1965.
Because Malcolm X had so many facets and stoked the passions of so many people, portraying his legacy would present a challenge to any film maker. Apprehensions about Mr. Lee's portrayal set a brushfire of controversy even before filming started last year. The poet Amiri Baraka, who criticized the project before he had seen the script, said it would be a distortion of Malcolm X's life "to make middle-class Negroes sleep easier." Some critics voiced concern that Mr. Lee would focus too much on the black leader's days as a hustler or, worse, make him seem in the end like the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. Others suggest that subsequent writings have revealed important inaccuracies in the autobiography and that a script that follows the book would leave audiences with an erroneous portrait.
But the trials of presenting Malcolm X on film did not begin with Mr. Lee but in 1968, when a screenplay by James Baldwin and Arnold Perl was commissioned by Marvin Worth, a producer who had acquired rights to the autobiography. Since then, the project has been beset by battles over such issues as Hollywood's readiness to deal with so controversial a leader, which phase of his ideological development to highlight and whether a white director -- Norman Jewison, in this case -- could do justice to the subject.
Mr. Lee says that his film does not glorify any one phase of the black leader's development but rather looks at "all the different Malcolms as making up one Malcolm."
"I know he was constantly evolving; I like the total evolution, the many transformations he made, because all of those together made Malcolm," he said recently at a midtown Manhattan hotel, adding that he realized that "there is a specific Malcolm some hold dear more than the other parts of Malcolm. Baraka and nationalists want their own Malcolm; the Nation of Islam definitely don't want you to push the Malcolm after he left the Nation of Islam. People just pick and choose what Malcolm fits their own personal agenda or own political beliefs."
"Malcolm X" comes in the wake of such historical epics as Richard Attenborough's "Gandhi" (1982), Alan Parker's "Mississippi Burning" (1988), Roland Joffe's "Fat Man and Little Boy" (1989) and Oliver Stone's "J.F.K.," which appeared last year. Increasingly, and most notably with "J.F.K.," the mixing of fact and fiction, especially in the service of explaining seminal events of our times, has raised serious questions about film makers' responsibility to the historic record.
Like those directors, Mr. Lee used the material of history selectively in an effort to tell a compelling tale. He shunned certain accounts of events that were at odds with Malcolm X's own account, specifically those set out by Bruce Perry in his 1991 book, "Malcolm: The Life of a Man Who Changed Black America."
In one of several places in which Mr. Perry's and Malcolm X's versions of events differ, the autobiography tells how Malcolm's mother, pregnant with him, confronted Ku Klux Klansmen when they surrounded the family's house in Omaha, looking for Malcolm's father, Earl Little. But according to an interview Malcolm's mother gave Mr. Perry, the incident never happened. While both the autobiography and Mr. Lee portray Mr. Little as a political militant who was martyred by white racists, Mr. Perry depicts him as a violent man who beat his wife and children and died when he was run over by a moving streetcar as he tried to board.
Mr. Perry also suggests that a fire at Malcolm X's home in Queens one morning in 1965, as his wife and four young daughters lay asleep, may have been set by the black leader himself and not, as he publicly insisted, by the Black Muslims.
"I don't believe it," Mr. Lee said of Mr. Perry's book. The film maker said his own historical interpretation was formed not only by the autobiography but by independent research, including interviews he conducted with Malcolm X's relatives and Black Muslims who were close to him. He also used information provided by Paul Lee, who Mr. Lee described as an astute scholar of Malcolm X who served as a technical consultant on the film. "Malcolm loved his family," said Mr. Lee. "Why jeopardize the lives of your wife and children by setting your own house on fire while the children are sleeping?"
Perhaps even more important than the biographical details is the legend of a man who, even in death, exerts extraordinary influence over generations who honor his memory. Clearly, Malcolm X has gained wider approval than he had during his lifetime, but sharp debate continues over what his legacy is -- or should be -- with people of competing ideologies claiming to be the rightful heir to his political philosophy.
Betty Shabazz, his widow, considers him a "person for all seasons," one whose message was sometimes misunderstood. Dr. Shabazz, who is director of communications and public relations at Medgar Evers College of the City University of New York, served as a consultant on Mr. Lee's film.
"He said freedom by whatever means necessary to bring about a situation where members of the African diaspora were respected and treated as human beings wherever they reside," she said recently. "A lot of people didn't like that and said 'freedom by whatever means necessary' is violence.
"No, it's not violence. It's a comprehensive statement that says use more than one option. It could be political, social, educational, or it could be self-defense." It is those who refuse to include blacks in the "human family," she said, who are violent and who "attempt to superimpose their perverted thinking, their negative thinking, their violent thinking, their unrighteous thinking on my husband."
For the writer and historian Paula Giddings, the enduring legend of Malcolm X is embodied by the man who had a "tremendous capacity to change" his views to encompass "a much more sophisticated vision about race in the global context and a much more sophisticated vision about gender, to a much more emancipatory view of women." It is this Malcolm X who broke with Elijah Muhammad and, in a pilgrimage to Mecca in 1964, learned that Islam could embrace people of all races. On his return, he renounced racism and took the Islamic name El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz.
Yet many young African-Americans champion a different Malcolm X, the one who was a fiery Black Muslim minister. And they view Louis Farrakhan, head of the Nation of Islam, as the ideological heir to the ideals of black moral superiority and economic self-reliance espoused by Malcolm and Elijah Muhammad. Radical rap artists, prophets of rage who echo the teachings of the Nation of Islam, have revived the ideas and, through sampling, sometimes the recorded voice of this Malcolm, putting the questions of cultural nationalism and violence-versus-nonviolence to a new generation of militants.
"He made history while he was Minister Malcolm, following the leadership of the Honorable Elijah Muhammad," said Kam, a 23-year-old Los Angeles rapper whose first album, "Never Again," will be released by East-West/Atlantic early next year.
"That's the only Malcolm I can say I personally respect, not the man who left the Nation of Islam," said Kam, who typifies many rappers with their serious ideas and combative attitudes. "The same thing that attracts me to Malcolm attracts me today to Minister Farrakhan: the truth, uncut and raw, the discipline, the sacrifice, the uncompromising stand and the love for black people.
"Malcolm was an eloquent speaker, and he stirred up the country. He was speaking about action, but people in his time weren't with that. Today we ain't with nothing else; we ain't with no talking, we want action. We were born for action."
But there is another school of thought. Swayzack, a rapper with the Goats, a Philadelphia group that records for Ruffhouse Records, said that he believes all of Malcolm's phases of development were "valuable" in making him the man he ultimately became. Young people attracted solely to "Minister Malcolm" are ignorant of his political evolution, he said.
"Kids running around with X hats and everything, they don't know the half of it," said Swayzack. "They look to Malcolm X as a hero but stifle themselves by not knowing the truth of the man. They wear Malcolm X hats but carry 9-millimeters and shoot other brothers."
To James H. Cone, a theologian and author of "Martin and Malcolm and America: A Dream or a Nightmare," Malcolm X's racial pride and strength of character defined the consciousness of many African-Americans.
"Malcolm's legacy is on the inside," said Dr. Cone, whose 1991 book shows how the visions of Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X were converging in their final years. "It is blacks renaming themselves from Negro to black to African-American. He was a cultural revolutionary who transformed the way in which black people thought about themselves. He revolutionized the black mind by reorienting them into a deep appreciation of the African cultural heritage, showing black people that you cannot hate Africa and not end up hating yourself."
With so many faces of Malcolm to be taken into account, how can a film maker hope to do justice to his legacy? Mr. Lee also refers to Malcolm X in his previous works, such as at the end of his third film, "Do the Right Thing," in which he juxtaposes quotes by Malcolm X and King. He said it was his intent in the new movie to leave audiences with "the Malcolm that is alive today," adding, "All of them are alive."
Thus, while the film depicts the assassination of Malcolm X, the final images are of schoolchildren and the South African black nationalist Nelson Mandela in present-day Soweto, the black township that symbolizes the political conflicts in apartheid. One by one, the children stand and say proudly, "I am Malcolm."
"We make the connection between Soweto and Harlem, Nelson and Malcolm, and what Malcolm talked about -- pan-Africanism, trying to build these bridges between people of color," Mr. Lee said. "He is alive in children in classrooms in Harlem, in classrooms in Soweto."
To some heirs of the Malcolm X legacy, this is the most enduring inheritance of all.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 8; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1575 words

HEADLINE: Profile/Marvin Runyon;
730,000 Employees and a Challenge

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The JOB has been called Mission Impossible, and the list of particulars is daunting. The work force is bigger than the American payrolls of G.M. and I.B.M. combined. The unions are powerful. The pay is modest. Costs are rising. Service is patchy. The customers are grumbling. Rivals are nibbling away more of the business. Meddling politicians are an ever-present threat. No wonder the previous occupant of the office said the job was like being a "public whipping boy."
The job title that comes with this litany of headaches? Postmaster General of the United States. 
 Marvin Runyon, the 68-year-old former auto executive who took over in July, says that next to being President the position of Postmaster General is "the most challenging management job in the country." No one doubts the challenge. Nor is there any dispute that since he arrived Mr. Runyon has made the most sweeping changes since the Postal Service became a quasi-independent agency in 1971.
With early-retirement incentives and plenty of Runyonite prodding, 30,000 supervisory jobs are being eliminated. The biggest slice, proportionately, is being taken from the top. Senior management positions are being chopped nearly in half to 24. The goal, of course, is to fashion a more efficient postal system, one that will behave like a business catering to customers instead of like a government monopoly.
"The Postal Service really hasn't faced the fact that we need satisfied customers to succeed," Mr. Runyon said recently in his spacious 10th-floor office at L'Enfant Plaza.
Mr. Runyon has been a roving evangelist for the New Postal Service. And he could pass for a television evangelist, this lean, sharp-featured Texan with a well-tended white mane and a steely manner. In recent weeks, his crowded itinerary has included stops in St. Louis, Dallas, Detroit, Pittsburgh, Miami, New York, Chicago and Nashville. He has met with postal workers, union officials, business mailers and ordinary citizens. The theme of his standard stump speech is that the changes he has initiated will "bring accountability, credibility and competitiveness to the U.S. Postal Service." His talks are filled with such terms as empowerment, participative management and customer-focused.
If the look and sound of what Mr. Runyon is doing is familiar, that's because the Postal Service has embarked on what amounts to the 90's makeover for corporate America -- cut layers of management, eliminate bureaucracy and make decisions more quickly. Mr. Runyon is trying to put his bloated organization through the regimen being tried at General Motors, I.B.M., Sears and many other companies.
Mr. Runyon is the chief executive of what is probably the largest service enterprise in America -- 730,000 workers at 40,000 post offices, handling 165 billion pieces of mail a year, and generating revenues of $43 billion a year. His annual salary of $144,900 is a fraction of one that the chief executive of a major corporation would command.
Still, Mr. Runyon believes that the lessons learned in business can be applied to the public sector, and that the chance to put the theory into practice is worth the pay cut. "It's easy to just complain about people in government and say if only they ran it like a business it would work better," he said.
Mr. Runyon comes to the Postal Service with an eclectic resume, a career of equal parts trench warrior and management pioneer. He began his 37-year tour at the Ford Motor Company on the assembly line, but he rose quickly, ending up a top manufacturing executive, overseeing 29 factories and 120,000 workers. In 1980, he became president of the Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation U.S.A., setting up its plant in Smyrna, Tenn., at a time when mimicking Japanese management methods was all the rage.
EIGHT years later, Mr. Runyon first tried his hand at public-sector management, when he became chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, the electric utility serving seven Southern states. A New Deal creation, the T.V.A. did everything from give farmers advice on soil erosion to head economic development programs, in addition to supplying electricity to households and businesses.
Such benevolence was fine, but expensive. The electric rates paid by T.V.A. customers had climbed more than 10 percent a year in the two decades before Mr. Runyon arrived. He reversed the trend, holding rates steady for five years, by narrowing the T.V.A.'s focus to supplying power and sharply cutting the payroll. The effort earned Mr. Runyon the nickname Carvin' Marvin.
The joke making the rounds in Tennessee these days is that Mr. Runyon's departure for the Postal Service will bring the worst of both worlds: electric rates will go up and the bills will arrive sooner.
Mr. Runyon is a skilled practitioner of the symbolic gesture, understanding the value of the minor theatrics of leadership. These skills, no doubt, were honed at Nissan, where, in keeping with Japanese practice, he wore the same uniform as rank-and-file workers and dined in the same cafeteria. When he arrived at the T.V.A., he ordered the lights burning all night at the Knoxville headquarters to be shut off. The glowing headquarters building, he explained, was a symbol of waste.
Shortly after he came to the Postal Service, Mr. Runyon made an example of the in-house newspaper, to stress the new business-like ethos. He was shown the plans for the coming year for the paper, called Focus. Roughly 800,000 copies would be mailed out first-class, six times a year. He was told the cost would be about $600,000 for a year to produce it. Mr. Runyon asked about the mailing costs. "Oh, we don't pay postage," came the reply.
Mr. Runyon hit the roof, appalled at the free-lunch mentality. He immediately issued an edict: every department will be charged for its postage. "We've got to behave like a private business to compete," he said.
TO win cooperation for his overhaul, Mr. Runyon has worked to create a sense of urgency, even crisis, within the Postal Service. The numbers he uses, especially when speaking to workers and union leaders, are disturbing. He projects a $2 billion operating deficit for 1993, which his cost-cutting program is intended to eliminate. And he sees competition on every front, not just from established rivals like United Parcel Service and Federal Express, but from electronic mail, fax machines, even low-cost long-distance phone service. In all, Mr. Runyon estimates that 50 percent of the mail volume of the service and 40 percent of its revenues are under threat.
Union officials and others question Mr. Runyon's dire projections, suggesting that some of the urgency is manufactured. But even they tend to favor the middle-management cuts he's made.
"The bureaucracy is too bloated, and Runyon made up his mind and moved boldly to do something about it," said Vincent Sombrotto, president of the National Association of Letter Carriers, the union that represents 219,000 postal workers. "We think he did the right thing."
Mr. Runyon is trying to hold down prices at the Postal Service just as he did at the T.V.A. Since 1975 the price of a first-class stamp has nearly tripled, to 29 cents from 10 cents, an increase of 11 percent a year, far more than inflation. Traditionally, the Postal Service files for a rate increase every three years; the last one came in 1991.
"We're going to break that three-year cycle," Mr. Runyon said. "We are not going for a rate increase in 1994."
 
 
 
A KEY TO PROGRESS: THE UNIONS
 In his streamlining drive, Marvin Runyon has studiously avoided one word -- "layoffs" -- and repeated one pledge, "Anyone who touches the mail is safe." His stance is both tactically shrewd and a concession to reality. For the people who touch the mail are mainly protected by two powerful unions, the American Postal Workers Union, representing clerks, and the National Association of Letter Carriers. Together, the two unions represent two-thirds of the 730,000 employees of the Postal Service.
After six years of employment, the clerks and carriers are covered by a lifetime no-layoff provision. When the current four-year labor contract expires in 1994, Mr. Runyon could presumably try to change the longstanding provision, but it would be risky.
Labor cooperation is essential to Mr. Runyon's attempts to increase productivity. "He understands that the people who handle the mail control the service," said Norma Pace, an economist who is chairwoman of the Postal Service's board of governors. They also control a big share of the costs; 83 cents on the dollar goes to wages and benefits.
The unions also have political muscle. The Postal Service, though a quasi-independent agency, is subject to Congressional oversight. In the 18 months ended last June, the most recent period tabulated, the political action committees of the two main postal unions raised $2.4 million.
The unions are worried about certain trends like the practice of contracting out more jobs to nonunion workers, from janitorial services to repairing canvas mailbags. But so far, union leaders are cooperating with Mr. Runyon, because they approve of many of his measures and because they have survived many an ambitious postmaster general. "There are grave concerns here," said Moe Biller, the 77-year-old president of the American Postal Workers Union. "But I want to give the guy a chance before I start beating up on him."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 7; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1562 words

HEADLINE: Mr. Pearce's Growing Domain

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
Seven years ago, the General Motors Corporation's legal department recruited an obscure trial lawyer from Bismarck, N.D., named Harry J. Pearce, who knew G.M. vehicle technology, having defended many product liability cases for the company.
Two weeks ago, in the G.M. shake up that elevated John F. (Jack) Smith Jr. to chief executive and John G. Smale to chairman, Mr. Pearce, 50, was the surprise choice to become the executive vice president in charge of G.M.'s two huge nonautomotive assets -- the Electronic Data Systems Corporation and the G.M. Hughes Electronics Corporation. 
 While Mr. Smith concentrates on restoring G.M.'s North American automotive business to profitability, Mr. Pearce has risen meteorically to become Mr. Everything Else of G.M.'s high command.
Chief among his tasks, he said in an interview last week, will be transferring technologies from E.D.S. and G.M. Hughes to the auto business, fulfilling a goal of the two acquisitions of the mid-1980's, which cost G.M. a combined $8 billion. But if G.M. does not start making money and needs capital, he may be forced to supervise the sale of one or both subsidiaries.
"Am I sitting around thinking about how to spin off these assets?" said Mr. Pearce, who earned an engineering degree before going to law school. "The answer is, 'No.' " Yet, he quickly added: "No one can predict the U.S. economy. No one can predict our industry. So if circumstances were to change dramatically, we wouldn't limit our thinking in any way. We would do what we have to do to insure that General Motors survived as a profitable corporation."
Wall Street, which is nervously watching G.M.'s tattered balance sheet and shaky credit ratings, knows that E.D.S. and, to a lesser extent, G.M. Hughes could be turned into fresh capital without harming automotive operations. The legalities and finances of unwinding a wholly owned subsidiaries represented by separate classes of common stock would be tricky, however, because the stocks are an odd invention that don't represent ownership but only dividends.
So, who better to have in place than a lawyer with a broader view?
"Harry is the best strategic thinker" at G.M., said Elmer W. Johnson, a former G.M. executive vice president who recruited Mr. Pearce. "He kept a diary for years detailing what he'd do if he ever had a chance to influence how cars were made, instead of fighting lawsuits."
Mr. Pearce also takes over G.M.'s government and industry affairs, and keeps his post as general counsel -- in all, an enormous portfolio that greatly extends his reach into the business operations of the company.
In the last few years, other G.M. executives "have been relying on him for not just legal but business judgment," said Ira Millstein, counsel to G.M.'s directors. "It's unusual for a lawyer to gain trust, but he's done it."
The question remains, however, whether Mr. Pearce's obsession for efficiency and performance can be amplified into an arena much larger than G.M.'s legal department. An opponent of G.M.'s go-along, get-along culture, he first showed his style when he was promoted to general counsel in 1987. Almost immediately, he weeded out dozens of in-house lawyers he deemed unproductive. To reduce bureaucracy, he stripped nearly everyone of their titles.
Armed with customized software that tracked billable hours and clerical costs, Mr. Pearce's department began forcing outside law firms to charge G.M. less money. In some cases, the economy was as simple as sending one lawyer to a deposition rather than three or four.
"I was put through it, and it taught me a lot about my own law firm," said Mr. Millstein, a senior partner of Weil, Gotshal & Manges in New York.
With 19,000 active lawsuits and a staff of 409 lawyers, G.M. still managed to spend $497 million on legal expenses in 1991. But without the cost-cutting, the bill would have been $51 million more, G.M. says.
Mr. Pearce will try for a similar success pushing E.D.S. to develop more sophisticated computer services for G.M.'s automotive operations. New software, for example, could simplify the design of common parts for different models, thus trimming engineering and tooling costs. Standardizing parts "cries out for world-class data-processing techniques," Mr. Pearce said.
In G.M.'s array of businesses, E.D.S. is a highly profitable crown jewel that could fetch $10 billion to $12 billion. Independent analysts say the company is run efficiently. Mr. Pearce won't say so directly, but he is sure to be careful that in his drive for better technology, he doesn't reignite the feuding of the mid-1980's. That was caused when E.D.S.'s can-do culture clashed with G.M.'s bureaucratic style, and the clash led to the celebrated departure from G.M.'s board of E.D.S.'s founder, Ross Perot.
G.M. Hughes, an amalgam of businesses, is tougher to value.
Its Delco Electronics unit builds radios and other automotive electronics, and performs well as an automotive supplier.
Hughes Aircraft, on the other hand, has weak profits and is grappling with the transition from defense contracting to commercial markets. On Friday, Hughes Aircraft announced it was starting subsidiaries to increase sales abroad of its defense and commercial electronics equipment. One subsidiary will concentrate on Europe, the other on Asia. Currently, about 18 percent of Hughes Aircraft's business is overseas.
Many Hughes high-technology applications, like charging equipment for electric cars, are intriguing but may take several years to turn a profit.
"I intend to sort through the list of common projects of G.M. and Hughes to make sure we've sorted through our priorities and are working on the right things," Mr. Pearce said.
The replacement of electric arc welding by laser welding, he said, is an example of a Hughes project with great potential. "If we can use Hughes technology to build safer structures or to build them with less people, obviously it drops to the bottom line," he said.
Roger B. Smith first articulated the promise of high-technology in the mid-1980's when, as G.M. chairman, he bought E.D.S. and Hughes. E.D.S., he said, would make G.M. into a "paperless" corporation with every computer talking to every other computer, from the dealership to the factory floor. It hasn't happened. Most manufacturing experts say technology is key, but G.M. first must solve other problems, like poor relations between hourly workers and managers.
"We became intrigued with things like robotics and didn't do adequate training," said Mr. Pearce. "We have a lot to learn from the Japanese; they are masters of simple approaches."
In discussions of advanced technology, Mr. Pearce brings a formal background that includes undergraduate training in engineering at the Air Force Academy. Because of color blindness, he eventually went to law school and served as an Air Force lawyer instead of as a fighter pilot.
After military service, he returned home to his father's law practice in North Dakota, where he represented G.M. and others for 15 years in product liability lawsuits. For those cases, he had to learn the intricacies of automotive engineering design.
During the so-called X-car trial of the early 1980's, when G.M. successfully defended the brake system of its X-body mid-size cars, "he was the technical guru," said James Farmer, now a vice president of G.M.'s Saturn Corporation, who worked with Mr. Pearce during the trial. "He made Perry Mason sound like a first-year law student."
Mr. Johnson, who himself was recruited from outside G.M. by Roger Smith, told Mr. Pearce in 1985 he would have a shot at becoming general counsel one day. After winning the job two years later, Mr. Pearce discovered at executive lunch meetings that he and Jack Smith shared a disdain for titles and for hierarchy.
"Jack's a pretty unstructured guy," said Mr. Pearce. "He's looking for good analysis and the logic of your position. There's not much difference between the cost problems of legal departments and elsewhere."
 
 
 
THE CHAINS OF COMMAND
 To demonstrate his disdain for hierarchical management practices at the General Motors Corporation, Harry J. Pearce often meets with clerks, secretaries and junior executives.
"If we can get people out from under bureaucracies and excessive management, our people will be our strongest asset and biggest contributors," he said.
But as executive vice president in charge of the company's Electronic Data Systems and G.M. Hughes Electronic subsidiaries, Mr. Pearce probably will conform more closely to the chain of command as he tries to coax out of the units more technology that will help G.M.'s auto business.
At E.D.S., Lester M. Alberthal Jr. is the chairman and chief executive; at G.M. Hughes, C. Michael Armstrong is the chief executive, but Mr. Pearce will be chairman.
E.D.S. has two officers, Paul Chiapparone and Frank Stoneking, who oversee work for G.M., which accounts for about half of E.D.S.'s revenue. Mr. Chiapparone gained celebrity as one of two E.D.S. executives rescued from Iran in a mission mounted by the company's founder, Ross Perot.
At Hughes, Mr. Armstrong's No. 2 is Michael T. Smith, whose brother Jack is G.M.'s new chief executive.
"These are two strong management teams who have done a good job of creating horizontal organizations," Mr. Pearce said.

HEADLINE: Sound Bytes;
Here Comes Comdex/Fall Again, With Thumbs Up

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
COMDEX/FALL is the mother of all trade shows. This year's five-day personal computer extravaganza, which opens tomorrow in Las Vegas, is expected to attract 130,000 buyers, sellers, manufacturers and journalists, who come to make deals and see the latest technologies. Sheldon G. Adelson, chairman and chief executive of the Interface Group in Needham, Mass., an operator of computer trade shows and vacation companies, started the Comdex show in 1979, in a hotel ballroom. Now he owns, among other things, the Sands hotel and casino.
Question: What is the industry's current financial and emotional health? 
 Answer: If I look at the growth of Comdex this year, and then I read The New York Times and see words like "recession" and "economic stagnation," I think I'm in two different worlds. In terms of numbers of companies participating in Comdex, we're seeing growth of 5 or 7 percent, to 2,000 companies. Exhibit space is up 5 percent. Preregistration is up 31 percent.
Q: So your industry indicators are all pointing up?
A: The best barometer that exists is the organizer of the trade show, because he knows who's doing what. Exhibitors are telling us what their plans are, whether they're going to be extravagant or conservative, whether they're going to shrink or enlarge their space, and I tell you, it works like a clock. The signs are up.
Q: Who has the largest display this year?
A: I think it's I.B.M., somewhere between 25,000 and 30,000 square feet of space. Microsoft is probably right up there.
Q: What's the going rate for a square foot?
A: The standard is $37.95. So now you want to figure out how much they paid us? Almost $1 million for each of those companies.
Q: How many feet have you sold overall?
A: About 1.2 million, net. Don't try to figure out how much we make. We don't discuss that. We do make money, but we certainly don't make the money that you're going to figure out that it looks like we're making.
Q: Comdex/Fall has become the monster that ate Las Vegas, and you created the monster. Any survival tips for the attendees?
A: Put in a full day. Also, no one person could run up and down 23 miles of aisles; you've got to have multiple people coming from one organization. Get up early and prepare your attack.
Q: And wear sneakers.
A: If you wear regular leather shoes, put footpads in them. I do.

 Ideal escape: "I love the sun. If I have enough time, Maui; if not, St. Martin."
 Current noncomputer reading: Books about Israel's founding and existence.

PUB-DATE: November 15, 1992

SECTION: Section 6; Page 23; Column 3; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3914 words

HEADLINE: Staging Painterly Visions

BYLINE: By John Rockwell; John Rockwell is European cultural correspondent for The Times.

 BODY:
When I was young, I did a children's play," Robert Wilson recalled recently. "I had 10 10-year-old boys wrapped in Saran Wrap so tight they had only one finger free. After five minutes, one of the mothers screamed, 'Mothers should take their children off the stage.' Afterwards, my father said, 'Son, not only was that thing absurd, it was sick.' "
There are those who have the same reaction to Wilson's mammoth theater pieces today; at every Wilson performance, some people can be counted on to walk out, huffily. Sometimes half the audience does, especially in his native United States. But those who stay, stay to cheer. Enough have cheered so that Wilson can be considered this country's -- or even the world's -- foremost vanguard "theater artist," a term that almost seems to have been coined for him. 
 Over his 25-year career in the theater, the 51-year-old Wilson has defined a new kind of hybrid stage work, one that combines glacial movement, painterly visions, stylized articulation of text or song and -- especially when he isn't reinterpreting the classics and is creating new work of his own -- a bizarre, post-modern, neo-Surrealist world view. Within the universe of avant-garde theater, at least, the term "Wilsonian" means something almost as distinct and original as "Brechtian."
Wilson's astonishingly copious output is now produced mostly in Europe, with only occasional pieces seen here. Abroad, Wilson looks like the archetype of what Europeans prize in American renegade movie actors, jazz loners, minimalist composers and oddball authors: a natural genius, an untutored eccentric who brings something fresh and uncompromised to the jaded European palate. He even comes from a legendary American state, Texas, to boot.
But his refusal to conform to mainstream conventions scares many Americans, unsure of their high-art credentials. His own work -- from the 12-hour "The Life and Times of Joseph Stalin" in 1973 to the five-hour "Einstein on the Beach" in 1976 to the uncompleted daylong "The Civil Wars: A Tree Is Best Measured When It Is Down" of 1984 -- is austere, stylized and, usually, protracted. It clashes with the staid, loosely naturalistic conventions of Broadway, films and television: a self-contained, more-than-three-hour act of "The Civil Wars" was recommended for a Pulitzer Prize by the jury for drama, but rejected by the Pulitzer board. His interpretations of classics can seem willful and bizarre. His biggest, and hence best, works are enormously expensive to produce, both in terms of scenic requirements and especially in the huge amount of rehearsal time that Wilson demands.
Now, however, even in the teeth of the current recession, Wilson's American prospects may be improving. Houston is becoming one American base, with a well-regarded production at the Houston Grand Opera of Wagner's "Parsifal" in February (first seen in Hamburg, Germany) and a new association with the Alley Theater that this fall involves a Wilson production of Georg Buchner's play "Danton's Death." Near New York, his official residence since 1962, he is building a museum, workshop and residence in Water Mill, L.I.
This summer, his staging of a Gertrude Stein play, "Doctor Faustus Lights the Lights," acted by drama students from the eastern part of Berlin, was done at Alice Tully Hall in Manhattan as part of Lincoln Center's Serious Fun festival. And on Thursday, a second revival of "Einstein on the Beach," his pioneering post-modernist collaboration with the composer Philip Glass that counts as his most famous work, will reappear at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
"I don't want to be an expatriate," Wilson says plaintively in the coldly impersonal apartment he had taken for the Hamburg "Parsifal" rehearsals. "I'm an American, and I want to keep my American roots."
AS A "THEATER ARTIST," Wilson is a stage director and also (perhaps pre-eminently) a set and lighting designer. For the last decade, he has played those roles in the staging of dramatic and operatic classics and in modern repertory, including plays by Marguerite Duras of France and Tankred Dorst and Heiner Muller of Germany, an opera by the Italian Giacomo Manzoni and an "Orlando" monologue masterfully compressed from Virginia Woolf's novel by the European-based American novelist Darryl Pinckney.
He has also created his own work, but his way of creating and collaborating is most unusual. Wilson is not a writer (except for occasional neo-Dadaist scenes) or a composer or a choreographer, yet he remains the dominant force in any production.
"Collaboration is very personal," says Jennifer Tipton, the renowned lighting designer who has chosen to work regularly with Wilson -- the set designer John Conklin has made the same choice -- when she could be earning more elsewhere. "I've learned a lot from him, and I hope he's learned from me. But my work with him is in no way my work."
Even his "dead collaborators," as one could call Shakespeare, Mozart and Wagner, are bent to his sensibility. Thus a Wilson staging of, say, "King Lear" is hardly the one "King Lear" you would like to pass on to your grandchildren (among other novelties, Wilson cast an 80-year-old German actress, Marianne Hoppe, in the title role). But as a statement in itself, a challenging clash of sensibilities across the centuries, it was fascinating.
Wilson blithely evokes canonical figures to justify his single-minded fixations: the dinosaurs, earthquake chasms and elongated chairs that recur from production to production. "Proust said he was always writing the same novel," Wilson says. "Cezanne said he was always painting the same still life. It is one body, one statement. But laws are made to be broken, too. You build a vocabulary and then you destroy it, and out of this destruction you build a new vocabulary. The best thing is to try to contradict yourself, to find collaborators as different as, say, Tom Waits and Heiner Muller. Listening to other people helps you to find new ideas, new windows."
When left to his own devices, Wilson's projects often take on a Wagnerian grandiosity. For an artist who arose out of New York 1960's minimalism, Wilson is a true maximalist of ambition and scale: For him, more is more, so that his intimate or low-budget works, the ones usually seen in New York, seriously misrepresent his achievement. His blockbuster for the 1990's is to be a two-part operatic extravaganza with Glass. The first part, entitled "White Raven," is scheduled for Bonn and Lisbon in 1994 and the second, "The Palace of the Arabian Nights," is to follow a couple of years later, possibly in Paris, with the combined diptych also in Paris.
What has distinguished Wilson's theater from the very beginning, despite enormous differences of subject and collaborative participation, has been his visionary stage pictures. Even without texts, as in his early works from the mid-60's to the early 70's, Wilson established a dreamlike narrative logic through a succession of vivid images, some indebted to other artists but indisputably original in their three-dimensionality and cumulative impact. No one person could say definitively what the pictures "meant" or tell their "story," but every sympathetic observer felt sure they meant something, something personal and profound.
For example, the final tableau of his 1988 "Le Martyre de Saint Sebastien" in Paris was all in dazzling white, a heaven containing white animals and white trees against a brilliant white backdrop, with the dancer Sylvie Guillem poised ethereally at the center but with a blood-red medieval figure of Death, complete with blood-red scythe, creeping slowly across the lip of the stage. Or take an image from "Stalin": a line of apes emerging from a dark and shadowy forest, scratching and picking at one another, then watching in dumb amazement as bright red apples rise from their paws and disappear upward, while a human couple in silver 18th-century formal dress appear from the left, the woman's parasol literally on fire as the curtain falls.
Such images stick in the memory with the force of an epiphany. Wilson himself is guarded about the religious implications of his work, and deliberately shied away from Christian trappings in his Hamburg-Houston "Parsifal."
"For me, to work is a religious experience," he says. "But I hate the word 'religious' and I hate to see religion on stage. What bothers me about 'Parsifal' is all this sacrilegious ritual when the music is religious. I tried to make the Grail scenes a private experience. Religion is inside. It's truth, in here, not some big gesture -- that's just acting."
Wilson's real religion, his God, has always been light; hence his plays about Einstein and Edison, who shared that faith, and, perhaps, his initial interest in the Gertrude Stein title "Doctor Faustus Lights the Lights." "Without light there is no space," he argues. "Light is the essential element in the theater, because it lets us see and hear. It's what produces color and emotion."
ROBERT WILSON IS A 6-foot-4-inch man with a way of walking that oddly combines stiff reserve with sinuous, sensuous grace. His manner similarly blends grave introspection, weepy sentiment and giddy humor. He was born the son of a God-fearing lawyer and a homemaker; he has a younger sister who lives in Houston. Both his parents are dead. By all accounts, Wilson was a strange, self-possessed boy, marked for something different from what his parents might have wished for him.
At the age of 17 he was cured of childhood stuttering by a Waco dance teacher named Bird Hoffmann, who slowed down his speech and taught him to express himself through movement; in gratitude, he still calls his New York office the Byrd Hoffman Foundation (the spelling change perhaps reflects an early aspiration toward artiness). Although he spent three years at the University of Texas in Austin to appease his parents (his father was by then the city manager of Waco), his real interest was working with brain-damaged children and a children's theater group. In 1962, he quit Texas for New York to study design and the arts at the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, where he graduated with a degree in fine arts in 1965. Although he acted in student plays and was exposed to the happenings and experimental theater of the time, Wilson thought of himself as a painter.
But something was lacking. In 1966 he suffered a nervous breakdown and spent several months as a patient in a mental institution. "I was very frustrated in the 60's," he recalls. "Then I realized I could do things on stage as a painter that I couldn't do on canvas. The stage brought together a lot of things; all the elements were there. Now I've gone back to painting, and I feel so much freer, so much more knowledgeable about myself."
His early theater, dance and performance works were both a refutation of prevailing conventions and an artistic expression of his continuing work with brain-damaged and autistic children and with chronically ill adults. In 1967 he created a slow-motion "dance" for patients in iron lungs. Important early collaborators included two teen-agers, Raymond Andrews who was deaf and Christopher Knowles who was autistic.
Even though he frequently appeared as a kind of pioneer performance artist in New York in the late 60's, Wilson earned little money and had to teach and conduct workshops to support himself. His breakthrough, the work that established him as a hero with European intellectuals, was the production in Paris of "Deafman Glance" in 1971, first seen in New York earlier that year and later incorporated into "Stalin."
"The French told me, You've had a phenomenal success," he says. "You can work, if you want, for the rest of your life in the theater. The offers came in. Before that, I really didn't know what to do with my life."
Proof of French enthusiasm was a $225,000 Government gift enabling him to present "Einstein on the Beach" at the Avignon Festival in the summer of 1976, then in Paris as part of a fall European tour and finally, in two performances arranged by Wilson, at the Metropolitan Opera House in New York in late November of that year. Its images of the scientist as innocent creator and inadvertent destroyer, of science and art on trial, of terrorism (Patty Hearst makes an appearance) and sentimental love transfixed audiences then and later in a popular recording: Glass's rippling minimalist music was also a landmark in his career. "Einstein" had a comparable success again in the slightly revised 1984 revival and again this summer and fall with the revival tour of the 1984 version due in Brooklyn this week.
"My father couldn't come to Paris in 1971," Wilson remembers. "Later, I invited him to 'A Letter for Queen Victoria' in Paris in 1974. He said he'd think about it. It opened on his birthday. He arrived and left the next morning and didn't say anything about the performance and I didn't ask him. A week later, he wrote me a letter that said, 'Son, your play had great beauty and poetry.' " (Wilson's 90-year-old maternal grandmother played the title role.)
"In 1976, he came to 'Einstein.' He said, 'Son, you must be making a lot of money.' I said, 'No, sir, it cost $1 million and I'm $125,000 in debt.' He said, 'Son, I didn't know you were smart enough to be able to lose $125,000.' I said, 'Dad, it was easy.' But that was one of the nicest things he ever said to me."
OVER THE YEARS, for better and for worse, he has changed. For some of his early devotees, fearful that his style has hardened into mannerism, it sounds like a rationalization to hear him remark: "As you grow older, you realize that compromise is part of theater. At the time, it may seem very painful, but in the long run, you learn from it."
Beyond the move a decade ago to staging works by others, the major change in his working habits has been his switch from amateur, volunteer American actors, many of them overt disciples, to professionals, particularly an accomplished cadre of German and French actors. Another has been the decision not to produce his work himself, to avoid the endless fund raising and crippling financial obligations of the 1976 "Einstein." There has been an increasing reliance on newly composed music and, more strikingly, a coming to terms with text.
A key to that development has been his collaboration with Heiner Muller, the (formerly East) Berlin playwright who looks and acts rather like Brecht and whose elliptical, densely layered works (notably "Hamletmachine") enjoy a big reputation in Europe. Muller has learned from Wilson, too: next summer he is scheduled to direct "Tristan und Isolde" at Bayreuth.
It would seem an open question just how much Wilson, who speaks only English, has really changed in his approach to words, or indeed to the craft of acting, and how intellectual he really is in his conceptualization of the classic pieces he directs. He prefers short texts, or he cuts theatrical classics radically and fills out the silences with gesture, movement and images. And he is still a minimalist in that his designs and his philosophy of acting create a neutral backdrop against which actors simply declaim the words, avoiding traditional theatrical interpretation. Recently he has begun to employ a stiff, Japanese-style gestural language in place of naturalistic movement and articulation.
"He feels the less we inflect the line, the more impact the words and actions will have," says Annette Paulmann, a young actress whose leading role in "The Black Rider," a popular Wilson collaboration with the rock composer Tom Waits in Hamburg, has propelled her to stardom in the German-speaking theatrical world ("She's my baby," the director remarks fondly).
Wilson is not above using psychology to elicit emotion. "An actor in 'The Black Rider' was having trouble with a ballad," he says. "I asked him, 'Who do you love?' He said, 'I have my wife, but it's a mess. I do have my 5-year-old daughter.' So I said, 'Sing it to her.' "
But mostly Wilson sets limits, suggests movements and then hopes the actor will fill in the blanks. As Dunja Vejzovic, a Croatian mezzo-soprano who sang Kundry in "Parsifal" in Hamburg and Houston and who is one of Wilson's more conscientious operatic actors, puts it: "Bob's language is pictures. He gives us the forms and we have to fill them with life."
Jutta Lampe, the Berlin actress who played Orlando in the Wilson-Woolf monologue, says: "Bob doesn't actually direct the pieces per se. His school is his own school."
All his career, Wilson has had to contend with charges that his work is merely imagistic, merely "pretty pictures," as he once himself disparaged himself. In interviews, he would still rather sketch designs than describe intentions. Some critics see his obsession with scenery as little more than a pretentious version of the likes of Franco Zeffirelli and Andrew Lloyd Webber. But some of Wilson's actors think he is cleverer than a mere imagist. "Bob counts on the audience's knowledge of a classic," Vejzovic argues. "He uses that knowledge and plays against it."
Wilson's directoral technique is the same for all of his operas or plays. He videotapes workshops in which he answers questions from actors or singers by miming the roles on camera. As with any innovative choreographer, his own movements, spidery and intense, are almost always more riveting than any imitator's. Routine actors give rote reflections of his movements but miss his undercurrents of terror, surprise and dark wit. The good ones build their own performances in a dialogue with his. The strongest ones, like Lampe and Guillem, blossom in the Wilson hothouse, finding in his devices liberation and inspiration rather than constraint.
It all comes down to the intuitive connection with Wilson that one performer may feel and another may not. "Look at her," Wilson says during a "Parsifal" rehearsal, pointing to one of two identically costumed Grail knights. "Look at her presence, the way the music is always inside her. That's what you need for Wagner." Or for Wilson, one might add. "The other girl, she looks like she's waiting for a bus. Dunja can be very still, and to do this kind of music, you have to start with stillness.
"Most actors are too text-oriented," Wilson complains. "The ones at the Schaubuhne in Berlin are more into movement. Martha Graham said once that when you turn, the whole universe turns with you. I don't want interpretation. Pieces like 'Parsifal' are so huge, so limitless, so full of ideas. As soon as you begin to narrow the interpretation, it's interesting but only that. Wagner has an inner logic. You don't need to interpret him psychologically; that only diminishes him. I look at it structurally. My idea is, If you don't know where you're going, you can't get there. For me, time is a horizontal line and space is vertical. So when Parsifal takes the lance and turns it vertically, that is time turning into space.
"The problem is when directors and actors think too much. Peter Sellars is too clever, too busy. I see Mozart, but I can't hear the music. In 'Parsifal,' I wanted to make a space where you could hear the music. The trick is to keep it superficially simple. Theater has to be about one thing first, then it can be about a million things."
AS HE HAS matured, Wilson has developed a way of working that permits him to get an amazing number of complex new productions onto the stage every year: four or more is normal. The system entails workshops involving either student stand-ins or the actual principals a year or more before the formal rehearsals begin, to help him refine his ideas. Thus, at any time as many as eight or nine productions are in various stages of development.
Alain Coblence, a French-American lawyer who is chairman of the board of Wilson's foundation, says Wilson has reduced by more than 50 percent the time he needs to achieve what he wants. Yet the director demanded and got 80 hours of rehearsals for lighting alone for the Hamburg "Parsifal." There still wasn't enough time to light a starry backdrop he had built for the final scene and he had to play it against a blank cyclorama -- an omission that was corrected by the time the production reached Houston.
Wilson's seemingly manic overachievement -- dashing about the globe to meetings and workshops and productions, bowing stiffly at one premiere and then hurrying off to the next -- has led to charges that he has greedily stretched himself too thin, particularly if compared to the mystical, contemplative, communal mode of working that defined his first theatrical ventures.
Coblence answers the charge of greed by pointing out that Wilson negotiations involve demands for rehearsal time more than for money. Wilson receives a salary from his foundation -- around $75,000 annually. He does have a sideline in his handcrafted chairs and other furniture, which are sold as art objects. But all his income from the theater, as well as the contributions of a few longtime patrons (including Pierre Berge of the Paris Opera and his business partner, Yves St. Laurent), goes to the foundation and is spent on workshops and other developmental projects.
Those who admire him worry about his overextension. "He does too much, but he's a true workaholic," says Lampe. "He empties himself." Wilson believes his variety of work serves as inspiration. "When I was 9 years old," he recalls, "somebody asked my mother on the telephone what I was doing and she said, 'I don't know, but he always has a lot of projects.' My father used to warn me to concentrate my energy on one thing. But it helps me to have many things going on at once; it makes things richer. It helped me to be working on 'King Lear' and 'The Black Rider' at the same time. It gave me different perspectives and let me contradict myself."
ONE PROBLEM ALL HIS wanderings have not solved is loneliness, which surely seems one reason for his longing for an American base. His closest collaborators become a source of emotional solace: Lampe remembers her initial fear of him turning into love and Wilson speaks of "the people I work with as a kind of family, even though they all have their own private lives." But that's not really enough, since Wilson, who avoids all public discussion of his private life, seems to have no steady intimate relationship and little immediate prospect of one, given his schedule.
In the meantime, the projects stretch into the future: a new "Don Juan" that has just opened in Madrid, a film with the dancer Trisha Brown, a second Hamburg collaboration with Tom Waits in December based on "Alice in Wonderland" and "Through the Looking Glass," Mozart's "Idomeneo" in Budapest, a new play for the Comedie Francaise in Paris, a Monteverdi madrigals evening produced by Milan's La Scala opera, a French version of "Orlando" with Isabelle Huppert that is then to be refashioned into Wilson's first feature film.
"Right now, I enjoy the work, I like the work, I'm in a very productive period," he says. "Ten days ago I was painting in Milan. A week ago I was talking to La Scala. Two days ago I spent the day with Phil Glass, and I just spoke with Marguerite Duras on the telephone. It's exciting for me.
"I know myself well enough that if I stay in one place too long, I have to move on. I think I know more people now in European cities than I know in New York. It's a very lonely life."
