HEADLINE: Focus: Indian Land Disputes;
South Carolina Settling Catawba Claim

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

DATELINE: ROCK HILL, S.C.

 BODY:
THIS state is close to settling the land claim of the Catawba Indian tribe. If the settlement is approved by Congress, the claim will raise the total Federal Government payments to Indian tribes east of the Mississippi River to nearly $200 million in the aftermath of landmark Supreme Court decisions since 1975.
In return for $30 million from the Federal Government and $20 million from South Carolina and local public and private sources, the Catawbas will relinquish claim to 144,000 acres surrounding and including this picturesque college town of 42,000 people 35 miles south of Charlotte, N.C. The land now includes such valuable property as Winthrop College and Heritage USA, the Christian theme park built by the disgraced evangelist Jim Bakker. 
 So far, the Federal Government and Florida, Massachusetts, Connecticut, Rhode Island, Virginia and Minnesota have settled Indian claims.
The Passamaquoddy, Penobscot and the Houlton Band of the Maliseet tribes, which claimed more than half of Maine, have won the largest settlement to date, $81.5 million, agreed to in 1980.
Still unresolved, though, are claims in New York, Massachusetts, Connecticut and Louisiana. In New York, negotiations continue with the Cayuga tribe, claiming 64,000 acres in Cayuga County, the Mohawk tribe, claiming 17,000 acres on the St. Lawrence River, and the Oneidas, claiming 240,000 acres in Oneida and Madison Counties.
The Catawba tribe, with 1,400 members still living in this section of northern South Carolina, used an innovative legal lever to get its way.
Just days before the settlement agreement was reached last August, the Catawbas stood poised to file lawsuits in Federal Court against each of the 61,767 landowners in the three-county area that they will relinquish.
The papers for the lawsuits -- each 18-inches thick -- are stored in a printer's warehouse in Rockville, Md., and will be filed if the settlement is not ratified by Congress and the South Carolina General Assembly, said Don Miller, a lawyer with the Native American Rights Fund in Boulder, Colo., who handled the Catawba case.
It was the threat of such a huge legal headache at the little York County Courthouse and in the offices of the dozen or so lawyers who practice here that convinced politicians to act, Mr. Miller said.
In addition, the lawsuits would have clouded the titles of all the property here, jeopardizing landowners' ability to sell their property. Stephen Turner, director of the Rock Hill Economic Development Corporation, believes the threat of lawsuits and the difficulty in getting title insurance caused several businesses to locate elsewhere.
Real estate agents said, too, that the possibility of court cases caused a decrease in home sales every month since April. By comparison, home sales in nearby Charlotte increased each month.
"Historical justice never got a settlement," said Mr. Miller, the Catawbas' lawyer. "There has to be a need for it, and the need has to alleviate potential discomfort for non-Indians. You walk a fine line."
One of the leading negotiators for the Federal Government was Representative John M. Spratt Jr., a Democrat who represents the area and owns a large parcel of land in the claim area. His ancestor, Kanawha Spratt, was the first white to lease part of the reservation from the Catawbas. The tribe had been granted the 144,000 acres by the Crown in 1763 in return for giving up claim to a much larger tract.
But within 60 years, South Carolina had control of virtually all the Catawba reservation. In 1840, the Catawbas agreed to give the state title to the land in return for 5,000 acres. Three years later, the state gave the tribe 640 acres, where about 50 tribal families live today, beside the Catawba River.
TRIBAL leaders have been trying to press their land claim though the Federal Government and the state since the early part of this century. They maintain that Congress never ratified any of the treaties, so they are not valid. Besides, they say, the state never lived up to its promises.
In addition to payments from the state and Federal governments, the settlement calls for $1.4 million from title insurance companies, $500,000 from Duke Power Company, $500,000 from Crescent Resources, $2 million from York County, $250,000 from Lancaster County and other contributions from banks and individuals. The payments are to be made over a five- or six-year period.
The money will go into several funds to be managed either by a private financier or the Secretary of the Interior, Mr. Miller said. The tribe wants the money to be held in trust for economic development, education and social services, especially health care and housing. On the reservation, about a third of the homes lack indoor plumbing, while the rest look somewhere between poor-but-maintained to middle-class.
There is only one paved road and no businesses on the reservation. An unheated gym was built with Federal funds 20 years ago.
Some of the settlement money, said the tribe's chief, Gilbert Blue, will buy as much as 4,000 acres next to the reservation, where leaders hope to build a new housing development, a tribal government center, a community center and some type of tourist-related facility like a museum or educational center.
He said the settlement would allow the tribe to operate bingo games, but there is not much fervor for gambling from the predominantly Mormon tribe. Instead, the tribe would rather invest in some type of industrial development in the area.
A small percentage of the money will be paid out to tribal members, who will be identified by a membership roll published in the Federal Record in 1961. Anyone on the list or their descendants will be eligible for the per-capita payment.
Lawyers' fees have not been determined, but that payment will not exceed 10 percent of the settlement, Mr. Miller said.
For the most part, the large financial gains for the tribes have have come not through the courts -- the two Supreme Court decisions notwithstanding -- but through political pressure, said Mike Anderson, the executive director of the National Congress of American Indians, an advocacy group in Washington.
"I think all parties see that the court process could take years and years and the legislative process is a way to short-circuit that," he said.
BUT lawyers who represented some of the tribes say while expediency played a part, political pressure was most advantageous because the tribes knew they could not win in the courts.
In fact, the only case an Indian tribe has lost was one that went before a jury in Massachusetts, where the Mashpee Wampanoag tribe sued every landowner in a portion of Cape Cod, including Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. The jury found the tribe ceased to exist in the 1800's, so no damages were merited.
"You've got to consider what you are asking the court to do: to displace people who have acquired the land in good faith," said Arlinda Locklear, the attorney for New York's Oneida tribe. "That would cause economic disruption far beyond anything a Federal court has ever done, including the integration cases."
The Supreme Court has issued two pivotal rulings for the rights of Indian tribes. In 1975, the court said that all tribes, even those that the Federal Government did not recognize, like the Catawbas and the three in Maine, would be protected by the law that prevents the acquisition of Indian lands unless Congress approves.
Then in 1985, the Supreme Court ruled that the Oneidas still owned their land because the United States had never approved the transaction.
"The court applied the law as it found it," said Ms. Locklear. "But no Federal court has ever transferred a single acre of land. That may be asking too much."

HEADLINE: FOCUS;

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 15; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 990 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
'Sweeney Todd,' in All Its Musical Power

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

DATELINE: MILLBURN

 BODY:
TO get right to the gist, the Paper Mill Playhouse's "Sweeney Todd" is the musical thriller's most thrilling production yet -- more so than the landmark Broadway staging in 1979, more so than the acclaimed scaled-down revival 10 years later and more so than the version that entered the City Opera's repertory in 1984.
Lest it be presupposed that Stephen Sondheim's macabre masterwork is but a gory story about a crazed barber who cuts throats and whose frumpy accomplice makes meat pie of the corpses, it should be emphasized that redemptive significance is never less than a shiver away. 
 "It's man devouring man, my dear/And who are we/To deny it in here?" Todd sings pragmatically to his conspirator. "Ah, these are desperate times, Mrs. Lovett, and desperate measures must be taken," he goes on.
The desperation is everywhere, and the Beggar Woman is a recurring cry for social conscience. Todd himself, an unforgiving, unforgetting victim of injustice -- the theatrical character dates back to the 1840's; the legend, perhaps five centures before that -- represents the classic irresistible theme of revenge. A lascivious, malicious judge perpetuates old sins, and a chorus of lunatics blares "City on Fire"; their prophecy, "It's the end of the world," is a chilling cacophony, signifying moral chaos.
Unlike the emphatic original staging by Harold Prince, in which the Industrial Revolution loomed ominously while the chorus pointed fingers, implicating the audience for society's disintegration, Michael Montel's graceful production at the Paper Mill is more musical-minded and trusting of the material.
Taking its cue from Todd's introduction -- "What happened then/ Well, that's the play/And he wouldn't want us to give it away" -- the rest is played as a mystery with messages implicit, not used as assault. Bloodletting scenes are actually subtle, more suggestive than splattering, and Judge Turpin's moment of self-flagellation is deleted.
Visible technicians operating spotlights on the stage provide a Brechtian distance. Eugene Lee's lithographic setting, with factory windows and ramps, a modified version of his own overpowering ironworks Broadway design, now on loan from the City Opera, is, effectively, a balance between the gargantuan original and the intimate revival.
Luckily, the orchestra is in full bloom here, sparing us the reductive, synthesized sound of an economically compromised adaptation. One can savor the richness of an extraordinarily diverse and rapturous score. The urgency of Jonathan Tunick's orchestrations and the nonstop current of the music, masterfully conducted by Jeffrey Saver, provide a singular aural high.
While attending to the "chill of ghostly shadows everywhere," Mr. Montel's staging sustains a lyrical flow that makes this "Sweeney Todd" musically stirring, dramatically involving and altogether accessible.
The place of this piece in musical history is so assured that it may be rash to call the leading performances here definitive, but it's going to be tough to come up with a Todd and a Mrs. Lovett comparable to George Hearn and Judy Kaye.
Mr. Hearn, a replacement in the first Broadway production, has never been in firmer vocal estate. His bass tones descend to the abyss of Todd's mind. The high notes ring with triumphant vengeance. The characterization, like Sweeney's hand brandishing a razor, is complete, as much in pathology as in poignance.
Ms. Kaye's voluptuous voice taps and illuminates musical treasures. The ribaldry, seductiveness and wit of her performance appear thoroughly rooted in Mrs. Lovett's love for Todd. Since wicked comedy, in set pieces and in innuendo, is essential to such oversized characters and to the show's conception, it is important to acknowledge how Ms. Kaye and Mr. Hearn radiate such palpable joy in these roles.
One of the wonders of Mr. Sondheim's score, with its references to opera buffa, liturgical oratorio and English music hall, is the soaring lyricism in sordid contexts, a cunning blending of the beautiful and the base. Emotions are expressed by unlikely characters at perverse moments.
In a nearly catatonic state, a dependent young helper, Tobias, though hardly "the sweet child" in the guise of Robert Johanson, sings a protective "Nothing's gonna harm you/Not while I'm around" to Mrs. Lovett. Todd's passionate ode to friendship is all about his razors -- how inevitable it now seems that Mr. Sondheim went on to create "Assassins."
A songbird is crushed during a heavenly musical interlude involving the young lovers, Anthony and Johanna. And the teasing "Pretty Women" is a prelude to a killing.
Although the floating passages of "Johanna," one of Mr. Sondheim's most stunning arias, are beyond the limits of Jay Montgomery (as Anthony, the sailor), the rest of the cast is resplendent of voice, notably Rebecca Baxter's silvery Johanna and Mary Beth Peil's Beggar Woman -- for the first time, a revelation of that role's musical values. Nick Wyman's Judge Turpin must surely be "the devil incarnate," and Mr. Johanson is a mercifully restrained Tobias.
For the state's most popularly oriented theater to take on a musical so potentially off-putting is a gutsy thing. And there's a lovely irony in that "Sweeney Todd" is being produced without the excess and ostentation -- in design, in direction, in performance -- that all too often mar the theater's more mainstream, audience-winning shows.
This, then, is the Paper Mill in full artistic control. One hopes it proves a great adventure for audiences. For those who gave up dreaming of a permanent musical repertory theater, here is a production of transporting power that captures the vision on a grand scale. This is as close as you'll get. Hold on to it for four more weeks.
"Sweeney Todd," produced by the Paper Mill Playhouse, Brookside Drive in Millburn. Performances through Dec. 13. Box office: (201) 376-4343.

GRAPHIC: Photo: George Hearn and Judy Kaye in "Sweeney Todd," at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn. (Gerry Goodstein)

HEADLINE: All Over State, Latin Redux

BYLINE: By JOYCE JONES

 BODY:
THE game was Simon Says, but in Mary Lou Mitchell's sixth-grade class at the Summit Middle School one recent morning, it had a different ring.
"Simon dicet caput," Mrs. Mitchell said. The students -- or most of them, at least -- touched their heads. And on the game went, through "auris," "nasus" and "dentes." 
 A few days later, in Westfield, a group of third graders were singing "10 Little Indians," led by two high school students of Latin. The numbers came out "unus," "duo," "tres."
All across the state -- in grade schools, high schools and colleges -- Latin, for decades the deadest of languages, has come alive. "The real hostility to Latin came from those who were forced to take it because of college language requirements," said Dr. Anna Benjamin of Highland Park, a retired teacher of Latin at Rutgers and the University of Missouri. Once the schools dropped the requirements, she said, high school enrollments in Latin plummeted.
In the view of Dr. Richard LaFleur, who heads the classics department at the University of Georgia, Latin was doomed in the 1970's by out-of-date textbooks and teachers who were not in tune with the new generation.
Today, at schools like Summit, teaching methods and materials are very different from those of earlier times. While declensions and conjugations must eventually be reckoned with, the sixth-grade lesson plan concentrates on reading and speaking the language and on word derivation. "In particular," Mrs. Mitchell said, "the oral component is new."
In the state's private schools, Latin has never ceased being a mainstay of the curriculum. But now it is taking off in the public schools as well.
At West Essex High School, Julia Gascoyne Fedoryk was hired this year to teach five beginning Latin classes; the language has not been offered there for six years. Parents like Janet Levitt, the mother of two teen-agers, urged the Board of Education to reintroduce it. "I didn't study Latin," she said, "but, growing up, I saw that those who did had the edge in the classroom."
Latin I enrollment doubled to 40 students this year at Lakeland Regional High School in Wanaque. At Wayne Valley High School, the Latin enrollment doubled to 20.
When Dennis Doogan, a teacher of Latin at Ridgewood High School, started there in the 1960's, there were nine Latin students in the junior high school and 30 in the high school; today there are more than 600 in the two schools.
And starting last month, 16 students from the suburban Westfield School District and 16 from the urban Plainfield School District, all fifth graders, began taking part in a joint Saturday morning Latin program financed by a grant from the state's Office of Equal Educational Opportunity. The goal is to increase the students' vocabularies and reading skills, said Mark C. Smith, the Westfield School Superintendent, as well as to help them to achieve a "greater understanding and acceptance of the diversity" found in the two school districts.
 
Teachers Hired in Rural Areas
 Holly Cook, who teaches the language at Howell High School in Farmingdale, said, "Even in the rural areas of central Jersey, additional Latin teachers have been hired at places like Lakewood and Wall High Schools."
College officials report a dramatic rise in the study of the classics, including Latin. Five years ago, Rutgers University had three students majoring in the classics; today there are 30. At Montclair State College, undergraduates minoring in classics have risen from 10 to 45, and more than 100 students are studying Latin.
The trend is also reflected in an increase in the number of requests for Latin teachers received by the New Jersey Classical Association placement service.
Dorothy Maxwell, an English teacher with a one-year contract in the Kearny school system, is among those who have spotted the new niche in the market. She has enrolled in intermediate Latin courses at Montclair State College to earn certification to teach Latin. "Teaching jobs are scarce," she said, "but there are more opportunities to be hired to teach Latin than English."
Dr. Benjamin offered this overview of Latin's ups and downs: "Sputnik brought about a renewed interest in subjects like math, physics and Latin, but then in the 1970's when courses had to be relevant to a vocation, interest in foreign language generally dropped and, in turn, Latin waned."
 
Latin Made Livelier
 The recent improvement in Latin's fortunes, Dr. LaFleur said, has come because "the four skills -- listening, speaking, reading and writing -- techniques used in other foreign language instruction, made Latin livelier in the classroom."
It was a report by Dr. LaFleur, published in the Classical Journal in 1981, that some experts say turned the tide for Latin in middle and high school curriculums. The clincher: students who studied Latin scored significantly higher than the national average on the Scholastic Aptitude Test in 1980.
And those results, he said in an interview, were not simply a result of superior students' taking Latin. Students of German, a difficult language that appeals to high achievers, scored markedly lower on the S.A.T. verbal than their counterparts in Latin, he said.
"What Dr. LaFleur documented was a major catalyst in the whole movement that ignited Latin in the state," said Laura Meierhans, the president of the New Jersey Classical Association, who teaches Latin in Westfield. "Recent studies show that if you offer Latin in elementary schools, English improves tremendously. The myth that Latin is only for the best and the brightest students has been erased because new methods of pedagogy have been introduced.
"Students start by reading Latin. They learn how the words are used in the text rather than reciting a declension which is meaningless to them. Grammar is better understood in a paragraph than over some isolated word structure."
 
Taught in Every Grade
 At the Princeton Latin Academy, which opened in 1988, Latin is taught in every grade. Christopher Marchetti, a teacher of Latin, had taught Latin in a private school in Princeton where parents continually pressed him, he said, to teach the subject to youngsters in the lower grades. At the start, 21 students were enrolled in the kindergarten to eighth-grade program; today there are 38.
Francesco Perrulli, the founder of the Princeton Latin Academy, believes that Latin changes a child's passive behavior in a classroom to that of wanting to work to learn. "Parents who were students when the study of Latin was at an ebb have come to realize that the less foreign language is taught, the less people are educated," he said. "Grammar, a participle, a gerund were regarded as irrelevant; children would learn about them by osmosis was the errant thinking. The study of Latin puts order back in our lives. What I really mean is sanity."
Dr. Timothy Renner, professor of classics and the chairman of the department of classics at Montclair State College, said Latin textbooks on a college level had changed. Where a chapter formerly began with an explanation of a grammatical point, followed by 20 sentences of disconnected ideas, the new texts are a medium of communications that deal with Roman daily life.
"Students are reading more," Dr. Renner said, "taking in a sentence as a whole rather than looking for the subject and the verb, like a biological dissection."
At Rutgers, Dr. Alden Smith, the director of the department of classics, credits the enormous interest in the classics in the last five years to the students themselves. He said: "They question: 'What was it like 2,000 years ago? How have people changed?' And the best way is to read about the culture in the Latin literature."
Mr. Doogan said that students were still reading Cicero and Virgil, but that they were relating the literature to what was happening today. "Two thousand years ago, at the time of Catiline's conspiracy when he plotted to overthrow the government, there was high inflation and people were out of jobs," he said. "Cicero railed against him in the Senate, attacking Catiline's character. My students say Cicero's oration against Catiline today would be labeled 'character assassination.' "
As students become proficient in reading the classics in Latin, Ms. Cook said, they are more likely to read the works of the ancients. "The universal themes prevail," she said. "Horace wrote, 'Carpe diem' -- 'Seize the day.' I tell my students who are concerned about S.A.T.'s and college to heed Horace's advice: 'Don't worry about the future. Take the opportunity you have today and make the most of it.' "
 
Spreading the Word About Latin
 Among the most fervent advocates of Latin are the 1,000 members of the St. Gregory Foundation for Latin Liturgy, founded in 1989 by the Rev. Peter Stravinskas, pastor of Holy Trinity Church in Newark.
The foundation's goal is to promote the tradition of the Latin rite in the Roman Catholic Mass. In 1964 Pope Paul VI and the Second Vatican Council gave permission to the clergy to substitute the spoken language for Latin.
Father Stravinskas said that in today's highly mobile society, Latin as a universal language was more important than ever. "I think people are beginning to realize that the liturgy in Latin was thrown out too hastily," he said.
"Americans are not linguists," Father Stravinskas said. "As a people they have a great resistance to learning a foreign language. Gradually, though, they are discovering what they have lost by abnegating the study of Latin: knowledge of the classics and mythology, the logical mental development that Latin brings, concepts of grammar which apply across the board, a good English vocabulary and the ability to spell correctly."
The foundation's goals are reflected in a bumper sticker it sells. The sticker reads: "Amo Missam Latinam."

HEADLINE: Environmental Causes Are Uniting Old Enemies

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
WHILE the Presidential candidates pitted environmental issues against jobs, a coalition of labor, industry and environmental groups maintains that Connecticut can have both.
The coalition advocates spending an estimated $6 billion on advanced sewage treatment plants that could clean up Long Island Sound. Every $1 billion spent on public works projects generates about 57,000 jobs, the group estimates. 
 "It's an opportunity to dismiss the myth that environmental protection equals loss of jobs," said David J. Miller of Greenwich, regional vice president of the Audubon Society.
But it is still a bit bewildering for people to be sitting across the table from those they have been fighting for years.
"Ten years ago I never could have envisioned this kind of cooperation," said John A. Barasso, director of operations at the Connecticut Construction Industries Association, one of the coalition members. He credited the environmental education that has been going on the last decade for bringing the two sides closer.
"Most of us in construction like to fish, like to boat, and we want clean water to drink," Mr. Barasso said. "But we also like to work. And we can do both."
 
A Pfizer Canoe Trip
 Cooperation between industry and environmental groups is becoming increasingly more common in Connecticut. For example, the Connecticut Environmental Roundtable, incorporated this year, has brought industry and environmental groups together to work on a series of projects, the first of which is aimed at making the cleanup of Superfund sites more effective. Also, an advisory panel to the State Department of Environmental Protection has brought both sides together to work on implementing the Federal Clean Air Act in Connecticut.
Last month, executives of Pfizer Corporation in Groton, a major pharmaceutical manufacturer, took a canoe trip on the Connecticut River to announce a $60,000 grant to the Nature Conservancy that will finance research on how to protect the estuary.
Pfizer's plant in Groton is the largest single source of chemicals being released into Connecticut's air and water, according to information filed under the Federal Toxic Release Inventory program, but the company has embarked on a program in which it will spend several million dollars on new programs and equipment to reduce its pollution at the Groton site.
"The manufacturing community, more and more, is on board with the environmental program," said William D. Huhn, senior corporate counsel at Pfizer.
 
'Strike a Balance'
 The executive director of the Nature Conservancy, Leslie N. Corey, in accepting the grant, did not dwell on Pfizer's past, but talked instead about the good that the money would do in understanding how to protect valuable marshland.
Mr. Corey said that while there had been some controversy among environmental groups in other states about whether to accept money from corporations, he thought that it was the only way to help the environment.
"We need to strike a balance between the needs of people and society, and the needs of the environment," Mr. Corey said. "If we are going to preserve nature, we have to find a way for humans to pursue our needs. Population is growing and the pressure is increasing all the time. But it's not too late to take the right steps."
There are natural areas that form a basis for cooperation, according to Richard A. Miller, counsel to the Connecticut Business and Industry Association's Environmental Policies Council.
For instance, Mr. Miller said, many environmentalists agree with industry on the need to streamline Connecticut's environmental permit process. That would allow the understaffed State Department of Environmental Protection to do a rapid review of applications that pose little threat to the environment, and focus more on applications that pose a significant threat.
 
How Laws Get Passed
 The General Assembly is also more likely to pass environmental laws that are recommended by both sides, Mr. Miller said, which means something gets accomplished.
"There needs to be an arm's-length alliance," Mr. Miller said. "But there does need to be an alliance."
Thomas P. McGuigan, director of development for the Nature Conservancy, said his group has long been willing to cooperate with various industries, perhaps because its focus was relatively narrow -- land preservation. But recently it has found industry more willing to cooperate with the Conservancy.
"I think there's a genuine interest in environmental issues," Mr. McGuigan said. Industry realizes that a state with clean air, clean water and beautiful land is a nice place to live, the kind of place where they can attract top-caliber employees, he said.
At first glance, it would appear the economy is driving many of the changes. Many of the environmental groups complain of memberships and donations that are declining or, at best, not increasing as they did in the boom years of the 1980's.
But both sides say it would be too simple to attribute it to just the economy.
One of the foremost reasons, most people say, is that 20 years of environmental litigation have not resulted in any significant change.
"A lot of environmental groups are beginning to realize the ineffectiveness of the adversarial relationship," Mr. Huhn of Pfizer said. "So much energy is used up on the process, very little is actually accomplished."
 
Successes Driven by Cooperation
 Karl J. Wagener, executive director of the State Council on Environmental Quality, an advisory group to other state agencies, said another reason was that there have been some notable successes that were driven by cooperation, such as when the Conservation Law Foundation worked with state utilities to develop one of the most progressive conservation programs in the country, which includes such incentives as having the utilities purchasing old, energy-wasteful appliances.
"People are tired of fighting it out in court because after so many years of small victories, what have we really done?" Mr. Wagener posed. "On the other hand, now that there have been a few real successes through collaboration, it's becoming more popular.
"If you work on one side or the other, you hate to punt even the little ones," Mr. Wagener said. "But you can't go all out on every case. You have to decide where you're going to put in the effort."
James W. DeWitt, executive director of the Connecticut Association of Metal Finishers, said that if the compromise was struck early, it would give both sides more leverage with legislators.
His group worked with the Connecticut Public Interest Research Group to develop proposals for small-business loan programs over the last couple of years: one for cleaning up contaminated sites, another to do pollution prevention programs.
"Confrontation and contention are not going to solve our major environmental problems," Mr. DeWitt said. "We have to work now on getting rid of the mistrust, which doesn't allow anything to happen."
 
Corporate Self-Interests
 Michael Stern, staff attorney for the Connecticut Fund for the Environment, said there was an element of corporate self-interest in some of the cooperative efforts. For instance, business worked closely with environmental groups on the provisions of the Clean Air Act because the businesspeople knew that more than three-quarters of Connecticut's air pollution came from cars. Among the recommendations to come out of the talks was an agreement that businesses would encourage employees to car pool or use mass transit, which would have been impossible to wring out of an adversarial relationship, he said.
"If some of the reductions in air pollution don't come from the transportation sector, they know it's going to come out of industry, where it will be hard to squeeze any more cutbacks," Mr. Stern said. "So they're willing to entertain more unorthodox solutions."
All the groups, though, know the future will hold other battles, perhaps in areas not yet known.
"We'll agree where we can, and build on it," said Mr. Miller of the Audubon Society.
"We're not naive, we know we're going to disagree in some areas as time goes by," he said. "But it's a lot more comfortable for everyone, and a lot more gets done, if we sit down and figure out what we can agree on."

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
Hollywood Agents On the Hard Streets

BYLINE: By Anne Thompson; Anne Thompson is a Los Angeles-based writer.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
In the movie "Glengarry Glen Ross," a flashy real-estate executive played by Alec Baldwin storms into a branch office and warns four longtime employees to sell more property than their office colleagues or be fired fast.
That cutthroat, survival-of-the-fittest approach is more than just a screenplay at some of the talent and literary agencies that had long provided an oasis of stability in volatile Hollywood. Especially fat during the 1980's boom, the industry has gone on a crash diet. In the last month alone, five major agencies have consolidated into three, and 50 or so agents and their clients have abruptly found themselves among the homeless. 
 "At an agency you used to have a lifetime job," said Michael Mahern, a screenwriter ("Mobsters") who has not been directly affected by the upheaval. "If you worked your clients right, there was a reluctance to lay off. Now it's a big trauma, and it's happening all at once."
Senior agents with many years at their firms joined junior up-and-comers in being pushed out. When the 97-year-old William Morris Agency purchased 8-year-old Triad, for example, only 50 of Triad's 80 agents were picked up, and 16 of Morris's 130 agents were let go. Furthermore, Triad's and Morris's methods in putting out the Oct. 16 pink slips seem unduly harsh.
To be sure, the companies did provide free job placement services and psychiatric counseling. But at Morris, a 43-year veteran, Lee Salomon, was informed of his new status at his daughter's wedding. Triad fired one 12-year agent who had just had a baby and whose husband was out of a job.
Jeff Witjas, who had worked at Morris for 16 years, was given the bad news just after escorting a client, the singer Tanya Tucker, to the Greek Theater. At the behest of some powerful allies, he was quickly rehired. "I took a weekend vacation," he said wryly.
Mike Simpson, co-head of the Morris film division, defends the company's need to change. "When we don't clean house, we're criticized for letting people who are not front-runners remain at the company," he said. "When we do ratchet up the level of agent, then we're guilty of being hard and calloused. You can't win for losing."
Arnold Rifkin, a former Triad partner who is Morris's new worldwide motion-picture chief, is a street-wise, Armani-clad executive who could easily be played by Alec Baldwin. He has wasted no time in making his presence felt at the staid old agency. He threw Ralph Lauren sheets over the conference room chairs to give it a radical new look, and asked everyone to hold off on vacations until after the new year. He flooded the market with scripts to alert the industry to Morris's new aggressiveness and stature.
"There were painful parts of this acquisition," Mr. Rifkin acknowledged, "but a lot of people made positive life changes. They were stuck in ruts or facing dormancy."
Mr. Rifkin, said Mr. Simpson, is "inspiring the troops with a new morale in the air."
The inspiration has bitter edges. "To have given years of your life, to make a contribution and be part of something and be cut -- that's cold," said Nancy Nigrosh, an agent at the Gersh Agency, a successful boutique agency not directly involved in the shakeout. "There are a lot of homeless agents out there. We took in one agent we had always wanted. But there's no room at the inn."
The taken-in agent was Ken Neisser, until recently head of Triad's television-literary department, who learned by not having been invited to a department meeting that he wouldn't be going over to Morris.
"Morris didn't need any TV agents," Mr. Neisser said. "I made huge money for Triad. They told me I had a big future with the company, that I was one of the people they were looking to turn the company over to. They made their money. What about the people who gave their all and got left behind?"
Ron Bernstein, another Gersh agent, said that overall, his industry "isn't in dire straits. It's contracting, but not like some other businesses." As he sees it, "We've been spoiled rotten." But, he added somewhat ominously, "the real bloodletting is still to come."
The seismic agency shifts came about because International Creative Management and William Morris, eager to catch up with the mighty Creative Artists Agency, siphoned key agents and talent from Intertalent and Triad, two mid-size agencies struggling with high overheads. Bill Block, who left I.C.M. to found Intertalent four years ago, returned to I.C.M. on Oct. 23 as chief of its motion-picture division, towing 12 of his agents with him. A second Intertalent group split off and joined mid-sized United Talent. Intertalent, like Triad, is no more.
"The weak won't make it," said Jack Brodsky, a veteran producer ("King Ralph"), "People you thought were good are not making the cut because they can't be afforded anymore."
I.C.M., true to its reputation for fostering a fiercely competitive environment, has cut 7 agents and is expected to lay off more. Joanne Roberts had earned her agent stripes only one month before I.C.M. let her go. Industry insiders are most horrified, however, by the firing of a 22-year employee who has been fighting cancer, now in remission.
Jim Wiatt, president of I.C.M. said: "We have a deal to pay her salary and all her benefits until such time as somebody else takes them on. This company has never abandoned anybody."
But the criticism persists. "What's going on is brutal business," said one prominent agent. "The agencies are cutting everywhere they can cut, so they can take the writedown all at once. They don't care how much they hurt people."

LENGTH: 609 words

HEADLINE: A Landmark For Families

BYLINE: By Daniel Patrick Moynihan; Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, is a member of the Senate Finance Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Revenue Act of 1992, which President Bush vetoed the day after the election, included a provision to begin the measurement and possibly the end of welfare dependency. This act marked the first occasion ever that Congress declared a national policy regarding children and families.
The act said, "It is the policy of the United States to strengthen families." It provided for an annual report on welfare dependency and for annual numerical goals for recipients and outlays. It established an interim goal of reducing dependency to 10 percent of families with children. (Last year's level was 13.5 percent.) 
 Over time, upward of one-third of all American children will be on welfare. In New York City, about half. Welfare dependency is the key measure of family stability. The problem of our age. Carl Zinsmeister of the American Enterprise Institute wrote: "There is a mountain of scientific evidence showing that when families disintegrate children often end up with intellectual, physical and emotional scars that persist for life . . . We talk about the drug crisis, the education crisis, and the problems of teen pregnancy and juvenile crime. But all these ills trace back predominantly to one source: broken families."
Since broken families tend to become welfare families, welfare dependency is our best indicator of our worst problem. This has been clear for a generation, but only just now have we summoned the will to face it.
In the 1930's, a quarter of the work force was unemployed. Or probably was unemployed. No one knew; we had no national statistics. In passing the Employment Act of 1946, Congress provided that we start measuring unemployment while declaring it to be "the continuing policy and responsibility of the Federal Government . . . to promote maximum employment, production and purchasing power."
This marked the acceptance of a previously disputed social responsibility. Congress also set up a Council of Economic Advisers and provided for an annual economic report.
Although there was as yet no official unemployment rate, the debate began to change. The data steadily improved and, after a point, the central dilemma and mystery of industrialization began to seem manageable.
Unemployment has hardly disappeared but neither is it ignored, much less denied. The act just vetoed made a direct comparison, asserting: "In 1990 there were on average almost twice as many households receiving Aid to Families with Dependent Children payments as the number of households and individuals receiving unemployment compensation benefits."
I will introduce the bill on the first day of the new Congress. For this is likely to be the most important moment in social welfare policy since Aid for Families with Dependent Children was enacted as part of the Social Security Act of 1935.
The Family Support Act of 1988 declared that welfare dependency must not be permanent. There was to be a reciprocal responsibility to be helped off the rolls and to get off the rolls. The measure could not have passed without Bill Clinton, then chairman of the Governors Association. In his campaign, he took the next step, as did the Democratic Party. Two years and off to work. He described it in detail in his book "Putting People First," and repeatedly returned to the subject in his speeches. Now we must deliver. Put me down as anxious but willing. By 1996, we will have to create 1.5 million jobs for former recipients -- half the size of the current Federal civilian workforce.
This could be the most important domestic initiative of the Clinton Administration. Having made this promise, we had better keep it.

HEADLINE: BRITON DENIES ROLE IN SALES TO IRAQ

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Faced with growing questions about his role in Britain's apparent violation of its own ban on military exports to Iraq, Prime Minister John Major denied over the weekend that he had taken part in any cover-up of the decision to sell sensitive machinery and technology to Baghdad in the late 1980's.
Mr. Major's statement was issued late Saturday in response to criticism from the political opposition based on evidence that the Government of former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher had knowingly helped to arm Iraq during its war with Iran and in the period leading up to the Persian Gulf war. 
 Mr. Major served in a number of posts in Mrs. Thatcher's Cabinet, including a three-month stint as Foreign Secretary in 1989.
The furor centers on the collapse of a criminal case here last week against Matrix Churchill, an Iraqi-controlled company in Britain whose top executives had been charged with violating the export ban by selling sophisticated machines tools to Baghdad. The charges were dropped after a former Government minister changed his testimony and admitted having helped ease the way for the sales.
 
Reasons for the Sale
 Government documents assembled by defense lawyers showed that officials were aware of the military applications of the items but approved their export nonetheless, as a means of helping Britain's ailing machine-tools industry and gathering intelligence on Iraq's weapons program. A top executive of Matrix Churchill, Paul Henderson, gave British intelligence officials information about Iraq's plans.
In his statement, Mr. Major said that when he was Foreign Secretary in 1989, he had not been informed by subordinates of a feud among lower-ranking officials over whether to allow exports of products with military uses to Iraq.
"I hope that even you will admit that I could not be expected to divine that which was not drawn to my attention," Mr. Major said in a letter addressed to Robin Cook, a member of Parliament who is the opposition Labor Party's spokesman on trade issues.
 
What He Knew, and When
 Since details of the Matrix Churchill case became public, the Government and Mr. Major in particular have been asked repeatedly about when they learned of the shipments and whether they had misled Parliament and the public about the Government's policy. Until recently, the Government's response was that the export ban had not been violated.
On Tuesday Mr. Major ordered an independent judicial inquiry into the sales and pledged that the Government would cooperate fully.
Today leaders of the Labor Party, citing unconfirmed information reportedly provided by a former Israeli military agent, also called on judicial investigators to determine whether a Texas-based company owned by Mark Thatcher, son of the former Prime Minister, had helped ship equipment from Britain to Iraq. Neither Mrs. Thatcher nor her son has commented on the matter.
The leader of the opposition Liberal Democratic Party, Paddy Ashdown, called for a full debate in Parliament on sales of British technology to Iraq. "At some stage, given the fact that the whole of the present Government at senior level seems to be involved in this, we cannot afford to wait longer for the answers to our questions," Mr. Ashdown said.
Mr. Cook, the Labor spokesman, said on Saturday that Mr. Major must have been fully informed of dealings with Iraq when he was Foreign Secretary and therefore must have been aware of the British shipments.
"It is just no longer possible to believe that John Major was not told that his own ministers were worried about the way Britain was arming Saddam Hussein," Mr. Cook said.
Mr. Major has not directly addressed the question of when he learned of the exports. The Sunday Times of London reported today that British intelligence officials had informed the Government as early as 1987 that Iraq was purchasing components and technology from Britain that it needed to upgrade its nuclear arms program, its Scud missile system and a planned "supergun" capable of hurling artillery shells long distances.
The dispute comes when Mr. Major is facing economic problems at home and objections to his policy of closer ties to the rest of Europe.

HEADLINE: Gambling Stirs Rhode Island Debate

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

 BODY:
Gambling ventures like video poker, off-track betting and scratch-off card games are increasingly being introduced in Rhode Island as a way to supplement declining government revenues. Now officials are considering proposals to establish casino gambling in downtown Providence, angering residents and gambling opponents.
The state introduced video poker this fall in two cities, despite residents' protests and a lawsuit seeking to block it. The state lottery commission recently added several new games, and off-track betting on horse races began a year ago. 
 The idea of a casino in the capital -- alongside state government buildings, a new convention center and Brown University -- has infuriated gambling opponents already irritated by what they say was the State Legislature's failure to hold a referendum, required under state law, before allowing video poker and off-track betting.
 
Voters Have Their Say
 Voters registered their dissatisfaction on Election Day, when they elected 51 new members to the 150-seat Legislature, replacing several gambling supporters with opponents.
And a recent poll by the Public Opinion Laboratory at Brown found that 61 percent of Rhode Island voters oppose casino gambling in Providence, while 31 percent favor it and 8 percent were undecided. The telephone survey involved 516 likely voters from across the state and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
"Rhode Island already has a very serious image problem," said Darrell M. West, director of polling organization. . "It's a state that has a history of organized crime. The fear is by expanding gambling, it turns the state over to mobsters."
Howard Kay, a former City Councilman in Newport and president of Citizens Concerned About Gambling, said the state's reputation as a haven for organized crime and political corruption was a primary reason for his group's opposition.
"When you introduce organized gambling to a state which already has ethical problems, you're throwing gasoline on fire," he said. "If you introduce casino gambling, which means lots of money, it's going to have an impact on the way the state is run, managed and perceived."
But Diane Hurley, general manager of Newport Jai Alai, objected to suggestions that organized crime would infiltrate legal gambling operations.
Pointing to a row of new video poker machines in her fronton, she said, "Every dollar is accounted for," with each game monitored by a central computer. "That's not the kind of environment organized crime likes to exist in," she said.
And state Representative Paul Santilli, a Democrat from Johnston, has argued that Rhode Island was merely one of many states seeking revenue from gambling. Limiting gambling would be foolish, given potential earnings for the state, he said in arguing in favor of the video poker bill. "Let's not be the last state to jump on a good idea," he said.
 
Slow Economy
 Like much of the rest of country, Rhode Island has struggled with a slow economy, which in its case has been aggravated by a banking crisis that froze the accounts of one-third of the state's 1 million residents. The video poker bill was part of a last-minute agreement intended to close a $17 million gap in the state's $1.5 billion budget.
Members of the Providence City Council also point to revenue potential in discussing the possibility of a Los Vegas-style casino here.
James Petrosinelli, the Council's president, contends that a casino would bring jobs and income to the city without raising taxes.
"The people who are out of work are all for it," he said. "I just want to see how many jobs it would bring. Then the voters can decide whether they want it."
Mr. Petrosinelli said the Council would decide next month whether to put the question on a ballot, but he conceded that voters were unlikely to approve the proposal.
Still, he said, "We're not going to jam it down their throats like the state did with video gambling." Indeed, part of the disagreement over gambling has stemmed from a dispute over whether the State Legislature overstepped its bounds in approving video poker and off-track betting.
State law requires a referendum be held before any expansion of gambling. Those who pushed the legislation that legalized video gambling in June, argued that it was not an expansion because the games were placed in existing gambling centers, a dog-racing track in Lincoln and Ms. Hurley's fronton in Newport.
Even if the Providence proposal fails, the state could still eventually have casino gambling. The Narragansett Indians plan a casino on land in Charlestown, near the Connecticut border.
They argue that they have sovereignty over their land and are not required to submit to a state or local referendum to build a casino. But construction has been blocked while the tribe fights a lawsuit, filed by the state, seeking to make the development subject to a such a referendum. The state would not receive revenue from a casino on tribal land.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: The New Team;
Clinton's Aides Search For Options and Offices

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 15

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton's transition team was in transition this weekend, moving from the Clinton-Gore campaign headquarters in the shell of a dead newspaper to the more modern, but empty, top floors of a half-dead skyscraper.
The White House it's not. While a guard on loan from an Arkansas maximum-security prison showed guests that if he quickly put his hand through the metal detector his metal watch would not set it off, members of Mr. Clinton's transition staff stepped around him toting cardboard boxes stuffed with files. 
 "If you find a computer that works, then just take it," growled Gene Sperling, deputy chief of Mr. Clinton's economic transition team, as he pounded away on a keyboard, oblivious to the fact that he was sitting in an entry hall.
The only transition cluster that already seems to have everything it needs is the foreign policy team, which in the center of its office has a television constantly tuned to CNN. Since CNN seems to be the medium through which President Bush got most of his news during the Persian Gulf war and the coup in the Soviet Union, Clinton foreign policy aides agree they are ready for business on the Cartesian-like principle: "I have CNN, therefore I exist."
 
Warren of Cubbyholes
 Little handwritten pink signs tacked to the walls identify the office spaces of important transition players, who find themselves in that nether world between plusher offices left behind at Harvard, a Washington law firm or corporate America and even more elegant surroundings many of them hope to inherit in the West Wing of the White House.
In the meantime, their fate is to inhabit a warren of cubbyholes and work spaces. The mood, though, is nothing if not upbeat, as the staff members seem to have retained the campaign team's attitude that if you can't take a joke you shouldn't have come.
Actually, the most important transition work is not being done in the skyscraper, but in the study of the Arkansas Governor's Mansion, where President-elect Clinton, Vice President-elect Al Gore, Hillary Clinton and a select few aides have been going over the lists of possible candidates for Cabinet posts. Those who know the names being considered don't speak, and those who speak don't know.
But one thing everyone knows and speaks is this: the best way to insure not getting a job in the Clinton Cabinet is to campaign for it, let alone ask Mr. Clinton himself. Therefore, say aides, there is remarkably little politicking, so far, for top posts.
 
Looking at Options
 The motto of the different transition policy directors, whose responsibilities are divided into subject areas like foreign policy, health and economics, is "options."
"What we're looking at are the foreign policy questions that will face the new Administration," explained Samuel R. Berger, the former Carter Administration State Department official who is heading Mr. Clinton's foreign policy transition team. "Our job is to make sure all the options for different policies are presented to the President-elect when he takes office."
Mr. Clinton has begun receiving regular written intelligence briefings from the Central Intelligence Agency, so he will be up-to-date when he moves in on Jan. 20.
Until then, Mr. Berger said he and his staff would be shuttling between Little Rock and the transition headquarters in Washington.
"We will have small teams of people who will go into the Pentagon, the State Department and National Security Council and try to get the best assessments from the career and political appointees of the status of ongoing negotiations and issues, basically what the world looks like from their perspective," Mr. Berger said.
Over in the economic cluster, Robert B. Reich, the Harvard University public policy expert, could be found on Saturday trying to locate a desk and computer to get on with his task of translating Mr. Clinton's campaign economic proposals into a detailed legislative plan.
Mr. Reich said his mandate was to help Mr. Clinton sort out the choices he would need to make to "have ready on Jan. 20 an economic package, which would be a budget for 1994 -- because that is where he can have an imprint from the beginning -- but also legislation that would begin to implement his programs."
While Mr. Clinton boasted during the Presidential campaign that he had the most detailed economic plan ever put forward by a candidate, it is still a long way from a legislative package, with numbers that add up.
One set of options, Mr. Reich said, concerns whether there should be an economic-stimulus package to jump start the economy, if need be, in January. Or should Mr. Clinton simply come forward with his plans for changing the economy, which call for upgrading manpower skills, training, infrastructure, job creation, technological development, competitiveness and productivity, but are financed from budget cuts and tax increases that would be "pay as you go" and therefore not increase the deficit.
"That depends on what the state of the economy is in January," Mr. Reich said, "but you want to make sure that you at least have the ability, come January, to do what is necessary. Governor Clinton has already said that any stimulus package must be linked to a credible commitment to reduce the deficit by an equal amount once the economy is back on track. Credibility is obviously critical."
But regardless of how the economy is performing in January, Mr. Reich said, Mr. Clinton's proposals for improving the structure of the economy would still have to be ready to go.
"The public has got to understand," Mr. Reich said, "that there are two things going on here simultaneously. One is a recession. If that recession continues in January there may be need for special action in the form of a stimulus.
"But there is a second and separate problem. Even when the American economy gets back on track, even when the recession is over, even as people get jobs, the track that we have been on over the past 15 years is not a very healthy track. It is a track of slow growth. President-elect Clinton made clear that he intends to put in place a long-term growth plan to make sure that our kids have at least as good life, if not a better life, than we do."
In the meantime, though, Mr. Reich said, as he headed off to rustle up that computer, "we still have to work out the details."

HEADLINE: Constitutional Change Losing in Panamanian Vote

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Panamanians who cast ballots today were voting decisively against a package of constitutional changes that included one prohibiting Panama from having an army, partial returns indicated.
Leaders of those opposing the package of 59 amendments said voting trends in the referendum amounted to a blunt rejection of the Government of President Guillermo Endara, which was installed in the midst of the American invasion of 1989. 
 They called on the President to open negotiations with them, including on their demand for a convention to write a new constitution.
Mr. Endara has been widely criticized for indecisiveness and for not doing enough to reduce unemployment.
 
60 Percent Opposed
 Early this evening, with more than half the ballots counted, the vote to defeat the package of amendments was running slightly more than 60 percent. The yes vote was 34 percent, with the remaining ballots void.
There was a high absenteeism among eligible voters -- about 60 percent -- which was attributed to a lack of interest in the detailed amendments.
Visitors to polling places noted a large number of people being turned away for not being properly registered, but political leaders said those numbers were not great enough to explain the turnout.
The voters were asked to cast a single yes or no vote on the entire reform package.
The proposal on the army, had it passed, would have amounted to constitutional recognition of the de facto situation since United States forces invaded on Dec. 20, 1989, and disbanded the Panamanian Defense Force, capturing the military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. General Noriega was taken to Florida for trial on Federal drug-trafficking charges. Panama now has only a police force.
The rest of the amendments, which were drafted in Parliament and supported by Mr. Endara's Government, included measures to raise minimum educational levels, improve social welfare benefits, and reorganize Parliament, the executive branch and the electoral service.
Although most of the proposed changes were viewed as technical, minor or innocuous, a broad array of groups and individuals organized to oppose them.
These included lawyers who thought that the country needed something more than adjustments to a constitution written under military control; those wanting a stronger head of government, and members of the Democratic Revolutionary Party, through which General Noriega and his predecessor, Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, ran Panama.
Although most opponents did not focus on the question of an army, some said that the possibility of organizing one in the future should be ruled out, given that Panama will assume responsibility for defense of the Panama Canal in the year 2000.
There were no immediate accusations of fraud today. Rather, election officials and some politicians suggested that the problems resulted from an effort by the election service to update registrations and eliminate the multiple voting believed to have been common over the quarter-century of military control.
In Chitre, a province capital about 100 miles southwest of Panama City, Delia Castillo Trelles, a human rights observer, said that by late morning about 20 people had been turned away from a voting center with roughly 4,000 registered voters.
She said she had heard of similar situations at other stations in the Chitre area, and Panamanian reporters in the capital also reported that a large number of people were finding no record of their being registered, at least in some neighborhoods.
"I don't know why it's happening," Ms. Castillo said, as she stood in a schoolhouse doorway. "They say they voted here in previous elections and that they haven't moved since then."
Hector H. Gallardo, director of the national-identification-card service in Chitre, said there had been a campaign in the last year to get people to check their registrations and an effort by the election service to eliminate duplication on voter rolls.
"If they're not on the list they can't vote," he said, noting that there was no appeals process.
Those who found today that they could not vote were given a form to fill out to register for the 1994 presidential election.
"Here in Panama there have always been problems with the electoral rolls," said Alberto Cigaruista, vice president of Parliament.
"Part of it is the problem of fraud that we inherited from the era of the military dictatorship," he said. "Then, there is the fact that everything is done manually, which makes both fraud and mistakes easier. And many people just won't go and update or check their registrations."

HEADLINE: Home Is a Bit Less Humble, So Fewer Leave

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Vietnamese officials and foreign diplomats stationed in Hanoi agree that the exodus of illegal emigrants is slowing because of changes in the Vietnamese economy, a growing awareness that there is no opportunity for them to resettle in other countries and the end of financial incentives to leave from the United Nations.
Few here doubt that the Vietnamese who braved the seas in unsafe boats in the mid-1970's were fleeing mostly from a fear of political persecution in a newly reunified nation. 
 But in recent years, Vietnamese officials and diplomats say, the chief motivation was financial -- a long-stagnant economy that left millions unemployed and underfed.
That is changing. Although Vietnam is still controlled by a rigidly authoritarian Government, since 1986 its leaders have championed free-market economic reforms, and the economy is now expanding at an annual rate of about 4 percent. It is expected to boom if the United States lifts its economic embargo.
"For Vietnamese this is incredible growth," said a Vietnamese official. "I do not say our Government is perfect, but our human rights situation is obviously better than in China or Burma. Surely this is the moment that Vietnamese men and women should stay in Vietnam. I think many people realize if they leave now, they will miss the boom."
The Government has tried to discourage illegal emigration by publicizing the squalid conditions that await Vietnamese who travel to Hong Kong and the virtual impossibility that the United States or any other nation will accept them as refugees.
The slowing of the exodus can be credited in part to international efforts to help Vietnamese emigrate legally, especially the program run by the United States.
Although Washington does not have diplomatic relations with Hanoi, State Department employees frequently visit to interview candidates for emigration.
So many Vietnamese enter the program that a chartered United States jumbo jet regularly visits Ho Chi Minh City, the southern capital once known as Saigon, to pick up families heading for the United States.
Last year, the United Nations ended a growing stream of so-called doublebackers, purely economic migrants who had fled Vietnam at least once before. Large numbers traveled to Hong Kong not by risky boat but safely, by bus, through southern China.
 
End of an Incentive
 The doublebackers left Vietnam a second or third time not because they had any hope of being resettled in a third country, but to take advantage of a repatriation package offered by the United Nations to Vietnamese who agreed to return home: about $400 per person, nearly double the annual per-capita income in Vietnam.
In September 1991 the United Nations, seeing the program was being abused, said it would not longer pay the repatriation fee to doublebackers.
"Without that financial incentive, the doublebackers stopped leaving," said a Western diplomat. "Simple as that. The word went out among the general population that the United Nations and the world community couldn't help them anymore. People began to realize that it was probably smarter to stay home."

HEADLINE: New Views on Life Spans Alter Forecasts on Elderly

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
If the Census Bureau is right, the number of people aged 85 or older will grow from 3.3 million today to 18.7 million in 2080. But if a Duke University demographer working with the National Institute on Aging is correct, the number of these oldest old in 2080 could actually be 72 million, a figure nearly four times as great as the Census Bureau's projection.
 This striking disparity involves a fundamental disagreement about the nature of aging. 
 If one assumes that little or no progress can be made in reducing the death rates of the oldest, their numbers will still grow a lot, said Dr. James Vaupel, the Duke demographer who directed research groups for the Institute on Aging. "But if you assume the death rates among the oldest old will come down, the numbers will explode."
 
Questioning Natural Limit
 The more conventional view, held by the Census Bureau, Social Security and some gerontologists, is that there is a natural limit to the human life span -- about 85 years on average -- and that that number is never going to budge very much.
But other researchers believe there is no biological limit to how long people can live. The average life span has been steadily increasing since the 1950's, they note. Because the population is generally healthier, people are entering old age in better shape than they used to, so life spans can be expected to continue to increase into the next century.
A leading advocate of this view, Dr. Vaupel, projects that by 2080 the average life span will be 94 for men and 100 for women.
If these researchers are correct, the trend will have major effects on retirement, Social Security funds and pensions.
"That's why this debate is taking place," said Dr. S. Jay Olshansky, a demographer at the University of Chicago.
 
Four Projects Supported
 The Institute on Aging has supported four research projects looking at subjects from fruit flies to Danish twins to ask which hypothesis of aging is correct. The studies, now reaching completion, are consistently failing to show any evidence for a pre-programmed limit to human life span, said Dr. Vaupel, who directed the research. He added that, in his opinion, a life span of 100 was not out of the question for people, like his 8-year-old daughter, who are alive today.
Not everyone is convinced. Dr. Olshansky, for example, said it was extremely difficult to keep increasing the human life span. Some gains were made in recent years, he said, but it becomes harder and harder to keep up the pace. In fact, he said, even to get to an average life span of 85 from today's average of 77.5, "you would have to reduce death rates by 55 percent at every age."
"That's not easy to achieve," he added.
Dr. James Fries of Stanford University comes to a similar conclusion. "Almost every curve you have -- health or economics -- is a curve of diminishing returns," he said. "It just gets harder and harder" to push out the average age of death.
But, said Dr. Richard Suzman, director of the office of demography at the National Institute on Aging, the institute's four projects argue otherwise.
 
Swedish Records Examined
 The research, which involves scientists from the United States, Sweden, Denmark and Finland, was initiated four years ago. "When we started out," Dr. Vaupel said, "I didn't hold to either hypothesis."
One project asked whether it was true, as some scientists have said, that little progress has been or can be made in reducing the death rates of people over age 85. There is little evidence to confirm or refute that belief because most countries do not publish data on death rates after age 85, Dr. Vaupel said. In the United States, it is particularly difficult to test the hypothesis because birth certificates were not required until 1933, so the oldest people whose age can be substantiated are just 59 years old.
Sweden has much better records with long-term data, going back to 1750, on population sizes and death rates at even the very oldest ages, Dr. Vaupel said. And when he and a colleague, Dr. Hans Lundstrom of Statistics Sweden, the Swedish statistics office, meticulously checked the country's records, combing over data in the archives of the Swedish national statistics office in Stockholm, they came to a surprising conclusion. The mortality rate among those over age 85 remained steady until about 1950 but has steadily dropped since then at a rate of about 2 percent a year.
The Swedish figures were "a gold-standard data set," Dr. Vaupel said. Now, Dr. Vaino Kannisto, a Finnish demographer, has gathered mortality data for the oldest old from 27 countries and finds that, like the elderly in Sweden, the oldest old elsewhere have had a steady, sustained increase in their life spans since 1950.
 
Looking at Genetics
 Another project asked whether there was a genetically preordained time of death. Or, in other words, is the old nostrum correct that the way to live to a ripe old age is to pick long-lived ancestors?
To test this hypothesis, Dr. Niels Holm, of the Odense Medical School in Denmark and director of the Danish Twin Registry, and Dr. Vaupel examined the registry, with data on 55,000 twins, identical and fraternal, born since 1870. "We could test the conjecture that identical twins will die at about the same time," Dr. Vaupel said. "It's just not true."
Dr. Vaupel added that genes do matter. Some people are genetically frail and others are genetically robust. And there is a genetic predisposition to certain causes of death. But, he said, "there is no evidence that genes dictate a maximum life span." Only 2 percent to 3 percent of the variance in ages of death in the population is explained by genetics, he said.
The remaining two projects involved insect demography. One project, by Dr. James Curtsinger of the University of Minnesota and his colleagues, used Drosophila fruit flies. The investigators looked at 10 groups of inbred flies, each group including thousands of genetically identical insects. If there was a predetermined time of death, the flies in each group should all die at about the same time. But they did not, the researchers found.
The other insect study, by Dr. James R. Carey of the University of California at Davis and his colleagues, followed more than a million Mediterranean fruit flies.
Conventional theory predicts that the older an organism gets, the more likely it is to die. If the maximum human life span were 120, for example, a person who lives to 110 might have a 95 percent chance of dying before reaching 111. If he lived to 111, he might have a 95.5 percent chance of dying before 112, and so on, until, at last if he reached 120, he will have a 100 percent chance of dying before reaching 121.
But the flies did not die according to this pattern. Instead, Dr. Carey found, the longer they lived, the greater their life expectancy. "If the same pattern held for humans, a 60-year-old, on average, would live 10 more years, but an 80-year-old on average would live 20 more years," Dr. Carey said. "As you get older, the number of years remaining to you would increase." Eventually all the flies died, but a few lived to an age equivalent to a person dying at the age of 500.
Although Dr. Suzman and others found the Mediterranean fruit fly data provocative and plausible, others were incredulous. Dr. Fries remarked, "From the scientific side, people recoil in horror," from the fruit fly data. He added that he thought there was "probably an artifact in the experiments," referring to a design error or overlooked factors.
And Dr. Olshansky said there was a difference between a genetically determined time to die and a genetic program that does not induce survival. 'It's not that we're going to die," he said. "It's that we're not going to survive. We are not programmed to survive very long past the end of our reproductive period. Our maintenance and repair programs decay fairly rapidly after age 65. Things start falling apart."
So far, said Dr. Gregory Spencer, the chief of the population project branch at the Census Bureau, the new research is not leading the agency to change the way it projects life expectancy. Both the Census Bureau and the Social Security agency assume that the future will be like the recent past and that the rather breathtaking increases in life spans that occurred in the past century will start to slow.
"We essentially project current trends to continue," Dr. Spencer said. "I don't project breakthroughs or magic bullets, all of which are possible. Although I freely admit all sorts of possible scenarios, it's hard for us to predict things that haven't shown up yet."
In making predictions, Dr. Spencer said, he calls on medical experts to help predict changes that might substantially alter life expectancies. "Interestingly enough, most people predicted the future will be like the past," he said. "It's hard to predict dramatic breakthroughs."
 
'A New Paradigm of Aging'
 Dr. Vaupel said he was confident that the findings from the four research projects supported by the National Institute on Aging had swung the balance toward the view that there is no end in sight to the ever-increasing human life span. "I think the debate is over," he said. "What's now emerging is a new paradigm of aging."
Dr. Samuel Preston, a demographer at the University of Pennsylvania, agreed. He said his own research showed one reason to expect a continued increase in life spans. He has found that improved childhood health makes differences in life spans. The healthier and better nourished children are, the longer they end up living when they grow old, he has found. Children who are alive today will enter old age much fitter than those born 80 years ago.
Dr. Kenneth Manton, another Duke demographer, said that if people continued to adopt healthy habits there would be enormous increases in the numbers of very old in the next century. Without postulating any breakthroughs or cures of dread diseases, Dr. Manton said, there will be 43 million people over age 85 in 2040.
Dr. Preston, who headed a committee convened last spring by the National Academy of Sciences to examine the widely disparate projections of the numbers of old people expected in the next century, said the group generally agreed that the Federal government's projections were too conservative.
Those who say there is no obvious cap to human life spans postulate that eventually, maybe centuries from now, people could live to be older than Methuselah. "There is not even theoretical evidence that there is a line there and we couldn't make it to 300 or 400 years old," Dr. Carey said. "There is no fixed limit to the human life span. It could be anything."
