HEADLINE: A Vietnamese-American Becomes a Political First

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WESTMINSTER, Calif., Nov. 14

 BODY:
His motto was "Tax Fighter, Crime Fighter," he had the endorsements of the police, the Mayor and local mobile-home owners, and his campaign posters were a bold red, white and blue.
It would be hard to be more all-American than Tony Lam, described by national officials as the first Vietnamese refugee to win elective office in the United States. 
 A restaurant owner and community leader in the Vietnamese enclave here known as Little Saigon, Mr. Lam, a short, energetic man of 56 years, topped a field of six this month to win a seat on the Westminster City Council.
"I feel I am opening up the door to my children, paving the way," Mr. Lam said in an interview in his campaign office above a bustling, modern Vietnamese supermarket. "I will always be grateful. I consider this country has been our sheltering tree, and we have to pay back what has been given to us."
But Mr. Lam, who has been in this country for 17 years and is now an American citizen as well as a member of the Republican Party, insists on describing himself as "just like any other normal candidate."
As with Asian-American politicians in most places, demographics gave him little choice. Few communities in the United States include Asian constituencies large enough to support candidacies in the way that Hispanic or black communities often do.
Even here in Westminster, 30 miles south of Los Angeles, with one of the nation's largest concentrations of Vietnamese immigrants, Mr. Lam was elected primarily by non-Vietnamese voters. His winning total was about 6,500 votes in a city where only 2,000 Vietnamese-Americans are registered to vote. About one-fifth of the 80,000 residents of Westminster are Vietnamese.
Mr. Lam said he looked forward to building bridges between his Vietnamese constituents and the community at large, to seeking more bilingual police officers and more business for the impressive Vietnamese shopping malls here.
But, he says, he knows that his success on the City Council will depend on his ability to serve the needs of his main electoral constituency: non-Vietnamese voters.
Since the fall of Saigon in April 1975, the Vietnamese population of the United States has grown to about 700,000, nearly half of whom live in California.
The number of these who are American citizens and the number who are registered to vote has been growing, and this year Mr. Lam was one of the first three local Vietnamese refugees to run for political office.
One of these, Jimmy Tong Nguyen, was among Mr. Lam's opponents for the Westminster City Council seat. The other, Henry Le, was defeated in a race for a City Council seat in neighboring Santa Ana, where the population is 60 percent Hispanic.
Randy Arndt, an official at the National League of Cities in Washington, said Mr. Lam was the first Vietnamese refugee to win elective office in the United States, according to information from Asian-American groups.
Yen Do, editor of Nguoi Viet Daily News, the nation's largest Vietnamese-language newspaper, also said Mr. Lam was the first Vietnamese-American officeholder. He said a half dozen local Vietnamese were already looking ahead to running for office in 1994.
 
'A Turning Point'
 While most Vietnamese immigrants have become Republicans, Mr. Yen said this year's elections signaled the emergence of a strong Democratic wing, known as Viet Democrats. He said a considerable portion of this more liberal vote came from a growing class of educated, professional young Vietnamese-Americans.
Since the Vietnamese arrived here as refugees from a repressive Communist Government, they here have been natural constituents for the Republican Party, Mr. Yen said. But grass-roots organizing by the Democrats has made inroads, employing the message of change and economic improvement made by Bill Clinton in this year's Presidential election.
"Paralysis of Republicans in the mainstream led to paralysis among ethnic Republicans," Mr. Yen said.
As an active, can-do, American-style pragmatist, Mr. Lam is not cut from the traditional cloth of intellectual Vietnamese politicians, Mr. Yen said.
Indeed, Mr. Lam was reared in northern Vietnam with what he described as American values, fending for himself from an early age as a cowherd and singer and heeding his father's advice to work hard and not be selfish.
Fleeing south when Vietnam was partitioned in 1954, Mr. Lam said he worked his way up in business, forming construction and food-processing concerns and becoming a multimillionaire by Vietnamese standards.
 
Quickly Climbing Ladder
 Using his connections, he was able to take his wife and six children from South Vietnam on the eve of the fall of Saigon, but he lost virtually all his assets in the Communist takeover.
But Mr. Lam began building a new life from the day of his flight. He spent his first three months in Guam, helping to run a camp for his fellow refugees and, among other things, teaching youngsters to play baseball.
After reaching the United States, he said he worked for just 10 days as a service station attendant and then began another climb up the economic ladder, as a supervisor for a shipping company, insurance salesman, immigration consultant and advertising executive.
Today he owns three popular Vietnamese restaurants, where he is known for serving his customers personally.
Among the many refugee stories in America, Mr. Lam stands out as a man who has adapted and thrived. But like his fellow refugees, he is nevertheless a victim of history, and he carries a spark of anger with him over the United States' failure to fight on in Vietnam.
"I feel that we were led down the primrose path 17 years ago," he said as he sat in his office, surrounded by American flags. "I lost my assets and everything.
"But I never feel bitter. I learned to have a thick skin. And now I've got to have the courage to stand up like a man again. We've been beaten down so many times."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I consider this country has been our sheltering tree, and we have to pay back what has been given to us," said Tony Lam, who is described as the first Vietnamese refugee to win elective office in the United States. He was recently elected to the Westminster, Calif., City Council. (Gary Moss for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Effort Renewed in Trenton To Allow Sports Betting

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Three New Jersey lawmakers revived the battle over casino betting on sporting events with the announcement this week that they would try to put a pro-betting constitutional amendment on the ballot.
An attempt to push such an amendment died earlier this year amid strong opposition from both sports officials and political figures like United States Senator Bill Bradley, a former National Basketball Association star for the New York Knicks. 
 On Oct. 29 President Bush signed a bill banning sports wagering in most states. But the legislation gave New Jersey voters until Jan. 1, 1994, to decide whether to permit sports betting in Atlantic City casinos.
The bill also exempted Nevada, Delaware and Oregon from the ban because they already allow legal betting on sporting events.
 
Illegal Betting Cited
 Senator Bradley has argued that sports gambling would open the door to efforts by organized crime figures and others to bribe players, referees and trainers.
The sponsors of the new amendment effort say that such unsavory influences are already a threat because of widespread illegal betting on sporting events.
"We have heard estimates that between $1 billion and $2 billion goes to the criminal element because of illegal betting," said Assemblyman Robert W. Singer, the Republican majority whip, who represents a district in Burlington, Monmouth and Ocean Counties just north of Atlantic City.
"We want to put the benefits in the public coffers," he said.
 
Job Growth Promised
 Legal experts say the issue requires a constitutional amendment. Although the 1976 amendment allowing casino gambling in Atlantic city did not specifically prohibit sports betting, proponents at the time said sports betting would not be allowed.
Before an amendment is placed on the ballot, it needs approval by three-fifths of each house of the Legislature in one calendar year, or a majority in two calendar years. The governor's signature is not needed before the amendment goes to the voters.
The sponsors of the amendment along with Mr. Singer are Assemblyman Melvin Cottrell, who represents the same legislative district, and Assemblyman Joseph J. Roberts Jr., Democrat of Bellmawr, whose South Jersey district could benefit from growth at Atlantic City.
Backers of sports betting say it would add 1,000 jobs in the Atlantic City casinos and would be worth $125 million to the New Jersey economy.
But opponents say sports gambling would offer a new temptation to compulsive gamblers and threaten the integrity of both professional and college athletics.
While the precise wording of an amendment has not been worked out, supporters said it would include two specific limitations on sports betting.
Bets could not be placed by telephone; rather, anyone wishing to wager on a sports event would have to go to an Atlantic City casino. And no gambling would be allowed on college teams in New Jersey.
But betting would be permitted on professional teams like the New Jersey Nets and on any game involving a college team outside the state, including playoffs of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.
Some legislators said they opposed the ballot proposal because of that provision.
Assistant Senate Minority Leader Richard J. Codey, Democrat of West Orange, said, "I still believe it would be a serious mistake to expose college kids to the lures of shaving points even before some of them even shave their beards."
Merely eliminating New Jersey college teams from the pool, he said, was nothing more than "a cosmetic attempt to use geography as a cleansing agent."
 
N. B. A. Opposition
 "The lure of payoffs," Senator Codey said, "will be greatest for those many athletes of modest means who know they will never turn pro and may succumb to cashing in while they can."
The National Basketball Association, which strongly opposes sports betting, argues that the mere specter of criminal influence is sufficient reason to ban wagering on games.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Costs are overwhelming early-retirement programs by states that sought to relieve payroll pressure by letting public employees step down early. Rather than produce savings, the programs threaten to run up hundreds of millions of dollars in unexpected expenses. [Page A1.]
Gov. Clinton's investment-tax-credit plan is a powerful tool for giving the economy a jolt forward without dangerously expanding the budget deficit, say economists, who predict that the measure will create up to 500,000 jobs by the end of 1993. [D1.] 
 Can city employees be more productive than contractors? New York City's parks department has begun an experiment in hopes of disproving the popular theory that cities save money when they contract out municipal services. [A1.]
 
International
 Europe's rush to a unified market has led to bureaucratic rules that strike many Europeans as invasive, arbitrary or just plain silly. Take cucumbers, for example, which can be sold only if they meet certain standards for length and curvature. [D1.]
Canada will begin debating repeal of its low-cost drug policy, as Parliament takes up a little-noticed provision of the North American Free-Trade Agreement. By giving pharmaceutical companies longer patent protection, Canada would end a system that has helped keep drug prices 32 percent lower than in the U.S. [D1.]
Argentina's economic adjustment plan has hit its worst crisis since it was put into place 19 months ago and brought remarkable stability to a country famous for hyperinflation. Speculation that the country might have to devalue its currency has produced a flight from the peso and a run on the dollar. [D3.]
Baxter International is to make surgical supplies in Moscow at a plant that once produced missile components. [D8.]
The Media Business
The faithful older audience is edging out youth at ABC and NBC, which began their seasons courting young consumers but are now retreating to the Nielsen-rating dependability of Ben Matlock and Perry Mason. Bill Carter: Television. [D1.]
Newsweek will be published quarterly on compact disk, the first general-interest magazine to employ a computer technology that has been hampered by hardware that is sold in roughly a dozen incompatible formats. [D6.]
A new magazine will cover industry's environmental problems from a business perspective, as a group of executives and environmentalists tries to create a publication that falls between advocacy books and trade journals. [D6.]
Donna Tartt's first novel was a cause celebre long before it was a best seller. Her agent is Amanda Urban of International Creative Management, one of the most powerful literary representatives, and her publisher is Sonny Mehta, head of Alfred A. Knopf. [D6.]
Products can be marketed like political candidates, according to an ad-agency white paper, which reverses the common wisdom that modern politicians have been packaged and sold like popular consumer brands. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]
 
Today's Columns
Fantasyland has crashed into Reality World for Euro Disney. The European company's shares have lost more than half their value since March, and now face an unusually strong sell report from an influential French investment house. Kurt Eichenwald:
Market Place. [D1.]
A new technique can produce three-dimensional images that the inventor says actually occupy space and can be viewed from any side. Edmund L. Andrews: Patents. [D2.]
Inflation is at its lowest sustained level since the early 70's, a record that should be good news for consumers and the bond market. But some investors seem convinced that a rebound in inflation is due. Jonathan Fuerbringer: Credit Markets. [D5.]

HEADLINE: AQUEBOGUE JOURNAL;
Breeding a Leaner Duck To Survive in Lean Times

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON

DATELINE: AQUEBOGUE, L.I.,

 BODY:
THE newly hatched ducklings at Douglas Corwin's farm on Long Island could well grow up to become a gourmet meal for a sheik in Saudi Arabia or a Japanese tourist in Hawaii.
Mr. Corwin, whose grandfather started the family duck business at the turn of the century, hopes that his worldwide marketing strategies will enable him to continue to breed and hatch one of Long Island's most singular products well into the next century. He is one of the few survivors in an industry that has declined precipitously on the island over the last 30 years from 70 duck farms to a precious nine. 
 And if a 336-unit condominium is built on four of those remaining farms overlooking the Terrell River in East Moriches, people will soon be replacing some 60,000 ducks, and shrinking the number of working farms to five. Plans for the condominium were recently approved by the Suffolk County Planning Commission.
Mr. Corwin's Crescent Duck Farm on Meetinghouse Creek off Flanders Bay is the largest farm left on the Island. He expects to produce almost one million ducks this year, up from 850,000 last year, and about half of all the commercial ducks raised on Long Island.
"We produce the world's finest gourmet fowl and sell it to the finest restaurants around the world," said Mr. Corwin, 34 years old and, like his father, Lloyd, 59, a graduate of Cornell University's School of Agriculture. Most of the farm's ducks are sold to restaurants.
"While our biggest market continues to be the United States, principally New England and New York, we regularly fill orders for restaurants as far away as Hawaii and Guam," he said.
And since duck is a gourmet treat for many Asians, he said, "we sell many to the Chinese community in New York City."
"If you see a duck hanging in a window in Chinatown, it's probably one of ours," he added.
Despite the dwindling number of farms on Long Island, which in the 1950's produced 80 percent of the ducklings consumed in the United States, demand has increased in the last several years, Mr. Corwin said. Long Island currently produces about 10 percent of the national market.
Urban sprawl in the 1980's caused many duck farmers to sell their acerage, farmers and officials say, with their desirable scenic waterfront views, to developers for an average $100,000 an acre. It was also a period when Suffolk County could afford to buy waterfront acreage for parkland, such as the Indian Island County Park just west of Meetinghouse Creek in Riverhead. That was because a slowdown in the economy eased the upward pressure on real-estate prices on the eastern end of Long Island.
"Our main objective was to clean up the shoreline and reduce water pollution," said Arthur Kunz, planning director for Suffolk County.
The odor from the traditional duck farm can be overwhelming to city dwellers who move to Suffolk and settle down near a farm. The picture-book setting gains a new reality when the smells of the barnyard fill the air, Mr. Kunz said.
On the land where ducks have been raised for decades, duck droppings that have accumulated near shoreline pens and in the surrounding waters are a reality. Once covered with fresh earth or sediment, the land cannot be disturbed without opening a Pandora's box of malodorous pollutants.
"Clearing the land is done with great care," Mr. Kunz said, and construction is done without disturbing the earth. Developers, as in the case of the East Moriches condominium project, he said, were barred from building marinas or any structures that would disturb the sediment in adjacent bodies of water.
Commercially raised ducks have not been permitted in rivers and bays since 1968. Under Federal and state regulations, they are restricted to lagoons, separated from main waterways.
New methods of raising ducks, developed with the help of the Cornell University Suffolk County Cooperative Extension Service, have not only helped to make duck farming more acceptable to neighbors, but have also produced a more efficient yearround operation and end products, including feathers for pillows.
"Duck farmers are producing a leaner, meatier, tastier bird," said Nils Berglund, livestock and poultry agent for the cooperative extension.
He described Crescent Farm as a "totally vertically integrated operation, from its own feed mill, to breeding superior stock and hatching, growing and marketing its birds."
While the number of farms has dropped sharply since a peak of around 70, producing six million birds annually in the 1950's, Mr. Berglund believes the remaining Long Island farms should be able to continue to hold onto their current market share of just over two million birds.

HEADLINE: Baxter International Plans A Joint Venture in Moscow

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DEERFIELD, Ill., Nov. 15

 BODY:
In a case of "swords into plowshares," Baxter International Inc. announced plans today to manufacture surgical equipment at a Moscow plant that once made military missile components.
Baxter agreed to make handheld instruments like vascular clamps, scissors and needle holders, said Tony L. White, Baxter's executive vice president for global businesses. 
 "This could be just the beginning of our investment in the Russian economy and people," he said.
The joint venture, called Rosoptimed, is to begin operations in June in a plant that used to make missile guidance systems and components for the Mir space station. Baxter will invest $10 million for a 75 percent stake in the venture; 25 percent will belong to NIIAP, a newly privatized manufacturing company formerly controlled by the Soviet military.
Mr. White said the need for high-quality surgical instruments in Russia was intense, with Russian producers able to supply only 30 percent of the current demand.
 
A Shortage of Expertise
 "We find that they can't produce enough now, and the instruments they do produce don't last as long as ours," he said. "There's no problem with the Russian metals -- we've lined up suppliers there who can meet our specifications -- but there isn't the manufacturing expertise. We're going to be bringing Russian managers and workers over here to train them in our techniques."
Because the Moscow plant was used for high-precision machining and has relatively modern equipment, it can easily be adapted to make surgical equipment, Mr. White said. He said that almost all the 200-person work force would be Russian, as would all the raw materials.
Baxter plans to recruit and train local residents for sales and marketing positions, a rarity for Western companies doing business in Russia.
Mr. White said the operation would be ruble-based, which means any profits could be eroded by inflation.
But that, he said, is a risk Baxter is willing to take, and the company, which had global sales of $8.92 billion in 1991, can afford to wait a long time for its return on the Moscow venture.

HEADLINE: Parks Workers Challenging Stereotype of Public Jobs

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
George Marchese and two co-workers needed less than 90 minutes the other day to cut down and remove a dead silver maple tree in front of Teresa Mele's house in Bensonhurst. Two men would return later to remove the stump and fill the hole with soil. Before this month, as many as seven workers might have done the same job.
While it hardly mattered to Ms. Mele how many people disposed of her 50-foot eyesore, how a tree goes in Brooklyn and elsewhere in the city is vitally important to the Parks and Recreation Department, other city agencies and union workers who lost their jobs after recent cutbacks in the city budget. 
 Mr. Marchese and his crew are part of a two-month test by the department to learn whether employees given new freedoms to set their own working conditions, like planning their own routes and workloads, can improve performance and save the city money.
 
Attack on a Stereotype
 Stretched for resources in recent years, New York and other cities have increasingly used private contractors for jobs traditionally done by public employees. The theory is that private contractors are more efficient, and that cities can save money by cutting less productive or higher-paid workers from the public payroll.
But the Parks Department experiment is a bold attempt to show that the trend is flawed. If the new approach proves more efficient than outside contracting, the department could cut back on contractors and use the money to hire back some laid-off workers. At the same time, it could help break a common stereotype of public workers as lazy and inefficient.
"If we're successful, the Mayor should jump on this," said Betsy Gotbaum, the Parks and Recreation Commissioner, who designed and championed the program. "We're now reshaping how we can deliver services."
Though officials acknowledge that early totals may reflect a "gung-ho start" that workers might not sustain, Ms. Gotbaum said she was "absolutely blown apart" by the results.
Preliminary results show that for the first week, city workers in Queens cut down 51 trees, for which the contractors would have charged $10,688. The city's projected costs were $2,644, a saving of $8,044. In the Bronx, workers removed 37 trees, for a projected saving of $2,578.
City officials say warily that without guarantees that performance will stay high, the program cannot justify rehiring laid-off workers or expanding the approach to other agencies.
"There are benefits, but it's a tricky thing," said Philip R. Michael, the city's budget director. "We have to be very cautious that there is true productivity. Unless there is measurable improvement, it's not worth it."
But if the experiment succeeds, he said, the concept could be "selectively applied" to other city agencies.
The program grew directly out of citywide budget reductions two years ago, which caused most agencies to lay off workers and reduce services. At the Parks and Recreation Department, for example, a $4.8 million budget for 104 climbers and pruners like Mr. Marchese was cut to $640,000, forcing layoffs of 84 people.
 
Tree Averages 7 Years
 Climbers and pruners, who make about $33,000 a year, cut down diseased, dying or dead trees with chain saws and use wood chippers to turn them to mulch. The workers also remove the tree stumps and fill in the holes. The life expectancy for city trees is only seven years, a result of abuse from sources like dogs, car fumes, oil seepage, collisions by vehicles and insufficient drainage.
With 700,000 street trees to care for in the five boroughs, plus two million more in city parks (which are outside the scope of this test), the department faced an overwhelming backlog of work even before the budget cuts. People like Ms. Mele, with trees not in immediate danger of falling, routinely waited three years for service. The cutbacks added at least two more; some stumps have waited almost a decade to be removed.
When the budget for the 1993 fiscal year restored the parks department's allowance for climbers and pruners to $1.8 million, Ms. Gotbaum saw an opportunity to solve several problems at once. First, she persuaded Mr. Michael's office to let her split the money, using half to pay for outside contractors and half for the existing 20 climbers and pruners, plus 22 others who had lost their jobs.
Then, she devised a competition of sorts to measure the performance of the city's workers, with their new responsibilities, against two outside contractors being paid per tree, as they have been since the city began using them in 1988. To determine costs for its workers, the department established a dollar value for all parts of the job, including each worker and piece of equipment.
If the city workers show they can remove more trees, they will not only have saved money and reduced backlogs, but will also have made a case for bringing back more laid-off workers like Mr. Marchese. He and his crew were rehired when the budget was increased.
"We welcome the competition," said George Tangel of the Lewis Tree Service in Holbrook, L.I., one of the city's contractors. "We're professionals at what we do, and I feel we can do the job as fast as anybody. That's how we became low bidders for the job."
The union, meanwhile, is so eager to try to restore jobs that it agreed to waive the time-honored use of larger crews. Frank Edwards, president of the Climbers and Pruners Local 1506, said the city employed 366 people in those jobs a decade ago.
But while he hailed the greater autonomy, he questioned whether some of the smaller crews, in their eagerness to justify more jobs, might sacrifice safety measures to work faster. In more flush economic times, a crew of four or more would take down a tree; later, another crew would remove the stump, and a third would fill the hole with soil.
"When crews were five and six people, it was a lot safer," he said.
Mr. Marchese said that his crew would never jeopardize safety, saying smaller crews were more flexible. If the worker sawing branches grows tired, he can switch jobs with a co-worker feeding fallen branches into the chipper, or with the worker directing traffic out of the way.
 
Special Reason for Effort
 He acknowledged, however, that the chance that more laid-off city workers might be taken back if the program succeeds "is the only reason we're working so hard."
Motivations aside, if the experiment shows that municipal workers with more autonomy can do the job as well or better than contractors, it might shake a common perception that government cannot work as efficiently as private business.
"For almost 50 years out of the depression, the feeling was government could solve everything," said Steven Cohen, a public management expert who teaches at Columbia University. "Then Vietnam began an era of anti-government rhetoric out of Washington which said governments can't solve anything. The truth is in between. It requires a mix of public and private."
Ms. Gotbaum and her colleagues met with climbers and pruners in devising the test.
 
Planning Their Own Jobs
 In a major departure from tradition, workers in four boroughs -- Manhattan is not included in the test -- were allowed to plan their own strategies. In Brooklyn, crews of three take down the tree and remove the debris; the same crew or another later removes the stump and fills the hole. In Queens, crews of four cut down trees and deliver the branches and trunk to Sanitation Department trucks. On Staten Island, crews cut trees down and repeat the route on another day to pick up the debris.
Workers were also allowed to plot the day's schedule, another big change. Often in the past, Mr. Marchese said, crews were forced into a haphazard route because local politicians or friends of a supervisor would get preferential treatment.

HEADLINE: Stresses of Unity -- First of two articles.;
Europe Copes With Details of Unity

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS

 BODY:
For Philips Electronics, a single European market means the Dutch company can ship compact disk players from Belgium to Spain without the need for its trucks to stop at customs. For American Express, the unified market means it can sell financial products like mutual funds throughout Europe for the first time.
But for farmers, it means new rules, including one that allows the sale of cucumbers only if they meet certain standards for length and curvature. And for other individuals, companies and nations, there is fear that old tensions and old nationalism will still, somehow, dampen the single market's positive economic effects. 
 As the European Community rushes to complete the framework for its planned single market by the end of the year, it is creating vast new economic opportunities for its industries and its 360 million citizens. "Lower costs, greater mobility, greater uniformity of standards, greater competitiveness, lower inflation, lower interest rates -- the list goes on," said Huub Elzerman, a spokesman for Philips.
But out of a bureaucracy intended to free the flow of goods, money and people across borders has sprung a bewildering set of new regulations that strike many Europeans as invasive, arbitrary or just plain silly.
Perhaps most important, as it nears the completion of the single market's legal framework before its self-imposed deadline of Dec. 31, the community faces political and economic divisions that could limit the effectiveness of its nascent free-trade zone.
All 12 nations and virtually the entire European business establishment support the single market, and many of the rules governing it have already taken effect. In many ways Europe has achieved the main goal envisioned four decades ago when France and Germany took the first steps toward a common market: creating sufficient economic interdependency that political differences would be blunted and the chances of war greatly reduced.
But the nations have yet to reconcile fully their domestic priorities, and their concerns about cooperation, with the vision of a borderless European economic powerhouse that can hold its own against North America and Asia.
Indeed, even as the single market is supposed to be drawing them closer, European nations at times seem to be moving farther apart. A feud between France and the rest of the community over trade concessions to the United States is only the latest example.
The bitter wrangling within Europe over trade followed a monetary crisis in September. In that instance, the widely divergent policies followed by each nation drastically slowed progress toward a linchpin of the common market -- a single currency -- and may have derailed that prospect entirely. And without a single currency, business executives say, Europe will never be a true single market, because investment decisions and profits will be colored by unpredictable swings in currency values.
Moreover, divisive debates in recent months in France and Britain over the Maastricht treaty on unification, following its rejection by Denmark earlier this year, laid bare the widespread distrust in many nations of the community's bureaucracy in Brussels.
In the view of many Europeans, Brussels, in the name of creating a uniform market, has developed a tendency to meddle where it has no business. Its questioning of mundane issues (Should Britain be allowed a few more weeks of daylight savings time than the Continent?) has raised fears that it will eventually swallow national identities and powers.
That distrust has led to a push for more decision-making power to be left at the national level -- a concept known, in the jargon of the European Community headquarters here, as subsidiarity. And some executives and analysts say that more authority over implementing the single market at the national level increases the likelihood that countries will backtrack on their commitment to free trade or implement single-market legislation in ways that put domestic considerations ahead of the spirit of a unified Europe.
"The business community is concerned about the achievements of the single market being fragmented by new laws at the national level," said Dirk F. Hudig, a lobbyist in Brussels for Imperial Chemical Industries. "Subsidiarity should not become an alibi for new forms of protectionism."
 
 
Most Rules Approved
 Fewer than two dozen of the 276 legal and regulatory directives proposed by Brussels when the single-market program was formally laid out in 1985 remain to be completed by the community's bureaucracy.
This month, the European Commission, the executive branch of the community, is concentrating on broad issues like standardizing drug-approval rules and imposing a uniform value-added tax, as well as on nettlesome details like which of the community's nine languages should be used in trademark-application hearings (Spain and Portugal fear the dominance of English, German and French).
By the end of the year, officials in Brussels said, at least 95 percent of the directives will be in place. They say that level will allow them to declare the single-market framework complete, even if some elements, like communitywide approval of innovative pharmaceutical products, will not be in effect for another year or two.
The 12 member nations, in turn, have translated most of the community directives into national legislation, much of which is already in effect. Officials said they hoped to move quickly to expand the common market to seven other European nations: Austria, Switzerland, Norway, Sweden, Finland, Iceland and Liechtenstein.
 
Wary of Some Steps
 But some European industries, like airlines, are only in the early stages of being opened up to cross-border competition. And commission officials say they have become extremely wary of pushing into new areas -- like breaking up state-sponsored telephone monopolies, weaning industries from government subsidies and pressing nations to do more to open up government procurement to companies from other countries -- for fear of stirring up political opposition.
They said there was also a real chance that the anti-Brussels feeling would embolden some members simply to ignore community directives, especially since the European Court, the ultimate arbiter of disputes, has limited power to enforce its rulings.
"If you take stock legislatively, it's incredible what's been achieved, but we shouldn't kid ourselves that there isn't still a long way to go in implementation and enforcement terms," said Stanley Crossick, who runs the Belmont European Policy Center, a consulting firm in Brussels. "The single-market process has not yet passed beyond the point of no return."
Officials in Brussels said the building of a single market should be seen as a continuing process, not something that will end on Dec. 31. They already point to substantial accomplishments. Goods, money and people can move through Western Europe relatively, though not completely, unhindered. New regulations providing even greater freedom will take effect on Jan. 1.
 
 
Less Paperwork
 Trucks full of merchandise, for example, usually do not have to stop for customs checks at the borders of the nine nations that have agreed to eliminate most border controls on commerce (the exceptions are Britain, Ireland and Denmark).
The amount of paperwork for trade within the community has been greatly reduced. Money can be transferred between countries without restriction, although during the recent currency crisis, Spain, Portugal and Ireland temporarily reimposed some controls.
Cars that meet emissions and other technical requirements in one nation will qualify for registration in other countries. Banks will be able to set up branches in any member nation. Doctors and lawyers are to be licensed under the same regulations, but there are lingering disputes over standards for jobs like that of ski instructor.
Travelers between many countries by road and rail no longer show passports if they are citizens of community nations. Border controls, even in airports, will all but disappear after Jan. 1, except in Britain, Ireland and Denmark, which have demanded the right to continue to scrutinize arriving passengers. Travelers from the United States, once admitted by one community nation, will generally be able to travel to other nations with no more restrictions than European citizens.
For the most part, industry in Europe and from around the world has long since signed on to the single market by reorganizing to take advantage of the new ease in conducting business across borders.
"The sense of the single market is in being, even if not all the rules are in place, much less being enforced," said Keith Richardson, the secretary general of the European Round Table, a group representing 40 of Europe's largest companies. "People have adjusted the way they run their businesses."
Take the American Express Company. The laws and regulations creating a single market for financial services have only been completed by the community in the last few months.
 
 
Consolidating Management
 For years, American Express has been preparing for the changes. Instead of running its business through separate offices in each of the 12 community nations, the company has consolidated its management centers in Germany, France and Britain. Instead of processing transactions in each country, it is consolidating its back-office operations in Brighton, England.
With the end of cross-border restrictions on the sale of financial services, American Express is now able to offer the same services to customers throughout Western Europe. With the removal of capital controls, the company's money management systems have become much simpler, since it need no longer meet Italian laws, for example, that required it to keep certain funds in lira.
"We're thinking and planning and investing for a single market," said Julian P. R. Oliver, a lobbyist for American Express in Brussels.
For the most part, companies from the United States and other non-European nations say they are satisfied that the community is creating a market that is open to the world. But European and non-European companies alike say they see signs that domestic political and economic pressures within the 12 nations could lead to new barriers to open competition.
Germany, for example, recently enacted legislation intended to promote recycling. The new rules will cost many foreign brewers more than it will cost their German rivals. The legislation, which had been supported by German environmentalists, may be well motivated, foreign executives said, but it also seemed to ignore the implications for free trade.
"If that sort of thing happened throughout the market, there's the strong possibility of a fragmentation of the market," said John Russell, the manager of European Community affairs for the American Chamber of Commerce in Brussels.

HEADLINE: For Afro-Amerasians, Tangled Emotions

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
When Luong Hung looks in the mirror, he says, shame ripples through his body. His sad-eyed visage, his tightly curled dark hair, are daily reminders of the relationship between his Vietnamese mother, a waitress in Saigon during the war, and his father, a cargo pilot he knows only as John.
"I feel ashamed that my mother was with a black man, and now I have to carry that," said the slender 26-year-old refugee, his knees almost touching his chest as he perched atop a child-sized plastic chair in his Bronx apartment. "I wish I were a white Amerasian." 
 Luong Hung is an extreme example of the tangled emotions twisting inside these children of the Vietnam War, now young adults in the land of the fathers they will probably never know. Black or white, their lives were forged through discrimination and hardship in Vietnam where they were derided as "the dust of life."
 
Ridiculed and Beaten
 But for those whose fathers were the black foot soldiers, sailors and airmen of that turbulent era, their upbringing in Vietnam's ethnically homogeneous and patrilineal society was doubly hard -- disenfranchised for having no father at home and scorned because that absent father was black. They recall childhoods spent hidden away by fearful parents, ridiculed or shunned by neighbors and beaten by other children.
Many of them live in places like the Bronx -- one of 55 resettlement communities nationwide -- where they receive education, jobs and counseling help as they try to shake loose the memories of years of a hardscrabble existence. For the first time in their lives, many say they feel they have a chance to succeed or fail on their own merits, blending into racially mixed communities.
At the same time, refugee workers who are guiding their transition to American life fear that these young people are still suffering the after-effects of racism they endured in their early lives. Tugged among three worlds, they say, the black or Afro-Amerasians exhibit more anger, anxiety and depression, if not self-hatred, than their white cousins.
Culturally Vietnamese, politically American and physically black, they do not easily fit into any one category.
"We almost saw these kids as tri-racial but in a sense disenfranchised in every domain," said Mark Johnson, a clinical psychologist and the co-author of a study on the mental health of Afro-Amerasians. "It's difficult to find a space or cultural home for these kids."
 
Taunted by Children
 Dat Thach, 21, knows that confusion. The Afro-Amerasian who came to the United States this year said he was always perplexed by the taunts of neighborhood children in Vietnam who told him he should "go to your country" because he was black.
"I didn't know my country," he said.
Some 65,000 Amerasian refugees and their relatives have arrived in the United States since Congress passed the Amerasian Homecoming Act in 1988. The Amerasians themselves accounted for a quarter of the refugee total, with some 4,000 of them being Afro-Amerasian, said Michael Kocher, director of the Amerasian Resettlement Program at InterAction, a Washington-based coalition of resettlement and relief agencies.
Speaking in general terms, Mr. Kocher said the sons of infantrymen who once walked point in the jungle were left behind to bring up the rear of a social order that shunted them to the margins of Vietnamese life.
"It is such a homogenous society, 'ethnically pure,' that it's difficult for anyone with mixed blood," he said. "For whatever cultural reasons, they tended to be even more marginalized."
Lee, a 21-year-old Afro-Amerasian who arrived in the United States two years ago, spoke on the condition that his family's name not be used. He speaks haltingly of his childhood in Saigon, one whose themes resonate in the stories of his fellow refugees.
His mother, who had married a black serviceman, hid Lee and his sister, Linda, in the closet for months after the fall of Saigon. Later, when she sent him to school, he said, he was teased relentlessly and often arrested by the police, who he said tried to coerce confessions from him for crimes he did not commit.
The ultimate indignity came in the fifth grade, when his classmates pounced on him, pummeling him until half his face was swollen. When his mother confronted the school's principal, he told her to stop sending her son to school because he could do nothing to prevent the beatings.
 
Feeling Some Kinship
 Lee and his family came to the United States in 1990, settling into an apartment in the Kingsbridge Heights section of the Bronx. He attends Martin Luther King High School in Manhattan, where he said his black classmates have welcomed him. He said he did not know much about black culture, although he said he intended to read more about it once his command of English improved. Nonetheless, he feels some kinship to his classmates.
"At the beginning I was surprised to see so many people with the same color skin as me," he said. "That makes me feel surprised and comfortable. I belong to this society."
His mother says, perhaps only partly in jest, that he now wants to forget the part of him that is Vietnamese. He listens grim-faced, slumped in a chair.
"Forget," he said, slowly shaking his head. "I don't want to remember."
The relief many feel for no longer being hounded because of their skin color can be supplanted by urgent economic concerns. Several refugee experts said the Afro-Amerasians were often denied access to education because of their color, arriving in this country with only a few years of formal schooling, if any. Now, many worry about catching up, enrolling in high school at an age when other teen-agers have graduated.
Others fret about finding work with little English and few marketable skills at a time when jobs are scarce for many in their neighborhoods.
 
Needing Federal Help
 "When I first got here my face was always angry," said Minh Nguyen, 21, who arrived in the Bronx last year and now is studying English and other subjects at St. Rita's Asian Center. "The language was difficult and this is a big country. I didn't know where to look for work. I don't know what is out there in the future."
There is a sense that time is limited, a sentiment shared by refugee workers who said that because the Amerasians were older, they should be eligible for more assistance from Government social-service programs. They said it was more critical for the Afro-Amerasians, given their frequent lack of education.
While some of the youths have black friends, their tightest bonds often seem to be with other Amerasians. They refer to living life "in the middle," identifying themselves as Amerasian.
Their blackness, the focal point of their abuse in Vietnam, is something that is either played down or avoided here. Mr. Hung said all he knew about black Americans came from a movie about the antebellum South he saw in his youth.
"I heard in Vietnam that black poeple were slaves," he said. "I didn't want to be a slave."
He still may be hostage to his decidedly derogatory view of black Americans, fearfully associating them with crime and homelessness. When asked if his time here has helped persuade him otherwise, he nodded affirmatively.
"Of course it changed," he said. "In the United States there is freedom. I don't have to live in the black community."
Although Mr. Hung said he felt more comfortable in New York, not all of his countrymen have been accepting. "Vietnamese here, especially the higher-educated Vietnamese, do not allow their children to make friends with black Amerasians like me," he said.
Psychologists and others who have looked into the experiences of Amerasian refugees said the lasting effects of the young people's difficult years in their homeland were unclear.
A continuing study that has tracked Amerasian refugees along their journey from Vietnam, through Philippine refugee camps and in the United States, found the Afro-Amerasians to be slightly more anxious and depressed than their white counterparts, but the difference was not statistically significant.
 
View Through Prism
 Dr. Robert McKelvey, the study's co-author and the head of the department of child psychiatry at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, said his impression remains that the Afro-Amerasians were having a harder time in the United States.
In terms of their self-image, Dr. McKelvey found that many of these young people consider themselves more Vietnamese than their appearance would suggest. But American society, whose own issues of color have never been resolved, views them through its own racial prism, said Carolyn Tisdale, the director of refugee resettlement programs for Catholic Charities in Memphis.
"I see them as black," said Ms. Tisdale, who herself is black. "I know that's what everyone else is going to see. Realistically, that is what they are going to have to deal with."
Unfortunately, she said, the Afro-Amerasians she has encountered in her work arrived in this country with negative racial stereotypes about blacks. "You get a lot of self-hatred," she said.
Some groups have tried to help the Afro-Amerasians better understand their black heritage by incorporating lessons or literature about black history into the school curricula. Sister Jean Marshall of St. Rita's Asian Center said her group hoped to enlist the aid of black military veterans and others to serve as mentors, to help bolster their fragile self-confidence.
"Their self-esteem is so low," she said. "Getting them to realize they can make it is very hard."
Ms. Tisdale and several others in refugee work said they thought that not enough black Americans have reached out to the Afro-Amerasian youths. Part of the problem, some said, was that the resettlement agencies themselves had not done a good enough job of reaching out to blacks.
A little more than two years after arriving here, Lee and his sister, Linda, 20, seem to be adjusting well. He is in 10th grade and talks about going to college. Linda unschooled in Vietnam, is enrolled in English as a Second Language classes at St. Rita's. She says she wants to be a model.
Part of the reason for their relatively smooth adjustment lies in the efforts of their mother, who hired a tutor for her children after Lee was beaten in school in Saigon.
Also helpful is the warm embrace of their father's family, which also lives in the Bronx. Their father is remarried and lives in the Virgin Islands, where the children visit him in the summer. Florence Hendricks, their grandmother, smiles broadly when she talks about how her grandchildren call her almost every day and how the family welcomed the children into their fold during a recent reunion.
Mrs. Hendricks recalls with a smile her excitement when she first met her grandchildren, a few days after they arrived in this country. "I wanted to see what they looked like,' she said.
And what did she think when she finally saw them?
"I love them."

HEADLINE: Canadians See Rise in Drug Costs

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Canada's Parliament will open debate this week on the repeal of a law that has kept prices for prescription drugs far lower than prices in the United States. The repeal is required by a little-noticed provision of the North American Free Trade Agreement initialed by the United States, Canada and Mexico last month.
The law currently limits patent protection on drugs to 7 to 10 years, and its repeal would bring Canadian patent protection in line with that of the United States and other industrialized countries, which allow drug companies to produce a drug exclusively for 17 to 20 years. After the patent expires, competitors are able to make and sell generic copies of the drug, and such competition can sharply reduce prices. 
 Canada's success at delivering drugs at costs lower than those in the United States is an important feature of its medical system, which has been a model for many health policy experts seeking to contain soaring costs in the United States. Medical costs are about 28 percent lower per capita in Canada than in the United States, although spending on health care has been rising there, too.
 
Approval Is Expected
 The repeal of the patent law, formally requested by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, is expected to pass the Conservative-dominated Parliament before next year's Canadian election, although Liberal and New Democrat Party opponents hope to attract enough disaffected members of Mr. Mulroney's majority to delay passage until after the election.
The shorter period of patent protection has helped keep prices of drugs 32 percent lower in Canada, on average, than in the United States, the General Accounting Office of Congress found in a recent study for a House Energy and Commerce subcommittee.
Strong opposition to changing the Canadian law is being voiced by advocates for the elderly, labor unions and health ministers of Canada's provinces. "The drug industry is making complete monkeys out of Canadians," said Angus Ricker, a health-care researcher in Ottawa for the opposition New Democrat Party.
In the United States, Canada's health-care system has been heavily criticized by drug companies, insurers and others with a stake in the American medical system.
The American drug makers say the high prices of many new drugs are necessary to finance the often risky investments in innovative drugs that may take a decade, and $200 million each, to develop. The drug makers have also promised to increase their research efforts in Canada once the patent law is changed.
The trade agreement requires Canada and Mexico to follow the United States' lead and allow exclusive marketing rights for drugs for as long as 20 years. The change is expected to cost Canadians about $400 million annually, a 12 percent increase in spending on drugs, pharmaceutical economists on both sides of the border say. The added cost would grow to about $800 million by the late 1990's, these experts say.
Canadian Government officials insist the added cost would be far less. They said their estimates were based on conservative assumptions about when specific drugs would be open to generic competition.
 
Burden for Canadian Health Plan
 Roughly half the cost of medicine used by Canada's 26 million people is paid for by Government health plans administered by the provinces, which provide medicine for the poor and elderly. Private insurance and individuals pay for the other half.
Extending the patent life of drugs is likely to cost consumers immediately and also add to the burden on the Government health plans, which are already under economic pressure.
Compared with hospital and doctors' bills, prescription drugs are a relatively small, though rapidly growing, expense.
But drug costs are a heavy burden for people with limited incomes and for people with chronic illnesses like cancer and AIDS. For most Americans over age 65, prescription drugs are an out-of-pocket expense because Medicare does not pay for prescriptions. President-elect Bill Clinton said during the Presidential campaign that he wanted to place limits on prescription drug prices.
 
Industry Lobbyists Credited
 For at least 10 years, American drug companies have lobbied hard for extending United States rules on patents to the country's trading partners, and they have pushed hard for similar rules in the proposed worldwide trade agreement being negotiated under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
The North American agreement is widely expected to serve as a model for future pacts with Latin America and other regions.
Putting the patent provisions in the North American accord was "a master stroke," said Edgar G. Davis, a former vice president of Eli Lilly & Company, who is now at the Kennedy Center for Business and Government at Harvard University. "It shows what an industry that has its act together can accomplish."
The Bush Administration had made eliminating the Canadian law a condition for concluding the trade agreement, which Canada hopes will bring increased American investment and economic growth.
Jacques Lapointe, chairman of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers of Canada and chief executive of the Canadian unit of Glaxo Holdings, which is based in Britain, said the proposed GATT text and the North American Free Trade Agreement were "attempting to bring Canada into line with international rules on the protections of intellectual property."
But Senator David Pryor, the Arkansas Democrat who heads the Senate Committee on Aging, asked, "Are we slitting our own throats by limiting our options to contain drug costs?"
Representative Henry A. Waxman, the Democrat from California who is chairman of a House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on health, said American consumers "are subsidizing the lower prices that Canadians and Europeans pay for pharmaceuticals." Mr. Waxman, who requested the G.A.O. study of American and Canadian prices, said the disparity was "another reason why we need a national health insurance system to get some control over the cost of health care."
 
Remaking Canada's Drug Policy
 Doing away with compulsory licensing would, for example, give Merck & Company 13 more years of Canadian patent protection for Vasotec, a heart drug that is one of the company's largest-selling products. Canadian sales of Vasotec exceed $100 million a year, industry executives say.
The Mulroney Government proposes to ease the effects of losing compulsory licensing by giving enforcement power to a federal board that reviews drug prices. The board would impose fines and jail sentences on violators of its price guidelines. But the proposal raises legal problems under Canada's Constitution, under which the provinces regulate business.
Canadian health officials are also discussing a plan to strengthen the provinces' clout as drug purchasers for the poor and elderly, drafting a proposal for a centralized "national formulary service" that would publish information on the medical benefits and cost-effectiveness of competing drugs. Formularies are lists of approved drugs compiled by insurers and other large buyers. To win a place on the approved list, drug makers often must reduce their prices.
Gerald J. Mossinghoff, president of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association in Washington, said his members would like to eliminate Canada's Government price controls. The American drug makers also oppose drug formularies, which are increasingly cutting into drug profits in the United States as well as Canada.
"Formularies, by definition, keep drugs away from patients," Mr. Mossinghoff said.
The drug makers reported about $41 billion in American sales of patent-protected products last year. Generic drug sales added about $5 billion. Drug prices, which rose twice as fast as general inflation in the 1980's, have slowed somewhat, the Labor Department said. But drug prices paid by consumers still rose 6.3 percent in the 12 months ending in October, while the overall Consumer Price Index was up only 3.2 percent.
And despite pledges to restrain increases by several large American companies, factory prices to wholesalers and other large buyers rose 5.4 percent in October, compared with only 1.7 percent growth in the general Producer Price Index for manufactured goods.

HEADLINE: Economists Back Clinton On Investment Tax Credits

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The investment tax credit proposed by President-elect Bill Clinton is probably the single most powerful tool for giving the economy a jolt forward without dangerously expanding the budget deficit, economists agree.
Several economic forecasters interviewed said Mr. Clinton's investment tax credit, probably limited to purchases of equipment, would create 300,000 to 500,000 additional jobs by the end of 1993 while increasing the deficit by just $500 million. 
 "Investment tax credits probably provide more short-term stimulus than any other changes on the spending side or tax side," said William A. Niskanen, president of the Cato Institute and a member of President Ronald Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers.
While economists agree that investment tax credits are a potent tool, not everyone agrees that they are needed now with the economy finally showing some signs of picking up. But with economic growth weak for the last three years, Mr. Clinton seems intent on stepping on the accelerator, if only in part to make sure the economy does not stall again.
Most of the jobs created by an investment tax credit would be in companies that produce equipment like computers, trucks or metal-working machinery, economists said. Only a fraction would probably occur in companies buying equipment, since much of that equipment would replace workers. Though this would penalize some workers, the tax credit is intended to create a wealthier nation over all by increasing investment, growth and productivity.
Mr. Clinton is seeking a marginal or incremental tax credit, meaning companies will receive a tax credit only on investments above a certain base level. If the tax credit was 10 percent, a number some Clinton advisers have suggested, a company that invests $1 million in equipment above its base level, for example, would receive a $100,000 credit.
 
Looking at 80%
 Although no final decision has been made about what the base level of investment would be, Mr. Clinton's advisers suggested during the campaign that the credit might be available on equipment purchases that exceed 80 percent of a company's 1992 levels. So if a corporation spent $1 million on equipment in 1992, a tax credit would be calculated on amounts it spent in 1993 that exceeded $800,000.
This marginal approach is intended to minimize a problem with the investment tax credits used by every President from John F. Kennedy to Ronald Reagan. These credits provided a windfall of billions of dollars for investments that would have been made even without a tax credit.
"In many ways a marginal tax credit is an ideal policy because the Government will leverage private-sector investment," said Gene B. Sperling, who was economic issues coordinator in the Clinton campaign and is now deputy director of the President-elect's economic transition team. "It has the attractive aspect of not increasing the deficit while providing significant stimulus to the economy."
The investment tax credit was repealed by the 1986 tax bill after many economists argued that it improperly distorted investment decisions in favor of areas where the credit was available. The idea behind the repeal was that corporations should make investment decisions according to market forces, not tax incentives.
Nonetheless, President Bush proposed an investment tax credit as part of his economic package last January, which aimed to stimulate the weak economy. That credit was never enacted into law, however, because Mr. Bush ultimately vetoed the package after Congress inserted some tax increases into it.
 
The Cost in Revenue
 Past investment tax credits have generally cost the Government about one dollar in forgone tax revenues for each dollar of investment generated. Mr. Clinton's advisers say they are confident that their marginal credit will spur several dollars of investment for each dollar of Federal revenue forgone.
DRI/McGraw Hill, a consulting firm in Lexington, Mass., estimates that a marginal tax credit that costs the Government $4 billion next year would bring an additional $20 billion in investment.
David Wyss, DRI's chief financial economist, said such a credit would create 300,000 jobs in capital goods industries next year and 200,000 additional jobs indirectly. These would be in trucking companies, software companies, restaurants or other corporations that sell goods or services to equipment manufacturers or their employees.
Laurence H. Meyer & Associates, the St. Louis consulting firm, estimates that a 10 percent marginal credit would cost the Government $3.1 billion in foregone revenues in fiscal 1993 while producing about $22 billion in extra investment. The firm says the investment incentive will increase growth and incomes by so much that the deficit will increase by just $500 million next year. But because most companies would act immediately to take advantage of the new credit, Meyer sees a far smaller stimulus in 1994, with the credit expected to produce just $4 billion in extra investment.
 
New Analysis Issued
 The firm, which was commissioned by the Clinton campaign to do a pre-election study of the tax credit, has issued a new analysis since the election showing lower job gains than originally estimated. Initially basing its computations on the assumption of a tax credit for equipment purchases exceeding 80 percent of a company's 1992 levels, the firm at first concluded that the credit would produce 500,000 additional jobs in 1993 and add seven-tenths of 1 percent to the gross domestic product.
The new study predicts the credit will create only 300,000 extra jobs and a five-tenths of 1 percent increase in output. The firm made the downward revisions, its economists said, because they had originally underestimated how much would be spent on imported equipment.
The Clinton plan could face numerous hurdles in Congress. For one, business groups are signaling that they will lobby for a tax credit on all equipment purchases rather on just incremental investments.
And some people dislike a marginal tax credit because it would seem to penalize businesses that bravely increased investment despite the 1990-91 recession.
"There is no reason to favor firms whose relative past investment has been low, rather than those whose recent investment has been high," said Barry Bosworth, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and an economic official in the Carter Administration.
 
Work at Harvard
 Mr. Clinton's push for a tax credit on equipment investment seems in part inspired by the work of Lawrence H. Summers, a Harvard professor who many say is on the short list to be chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. Research by Mr. Summers and his Harvard colleague, Bradford Delong, shows that machinery investments have huge returns -- not just to corporations but to all of society. Such investment, they argue, helps spread new technologies and pushes companies to improve their workers' skills.
Mr. Summers said in an interview, "A dollar of equipment investment does more for economic growth than a dollar invested in office buildings, shopping centers or housing."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Taming Inflation, and Its Impact

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
When inflation in the United States is out of control, as it was in the 1970's and early 80's, it is the talk of the land and topples Presidents. When it is under control people just don't seem to notice it.
Well, for the record, inflation in the United States should dip this year to its lowest sustained level since the beginning of the 1970's. 
 This is not a flash in the pan. The data would cover the 10-year period through the end of 1992. If the Consumer Price Index for the United States rises only 3 percent this year -- and it is moving at that pace right now -- prices will have risen just 3.8 percent a year on average in the last decade. That would be the slowest 10 years' worth of inflation since the same 3.8 percent in the period that ended in 1973.
There has not been a 10-year period in which consumer prices rose at an average annual rate of less than 3 percent since 1961 to 1970, when the average was 2.77 percent.
 
Trend Among Industrial Nations
 America's industrial allies have seen similarly tame inflation, from Britain and Germany to Australia and New Zealand. Inflation in the 23 most industrialized countries could average 3.9 percent a year for the last decade, according to International Monetary Fund data. That would be the lowest level for the group since the 3.82 percent figure for the 10 years that ended in 1972.
This should be good news for the consumer and the bond market although there has been quite a cost for this success. In the United States it was the steep recessions of 1980 and 1981 and, later, the four years of either minimal growth or recession since 1988 that undermined President Bush's chances for re-election.
But low inflation has its benefits, one of the most important being the opportunity for a longer period of sustained growth in the economy.
There are numerous signs of continued moderate inflation in the United States. Despite the somewhat surprising rise of four-tenths of one percent in the Consumer Price Index for October, reported Friday, several analysts said they were not worried, in part because one-time factors, like increases in airline fares, contributed to the overall jump.
 
Inflation Scenario Discounted
 Closely watched inflation monitors, like the Commodity Research Bureau's index, are declining. What ismore, both the recent rise of the dollar, which makes imports less expensive, and slow growth in Europe, which cuts demand for American products, should both help restrain inflationary pressures.
"There is just no inflation scenario," said Rudiger Dornbusch, professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "You need 3.5 percent growth for three or four years to get a crunch."
Still, it seems that traders and investors in the bond market, which is ultrasensitive to price movements, have yet to believe the inflation story.
Some analysts contend that long-term rates, given the recent inflation performance, should be lower than the 7.57 percent yield on Friday on the new 30-year bond. This belief was the basis for many of the projections, now generally abandoned, that long-term rates would soon fall below 7 percent.
"I still don't believe that most bond investors believe we are looking at a major structural break in inflation," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence. "I think the bond market is still very concerned about a rebound in inflation."
Others believe that in the next year the story on low inflation will finally sink in and bring down bond yields. Mr. Yardeni said the inflation downdraft could pull rates on the long bond close to 6 percent. Others are more conservative, projecting a fall to around 7.25 or 7 percent.
But there are others who think that much of the inflation story is reflected in the market already, which means that other factors -- like the performance of the Clinton Administration -- will have more impact on the future course of bond yields.
"I don't think that the bond market is misinterpreting the inflation facts," said Richard B. Hoey, chief economist at the Dreyfus Corporation. What worries the market, he said, is not an expected rise in inflation in the near term but the "uncertainty about the economic policy of the Clinton Administration."
"The difference between the bulls and the bears," he said, "is not about what inflation will be in 1993, but about what economic policy will be in 1993, 1994 and 1995. There is a fear we won't deal with the deficit."
 
'Crowding Out' Feared More
 John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said the concern in the market now is not inflation but of "crowding out," a term that became popular early in the Reagan Administration. It is the worry that with a rising Federal budget deficit the borrowing demands of the Treasury will "crowd out" the private-sector demand for borrowing. And this, the theory goes, will lead to higher interest rates.
Nancy J. Kimelman, chief economist at Technical Data in Boston, takes a different view. She says investors and traders are already correctly interpreting a Clinton Presidency. The current interest rate on the 30-year bond, she said, assumes that inflation will rise under Mr. Clinton.
"I am not sure that the market is wrong in assessing that Clinton will mean higher bond yields than Bush," she said. Mr. Clinton, she said, wants to get the economy growing to create more jobs. And this, she acknowledged, will probably mean higher inflation.
"The bond market knows that sluggish growth, no real improvement in incomes, and austerity are not the American way," she said. "And everyone knew that the deficit was at a record level, and they still elected Bill Clinton."
