HEADLINE: U.S. Panel On Arts May Be Revived

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
As plans take shape for revamping Federal support of the arts under the Clinton Administration, some of those on the transition team or close to it say President-elect Bill Clinton may revive the dormant Federal Council on the Arts and the Humanities and name its chairman even before selecting a new head for the National Endowment for the Arts.
Theodore W. Striggles, a former executive director of the New York Council on the Arts who has advised the Clinton campaign on arts policy, said on Friday that while it was obvious that economy-related and cabinet-level jobs must be filled first, the relatively prompt appointment of a new Federal council chairman "could solve two problems at once." 
 He was alluding to the fact that the arts endowment must have its life extended by Congress next year. The issue is unlikely to bring about the end of the endowment, but it is almost guaranteed to renew debate on whether Congress should impose content restrictions on federally financed projects. Even if the new President names a chairman for the endowment as soon as February, there is little chance that the appointee could pass a routine security clearance as well as Congressional confirmation in time to guide the debate on reauthorization.
 
'Would Not Have Been Bloodied'
 "It might be best," Mr. Striggles said, "for the new President to first appoint a chairman of the Federal council, which he can do by executive order, and then have that person guide the debate. Furthermore, when the new endowment chairman takes over, his hands would not have been bloodied by the reauthorization battle."
George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's assistant director for communications, said last week from Little Rock, Ark., that the transition team would establish "cluster groups" within 10 days and that one of them would begin to deal with the arts and humanities. He acknowledged that Deborah Sale "or someone like that" would head the arts-cluster group.
Ms. Sale, who represented Mr. Clinton at the annual meeting of the National Assembly of State Arts Agencies in Chicago on Saturday, has been a friend of Mr. Clinton's since their high school days in Little Rock. Before joining the Clinton campaign staff as a senior adviser, she was the campaign manager and chief of staff to Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine of New York. She is married to Mr. Striggles.
Although Ms. Sale has been mentioned as a possible future chairwoman of the arts endowment, some close to the Clinton organization said they believed that she would be even more highly placed in the new administration.
 
After 'Joan of Arts'
 They also said they were attracted to the idea of reviving the Federal Council on the Arts and the Humanities as a means of broadening the base of the arts throughout the Federal Government. The Federal council was used for this purpose during the Jimmy Carter Administration by Joan Mondale, the wife of Vice President Walter Mondale, who was frequently referred to as "Joan of Arts."
Others on the transition team or close to it, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity, said Mr. Clinton's arts policy would focus on arts education and making the arts more generally available to the population, a stand likely to rekindle the populism-versus-elitism debate that hounded the cultural leaders of the Carter Administration.
The policy of the Clinton Administration toward National Endowment for the Arts grants, which are often heatedly debated, is likely to be carefully measured. Although no one close to the President-elect was willing to discuss the subject in detail, Bruce Reed, a top campaign aide who was named a deputy of the transition team on Friday, stated in April during the New York primary that a Clinton Administration "would never allow outside pressure to infringe the basic freedom of artists."
 
'One of the Toughest Issues'
 But Mr. Reed conceded that finding a way to protect the rights of both artists and a public that finds some art deeply offensive is "one of the toughest issues we face today."
The implication of Mr. Reed's statements is that although the Clinton Administration would go far to show itself as a friend of artists, it would not approve Federal grants to support exhibitions of the most provocative work of artists like Andres Serrano and Robert Mapplethorpe, which proved incendiary in 1989.
Mrs. Mondale casts a long shadow among the President-elect's most highly regarded arts advisers. Two of them -- Beverly Lindsey and Ms. Sale -- worked for her during the Carter years and say they were influenced by her activities.
Mrs. Lindsey was the executive director of the Arkansas Arts Council from 1987 to 1990 and remains close to Mr. Clinton. Her husband, Bruce Lindsey, served as a chief traveling adviser to Mr. Clinton in the Presidential campaign.
 
From Active to Nearly Moribund
 The Federal Council on the Arts and the Humanities was created in 1965 to coordinate the activities of the arts and humanities endowments with those of other Federal programs. Livingston Biddle, who helped write the legislation that created the Federal Council and was appointed the chairman of the arts endowment by President Jimmy Carter, suggested to Mrs. Mondale that she could make effective use of the council.
At first, Mrs. Mondale worked with the Department of Transportation to convert rarely used railroad stations into small cultural centers. Eventually, and largely as a result of Mrs. Mondale's efforts, the Department of Labor became the largest employer of artists in the nation.
The Federal council became nearly moribund during the Reagan and Bush Administrations, but the idea of supporting artists and arts projects by means other than direct financial awards by arts agencies was picked up in Arkansas, among other places.
Mrs. Lindsey said Governor Clinton's expansion of an annual blues festival in Helena, Ark., which was supported by the state arts council, into a broadly supported, multi-disciplinary arts festival operated by the Delta Cultural Center, was inspired by the work of the Federal council. The Delta Cultural Center, based in a restored Union Pacific railroad depot in Helena, receives a trickle of financial assistance from the state arts council and the National Endowment for the Arts, but 95 percent of its money comes from a state grant to its parent agency, the Department of Arkansas Heritage.
 
From a Real Estate Tax
 Another example of Mr. Clinton's interest in seeking means outside arts grant-making agencies to support artists and arts projects, Ms. Lindsey said, is the Arkansas Natural and Cultural Resources Council, a state grant-making body Governor Clinton pressed for in 1987.
The council, supported by a tax of $1.10 per $1,000 on all real estate transactions in the state, was originally used to finance environmental protection and historic preservation projects, but soon began awarding grants for arts projects.
"Governor Clinton knew that in bad economic times, when we couldn't get more money for the arts council, this was a way we could fund the arts," Ms. Lindsey said.
"I hate to put words in anyone's mouth, but this is the sort of thing the Governor will be looking at: cooperative projects between agencies instead of just one agency."
Asked about the prospect of reviving the Federal council, Ms. Sale responded, "It would certainly not be inconsistent with the sort of work Bill Clinton has been doing here in Arkansas."
 
A List of Potential Candidates
 In addition to Ms. Sale and Mrs. Lindsey, the list of possible replacements for Anne-Imelda Radice, the acting arts endowment chairwoman, includes Dr. Mary Schmidt Campbell, the dean of the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University; Adele Chatfield-Taylor, the president of the American Academy in Rome and a former head of the design-arts program for the National Endowment for the Arts; Claudine Brown, a deputy assistant secretary at the Smithsonian Institution; Cynthia Mayeda, the chairwoman of the Dayton Hudson Foundation; Anne Hawley, the director of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston; Lloyd Richards, a former dean of the Yale School of Drama; John Brademas, a former president of New York University, and Luis R. Cancel, the commissioner of the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs.
Prominently mentioned as a possible successor to Lynne V. Cheney, the chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, is Vartan Gregorian, the president of Brown University.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Elizabeth II: Pageantry, Small Talk, but No Gossip

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
I cannot say with certainty that "Elizabeth R: A Year in the Life of the Queen" is the most boring two-hour BBC import ever to make its way to American public television, since I wore out after about 30 minutes. But it must be in the running.
The pageantry in this authorized tour, which can be seen tonight on PBS (at 9 P.M. on Channels 13 and 49 in New York), may remind you of the sets of postcards available around Piccadilly Circus; there are also statistics of the mildest interest (368 people work at Buckingham Palace), glimpses of the royal family, but no gossip, and snatches of conversation, official and less official. 
 Here is Her Majesty giving a gift to Francesco Cossiga, the President of Italy, a high point of a state visit:
The President: "This is for my wife?"
The Queen: "And that is for your wife."
The President: "Oh thank you very much, yes."
The Queen: "Which is a small clock."
The President: "A small clock."
Here, in a less formal encounter, is the Queen talking to Michael Oswald, an overseer of her stud farm at Sandringham:
The Queen, referring to a horse: "If you listen, it's a very level walk, that."
Mr. Oswald: "Yes."
The Queen: "Isn't that interesting."
Well, as they say, it doesn't get more interesting than that, at least not in the first half-hour, which includes scenes inside Buckingham Palace of Elizabeth going over letters to the Queen with her principal private secretary, Sir Robert Fellowes, who tells her that the National Canine Defense League would like her to become a patron; sitting for a portrait; paying a visit to a retirement home in Heckmondwike with her press secretary, Charles Anson, one of her ladies-in-waiting, Richenda Elton, and the Equerry, Blair Stewart-Wilson. She asks a resident, "You have a room here of your own, do you?" (An equerry, if you were wondering, is an officer of the Royal household who attends upon either the Sovereign or her horses)
Although the press release that calls this program "an intimate portrait" will not make the 1992 truth-in-publicity honors list, those who bear with it may get an inkling of the Queen's public life and her personality.
Elizabeth II seems to be a straightforward sort, who goes about her duties uncomplainingly and has developed a talent for the smallest of small talk during her endless round of visiting and being visited. Her duties and pleasures -- which in the unreviewed 90 minutes of the program include a visit to naval wives in Portsmouth during the war in the Persian Gulf; visits by dignitaries, including Lech Walesa, to Windsor Castle; an official visit to Northern Ireland, and the royal visit to the United States in May 1991 -- are all minutely programmed for her. Her most spontaneous moments come at Derby Day at Epson, where she wins 16 pounds and actually seems to be enjoying herself.
 
"The New Europeans"
 Britain also figures in "The New Europeans," three hourlong looks at the developing European Economic Community, its promise, its problems and, especially, its complexity. The first program, "Road to Unity," tomorrow on PBS (at 10 P.M. on Channels 13 and 49 in New York), treats some of the main issues through a few entrepreneurs and workers in several countries. It doesn't go very deep, but does manage to get across considerable information in easy doses.
Next week "Global Agendas" touches on such difficult matters as the mass immigration within Europe that is raising political tensions and temperatures and a united Europe's relations with Japan and the United States. The final program, "Regional Dreams," focuses on the deep economic divisions within Europe and other differences among the nations involved. All in all "The New Europeans" is a serviceable introduction to a changing or unraveling story.

HEADLINE: Iran Resurgent

 BODY:
Iran, once the dominant military power in the Persian Gulf, now races to reclaim supremacy. No longer distracted by internal turmoil or endless war with Iraq, Teheran is using its oil wealth to buy weapons systems from the East and sophisticated technologies from the West that can be used to build nuclear bombs, ballistic missiles, advanced aviation and germ warfare weapons.
In the hands of a regime that still sponsors international terrorism and exports Islamic revolution, this dramatic buildup could develop into a world-class problem. Better to take preventive action now, with an international agreement to regulate the most dangerous transactions. 
 President Rafsanjani has restored a measure of stability at home and revived economic growth. But Iran's foreign policy remains adventurist. It seized a strategic gulf island in September and continues to aid violent fundamentalists abroad.
Chastened by the experience of helping Iraq build its war machine only to confront it in combat, Congress and the Administration are wisely moving to tighten restrictions on what Americans can sell to Iran. But to be effective, the new rules have to be coordinated with other sellers.
Much of what Iran is now buying from the West falls into the ambiguous category known as "dual use." High-speed computers and software, navigation equipment, specialized switches and communications technology can be used for civilian purposes, like petrochemical plants and civilian aviation. Or they can be used for weapons.
American companies legally sold Iran hundreds of millions of dollars worth of dual-use items last year. That figure will be cut back sharply by the new U.S. restrictions. But these won't limit sales from U.S. allies, or direct weapons transfers from China or former Soviet republics.
Tighter rules on transferring dual-use technologies have to be negotiated among the main supplier countries, the way Western nations once policed sensitive exports to the Communist bloc.
Not every potential dual-use item need be prohibited. That would only complicate agreement among suppliers and invite evasion. The U.S. has no interest in handicapping Iran's development, only in restricting military technologies.
Actual weapons sales can best be restrained by building on a five-power initiative the Bush Administration sponsored right after the Persian Gulf war. By July 1991, Washington, London, Paris, Moscow and Beijing had agreed to a joint statement on curbing the destabilizing transfer of nuclear and conventional weapons to the Mideast.
But there was no real follow-up, and during the Presidential campaign President Bush announced huge new deals with Saudi Arabia and Israel. Teheran's current arms drive gives Mr. Bush, and Mr. Clinton, a compelling reason to revive the 1991 initiative and make sure it covers Iran.
New revelations about how Western dual-use exports helped Saddam Hussein turn Iraq into a dangerous military power appear almost daily. It's important not to make the same mistake in Iran.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Rogue White Elephant

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Where will the new President turn for vital information to help him make life-or-death decisions on foreign affairs?
To the C.I.A., of course. His national security adviser will tell him not to curtail that vast establishment. His new economic security adviser will suggest expanding its reach into the world of economic intelligence. 
If President Clinton should trouble to ask what all this costs, he will be told a fact kept secret from the American public: about $20 billion a year goes to military intelligence -- from satellites still reading Kremlin license plates to Big Ears listening to millions of voice and data transmissions -- and an additional $10 billion per year to the C.I.A. for human spying, covert operations, and analysis that winds up in the President's daily intelligence brief.
He may ask: Why can't the American taxpayer be told, at least in the aggregate, how much is spent on the intelligence gathering and evaluation?
Reaction: horror. He would be told that sources and methods would be blown, allied services betrayed by publication of our overall intelligence budget. Worst of all, the cozy symbiosis between the intelligence community and its Congressional overseers would be shattered if nosy outsiders knew the real rate of growth of our spying spending.
If the new President has any moxie, he will cut through this stultifying secrecy and demand to know: Are we getting enough data for the dollar? How does the efficiency of our operation compare with that of other major nations? Is the information so expensively gathered lost in the bureaucracy or made available to the decision-maker at the moment of decision?
A recent episode is illuminating. If C.I.A. spokesmen are to be believed, the agency "misfiled" some pertinent intelligence about the participation of Italian officials in the decision to help finance Saddam Hussein's arms buildup. This supposedly led our gullible Justice Department to absolve Rome of wrongdoing and cost U.S. taxpayers billions in loan guarantees.
Misfiled? Lost some memos? That suggests C.I.A. clerks sticking handwritten slips into red-taped folders and putting them in oaken file cabinets, with the system of retrieval in one Uriah Heep's head.
In fact, even the agency's new family jewels are on computers. Any hacker with software costing $49 and all the relevant C.I.A. access codes in hand could type in "Lavoro or B.N.L. or Matrix or Dragoul or Atlanta and Iraq," command "Search," and turn up all the memos that were mysteriously "misfiled" for years -- and more.
Either the C.I.A. method of handling data is egregiously inefficient -- unable to call up and present hard intelligence to help the President make a far-reaching decision directive -- or the organization is corrupt, deliberately concealing the truth from lawmakers and law enforcement officials.
Faced with this reality, what's a new President to do?
1. Pick a Director of Central Intelligence who knows how accountability has been avoided but is not a compromised insider.
Senate Intelligence Committee chairman David Boren, who bet the Company on Robert Gates, was betrayed and is sore; he's the sort who could introduce competitive "Team B's" to improve the product while reducing waste. Scheduled to be next year's chairman is Senator Sam Nunn; President Clinton should agree to notify Congressional leaders of "findings" within 24 hours.
2. The Intelligence Oversight Board within the White House has always been a joke, but the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board -- "Piffiab" -- was once useful in providing a quality control check by informed outsiders.
When Mr. Reagan purged Martin Anderson and other critics at Director Bill Casey's request, Piffiab lost its independence; Mr. Bush further reduced it to a panel of technocrats. The new President should replace and expand the board, let it hire competent new staff and make it a source of citizen oversight of Langley's old pros.
3. Focus on new missions for the new C.I.A.: protection of industrial privacy and preparation for decisions involving "the right to intervene" when genocide looms. We didn't hear about intelligence in the campaign, but now it's time to get serious.

HEADLINE: Mexican Accounting

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A variety of objections, speculation really, is readily at hand for those who sense danger and worse in the prospective North American free trade agreement. For example, while those on both sides tacitly assume that Mexican demographic and economic data are reliable, the assumption can in no way be justified. 
 The Latin American republics were introduced to modern accounting methods by the 19th-century railroad barons and the banking houses that sold their bonds.
Invariably, the result was oversubscribed bond issues that financed railroads that were either never built or that were ceded to foreign commercial control.
Latin governments soon learned two responses to this scam: one was to inflate currency outrageously to repay bondholders; the other was the practice each revolutionary government followed of declaring a clean economic slate, not incidentally renouncing the debts of the previous "criminal" regime.
Thus, creative accounting became a time-honored feature of Latin American economic reports. An Oct. 22 front-page article on United States migrant law refers to Mexicans "fleeing severe unemployment at home," which can be confirmed by anyone who has visited Mexico in recent years. Despite such reports, you quote Mexican unemployment as hovering around the 3 percent level.
They're cooking the books, and that's the problem.
 
DONALD KERR
Bronx, Oct. 29, 1992

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: The President-Elect;
CLINTON DISCUSSES LEGISLATIVE MOVES WITH CONGRESSMEN

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 15

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton met tonight for three hours with three top Democratic Congressional leaders to begin setting a legislative agenda to get his Administration off to a fast start, beginning with an economic stimulus package.
Mr. Clinton sought advice from the leaders, Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, on what obstacles they thought his economic package and legislative program might face in Congress, a Congressional aide said tonight. 
 Mr. Clinton told reporters after his morning jog that the theme he wanted to strike in this session was "we've got a big job to do and we've got to do it together."
And after the meeting a top Clinton aide, George Stephanopoulos, said the session had shown that "everybody is ready to work together on the same priorities." None of the lawmakers would discuss the meeting with reporters tonight, but they will hold a news conference with Mr. Clinton on Monday.
 
Seeking Cooperative Spirit
 While two of tonight's dinner guests, Mr. Foley and Mr. Mitchell, have scoffed at the importance of measuring accomplishments in the traditional first 100 days, on all sides there are strong hopes for some quick victories.
Fast, cooperative action, leaders and Clinton aides believe, could lay to rest the fears that Congress can no longer cooperate with any President and still memories of the conflicts a Democratic Congress had with the last Democratic President, Jimmy Carter.
Mr. Clinton himself told reporters after his jog, "Oh, I think we're just going to have a meeting to kind of renew our acquaintance, talk about our obligations, look to the future a little bit, talk a little bit about next week when I go to Washington."
 
'Clear Priorities'
 Tonight's meeting had originally been expected to touch only lightly on the substance of legislation and instead focuse more on how to work together. But one Congressional aide said afterward that most of the three hours had been spent on the issues Mr. Clinton will ask Congress to face, from the economy to health care to campaign finance.
In setting his legislative agenda, Mr. Clinton must put order to the "clear priorities" he spoke of on Thursday at his first post-election news conference. Those priorities include job creation, deficit reduction, the establishment of a national health-care system and the strengthening of political ethics rules.
At the news conference, he said he recognized that President Carter had tried to pass so many ambitious measures in his first three months that he overloaded Congress and achieved little. He said he would not fall into that trap and said, "I expect to keep the focus on these economic issues, and I'm not trying to scale back, or scale down, or anything else."
Before tonight's meeting, Mr. Clinton got some encouragement for his prospects in Congress when Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, abandoned the harsh tone he has used toward Mr. Clinton since the election. "My view is that they deserve some time to get things under way," he said.
Mr. Dole said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" that all-out Republican opposition to Mr. Clinton's legislative proposals would be "very selective." He said, "We're not trying to frustrate what he does," and added, "I don't think we want to be obstructionist."
Mr. Dole also dismissed the 100-day measuring stick as artificial, saying: "I don't think there's any magic in how much you do in the first 100 days. If you push too hard to do too much in too short a time span, you may end upon the reef somewhere."
But Mr. Clinton also encountered some strong opposition to his plan to lift the ban on homosexuals serving in the military. Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee, said he favored the present policy, and said extended hearings should be held on the issue. "If you did it overnight, I fear for the lives of people in the military themselves," he said on the CBS News program "Face the Nation."
The meeting with Mr. Foley, Mr. Mitchell, Mr. Gephardt and Vice President-elect Al Gore was Mr. Clinton's first post-election encounter with Congressional lawmakers. But he has been talking on the telephone not only to them but to other important legislators as well.
For example, Mr. Clinton has spoken more than once to both Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, and Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who heads the Senate Appropriations Committee.
 
Opposing Line-Item Veto
 From the tax elements of any economic stimulus package to changes in the health-care industry, many of Mr. Clinton's most cherished plans must go first to Ways and Means, which also has the early, but politically painful duty of moving legislation to raise the statutory limit on the national debt.
The $4.145 trillion ceiling is expected to be reached by March or April. Mr. Rostenkowski, Mr. Foley and Mr. Gephardt have said frequently that a new limit cannot be passed unless it is accompanied by measures to insure reductions in the annual Federal deficits that boost the debt.
Mr. Byrd opposes Mr. Clinton's call for a line-item veto, which some supporters see as a necessary method to trim deficits. The Senator also appears to oppose a substitute the new President might welcome, an increased authority to rescind appropriations.
Under a line-item veto, it would take two-thirds majorities in both houses to retain a piece of spending challenged by the President. Under existing rescission laws, the President can challenge spending, but it only takes a majority for Congress to reinstate it.
Tonight's meeting will be followed by two more encounters in Washington on Thursday with the legislative branch.
Mr. Dole, with whom Mr. Clinton spoke by telephone last week, offered the President-elect some hope today of better relations with Republicans than President Bush has enjoyed with Congressional Democrats. While Mr. Dole did not specifically recant his threat to block any "awful legislation" proposed by Mr. Clinton, or his insistence that as the Republican leader in the Senate he would speak for the majority who did not vote for Mr. Clinton, his tone today was generally amiable.
The Kansas Republican said his purpose had been to make clear that "we're not going to be patsies and floor mats and rubber stamps." But, he said, "My view has been from the start that we have an obligation where we can to help the President-elect."

HEADLINE: U.N. Tightens Curbs on Belgrade By Authorizing a Naval Blockade

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 16

 BODY:
The Security Council voted tonight to impose a naval blockade against Yugoslavia, for the first time adding enforcement provisions to trade sanctions that were adopted against the Serbian-led Belgrade Government in May.
The United States was among 13 nations voting in favor. The Council's other two members, China and Zimbabwe, abstained. 
 Sanctions were originally imposed on May 31 on Serbia and Montenegro, the two remaining republics of Yugoslavia. But intelligence reports in recent weeks have indicated that arms and petroleum products slipped through with relative ease. According to information from the United States, oil has been illegally shipped into Serbia from Greece, Malta, Italy and Egypt.
The new resolution imposes the naval embargo on both the Adriatic Sea and the Danube River, which by law is an international waterway and is said to carry oil shipments to Serbia from the Black Sea. Vessels suspected of carrying illegal supplies can now be stopped and inspected. Diplomats said shots could be fired across the bow of vessels refusing to stop for inspection.
How far any confrontation could be taken beyond that point, no one here was prepared to say. NATO and the Western European Union, the military arm of the European Community, have 10 naval vessels in the Adriatic but had not been authorized to stop and search. Diplomats said it was possible that United States vessels could be involved in the Adriatic.
Ships suspected of carrying illegal cargo by way of the Danube would fall under the responsibility of member nations along its borders, particularly Bulgaria and Romania.
The resolution, drafted by the United States, Britain, France, Russia and Belgium, also declared that strategic supplies could no longer be transshipped across Serbia and Montenegro without first being inspected by United Nations monitors. Diplomats said trucks headed for other countries had been dropping off illegal strategic supplies in Serbia. Commodities falling under the sanctions include crude oil, natural gas, aircraft, vehicles, metals, tires, motors and coal.
The Chinese representative, Li Dayou, said he abstained because sanctions were ineffective. When sanctions were first imposed, Mr. Li recalled, China said they would not help but would further aggravate the situation. "We cannot take a different position now, he said.
The resolution also calls upon Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali to study the creation of security zones, or havens, for civilians in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Diplomats stressed that the idea was still in the formative stage and acknowledged that an important military or police presence would probably be needed to make the zones effective.
The two-day debate leading to the new resolution was requested by a group of Islamic countries as a show of support for the Muslim-led Government and people of Bosnia. During the debate, a number of the Islamic countries, including Afghanistan, Jordan, Iran and Pakistan, called on the Council to exclude Bosnia from an embargo on weapons sales imposed on all the former Yugoslavia republics in September 1991.
Since there are no plans to intervene militarily, they argued, Bosnia should at least be allowed to defend itself against the heavily-armed Serbs.
The Security Council refused, heeding the advice of one of the first speakers in the debate, the former American Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance. Mr. Vance, one of the two principal mediators at the Geneva Conference on Yugoslavia, told the Council on Friday that "it taxes credulity to suggest that lifting the arms embargo for only one party is either feasible or desirable."
The Yugoslav Foreign Minister, Ilija Djukic, said the sanctions would only hurt the "most vulnerable part of the population." He insisted that the Serbs fighting in Bosnia were irregulars who did not answer to the Belgrade, while their Muslim opponents were mercenaries from other Islamic nations.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
No Details Yet, U.S. Says
 WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (Special to The New York Times) -- A White House spokeswoman said tonight that "no detailed plans have been discussed on the actual implementation" of the embargo approved by the Security Council. She added that the Pentagon would probably release information on Tuesday.
An Administration official said the Government supported stricter sanctions against Serbia, but the official was unwilling to publicly commit the United States to military support of the embargo.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.N. General Expresses Hope
 SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Nov. 16 (Reuters) -- The commander of United Nations peacekeeping forces in Bosnia and Herzegovina said today that he believed the worst of the civil war might be over.
"Some small steps forward could prove that the nightmare is over," said the commander, Gen. Philippe Morillon of France.
He spoke after representatives of the allied Bosnian Croats and Muslims sat down with their Serbian nationalist antagonists and agreed to open the road from Mostar to Sarajevo for United Nations and humanitarian aid convoys.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: The President-Elect;
Clinton and Top Legislators Pledge Amity on Economy

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 16

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton gathered Democratic leaders around him today to pronounce an end to the "cold war" between Congress and the White House. But Mr. Clinton quickly confronted the degree to which his campaign pledges strain the coalition he will need to enact his programs.
At a news conference in the Arkansas State House, Mr. Clinton vowed to press ahead with his pledge to lift the ban on homosexuals in the armed forces, despite complaints from the Pentagon and signs of resistance from an important Democrat in Congress. 
 But today, Mr. Clinton, Vice President-elect Al Gore, Speaker Thomas S. Foley, Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, and George J. Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, were all smiles as they extolled the virtues of one party controlling the Senate, the House and the White House for the first time since 1980.
After talks on Sunday night with Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, they vowed to cooperate on a shared agenda of legislation to create jobs, affordable health care, middle-class tax relief and disciplined deficit reduction and to improve the long-term competitiveness of the American economy.
As he has throughout the transition, Mr. Clinton made no attempt to disguise the advisory role that his wife was playing. Although she was not present at the news conference, Mrs. Clinton took part in Sunday night's dinner talks. Mr. Clinton said she sat in on all the discussions, adding that "she talked a lot," and "knew more than we did about some things -- I think they would agree with that."
Mr. Clinton sounded conciliatory notes, as on his campaign demands for a cut in the size of the Congressional staff. After talking with his three guests, he said he no longer believed such a cut was needed and promised to slash the size of the White House staff. But the news conference was often diverted by questions about Mr. Clinton's plans for lifting the ban on homosexuals in the military.
 
No 'Timetable' on Lifting Ban
 Mr. Clinton said he had no "timetable" for lifting the ban and said he would impose a "very strict code of conduct" on homosexuals in the armed forces in an effort to insure that any inappropriate sexual behavior would not be tolerated. He also went out of his way to address concerns raised by Senator Sam Nunn, the George Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee.
But he made clear that he would press ahead with his plan, underscoring the tension between Mr. Clinton's hopes of focusing on the economy and health care -- issues for which he will need a broad coalition to make changes -- and some more controversial campaign pledges aimed at specific groups, which could splinter that coalition.
Mr. Clinton spiced his boilerplate remarks about working closely with Congress with some pointed jabs at the Bush Administration.
He went out of his way, for example, to say he hoped the size of the budget deficit his Administration would inherit from President Bush had not been "understated for next year and the year after."
Clinton aides say they are confident that the 103d Congress, impelled by public contempt for the gridlock that has characterized lawmaking in the last few years, will be eager to cooperate on legislation. Even Republicans, they say, will be judged more for what they pass than what they block.
Mr. Clinton said that he hoped Congress would promptly pass economic legislation but that his proposals for controlling health-care costs would take much longer because of their complexity.
"I do think we'll be able to do some things within 100 days," Mr. Clinton said. But on the issue of health care, he added, "what I have committed to do is present a plan within the first 100 days; I never said I would be able to pass a health-care plan" in that time.
The discussion in recent days of the ban on homosexuals in the military appears to be more the result of a miscalculation by Mr. Clinton than a choice. Clinton aides acknowledge that they have had a hard time adjusting from the campaign -- where the candidates shout as much as possible at the public and hope that something sticks -- to being President-elect, when every word is suddenly translatable into policies.
The issue of lifting the ban was raised last Wednesday when Mr. Clinton, answering a reporter's question after his Veteran's Day address, acknowledged that he intended to fulfill his campaign promise on this issue.
Now the issue has taken on a life of its own. Various active and retired military officers, along with Senator Nunn, cautioned the President-elect that lifting the ban would be insensitive to military men and women who live at close quarters in barracks.
In response, Mr. Clinton said, "We know that there have always been gays in the military, and we know, according to the study which was released near the end of the campaign, that it costs the United States taxpayers about $500 million to get fewer than 17,000 gays out of the military over the last 10 years."
Mr. Clinton was referring to a General Accounting Office study about the cost of investigating and litigating the effort to eliminate homosexuals from the military.
"The issue is not whether there are gays in the military," Mr. Clinton said. "It is whether they can be in the military without lying about it, as long as there is a very strict code of conduct which if they violate it would lead to dismissal from the service or other appropriate sanctions. There is a big difference between someone doing something wrong and their condition in life."

HEADLINE: BISHOPS MAY AVOID STAND ON WOMEN

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
The nation's Roman Catholic bishops gathered here today to take a stand on a long-awaited pastoral letter on women in society and the church, but it was far from certain that the document they have been working on for nine years will actually come to a vote.
Rather than trying to achieve consensus on a sweeping document that has caused them only strife so far, the bishops may decide to have various committees develop positions on narrower questions that concern women. 
 In the nine years that the bishops have been writing and rewriting the letter, trying to reach agreement among themselves and with the Vatican, "we have managed to alienate at one time or another every identifiable male or female group," Bishop Joseph L. Imesch of Joliet, Ill., said today in remarks introducing the document to the meeting, whose sessions continue through Thursday.
 
Discrimination Is Condemned
 The four successive drafts of the letter have all affirmed the equality of women and condemned discrimination as a moral evil, but they have increasingly insisted that natural differences between men and women should not be minimized. The last draft, issued in August, also emphasized the church's traditional teaching that only men can serve as priests and expanded the section dealing with contraception and other sexual behavior that the church has judged sinful.
Conservative Catholics, including some women's groups, have criticized all the drafts as conceding too much to feminist views. Some liberal Catholic women's groups have said from the start that a document from the all-male hierarchy would lack credibility.
But when the bishops held extensive hearings throughout the nation, and included in the first draft many passages quoting women from those hearings, the liberal faction welcomed that draft as opening the process to women. Since that first draft in 1988, later drafts have followed more closely the traditional Vatican teachings.
At coffee breaks between business sessions today, many bishops were talking about a proposal to terminate the work of the committee drafting the letter by handing over all four drafts, plus all the material the committee had gathered, to several permanent committees of the bishops' conference that deal with women's issues.
These committees could issue much more limited documents on specific topics, like economic and social discrimination against women and some widening of women's roles in the church. The committees would be expected to concentrate their actions on areas where the bishops were already in substantial agreement. The model would be a strong condemnation of domestic violence against women issued several weeks ago jointly by the bishops' Committee on Marriage and Family and their Committee on Women in Society and in the Church.
Pastoral letters are among the weightiest teaching documents a conference of bishops can issue. Although not automatically binding on Catholics in their entirety, these letters frequently contain binding precepts, and in any case set out positions that Catholics are at least obliged to consider seriously in making decisions. In addition, pastoral letters set policy for the church's national agencies.
By comparison, the force of letters issued by bishops' committees depend largely on whether they articulate views already widely held among the bishops or the Catholic population.
 
Seeking Test Vote
 Passage of a pastoral letter requires the approval of two-thirds of the 287 active American bishops, but the hierarchy usually strives for an even greater consensus. A full-scale debate on the letter would dramatize exactly how split the bishops still are on a number of issues in the document.
Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago, considered a master of compromise among the bishops, will offer a proposal to turn the document over to the committees, several bishops said, perhaps at the very beginning of debate on the letter on Tuesday morning.
Still other bishops, primarily conservatives, expressed concern that setting aside the letter might be seen as indicating the bishops' lack of support for the church's official teaching limiting ordination to the priesthood to men. Those bishops are seeking some kind of test vote to demonstrate support for Rome.
Archbishop William J. Levada of Portland, Ore., pointed out that in the latest round of criticism of the letter, two bishops had published articles in two Catholic publications questioning the church's bar against ordaining women. Those statements and the attention given to last week's approval of ordaining women by the Church of England "have raised the stakes," he said, and "call into question the teaching of the church."
 
'So Many Nuances'
 Archbishop Levada, who also wanted the pastoral letter fully debated and predicted that it would be approved, favored a clear indication of "the mind of the body of bishops" on the question of women and the priesthood, whether linked directly to a vote on the letter or as a separate motion.
Bishop Imesch, who headed the committee drafting the letter, disagreed. "I don't think we want a black-and-white, a yes-and-no vote" on the ordination issue, he said. "There are so many nuances."
Other bishops said that a separate vote just on the question of ordination would be seen as a "loyalty test" toward the Vatican.
At a daily press briefing by the bishops conference today, Bishop Matthew H. Clark of Rochester said that although the vast majority of bishops accepted the church's limitation of the priesthood to men, a considerable number recognize that many "in the Catholic community today, many well-informed, loyal people" disagree. Those bishops do not want "to say that these questions are forever closed, pre-empted and not discussable," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In the nine years that bishops have been rewriting the letter on the role of women in the church, trying to reach agreement among themselves and with the Vatican, "we have managed to alienate at one time or another every identifiable male or female group," said Bishop Joseph L. Imesch of Joliet, Ill. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
Avoiding Gridlock by Wooing Both Sides of Aisle

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 16

 BODY:
When President-elect Bill Clinton promised today to cooperate with Congress, saying "Pennsylvania Avenue will run both ways again," his hopes were grander than mere cooperation with the Democratic leaders standing behind him.
He wants Republican votes for his proposals, too. 
 His assertion at a news conference that "the Republicans know that the country voted for action, for an end to gridlock and an end to blame" could be dismissed as wishful puffery had he not made it clear to the leaders on Sunday that he intended to pursue Republicans, wooing the other party more more aggressively perhaps than any President since Lyndon B. Johnson.
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said he had urged Mr. Clinton to work with some Republican senators, telling him they had as much interest in the good of the country as Democrats did. He said today that they discussed several particular Senators on Sunday night.
 
Lunch With the G.O.P.
 One Congressional aide said Mr. Clinton had made it clear that he planned to have Republicans to the White House -- where Democrats were rarely invited to business meetings this year -- and seek their views on how to structure some legislation.
He is not waiting for Inauguration Day. Last week he spoke by telephone with Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, who had saluted his victory with a furious attack on Mr. Clinton's slim mandate. This week he will meet the entire Republican leadership at a bipartisan lunch.
Of course, the desire for cooperation does not guarantee its accomplishment. Despite the optimism everyone offered today, his relations with Republicans, and Democrats, may end up badly.
Many Democrats are much more liberal than Mr. Clinton and may be suspicious of him if he is dealing seriously with Republicans. And most Republicans are much more conservative than he is. Beyond ideology, moreover, there is inherent constitutional tension between the two rival branches.
 
Dole's Rapprochement
 But Mr. Clinton appears to be counting on Congress's sharing his sense that government is on the defensive.
He may have a little bit of success to claim already, in the muted partisanship Mr. Dole displayed Sunday on the NBC News program "Meet the Press." The Kansan proclaimed himself interested in cooperating where he could and even offered the helpful thought that Mr. Clinton should not try to do too much in his first 100 days or else he could end up "on a reef."
There are two plausible motives behind Mr. Dole's shift, and neither is Mr. Clinton's charm. One is that Mr. Dole got a lot more criticism than he expected for his early pledge to block "awful" Clinton proposals and his insistence that he could represent the 57 percent of voters who did not vote for the Democrat.
The second is that Mr. Dole is happiest when he can legislate, when he can help forge a compromise that gets a bill passed. He did that on civil rights and unemployment compensation in 1991 but was frustrated by the Bush Administration's rejection of similar efforts regarding abortion counseling and fetal tissue research in 1992.
But if Mr. Clinton is going to try to legislate, Mr. Dole wants to be a player.
If they can deal from time to time, that will matter to Mr. Clinton's success not just because it will mean less Republican obstructionism in the Senate. If a bill in either house gets some significant share of Republican support, it becomes easier for conservative Democrats to support it, too. So even if dealing with Republicans means that some proposals have to be toned down a bit to get their support, the result may be that more of Mr. Clinton's proposals get passed.
The President-elect also offered hints of his legislative tactics in the news conference. Twice he stood firm on substance, and once he showed himself eager to compromise on process.
He praised Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee, for raising the important issue of personal privacy over the question of homosexuals in the military, but insisted he would not be deterred from ending the ban on their service.
He defended Senator Mitchell against a questioner's suggestion that the majority leader was not a full-fledged supporter of a middle-class tax cut, saying Mr. Mitchell worried about the deficit just the way he did. But he said Mr. Mitchell joined him in believing that fairness on the tax code was essential.
Finally, he embraced a substitute for the line-item veto he has advocated, saying the change was "functionally almost identical" to the procedure used in Arkansas. The substitute would enable him to force a separate vote on spending he considered unjustified.
That subject, incidentally, highlighted one of the major legislative problems he will face: the Senate.
The proposal is being pushed by Speaker Thomas S. Foley and eagerly backed by Mr. Clinton's associate from the Democratic Legislative Council, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader.
 
Avoiding Carter's Lead
 But Mr. Mitchell could commit himself to do no more than "review" the proposal. His style of leadership reflects the deference other senators expect, and in this case he was not going to step one inch out in front of Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the chairman of the Appropriations Committee and a critic of procedures intended to help the President thwart Congressional spending.
No one doubts that there will be clashes between Mr. Clinton and Congress. But this week's efforts are a notable contrast to the last time the Democrats had both the White House and the Congress in their control with a new President coming in. Sixteen years ago Tuesday Jimmy Carter had a group of Democrats down to meet with him at Lovejoy, Ga., and the retiring Speaker of the House, Carl Albert, did not bother to go.
This time they apparently discussed dozens of possible legislative issues, from economic stimulus to campaign finance. In 1976, they talked mostly about how much authority to give Mr. Carter to reorganize the Federal Government, and hardly at all about the recession that had helped put him in office or his other legislative plans. When the Democrats emerged and said they expected cooperation, they really did not know what they expected to cooperate on. In the end, they did not cooperate very much.

HEADLINE: Hanoi Backs Study To Trace M.I.A's

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Members of a Senate panel investigating the fate of Americans missing from the Vietnam War hailed what they said today was a new spirit of cooperation from Vietnam and suggested strongly that President Bush might soon relax an economic embargo against the Hanoi Government.
The comments by the senators followed a meeting in Hanoi with a senior official who pledged that Vietnam would provide "the clearest possible answers" to questions about the 2,265 Americans still unaccounted for. 
 "We are at a critical juncture," said Senator John F. Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat and Vietnam veteran who is chairman of the Senate Select Committee on P.O.W.-M.I.A. Affairs. "We are definitely on a road leading to normalization.
"It's my sense that the President may be in a position, if we get adequate cooperation and if we can speed this process up, to make positive moves with respect to the embargo. I think that the Government of Vietnam has made a decision to help us get answers."
 
Letter From Bush
 The embargo has barred United States investment in Vietnam, has discouraged other foreign investment and has prevented the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and other large international financial institutions from assisting Hanoi in rebuilding an economy that is only now beginning to recover from the war.
Senator Kerry said he was carrying a letter from President Bush to President Le Duc Anh. The Senator said he believed it was the first direct communication from a United States President to his Vietnamese counterpart since the fall of South Vietnam in 1975.
While Senator Kerry did not make the contents public, Congressional officials said they understood the letter made clear that President Bush, in his final weeks in office, was willing to move quickly to improve relations in exchange for further cooperation on the question of missing Americans.
Senator Hank Brown of Colorado, the Republican on the three-member delegation, said that "if there is a perception that we have had positive meetings this week, then you'll see the White House act" on the embargo.
 
The Pain of the Embargo
 Vietnam is eager to begin normal diplomatic relations with the United States and is desperate to see Washington lift the embargo, which was imposed against the North Vietnamese Government in 1964 and against all of Vietnam in 1975.
The Vietnamese are aware that they are operating against the clock -- specifically, they want Washington to lift the embargo before the transfer of power in the White House in January.
Vietnamese officials say their best of hope of ending the embargo quickly rests with President Bush, since President-elect Bill Clinton has already told veterans' groups that he feels no pressure to improve relations with Vietnam while there are unanswered questions about the fate of missing Americans.
Last month Hanoi announced that it would provide Defense Department investigators with full access to military museums and war archives.
 
Senate Report Due Soon
 Defense Department officials have described the announcement as a breakthrough in their efforts to determine what became of the Americans. The museums and archives are believed to hold thousands of artifacts collected from Americans -- as well as photographs of some of them -- after they were captured or killed in territory held by North Vietnamese forces.
Senator Kerry, Senator Brown and Senator Tom Daschle, a South Dakota Democrat, are representing the committee on a five-day tour of South Vietnam and Laos, the panel's last scheduled trip to Southeast Asia before it completes its work at the end of the year and submits a final report.
The Senators are expected to meet Tuesday with Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet and Foreign Minister Nguyen Manh Cam, and to tour military installations in Hanoi where Americans were once rumored to have been held.
In a meeting today with the senators, Deputy Foreign Minister Le Mai pledged that "any request, any question you raise, we will give the clearest possible answers."
 
20 Years Is 'Long Enough'
 "It has been 20 years now since the end of the war," he said. "That is long enough. That is why we should accelerate our cooperation."
The Senators also met with the senior officials directly involved in assisting the Pentagon in searching for information about missing Americans.
Although the meeting did not resolve the fate of any of the Americans unaccounted for, Senator Kerry said the spirit of conciliation may signal an important shift in Hanoi's policies. It was the first time the Vietnamese had opened such a meeting to reporters.
"This is the first time we've ever had a discussion in the open like this -- about substantive cases, about real facts," Senator Kerry said. "It's fair to say that the policies of Vietnam have changed. It's very, very welcome."
Senator Daschle said, "For the first time, they're as forthcoming as we could hope them to be."

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: The Economy;
Liberals Advise Clinton to Raise Deficit Spending

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
As President-elect Clinton shapes his economic plan, he has had plenty of counsel from supporters of Ross Perot, who are pressing him to cut the budget deficit sooner rather than later.
But today he got a heavy dose of advice from the other side, as a liberal-leaning commission appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York called for a generous dollop of increased deficit spending to lift the weak economy. 
 The commission, which included business executives, union leaders and economists, said cutting the deficit should take a back seat to getting the economy moving again, although it added that any plan to stimulate the economy should be tied to a long-term effort to trim the deficit.
Members said the panel formed in 1990 to prepare the report as a possible economic program for Mr. Cuomo if he ran for President in 1992.
The report is the latest to offer advice to the President-elect. But today's recommendations carry more weight than most because Governor Cuomo has considerable influence among Democrats and because several of the report's authors are prominent advisers to Mr. Clinton. Members of the panel include two men mentioned as possible Treasury Secretaries: Robert E. Rubin, co-chairman of Goldman Sachs, and Felix G. Rohatyn, an investment banker at Lazard Freres.
 
More Activcism Is Urged
 The commission urged the Federal Government to take a more active approach to revive the economy than Mr. Clinton has indicated he will take as President. It called on him to spend $50 billion extra on public works this fiscal year, far more than the $20 billion extra he suggested in the campaign.
Moreover, the report urged the Federal Reserve to play a far more aggressive role in spurring the economy, saying it should pump $20 billion in capital into the nation's banks to make it easier for them to lend money. But Mr. Rubin dissented from that proposal, saying it would be undue Government interference in business. The report noted that not every member supported every proposal.
The commission suggested that Mr. Clinton adopt an investment tax credit and invest $22 billion more a year in education and job training than the current budget.
"America is failing to invest," it said. "We are neither matching the investment of our competitors nor making the amount of investments we once made. If we allow this dangerous 'investment gap' to continue, it will undercut the capacity and productivity of our factories and stunt future economic growth."
 
Less Caution on Pump-Priming
 The panel, called the Cuomo Commission on Competitiveness, was less cautious about stimulus than Mr. Clinton, who worries that any hint that he will embrace increased deficit spending will frighten financial markets and push up long-term interest rates.
The report, titled "America's Agenda: Rebuilding Economic Strength," called for a $3 billion public employment program to create jobs for the poor, a one-year temporary cut in Social Security payroll taxes and $10 billion in emergency revenue sharing for states to use for investments in highways and other infrastructure.
"A package to stimulate investment is critical to get us out of the cyclical downturn and to build our long-term strength," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a commission member and an economics professor at the University of California at Berkeley.
To rein in the deficit, the commission proposed deeper cuts in the Pentagon budget than Mr. Clinton has suggested, raising income taxes to 38 percent for households earning more than $200,000 from the present 31 percent, and increasing taxes on Social Security benefits to the wealthy.
 
More Public-Private Research
 One major thrust of the report was for greater cooperation between government and business in numerous areas, including research and in building sophisticated technologies like high-speed rail.
The 28-member commission made several recommendations that Mr. Clinton has also proposed, including reducing capital gains taxes for investments in new businesses, placing a cap on health-care spending and establishing a manufacturing extension service that would help small businesses obtain new technologies. Like the President-elect, the Commission supports far greater spending for Head Start and job training.
This June, Mr. Cuomo surprised Mr. Clinton with a unilateral announcement that he had persuaded the Arkansas Governor to outline a legislative agenda in cooperation with the Democratic leaders of the House and Senate. The idea was for Mr. Clinton to show that he could end Washington's gridlock. Later in the campaign, however, Mr. Clinton strained to keep his distance from Capitol Hill.
The panel today called for Washington to work far more aggressively with other industrial nations to end the global slump.

HEADLINE: New York Slips in Medical Research, Study Says

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
New York City's competitiveness in biomedical research -- a segment of the health-care industry that provides thousands of highly paid, highly skilled jobs -- is eroding at a worrisome pace, according to a new study and government and private experts.
New York is still a national leader in the field, with private nonprofit medical schools and hospitals like Mount Sinai, New York Hospital, Albert Einstein and Montefiore and those at Columbia, New York University and Rockefeller University. 
 But the study found that the city's share of Federal money for medical research is shrinking. In addition, New York City is not attracting many private biotechnology companies, which in other regions are a growing source of research money though cooperative and licensing arrangements with hospitals and universities.
From 1987 to 1990, the metropolitan region's share of all grant money from the two main Federal sources fell from 9.7 percent to 9.1 percent, largely because the city's share slipped from 8.1 percent to 7.3 percent. While the actual dollar amount of the Federal grants to New York City rose during that period, to a total of $517 million, the shrinking share of the pie meant that by 1990 the Boston area surpassed the New York region as the top recipient of this Federal money.
As a result, the city's top-tier position in this type of research could be lost, the study says.
"That would take a decade, but it would take a decade to put anything meaningful in place to stem the tide," said John W. Rowe, president of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and the Mount Sinai Hospital and chairman of the group that commissioned the report. "This study should be an alarm both for leaders in the medical-research and health-care fields and for public officials."
The study was conducted for the New York Academy of Medicine's Commission on Biomedical Research and Development, a group formed in 1991 by research institutions, companies and state and local officials. The commission is exploring ways to enhance the city's competitiveness in biomedical research.
The study emphasizes the economic importance of biomedical research to metropolitan New York: It is directly or indirectly responsible for nearly 32,600 jobs, including 11,500 in research, and more than $2.3 billion in economic activity.
Barry F. Sullivan, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, echoed the concerns of the study and said the city was working on a strategy to help strengthen the sector. But he also contended that the ivory-tower attitude at medical centers, as well as government policies, are to blame for the sector's woes. "We've got great brains, great research going on and we don't translate it well into business and then into jobs in New York," he said.
Long Island, which has three times the number of biotechnology companies that New York City has, seems to be doing a much better job.
Commission members insist that aid from the state and New York City governments will be needed to strengthen the biomedical sector. The medical centers -- as well as biotechnology companies -- want financial help to build laboratories and offices, buy equipment and provide training and affordable housing for staff. They also want to create a new public agency to help new companies through the governmental maze.
Dr. Rowe said the city's institutions have been much less successful than those in San Francisco and Boston in obtaining money from an increasingly important source: biotechnology companies. Given the size of the city's research base, there are few established biotechnology companies with laboratories in the city: only 6 to 10. Industry of all kinds provided a scant 5 percent of the institutions' research money last year.
 
Share of N.I.H. Grants Falls
 The commission's study examined the two main types of Federal financing for biomedical research: grants from the National Institutes of Health and from the Alcohol, Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration. New York City's slumping performance in winning grants from the National Institutes of Health is especially worrisome because it indicates a decline in competitiveness. The city's share of N.I.H. grants fell to 6.8 percent in the year that ended Sept. 30, 1991, from 9.7 percent in 1980 and 10.4 percent in 1970.
Besides accounting for the vast majority of Federal research money, N.I.H. grants, unlike other types of Federal financing, are based mainly on competition among institutions, including a peer review.
Had metropolitan New York maintained its share of N.I.H. grants in the 1987-90 period, there would have been an additional 1,730 jobs in the city and 1,600 in the region in 1990, according to the study, which was conducted by Nancy Aries, a professor of public administration at Baruch College, and Elliott D. Sclar, a professor of urban planning at Columbia.
 
Need for Laboratory Space
 "If you want to be surrounded by first-rate scientists, you can now find that in New York, but it is not clear that you will a decade from now," said Mitchell L. Moss, director of New York University's Urban Research Center and an expert on the regional economy.
Commission members say one reason for the weakening of New York City's competitive position is inadequate laboratory space.
"Institutions in town have not developed new research space and facilities over the last 15 years at nearly the rate of Boston, Baltimore, San Diego, Los Angeles, San Francisco or even Birmingham, Ala.," Dr. Rowe said. "We are capital-starved."
The causes most often cited by medical centers include reductions in government financial support for research dating to the state and city fiscal crises of the 1970's; state restrictions on health-care reimbursements that were somewhat eased in 1990; the rising burden of caring for the poor, and the difficulty and high cost of building in the city.
Some executives of biotechnology companies say there is plenty of available space in Manhattan -- at old factories, for example. But while rents for it are low, the cost of turning it into laboratories makes it uneconomic, some say. They point to Long Island, whose biotechnology industry is three times the size of New York City's and growing faster, as an example of what the city needs to do.
Last month, the State University of New York at Stony Brook expanded its so-called incubator space for new high-technology companies, when it opened a 40,000-square-foot building. There is also a state research center for biotechnology at Stony Brook for fostering cooperation between companies and the university.
Institutions and the Federal, state and local governments are trying to expand research space in New York City. A $200 million biotechnology center at New York University is scheduled to open by next fall. Columbia just dedicated its $10 million Irving Center for Clinical Research and the university, along with the state and city governments, is financing a $30 million biotechnology incubator near Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan. Construction is scheduled to begin next spring.
But New York City's reputation as a tough place to live and work -- deserved or not -- also appears to be making it more difficult for research institutions to attract top-notch scientists, according to a survey conducted for the commission.
 
Barriers Remain
 Some scientists have also been discouraged by rules at their institutions that restrict the scientists' involvement in profit-making commercial ventures. As a result, some of the research centers are loosening those restrictions.
Some institutions now will exchange technology for an equity stake in a biotechnology company. Several are making it easier and more affordable for these companies to gain access to their scientists and labs and to use their hospitals for clinical tests. And institutions like Mount Sinai, N.Y.U. and Rockefeller University have hired specialists in commercializing discoveries.
The hope is these steps will make it easier for institutions to attract leading scientists who want to benefit financially from their discoveries and will accelerate the development of the city's biotechnology industry.
But barriers remain. And some wonder whether New York can catch up to places like San Francisco and Boston, which already have an abundant supply of technicians, scientists and laboratory space for start-up companies. Indeed, several start-up companies are using technology from New York University or Mount Sinai have chosen or intend to choose the Boston or San Francisco areas.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
CHANGES ORDERED IN POLICE MONITORING
Stung by an avalanche of criticism over police corruption and apparently flawed controls for rooting it out, Police Commissioner Raymond Kelly has ordered sweeping changes in his department's structure and methods for investigating and exposing corrupt officers. As part of the plan, Mr. Kelly said the Internal Affairs Division, the department's main anti-corruption unit, would be transformed into a full bureau, equivalent in the hierarchy to patrol forces and detectives. A1.
 
SHOWDOWN OVER SCHOOL CURRICULUM
In another round in their battle over whether to teach children about homosexuals, Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez has told a defiant Queens school board that its anti-bias curriculum still does not teach youngsters to respect gay people. He says he will send an emissary from his office to help the local board comply. B3.
 

AFTER A FIRE, CONCERN ABOUT CHEMICALS
City environmental officials have ordered the removal of a large stock of chemicals from a Brooklyn warehouse that was destroyed in a suspicious, five-alarm fire Sunday night. But they say the chemicals were secure in drums, not flammable or especially toxic, and posed no hazard to the surrounding Bushwick neighborhood. B3.
 
THE ART OF CONSENSUS
As the City Council continues to review Donald Trump's plans for a huge development on the Upper West Side, it has become clear that Mr. Trump still faces significant hurdles but enjoys a strong current of support among many members who see any large development in tough economic times as welcome news. B4.
 
REGION
 
SETTLEMENT IN AVIANCA CRASH
In its first public acknowledgement of any liability for the Avianca Airlines crash on Long Island that killed 73 people in 1990, the Federal Government has joined Avianca in a preliminary out-of-court settlement intended to apportion financial responsibility in the crash. Lawyers involved in the case say the settlement is important because in the past, the Federal Government has generally argued that it is not a party to lawsuits stemming from air crashes, even though most of the nation's air traffic controllers are Federal employees. B6.
 
FOUR DEFENSE LAWYERS, FOUR ANGLES
Although the four defense lawyers in the Glen Ridge sex assault trial are working as a team, when they take on prosecution witnesses, each attacks from a different angle. For the jury, that means that cross examination by the defense drones on, burying in a sea of words the points and images that prosecutors have elicited from the witnesses. And some defense themes, principally the young woman's sexual past, have become drumbeats before the jury. B6.
 
THE POWER OF THE AIRWAVES
Stunned by an outpouring of support for the New Jersey Network's preservation as the voice of the state and the realization that turning it over to another operator would be fiscally unsound, the New Jersey Assembly has voted overwhelmingly to scuttle a plan to abandon the television system and has restored most of its financing. HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Clinton Faces Deflation Worries

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
GLEAMING, frostless refrigerators are a staple in millions of American homes. So are modern cooking ranges, dishwashers and air-conditioners. Yet the prices of these ubiquitous household appliances have been falling since 1989, reversing a decades-old trend toward higher prices -- and creating one of the pockets of deflation that keep appearing in these hard times.
Deflation can be dangerous. Nothing so characterized the Great Depression as the phenomenon of falling prices, falling real estate values and falling wages, snowballing across the nation. The pockets of deflation that exist today are only a shadow of that 1930's experience, and almost certain to remain so. But they are helping to gradually reshape the national outlook. 
 "There has been a certain resurgence in fond memories of inflation," according to Richard T. Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's Consumer Research Center, whose polls go back to the late 1940's, the last period of noticeable deflation. "Our surveys show that the kind of animosity that we have had toward inflation in the past decade is weakening at the edges. People are starting to associate more inflation with more jobs and greater wealth."
That association might be helpful to President-elect Bill Clinton. His prescription for reviving the economy involves more spending on public works projects and tax credits to encourage companies to invest in machinery. Both are steps that in the past have increased the Federal deficit. Deficit spending, in turn, often increases inflation -- a no-longer-so-unhappy prospect, if the polls are accurate.
Whatever the case, deflation is certainly a discussion topic in the Clinton camp, Derek Shearer, an adviser to the President-elect, said. Because some prices have fallen, the nation's annual inflation has been a very mild 3 percent or less in recent months. "Business people that we deal with bring up deflation all the time," Mr. Shearer said.
Presumably, these business people include manufacturers of steel, paper, chemicals, oilfield equipment, aluminum, copper, printed cotton cloth and shipping cartons. All have suffered from falling prices since the late 1980's, according to the Labor Department, which tracks price changes. Even car manufacturers, which always seem to raise prices, have gotten a whiff of deflation in new car prices over the last 12 months.
In some cases, such as chemicals and paper, prices rose sharply until 1989 because demand exceeded supply and, to fill all the orders, plants operated at full capacity. But as these industries opened new plants, the United States economy fell into the long period of recession and slow growth that still endures. As demand has evaporated, the scramble for orders to keep the new plants busy has forced down prices, and as prices have fallen the companies have cut costs -- through layoffs, staff attrition and wage freezes.
Similar labor cost-cutting is common in the home appliance industry, although deflation there has different causes. Five major manufacturers compete for sales at a time when the weak economy has curtailed home construction and also home remodeling, once major sources of sales.
"We have become pretty much a replacement industry," Marian Stamos, a representative of the Association of Home Appliance Manufacturers, said. "And people nowadays resist replacing their appliances until repairs become too expensive."
The most dangerous deflation involves real estate values -- primarily office buildings where high vacancy rates have driven down rents and building values. Unable to repay loans, many building owners defaulted. Similarly, deflation has made many families reluctant to keep up mortgage payments. Why pay off a $130,000 mortgage to own a house whose resale value has declined to, say, $115,000 from $145,000? And, in fact, mortgage defaults have risen in the Northeast and in California, where home price deflation has been greatest.
Such defaults in the 1930's brought on bank failures that wiped out the savings deposits of many Americans. Wages also fell, making loan payments ever harder to pay. To raise cash, there was panic selling of homes and businesses, and that made prices fall even more. Deflation spread.
None of these things are happening now. Wages are stagnant, but for most Americans they are not falling. More important, deposit insurance, bank bailouts and other Federal programs have made the Government, in effect, the custodian of buildings and other assets that in the 1930's were so hurriedly sold.
But deflation, confined as it is today, clearly has delayed a recovery. Falling prices destroy wealth and prompt companies and consumers to cut back. "The mandate that the Clinton Administration has," said Donald Hilty, a Chrysler Corporation economist, "is to stop deflation."
