HEADLINE: Trump's Riverside West Plan Appears to Be Gaining Favor

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
As the City Council continues to review Donald J. Trump's plans for a huge development on the Upper West Side, it has become clear that Mr. Trump still faces significant hurdles but enjoys a strong current of support among many members who see any large development in tough economic times as welcome news.
Mr. Trump will have to make some concessions in the $3 billion Riverside South project to win Council approval, Council aides said. Council members have raised questions about whether the city's sewage plant in western Harlem can absorb the 1.3 million gallons of sewage the project will produce each day. Some advocated asking the developer to build a small plant on the 56-acre site, a requirement Mr. Trump insists would kill the project.
 
'Movement for Jobs'
 Influential lawmakers are also seeking a public authority to oversee construction of the office and apartment complex, which is expected to take more than 10 years, as well as the creation of a public entity to manage the park, which will be built inside the development. 
 But under most of these worries ran the current of support, especially among members outside of Manhattan. Council leaders said they expect to reach a compromise with Mr. Trump on most of the sticking points before the full Council must vote on the plan on Dec. 17.
"My sense of the moment is that there is a desire to see a movement for jobs in the city," Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey of Queens said Friday.
 
10,000 More People
 If approved, the project would generate, on average, nearly 2,700 construction jobs a year at a time when the real-estate industry is moribund. Mr. Trump plans to build two office towers of up to 25 stories and a necklace of 16 apartment buildings between 18 and 49 stories on a gentle curve along the Hudson River. The West Side Highway would be moved inland to follow the curves of the buildings and would run under a new extension of Riverside Drive. The site stretches along the Hudson from 59th Street to 72d Street -- the site of the old Penn Central Rail Yard.
With nearly 7.9 million square feet of commercial and residential space, the project would increase the population of the area by 10,000 people, who would live in 5,700 apartments. Along the river a park of 21.5 acres would be built.
Gaining approval from the Council -- the final step in the review process -- is always a game of satisfying the needs of certain members in crucial positions, and the project's future hinges on whether Mr. Trump can give those members what they want without hurting the development's economic viability, opponents of the project and political strategists said.
One pivotal member is C. Virginia Fields of Harlem, the chairwoman of the Subcommittee on Permits, Dispositions and Concessions, which was reviewing the project yesterday. Ms. Fields represents the neighborhood that has been most affected by odor problems at the North River Waste Water Treatment Plant, which is where the Riverside South sewage would flow.
The Harlem Council member has said she would support the project only if Mr. Trump builds a sewage plant on the site. "There are major problems with that sewage plant and it has not been fixed and now we are talking about exacerbating the problem," she said Friday.
But the city's Environmental Protection Commissioner, Albert F. Appleton, testified yesterday that the plant could easily absorb the extra sewage because the city's water-conservation program has significantly reduced the flow coming into the sewage tanks and will save far more water over the next 10 years.
Stanley E. Michels, who represents upper Manhattan, grilled Mr. Appleton during the hearing until the commissioner acknowledged that he could not guarantee that the water-conservation steps the city was taking would solve the odor problem.
Mr. Trump threatened to abandon the project should the Council insist on a sewage plant within the complex. "It's a total deal breaker," he said yesterday.
Another pivotal lawmaker is the chairwoman of the Land Use Committee, June M. Eisland of the Bronx. Ms. Eisland, whose committee must approve the project before the Council takes it up, has made it clear she will not support the Trump project unless a public authority is established to oversee its construction.
Ms. Eisland is also angling for stronger assurances that Mr. Trump will contribute $7 million in the early years of the project toward the construction of rail yards along the Harlem River in the Bronx.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
A Good Deed With Its Own Epilogue

BYLINE: By Andrew H. Malcolm

DATELINE: POUND RIDGE , N.Y.

 BODY:
IT seems to have started with a Russian massacre that followed a dispute over ownership of a bunch of dead otters. Then, 208 years later, came a dinner party in Boston. Nancy Freiheit, a teacher from here, was sitting next to David Brown, a lawyer from Hartford who is intrigued by archeology.
Suddenly, there's a flurry of activity in the basement over at the Hiram Halle Library in this affluent rural Westchester hamlet. The next thing this mail pilot up in Alaska knows, he's got so many heavy boxes for one isolated fishing village. But Emily Capjohn is delighted. 
 This story will never make the front pages or the evening news ("This just in: Authorities are puzzled by an unidentified band of adults roaming the suburbs doing selfless things for distant people they'll never see because it makes everybody feel fine for a few moments and might also cause some lasting good, although no one is certain. Film at 11.")
Now, reconstructing a good deed, just for fun, is, surprisingly, sometimes as difficult as tracking down a culprit. Oh, that! everybody says. Well, that's just something that happened, you know, like constructive spontaneous combustion. Every finger points at somebody else. Nobody saw anything unusual. Nobody did anything unusual. Why are you asking all these questions?
Maybe in the end that's what we should remember now and then; that amid all the fearful finger-pointing, the frustrated shouting and the useless hand-wringing about all the things wrong around us, there's usually a whole lot of good going on quietly, too.
Anyway, here's what we've dug up: In 1784, according to Czarist documents, the Russians arrived, the Russians arrived, by Old Harbor, Alaska, an isolated island hamlet nearly 300 miles southwest of what became Anchorage.
The Russians thought that because of their large guns they should have ownership of a treasure trove of furs there. The natives disagreed, with their spears. Hundreds of natives died. In the eloquent oral tradition of northern peoples, the story has been passed down over 11 generations.
Now, the local native association is financing a Roots-type exploration of the massacre site. One volunteer last summer was Mr. Brown, a 49-year-old native of suburban Chicago who now lives in suburban Hartford. For the last two years he's been so fascinated by archeology and Alaska that he's read nearly 20 books.
That's what you do in his written culture when you want to learn. You read a book. The Browns often take their two children to the local library, where the librarian treats the youngsters' interests and curiosity with the utmost seriousness, as if reading provides individual empowerment.
One night in Old Harbor Mr. Brown was looking for a good book. He sought directions to the library. Well, they said, actually, there isn't one. Back in '64 the tidal wave washed everything away. Then, 15 years later a fire destroyed the new one.
Life in Old Harbor (Population 300 to 350, depending on the tides, migrating fish and the economy) is still based on harvesting natural resources. Virtually everyone has something to do with fishing and the sea, which, with all roads ending at the town limits, remains the main highway to anywhere. But Kodiak city is only seven hours by boat.
Rick Berns, the part-time Mayor and fisherman, said Old Harbor had a library room ready near the health clinic, but no money for books.
Since his return, Mr. Brown has hustled good books big-time. He told Mrs. Freiheit who told Marilyn Tinter, the library director here. "It's hard to imagine a community without a library," she said. Mrs. Tinter oversees a book sale every two months when volunteers like Jackie Rodney, Gloria Smith and Ginny Powers peddle surplus and donated books. Edith Waters, who is 93, guards the till ($804 last weekend). It all helps an institution that gets only 28 percent of its $193,000 budget from government.
One afternoon Mrs. Freiheit and Mrs. Tinter rummaged through the storage room. That night Mrs. Freiheit weighed books on her bathroom scale. The next morning three boxes -- 170 pounds of words, maps, history, photos, stories and dreams -- left for ZIP code 99643. The book-rate: $48.18.
"Books," says Mr. Brown, "are wonderful symbols. So intimate and personal -- and cheap! -- to share." He thinks the lives of children will be touched by these very books. And perhaps such book-sharing among strangers will prove contagious, touching more little lives and recreating the warmth Mr. Brown feels on these chilly nights.
In Old Harbor, where it's down to 20 these days, Ms. Capjohn, the new librarian, actually has something to catalogue now. She reports big boxes of books have begun arriving. "We appreciate it so much," she says. "They're just wonderful. Please tell everyone."

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Oil Prices Stage a Recovery As Colder Weather Is Seen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil futures prices snapped back yesterday, erasing last week's losses in a rally prompted in part by expectations that colder weather will raise heating oil demand.
In trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil for December delivery rose 29 cents, to $20.37 a barrel; December heating oil surged 1.07 cents, to 58.9 cents a gallon; December unleaded gasoline jumped 1.25 cents, to 54.86 cents a gallon, and December natural gas fell 1.2 cents, to $2.411 for 1,000 cubic feet. 
 "We're beginning to see renewed interest in heating oil as we approach this colder weather," said Gerald Samuels, managing director in Los Angeles of ARB Oil Inc., a New York-based energy trading company.
Crude oil had dropped more than $2 a barrel and heating oil had fallen about 9 cents a gallon since Oct. 9 on signs of increased crude production by OPEC, despite the sluggish world economy.
The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is scheduled to meet next week. Oil prices are likely to rise if the organization agrees to trim its output, so this would be the week for speculators to try to push crude prices down to find the market's bottom, Mr. Samuels said.
Coffee futures soared on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange on news that Brazil, the world's largest producer, was moving closer to a plan for an orderly release of stockpiled coffee onto its internal market.
Coffee for December delivery leaped 3.3 cents, to 72.5 cents a pound.
Wheat futures prices rose to a five-month high on the Chicago Board of Trade as the Bush Administration pressed ahead with its aggressive program to subsidize exports of the grain. Other grain and soybean futures retreated amid profit taking after last week's across-the-board gains.

HEADLINE: October Output Rose 0.3%, Reversing Summer Decline

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
After a slump last summer, industrial production perked up in October, helped by a large gain in light-truck manufacturing, the Federal Reserve said today.
Output at factories, mines and utilities rose a modest three-tenths of a percent last month, only the second increase in five months. Output had fallen two-tenths of a percent in September and three-tenths of a percent in August. 
 In another positive sign, the Commerce Department said business inventories were up only slightly in September after rising a revised two-tenths of a percent in August. The August figure was initially reported as a gain of three-tenths of a percent. Stocks of goods held by businesses in September stood at $837.31 billion, compared with $836.97 billion in August. Business sales jumped 1.3 percent, reversing a 1.3 percent decline in August.
 
No Shift Toward Hiring
 The combination of rising sales and flat inventories bodes well for factory production, economists said. But they cautioned that the figures indicated that industrial growth was still far from strong.
The industrial sector "has to be considered feeble," said Robert G. Dederick, an economist at the the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "Gains of this size are not adequate to bring us employment gains in manufacturing."
Factories laid off 56,000 workers in October, but the workweek and overtime hours for existing employees increased. If the economy continues to improve, factories will be pressed to start rehiring -- but the question is when.
Some analysts were disappointed that much of October's rise in production was in light trucks, which were assembled at an annual rate of 4.4 million units, up from 3.8 million the month before. Automobiles were assembled at an annual rate of 5.5 million, unchanged from September.
Excluding autos and trucks, overall industrial production rose just a tenth of a percent.
Manufacturing in October rose three-tenths of a percent. A decline of five-tenths of a percent in output by utilities offset an increase of five-tenths of a percent in mining, which includes oil and gas production.
Within manufacturing, the output of durable goods -- big ticket items expected to last three years or more -- rose seven-tenths of a percent. Areas showing gains besides light trucks included computers and furniture. Appliance production fell.
Nondurable goods were unchanged over all. The weak points were chemicals, rubber, plastic products and textiles. The production of petroleum products rose.
 
Few Inflation Concerns
 The various changes left the Fed's index of industrial production at 109 percent of its 1987 base, only six-tenths of a percent higher than a year ago.
October's production gain caused a small increase in the operating rate at industrial concerns. It rose from 78.4 percent of capacity in September to 78.5 percent last month. The rate was far below the 85 percent level that economists say often means an increase in inflation.
In a third report today, the National Association of Realtors said the ability of the typical American family to purchase a home jumped in the third quarter to the highest level in 18 years. The trade group's affordable housing index rose from 119.4 to 127, meaning the typical family had 127 percent of the income needed to purchase a median-priced home.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Renewed Gains On Stronger Economic Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar resumed its rally yesterday, rising on the heels of fresh reports pointing toward a reviving American economy.
Gold prices declined in domestic trading after rising overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $333.90 an ounce, off $1.40 from Friday. The Republic National Bank said gold slid $1.20, to a late bid of $334.50. 
 Analysts said the dollar's advance began late Friday after the Government reported the nation's money supply had expanded in the recent week. An increase in money supply tends to portend a strengthening economy.
Dollar-buying was strong when foreign markets opened yesterday and it carried through when trading shifted to the United States.
The dollar was supported by a report showing industrial production rose three-tenths of 1 percent in October after slumping through much of the summer. A separate and equally favorable report showed business sales rose in September and the backlog of unsold inventories was unchanged.
"The dollar is resuming its uptrend," said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. "We've had some very good news -- money supply, industrial production. The market was looking for it."
Among individual currencies, the Japanese yen was under pressure from speculation that Japan's monetary officials were about to reduce interest rates. In Britain, the pound was weak after comments by the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Norman Lamont, that Britain must first have an economic recovery before it could rejoin the European Exchange Rate Mechanism.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 124.25 Japanese yen from 123.84 yen at Friday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 124.80 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 124.70 yen, up from 124.05 yen on Friday.
In London, the pound fell to $1.5185, from $1.5510 late Friday. In New York, a pound cost $1.5245, down from $1.5505 on Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.5915 German marks, up from 1.5725; 1.4365 Swiss francs, up from 1.4190; 5.2645 French francs, down from 5.3055; 1,357.00 Italian lire, up from 1,344.00, and 1.2713 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2644.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.5920 German marks, up from 1.5665; 1.4380 Swiss francs, up from 1.4135; 5.3615 French francs, up from 5.2815; 1.7891 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7615; 1,357.00 Italian lire, up from 1,338.50, and 1.2698 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2636.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $335.75 an ounce, from $334.40 late Friday. In Zurich, gold was up to $335.25 from $334.95. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold gained $2.67 to close at a bid of $336.92.

HEADLINE: Fleet Down After Report

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 16

 BODY:
Shaes of Fleet Financial Group Inc. fell as much as 4.4 percent today after a CBS television broadcast reported charges that its mortgage lending practices in Georgia were intended to profit at the expense of minority homeowners.
"We take strong exception to their charge we actively seek to foreclose on mortgage holders," said Thomas Lavelle, a spokesman for the bank holding company. "Also, the charge we prey on lower-income people is simply untrue." 
 CBS reported the allegations Sunday on the "60 Minutes" news program. It interviewed homeowners and their lawyers who accuse Fleet of charging low-income customers exceptionally high interest rates on second-mortgage loans, controlling outside mortgage companies that canvassed minority areas for customers, and foreclosing on borrowers who missed even one payment.
Fleet faces two class-action lawsuits tied to the charges. The "60 Minutes" report said the suits had a total of more than 20,000 plaintiffs, and could cost Fleet $500 million to $1 billion.
Shares of Fleet opened today at $30.50, down $1.125, on the New York Stock Exchange and sank as low as $30.25 before rebounding. The stock closed at $31, down 62.5 cents, on volume of 454,100 shares.

HEADLINE: 'Cleaner' Dry Cleaning Test

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
"I would like to air some dirty laundry to the press," William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, told reporters at a news conference today. And he meant it.
Mr. Reilly was the first Federal employee to drop off a few dirty clothes at a local dry cleaner that is participating in a test of a new cleaning method based on biodegradable soaps instead of the harmful chemicals normally used to dry-clean clothes. 
 In turning his blue suit over to agency officials, Mr. Reilly inaugurated a four-week experiment intended to cut down on the use of the standard dry-cleaning agent, per-chloroethylene, which is a hazardous air pollutant. The agency is sponsoring the experiment along with two trade groups, the Neighborhood Cleaners Association of New York and the International Fabricare Institute of Maryland.
The widespread use of perchloroethylene, or Perc as it is more commonly known, has contaminated underground water, apartments and restaurants situated next to dry cleaners. Perc residue also remains on clothes after they are cleaned.
The new process relies on heat, steam pressing, biodegradable soaps and water, said Ohad Jehassi, an economist with the environmental agency.

HEADLINE: A U.S. Spy Satellite May Be Sold Abroad

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
THE United Arab Emirates is shopping in the United States for a spy satellite, raising tough new questions about the intersection of economic and national security needs at a time when military contractors are hungry for work after the cold war.
The deal would have an American company make, launch and operate the orbiting spy craft for the emirates. Federal officials, who have wrestled with the proposal for a half year, is said to be bitterly divided on its merits and has not yet issued an export license. 
 "The dilemma," said John E. Pike, head of space policy at the Federation of American Scientists, a private Washington group, "is how to promote exports and American jobs without creating new military threats abroad. It's going to be one of the most challenging issues of the decade."
A Federal official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the Government was carefully considering the risks and benefits of the proposed sale, which might run to several hundred million dollars.
 
National Security Issue
 "There are a number of folks who are not opposed to this kind of thing in principle," the official said. "But it's situational. It depends on which country, the conditions of sale and a number of related factors bearing on the security of the United States."
Private experts said the bid by the emirates, reported yesterday by Space News, a weekly trade publication, and confirmed by Federal officials, was the first of its kind to be disclosed publicly.
Yesterday, an official at the emirates Embassy in Washington said he had "no information" about the spy-satellite sale.
As to why the emirates might want such a satellite, Dr. Peter D. Zimmerman, a reconnaissance expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a private group in Washington, said the nation might want to share the imagery with its Arab allies, but he judged it as having little direct military usefulness for the small nation.
Mr. Pike of the science federation agreed. "It probably comes down to a calculation of what is going to enhance their status more in the Arab world," he said, "buying another squadron of jet fighters or being the first kid on the block with a spy satellite."
One issue in the emirates' initiative, American experts say, is whether blocking the sale might simply send the oil-rich Persian Gulf nation shopping elsewhere, and whether it would be better to strike a deal that enabled the United States to retain some control over reconnaissance imagery produced by the spy craft.
 
Concerns About Deal
 But some military planners fear that any deal could eventually endanger the nation's security, both militarily and economically. The emirates, they say, might quietly sell the imagery to an American enemy or devote itself to monitoring oil refineries, tankers, and wells abound the globe in search of a marketing edge.
Space News, based in Springfield, Va., said that more than six months ago an unnamed American company applied for an export license for a new spy satellite on behalf of the emirates, throwing Federal intelligence and export officials into conflict. The proposed spacecraft, the publication said, would be able to resolve, or "see," objects on the ground about a meter, or three feet, in diameter.
By contrast, the most powerful commerical satellites in the world, made by the French, have a resolution of 10 meters. Moscow recently starting selling spy photographs that have two-meter resolution, one sample photograph showing cars in a Pentagon parking lot. The best American spy satellites are said to be able to see objects as small as a baseball, although such claims have been disputed.
Space News said Federal officials in the departments of State, Commerce and Defense, as well as the nation's intelligence agencies, were currently deadlocked on whether to give the proposed deal a go-ahead, and suggested that the dispute would probably be passed for resolution to the Clinton Administration.
"It's a first as far as I can tell," Dr. Zimmerman said in an interview.
"Now we have to decide whether it's a technology we want exported to other countries," he added. "My own feeling is that it isn't. The potential for use contrary to the interests of the Unites States is too high."
 
Worth Hundreds of Millions
 The commercial sale of spy satellites could open up a lucrative new market for American industry. Mr. Pike estimated that a one-meter spy satellite might sell for several hundred million dollars, including launching costs.
If the actual sale is approved and an export license granted, the Space News article said, quoting Federal officials, the two governments would negotiate a set of agreements "restricting the emirates' use of the satellite for intelligence purposes" and prohibiting the Persian Gulf nation from selling the data commercially.

HEADLINE: Clues Etched in Bone Debunk Theory of a Plague's Spread

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

 BODY:
AMONG human bones from pre-Columbian America and Europe, scientists are finding distinctive scars, some like the patterns in worm-eaten wood, that could be decisive clues in one of the enduring mysteries of medical history: Where did syphilis originate, and how and why did it erupt with epidemic virulence in Europe at the end of the 15th century?
The latest clues are etched in bones discovered in the cemetery of an ancient Greek colony in southern Italy. These bones, and two other skeletons examined recently in England, could be the first unequivocal evidence of the presence of the organism causing syphilis in Europe before Columbus. 
 Strong circumstantial evidence had long placed the blame mainly on the crews of Columbus and other explorers of the New World. Since the first clearly recognized cases in Europe occurred soon after their return, it was assumed that they had contracted the infection through sexual intercourse with American Indians and then spread it back home.
If the Columbian connection is correct, this was a kind of rough justice, considering the terrible toll European diseases like smallpox, measles and influenza took on the immunologically defenseless Indians.
An opposing hypothesis holds that syphilis originated in early human evolution and so existed in some form in populations worldwide. In this view, the venereal disease had been in Europe all along, but was perhaps confused with leprosy. A convergence of social and economic trends, more than returning sailors, presumably accounted for the spreading European epidemic by 1500.
The weight of evidence in recent years had tipped the scales in favor of the Columbian hypothesis. Examination of thousands of skeletons from prehistoric burial grounds in the Americas revealed the marks of bone lesions showing that the infection causing syphilis must have been common and widespread there long before 1492, though it probably manifested itself in milder, non-venereal forms like yaws.
By contrast, similar research on European skeletons, even those from leper cemeteries, had failed to turn up any unambiguous traces there of the disease before the return of Columbus.
But now the cemetery in southern Italy has produced evidence that is certain to re-ignite the controversy. Specialists in the science of paleopathology said many of the skulls, nasal and leg bones and teeth showed the characteristic ravages from the class of bacteria called treponemes, which when transmitted sexually leads to syphilis.
The cemetery, discovered in an olive grove near the ancient town of Metaponto, occupied by Greeks from 600 to 250 B.C., was excavated by Dr. Joseph C. Carter, a classical archeologist at the University of Texas at Austin. Analysis of what the skeletons reveal of the colony's health was conducted by Dr. Maciej Henneberg and Renata Henneberg, anatomists at the University of Witwatersrand in Johannesburg.
In a report published last week in the journal National Geographic Research & Exploration, the scientists said their results contradicted the arguments in favor of the New World origins of syphilis and supported the pre-Columbian hypothesis. The initial reaction of anthropologists was one of surprise and caution.
"I would need to see for myself what they are describing," said Dr. John W. Verano, an anthropologist at the Smithsonian Institution.
Dr. George J. Armelagos, a physical anthropologist at the University of Florida in Gainesville and a leading proponent of the Columbian hypothesis, praised the Hennebergs as careful paleopathologists. "It is a puzzlement," he said of their findings.
But Dr. Donald J. Ortner, another Smithsonian anthropologist, who has just returned from examining two skeletons in England, said the Hennebergs' results should not be surprising in view of what he had found. He said the two skeletons, dating from before 1420, contained the kind of bone damage caused by treponematosis, a group of allied diseases including syphilis and yaws. Some of the skull lesions are "classic syphilis" evidence, he said.
"More and more evidence is coming in indicating that treponematosis was in Europe before Columbus," Dr. Ortner said yesterday. "I've argued for a long time that it ought to be in Europe, and it was just a matter of finding it."
 
Yaws and Syphilis
 The mystery has been complicated by the fact that the treponomal organism that causes syphilis is indistinguishable from the organisms responsible for yaws. The same bacterium somehow causes different symptoms depending on how it is acquired. Only syphilis is sexually transmitted. Yaws is a chronic childhood infection spread by casual contact and causing long-lasting sores on the legs and arms. In time this infection attacks the bones, leaving scars similar to those from syphilis.
Though most attention has focused on the history of syphilis, Dr. Ortner said, "A far more interesting question is why what appears to be a single organism results in different pathogenic processes."
The case for the American origin of treponematosis gained wide backing four years ago when Dr. Armelagos and Dr. Brenda J. Baker, now at Tufts University, published the results of an extensive survey of skeletal material from both the New World and the Old. They cited research showing unambiguous cases of treponemal infection in South American bones from 3,000 to 4,000 years old. By at least A.D. 600, the disease was widespread in North America. At the time, no similar skeletal evidence had been identified anywhere in Europe.
 
A Possible Reconstruction
 So Dr. Armelagos developed a possible reconstruction of what happened. If the disease in America was mainly contracted in childhood, the people would be immune to it by the time they reached sexual maturity. They would not have passed it to each other during sexual intercourse, but could have with Europeans having no such immunity.
This could explain the outbreak of syphilis in Naples in 1495 among the mercenary soldiers of Charles VIII of France. Some of those soldiers were presumably Spanish who carried the infection brought home by Columbus's men. Even then, the disease's origins were disputed, the French calling it the Italian disease, others calling it the French disease. It reached all the way to India in 1497, borne by the Portuguese explorers, and soon was so prevalent in Europe that in France it was said that noblemen who did not carry syphilis were scarcely noble. Syphilis remained a notorious plague until the introduction of penicillin in the 1940's.
Dr. Alfred W. Crosby, a University of Texas historian and author of "The Columbian Exchange: The Biological Consequences of 1492," said most scholars tended to accept this Columbian hypothesis in which syphilis was "the only disease of significance" to be transmitted from America to Europe.
According to the pre-Columbian hypothesis, however, syphilis was already in Europe, probably misdiagnosed as leprosy. Even the biblical term "leprosy" could have referred to syphilis. King David suffered from shooting pains and his "loins are filled with a loathsome disease." He suspected Bathsheba.
 
272 Individuals Studied
 In this interpretation, the sudden outbreaks of syphilis at the end of the 15th century occurred because of increasing travel around the continent and papal edicts closing the leper asylums. Patients who might be carrying the syphilis infection were thus released, spreading the disease. Physicians also began to recognize syphilis as distinct from leprosy.
The cemetery at the Metaponto site may have tipped the scales back toward the pre-Columbian hypothesis. Dr. Carter said the cemetery's 320 virtually undisturbed burials were the "largest sampling of human skeletons in one place from the ancient Mediterranean" societies. Previous excavations in the region had concentrated on architectural ruins.
In their analysis of the remains of 272 individuals, the researchers said they found the clearest evidence to date of malaria in a classical population. Although artifacts suggest that Metaponto was a prosperous agricultural colony of Greeks, the people appeared to have been plagued with anemia and malnutrition. They were small of stature and at birth had a life expectancy of 32 years.
In literary accounts, Dr. Carter said, "Metaponto was famous for its medical school, the quality of its doctors, but archeology seems to contradict this." The researchers found several skeletons of people who had suffered severe bone fractures that had healed naturally without any apparent attempt to set them.
 
Early Malpractice Suit?
 These unset bones, the researchers concluded, could explain the curses inscribed on lead tablets in one tomb. The inscriptions denounce by name no less than 15 local doctors, just possibly an early medical malpractice suit being appealed to some higher court in the hereafter.
Among the skeletons the Hennebergs found 16 cases of thickening of the skull, a discorder associated with treponematous infections of long duration. In seven cases, these characteristics coincided with scars on long bones, also evidence pointing to treponematosis. The high frequency of tooth enamel defects, the scientists said, indicted that many of the people had become infected in the womb or in early childhood.
"We are sure of our findings," Dr. Henneberg said in an interview by telephone from South Africa. "But we cannot tell whether the infection was venereal or not, whether any of the cases were syphilis or something non-venereal like yaws."
Dr. Henneberg held out little hope of arriving at a more definitive diagnosis. The pits and eroded areas on the bones seem to be virtually the same for syphilis and yaws. The ultimate test, he said, would have to be provided by a direct immunochemical analysis of antigens extracted from the bone. Such tests are unlikely to succeed, he added, because in these diseases little antigen is present in the bones and what there is decomposes after death and during the centuries in the soil.
"As long as all we've got is bone deformations, I don't think we are getting anywhere in solving the origins of syphilis," a disappointed Dr. Crosby said. "I was hoping the molecular biologists were going to solve it for us."
Dr. Armelagos, however, plans to give it a try this winter in molecular biological tests on ancient bones from the Americas, where the scourge may -- or may not -- have originated.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Columbus-era sailors returning from the New World are often blamed for European syphilis. Recent discoveries in a pre-Columbian cemetery in Metaponto, Italy, suggest otherwise. Researchers open a tomb there. (National Geographic Research & Exploration) (pg. C8)
 
Map/Drawings: "Paths of Trade And Exploration: Paths of Disease Transmission"
 
New Discovery in Europe's Past
Although a consensus was developing that the origin of syphilis was in the Americas, a recent excavation of bones in a Greek cemetery at Metaponto in southern Italy suggests that the disease did afflict inhabitants of the Old World before Columbus, leaving telltale lesions on their skeletal remains. The bones include 16 skeletons with thickening of the skull, characteristic of infection of long standing with the bacteria that cause syphilis.
 
Confused diagnosis?
In medieval Europe, the symptoms and transmission of leprosy were inaccurately described and, some researhcers contend, many leprosy cases may have actually been syphilis. Thus the course of syphilis in Europe may have been camouflaged.
 
Epidemic in Europe
Increasing numbers of people living in cities and traveling and other demographic factors were kindling for the epidemic that erupted in Europe after Columbus returned. During 15th century wars, French and Neapolitan troops each branded the disease with the nationality of the enemy.
 
American Origins?
There is ample evidence that pre-Columbian Indians suffered from infection with bacteria called treponemes, which when transmitted sexually cause syphilis. But the evidence suggests that it was not a venereal disease, but a childhood illness, spread by casual contact, like yaws, so that by the time Indians reached sexual maturity, they already possessed immunity.

HEADLINE: The Economy Still Needs a Prod

 BODY:
With an uptick here and a rosy look there, the economy gives faint signs of revival, raising sensible doubts. If things are looking up, should the new Clinton Administration continue to plan for a temporary burst of Federal stimulation? The answer, in a word, is yes; the signs of revival may be, in a word, false.
A year ago the economy was staggering along, threatening to plunge back into recession. Short-term spending hikes and tax cuts seemed like a sensible way to ignite recovery without worsening the long-term deficit. 
 As summer neared, unemployment mounted. With no relief in sight, many people started calling for stimulus, including Michael Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. Had President Bush listened, he might be looking forward to a second term.
That was then. But today the economy seems to display some faint pink signs of dawn. Growth during the third quarter, according to preliminary estimates, reached an annual rate of almost 3 percent. In October, retail sales rose at double-digit rates, and first-time jobless claims fell.
But the data are all murky, even deceptive. Take, for example, the surprising 3 percent growth estimate. The figure appears exaggerated, for technical reasons having to do with the way the Government corrects for inflation. Besides, consumers are unlikely to be sustaining their high recent spending, and businesses could be expected to reduce factory orders to work off sizable inventories.
As a rule of thumb, growth must exceed 4 percent for two years to knock even one point off the unemployment rate, now 7.5 percent. With a true 3 percent nowhere on the horizon, the need for stimulus endures.
There's no reason for Bill Clinton to be doctrinaire about it. If the fourth quarter shows a dramatic turnabout, he could slow down on his promised jobs program and go on to his long-term program without detour. But if this fourth quarter is, as most experts expect, disappointing, then he would continue to be wise to press Congress for a modest stimulus package.
His advisers are discussing a $60 billion package -- temporary spending hikes for accelerated infrastructure projects and temporary tax cuts on business investment. A package of that size, about 1 percent of economic output, poses no danger of over-igniting the economy or, because it is self-liquidating, running up the deficit.
The prudent course is to prepare Congress to pass a stimulus package, tied to long-term deficit reduction, immediately on its return in January. The need today, still, is to light the fire.

HEADLINE: Short-Term Stimulus? Long-Term Error.

SERIES: Bill's List

BYLINE: By Steven Rattner; Steven Rattner is a general partner of Lazard Freres & Company, investment bankers.

 BODY:
The country has just endured a wrenching recession, modest growth has resumed but employment remains stubbornly high. The nation rejects its President in favor of a voice for change. With inflation seemingly under control, the new occupant of the White House announces a formidable $30 billion program to stimulate the economy.
Sound familiar? That's what happened in 1976 when Jimmy Carter replaced Gerald Ford, with results that are still all too poignant. The parallels for Bill Clinton are clear. While our economy needs lots of attention, new Government spending or tax cuts should not be allowed to further increase the enormous budget deficit. Even as a Democrat, I can't justify more stimulus -- including lower interest rates -- on the basis of the economic news from Washington. 
 Despite much talk of America's collapsing economy, by virtually every statistic the recessionary decline ended in the first half of 1991 and the economy has been climbing ever so slowly since then. Pick almost any sign -- retail sales, industrial production, consumer debt, even the number of jobs -- and it's better than 18 months ago.
In the past several weeks, the number of new applicants for unemployment insurance dropped to the lowest level in more than two years, suggesting improvement in the labor market. The gross domestic product rose faster than expected in the third quarter; it's now above the pre-recession peak. Even bank lending and consumer confidence, two of the weakest indicators, are turning upward.
However pathetic America's economic performance during the past four years, we shouldn't confuse short-term solutions such as stimulus with long-term problems such as weak productivity and investment. Fiscal stimulus is like an efficacious medication with side effects. It often takes so long to enact, even with a new President, that it arrives just in time to help reignite inflation -- as it did for Jimmy Carter.
The prospect of fiscal stimulus already has the financial markets on edge; long-term rates, the surest barometer of inflationary fears, have gone up by a half percentage point in the past two months, a meaningful rise.
And even the most temporary additions to the budget deficit have a nasty habit of becoming permanent. Today's deficit, equal to more than 5 percent of economic activity, is two and a half times the level of the 1970's and more than five times the rate of the 1960's. While the fragility of the economy argues for not trying to shrink the deficit quickly (as Ross Perot would do), longer-term reduction will be unattainable if we don't hold the line now.
But digging in doesn't justify doing nothing. The budget and tax system need reform badly. Increasing taxes on the richest 2 percent -- an increase in the top rate to 36 percent from 31 percent and a 10 percent surtax for millionaires -- would raise $13 billion to $18 billion a year, according to Mr. Clinton's numbers. That money could, in turn, finance modest middle class tax cuts and a targeted investment tax credit to raise investment, currently at the lowest level in 30 years. Selected defense cuts -- such as not rebuilding Homestead Air Force Base in Florida, for an immediate saving of $500 million -- could pay for improvements in transportation, information and environmental facilities. Ideally, these trade-offs should rely on market forces rather than bigger Government -- more investment tax credits than federally funded research and development, for example.
But so long as the trend of modestly positive statistics continues, initiatives must remain trade-offs and not become add-ons. At recent press conferences, including yesterday's, Mr. Clinton has suggested programs to restart growth but has left unstated -- apparently deliberately -- the likely impact on the deficit.
To be sure, he faces risks in not attacking short-term problems; there's more than a passing chance that the economy will slide back, and if he is perceived as having done little, he's likely to slide with it. That's what did in George Bush. But for Bill Clinton, focusing on long-term economic problems like investment and productivity would be the true act of leadership.

HEADLINE: Social Workers: Targets in a Violent Society

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON

 BODY:
A released convict, angered because his daughter was placed in foster care, pursued a social services worker to her farmhouse near Auburn, N.Y., last year and beat, bit and strangled her.
Last month in Watkins Glen, N.Y., a truck driver infuriated by child support payments killed four women working in a county welfare office and then turned his gun on himself. 
 And earlier this month in Danielson, Conn., in yet another attack on a social service worker, an auto mechanic embroiled in a custody battle shot and killed his 6-year-old daughter and badly wounded the caseworker supervising his visit with her.
Across the New York region and around the nation, experts say that social service workers are increasingly at risk of violent assault. At least eight workers have been slain by clients in five years.
Hundreds of others have been assaulted as they work the front lines between desperate clients and a government they believe has caused their problems or cannot solve them.
"We're constantly getting reports of violence," said Jordan Barab, who tracks working conditions in public offices for the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. "Every time somebody gets killed, I get calls from around the country about social service workers getting beat up and attacked."
And workers fear that publicity about attacks will breed even more violence. In Baltimore, where a man enraged by delays in getting food stamps drew a butcher knife and killed a receptionist last year, callers have since threatened to "take out more of you social workers."
Ever since Jane Adams braved Chicago's tenements, social service workers have been at some risk, and until recently, there has been little awareness that the dangers were mounting. As a result, there has been no nationwide system for reporting attacks on them. But union officials, academics and other experts say the violence is increasing.
Most of the recent victims have been women, reflecting a larger epidemic of work-place violence against women. According to a recent study by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, the leading cause of "traumatic work-place death" for American women is homicide.
A number of reasons have been offered for the increase in violence. The ranks of those seeking public assistance have been swollen by mental patients released onto the streets in recent years. Clinic-based psychiatric social workers now routinely face clients who previously were confined to high-security mental hospitals.
Another cause is the changing nature of cases at welfare offices. Men who owe child-support payments are confronted by newly aggressive efforts to track them down. Social workers are being asked to deal with increasingly volatile issues in family disputes, particularly in child-abuse cases. Aggravating the problem is the recession, which has forced welfare cutbacks as need has grown.
"Social work gets more dangerous every year," said William Griffin, an adjunct professor of social work at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Mr. Griffin said he had been called in on about 75 assault cases around the country since he began counseling government agencies in 1985 about how to respond to such attacks.
 
'Yelling in the Wind'
 "Many incidents get little attention," Mr. Griffin said. "I'm one of the few people who is collecting this information, and sometimes I feel like I'm yelling in the wind."
In fact, others are beginning to document the violence.
A 1,400-worker division of Kentucky's social services bureaucracy reported 225 threats and physical attacks last year, including 15 in which victims required medical attention. In one recent incident, a father accused of sexual abuse brandished a .357 Magnum during a meeting with caseworkers. In another, an assailant with a shotgun took a worker hostage, said Richard Newman, a branch manager in Kentucky's human resources agency.
"Our people have been kicked with cowboy boots, threatened with Coke bottles, poked with umbrellas, bit on the ears, grabbed by the hair and smashed into desks," Mr. Newman said.
 
Small Towns, Too
 A California report documented 58 cases during 1990 in which workers were struck, stabbed, beaten, or shot and 16 other cases involving other forms of physical assault.
It is not just a big-city problem, as Watkins Glen learned when the four workers were shot to death on Oct. 15. Since then Sheriff Michael J. Maloney has stationed two deputies in the county building where the workers were shot to death. Sheriff Maloney said he had also received requests for protection at "other offices that deal with an irate public," including family court and the local tax assessor. Several other New York counties, including Cayuga, Chemung and Yates, have installed metal detectors and deployed additional deputies to guard social services offices since the October shootings.
In Yates County four days after the Watkins Glen killings, James T. Wallace, a father angered by efforts to collect child support, threatened to carry out a similar massacre.
"He implied that the same thing could happen in Yates County if people didn't leave him alone," said Ron Spike, the Yates County Sheriff. Mr. Wallace was arrested on Oct. 26, charged with aggravated harassment and released on $10,000 bond, Sheriff Spike said.
In Orange County, the impetus for increased security came in March, seven months before the Watkins Glen killings, when a client stabbed a caseworker, Linda Char, in the face and chest, said a county spokeswoman, Joanne Stricko. Ms. Char, who survived the attack, has continued her career.
A major factor heightening the danger has been the growing number of child-abuse complaints that social workers must investigate, as a result of a 1974 child protection law. The number of abuse reports nationwide has quadrupled from 669,000 in 1976 to 2,694,000 in 1991, according to statistics provided by the American Humane Association, a Denver-based group.
These investigations often require caseworkers to confront parents about abuses, and such cases can result in "an explosion of anger and energy," said Robert Van Marle, a social worker who was shot through the stomach and kidney in 1985 in Darby, Mont., by an indignant rancher he was questioning about reports that he had abused his 8-year-old daughter.
 
'When You Meddle'
 "People have less of a grip on who they are today, relative to traditional values, and they're more volatile," Mr. Van Marle said. "And when you meddle in family abuse questions, you're stirring up a hornet's nest."
Circumstances like these appear to have spurred the murder last year of Sabina Kulakowski, who worked for the Cayuga County, N.Y., social services department. After caseworkers investigated reports of violence and removed the 7-year-old daughter of Roy Brown to a foster home, Mr. Brown phoned county offices threatening to "spray" workers with Uzi rifle fire to "wipe everybody out."
The authorities taped the threats, and Mr. Brown was arrested and jailed for six months. Five days after his release in May 1991, Ms. Kulakowski, 49, the county's day care coordinator, was followed to her farm home and stabbed, strangled and beaten until her skull was crushed. Her murderer burned her house down.
The police matched human bite marks covering Ms. Kulakowski's body with Mr. Brown's jaw, and Mr. Brown was convicted of the killing in February. Sentenced to 25 years to life, he has appealed.
"It's difficult to imagine a more brutal murder," said James Vargason, the Cayuga County District Attorney, who prosecuted Mr. Brown. Though Ms. Kulakowski personally never had any dealings with Mr. Brown, Mr. Vargason concluded that Mr. Brown killed her as a way of taking revenge on the county bureaucracy.
A family dispute was behind the Nov. 2 shooting in Danielson, Conn., that left a 6-year-old girl dead and a caseworker, Joyce L. Lannan, 36, seriously wounded in the head. Diego M. Vas, a 40-year-old mechanic locked in a custody battle with the mother of his child, pulled a pistol during a court-ordered visit, shooting Ms. Lannan and his daughter, who died. Ms. Lannan was blinded in one eye in the attack.
Another factor contributing to the mounting violence has been the mass deinstitutionalization of mental patients, according to LeRoy G. Schultz, professor of social work at West Virginia University, in Morgantown.
 
An Obsession
 In February 1989, David Smith, a 26-year-old homeless Air Force veteran, charged into a Los Angeles County clinic and fatally stabbed his psychiatric social worker, Robbyn Panitch, 31 times with a knife.
Mr. Smith, who had been convicted in 1987 for assaulting his own mother, developed an obsession that Ms. Panitch, 36, was the Antichrist, and Ms. Panitch, fearing an assault, had ordered him committed for hospital evaluation. But the authorities -- who at the time were shutting down 13 county mental health centers and laying off hundreds of social workers because of budget cuts -- ordered Mr. Smith released days before the fatal attack.
Two months after Ms. Panitch's murder, another Los Angeles County psychiatric social worker, Shirley Ann Sauerwein, was stabbed five times by the mental patient she was counseling. She returned to work after being treated for a collapsed lung.
Edith Pollach, a colleague of Ms. Panitch, who recently retired as president of the local union that represented Los Angeles County psychiatric social workers, said budget cuts had greatly increased the perils of social work.
"Dangerous people are released because there is not enough money to confine hem," Ms. Pollach said.
Money troubles have also aggravated the dangers in other social service settings, as welfare clients, angered by cutbacks and delays in receiving public assistance, have become increasingly aggressive.
In June 1991, Arnold Bates, a 34-year-old food stamp applicant in a Baltimore welfare office, fatally stabbed a caseworker, Tanja Brown-O'Neil.
Ms. O'Neil's grieving co-workers were dismayed by the harsh public reaction to her death.
"We got no sympathy from the public on this," said Donna Edwards, president of Maryland's Social Services Employees Union, to which Ms. O'Neil belonged. "We got callers who said: 'We got one of you. Now we're going to have to take more of you social workers out of there.' It was as if we had caused this incident because we were treating people badly."

HEADLINE: An Extra $2 Billion a Month, Thanks to Lower Mortgages

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Early next month, Robert E. Pearson Jr., a 45-year-old advertising executive, and his wife expect to close a deal to replace the mortgage on their suburban Milwaukee home with one at a cheaper interest rate. The transaction has induced the Pearsons to unzip their wallets: about $6,000 worth of new furniture now graces their living room and family room.
"We feel we made the right move," said Mr. Pearson, who took out a larger mortgage, but at a lower rate, to give his family extra cash to pay down debts and buy new furniture. "We feel psychologically more comfortable." 
 Over all, according to a Federal Reserve Board estimate, American consumers will enter the new year with an additional $2 billion each month in their pockets as a result of savings in 1991 and 1992 from refinancing their mortgages or from the lower rates on their adjustable-rate mortgages.
 
More Consumer Spending
 The savings are helping support recent upturns in consumer spending, which during the July-September quarter bounded ahead at a 3.4 percent annual pace after being virtually unchanged during the spring.
"People find out they've got more dollars left" after paying the mortgage, said David Seiders, economist for the National Association of Home Builders.
But alone, they are not enough to spur a lackluster economy for several reasons. Lyle E. Gramley, chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, reckons refinancing and lower rates on adjustable mortgages to be roughly equivalent to a $50 billion tax cut, big enough to matter but a tiny fraction in a $6 trillion economy
Since incomes have not rebounded as much as spending, the upturn presumably has come from tapping existing assets or from lower mortgage payments. With interest rates tumbling over the last two years, touching levels not seen in two decades, millions of Americans have renegotiated mortgages or are in the process of doing so. There's nothing like an upturn in rates, like the half-point rise since Labor Day, to cause a stampede among the holdouts.
 
Paying Off Debt
 Morever, an even larger number of additional households have benefited from automatic cuts in adjustable-rate mortgages, a portion of these of the home equity variety.
Yet, as the Pearson household helps illustrate, not all of those savings find their way into cash registers. Some people are putting the new-found money in the bank while others use it for another kind of savings -- paying off accumulated debt.
The refinancing by the Pearsons involves trading a $117,000 mortgage at 9 percent for a $132,000 mortgage at 8 percent. Normally, specialists say, refinancing pays only when the new rate is at least two points below the old one, but in this case the family had an additional desire for cash. While many people are shortening the maturity of their mortgage, often to 15 years from 30, the Pearsons already had a 15-year mortgage and made no change.
Besides buying the furniture, the Pearsons are using the $15,000 of cash to repay some high-rate credit-card debt, to pay off bills from their daughter's wedding, to send some money to their son at West Point and to buy a snow board and a few other items.
Still, economists caution, mortgage-interest savings alone cannot fuel a recovery.
One reason is that low interest rates produce losers as well as winners. For instance, tens of millions of people's livelihoods depend to one degree or another on certificates of deposit, Treasury bills and other interest income, which has shrunk as interest rates have fallen.
Another is that the nation's households, though paying off more old obligations than they took on in most recent months, remain heavily indebted. Debt service during the Bush Administration is still a higher proportion of disposable income than in any Presidency in over a generation.
"We've got debt overloads all over the place," Mr. Seiders said, referring to governments and corporations as well as consumers.
Low rates have long been assumed to encourage people to borrow, both by cutting the cost of financing new purchases and cutting the burden of existing debts whose terms can be renegotiated. But with rates having fallen so far, so fast, many consumers are now also motivated to spend rather than save money, since it may now earn only 2 3/4 percent at a bank, versus perhaps three times that much a few years ago.
But as recent history shows, low interest rates are not enough by themselves to spur a lackluster economy.
 
Jobs and Income
 "The primary factors are always the fundamentals -- income and employment," said Jeffrey M. Humphreys, director of the Selig Center for Economic Growth at the University of Georgia. "These are the essential building blocks of confidence" that lead consumers, who account for two-thirds of economic activity, to spend.
And though first-time jobless claims have dwindled of late and the nation's jobless rate has edged down for four straight months, reaching 7.4 percent in October, it's not yet proved that the job market is on the mend.
Without this, recovery will almost certainly founder, contended Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist for Midland Montagu Securities in New York.
"It is employment growth that drives confidence rather than debt repayment and restructuring," he said, "since even with smaller debt service charges and greater housing affordability, consumers are unlikely to increase spending if their jobs are threatened or eliminated."

HEADLINE: U.S. Hopes to Broaden Ban on Arms Sales to Iran

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The United States is to meet Friday with six of its closest economic partners in an attempt to persuade them to halt sales of all militarily useful equipment and technology to Iran, Administration officials said today.
But in preliminary discussions, the Bush Administration has already met considerable resistance from its allies, who are eager to increase trade with Iran. In addition, the United States has pressed for the plan at such a low level that none of the allies have taken it seriously. 
 Another obstacle is that the United States itself does not completely ban all sales to Iran's military establishment. If Iran's military wanted to buy certain laptop computers, for example, it would be able to do so without approval from Washington.
The meeting, at an undisclosed location in Europe, is to include representatives from Britain, France, Italy, Canada, Japan and Germany. It will represent the first time that the countries, known as the Group of Seven, will specifically discuss such exports to Iran. Although Iran will be the main focus, the seven will also discuss such sales to Libya, Iraq and North Korea.
Richard A. Boucher, the State Department spokesman, said today that the meeting was part of the Administration's effort to "harmonize export controls among major industrial nations with regard to Iran." He added that the United States will "be talking to other governments about the need for the kind of strict export licensing on Iran that we have already."
Since the beginning of the year, the United States has unsuccessfully tried to persuade its allies to halt sales to Teheran of equipment that could be put to military uses. The goal of the initiative, first reported last week in The Washington Post, is to prevent Iran from buying and producing both conventional arms and so-called weapons of mass destruction, which include ballistic missiles and chemical, biological and nuclear weapons.
Three senior Administration officials presented the initiative last month to officials during an unpublicized trip to the six nations.
 
Rejection by Tokyo
 In a statement Friday, Japan expressed its reservations about the plan. "We cannot agree 100 percent with the United States because our ties go a long way back and are different from Iran-United States relations," Foreign Minsiter Michio Watanabe said at a news conference.
Even Administration officials have reservations. "The initiative has no bite," said one official who closely follows the issue. "It's being done at a low level and there's nothing in it to convince the allies why they should give up such a lucrative market."
Washington's concern about Iran's military buildup drew a response today from Iran's President, Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, who told a group of Revolutionary Guards that the West was trying to alarm Iran's neighbors, thus encouraging them to buy more weapons.
"Western powers and their news media state that Iran is seeking military dominance in the region through the purchase of advanced weapons," Iran Radio quoted President Rafsanjani as saying. "In fact, they try to alarm the regional countries in order to sell them more weapons and try to prevent the strengthening of cordial ties between Iran and these countries."

HEADLINE: Trade Pact May Have To Wait

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The Mexican Government has stopped pushing for a quick adoption of the North American Free Trade Agreement, amid signs that the new Clinton Administration will want to deal first with the domestic economy.
After initially seeking a resolution of the outstanding issues by next March, Mexican officials now say they are prepared to discuss President-elect Bill Clinton's objections to the pact whenever and wherever he wants. 
 Some Congressional Democrats are also reluctant to confront the international issue early in the next term if problems like the sluggish economy and joblessness persist. At the same time 121 new members of Congress are still sorting out their views on the free-trade agreement by Mexico, the United States and Canada.
 
Eventual Passage Still Seen
 "A lot of the members who have been elected are more nationalistic, and a lot of the Democratic members are closer to labor," which has opposed the agreement, said Representative Robert T. Matsui, Democrat from California, who is a senior member of the Ways and Means Committee's trade subcommittee.
He added, however, that he still eventually expected passage of legislation putting the pact's provisions into American law.
Mr. Clinton mentioned at a news conference last Thursday in Little Rock, Ark., that reviving global economic growth was one of his top foreign policy goals, and that he hoped to achieve it partly by "resolving outstanding matters with Mexico." But Mr. Clinton has said little else about the agreement, and has conspicuously not mentioned it in describing his early priorities.
 
Commission Taking a Look
 Democrats said that a Clinton Administration was likely to take a much closer look at the probable effects of the free-trade agreement than did the Bush Administration, which has relied primarily on private-sector studies and economic theories of free trade in advocating prompt Congressional passage of legislation that would put the agreement into law.
Congress in the final days of the last session instructed the International Trade Commission, a bipartisan Federal agency independent of the executive branch, to conduct a lengthy review of the pact and make a report next year.
The six-member commission began three days of hearings today in its main hall, which is remarkable for its pink walls, pink ceiling beams and even pink chairs. Exporters favoring the agreement alternated testimony with importers who fear further competition from Mexico if the pact takes effect. The agreement would reduce tariffs and other trade barriers across North America.
Arnold Delin, the executive director of the Atlantic Apparel Contractors Association, said at the hearing that the agreement would devastate the small sewing companies in Pennsylvania that his trade group represents. The pact would allow large clothing companies to ship American-made fabric to Mexico, pay low-wage workers there to sew it into garments and then ship the finished apparel back to the United States free of import taxes, Mr. Delin said.
The result will be cheaper clothes for American consumers, but possibly fewer jobs for American workers. "We have been betrayed by our own Government," Mr. Delin said. "Why us? We are American citizens."
But Rodney C. Schonland, the manager of trade and regulations for the Polaroid Corporation, told the commission that his company would ship more instant film and instant cameras to Mexico from the United States instead of Europe if the pact took effect.
Polaroid, which has its headquarters in Cambridge, Mass., currently uses plants in Europe to produce half of its products for the Mexican market, because the European operations are better organized for printing boxes and instructions in languages other than English. But this difference would be more than wiped out by a provision in the free-trade agreement that on Jan. 1, 1994, would eliminate all Mexican import taxes on instant photographic equipment from the United States and Canada, Mr. Schonland said.
The hearings have attracted an eclectic group of trade lawyers, academics and association presidents. Participants include such obscure groups as the Broom Manufacturers Tariff Task Force, which is angry that the agreement will rapidly eliminate the nation's 32 percent import tax on Mexican brooms.
Mr. Clinton has staked out a middle ground on the free-trade pact's merits. In a speech in Raleigh, N.C., on Oct. 4, the President-elect said that he would not renegotiate the pact. But he also set seven conditions that would have to be met before he would sign legislation putting the pact into law.
Three of the conditions require further negotiations with Mexico. The main two involve the strengthening of trilateral labor and environmental commissions already set up by companion texts to the free-trade agreement. Mr. Clinton also wants stricter rules for temporarily reimposing tariffs or quotas if imports suddenly surge.
The other four conditions, involving such matters as the use of Mexican immigrants to break strikes in the United States, can be met with Presidential orders or acts of Congress, without Mexico's consent.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: Visit to Washington;
Clinton to Take Walk in the 'Real City'

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Bill Clinton visits his new hometown this week to meet with President Bush at the White House and Congressional leaders on Capitol Hill, dine in Georgetown salons and sleep at the elegant Hay-Adams hotel in a two-bedroom suite that commands a view of the Executive Mansion.
But as rich as the visit will be with the trappings and symbolism of official Washington, it will depart from the traditional for at least two hours on Wednesday afternoon, when the President-elect will journey to Georgia Avenue, the commercial spine of a large proportion of the city's black neighborhoods. 
 Before he heads to the avenue in Northwest Washington, Mr. Clinton is scheduled to meet for an hour with the incumbent President he defeated. Aides to Mr. Clinton said today that the meeting would be an open-ended courtesy call between the two men. Hillary Clinton is scheduled to tour the White House with Barbara Bush on Thursday.
On Wednesday evening, the Clintons will attend a fund-raising reception for the Children's Defense Fund at the National Building Museum and dine at the home of Vernon E. Jordan, the prominent Washington lawyer who is heading the President-elect's transition operation. After meeting with Congressional leaders on Thursday, Mr. Clinton will attend another dinner at the Georgetown home of Pamela Harriman, a Washington hostess who is an influential figure in the Democratic Party.
 
Going Beyond the Bubble
 But Mr. Clinton is apparently making an effort to reach beyond the secure Presidential bubble that usually limits Federal officials to areas of Washington that are dominated by monuments.
The worn stretch of Georgia Avenue that Mr. Clinton will visit -- a combination of working-class residences and businesses that include a West Indian restaurant, a Korean-owned liquor store, a Chinese take-out restaurant and a beauty salon owned by a black woman -- is probably as far away as the President-elect can get psychologically from official Washington.
"It's the first time in my life a national figure has come here," Tony Mondy, a 32-year-old civil engineering student at the University of Maryland, said today as he waited for a bus on the avenue.
"It's a pretty good neighborhood," he added. "You hear a lot of things about Washington and black people and violence going on. But people here are hard-working. They're trying to make a future for their kids."
 
New Role, New Emphasis
 As Mr. Clinton moves into a new role, even his simplest decisions have acquired a political veneer. He is to fly to Washington on a chartered Boeing 727 instead of the usual military plane, and he has decided to stay at a hotel instead of at Blair House, the 14-room residence across the street from the White House where dignitaries usually are lodged.
His aides said today that both decisions were made to save taxpayer money, but in the end, Mr. Clinton's accommodations will actually cost more because of the additional Secret Service protection that will be needed to secure a commercial hotel.
Mr. Clinton is expected to spend little time at his hotel, and his visit to Georgia Avenue may be his best effort to showcase what he likes to present as his informal side and to demonstrate that he will not lose touch with the people who elected him.
 
Rewards of Support
 It is also an elaborate political payback to Charlene Drew Jarvis, the area's representative on the District Council.
Mrs. Jarvis, whose name has hit the rumor circuit as a possible Clinton appointee, spent much of her time campaigning for Mr. Clinton and barely won re-election to her council seat. On election night, she was in Little Rock instead of Washington.
But Mrs. Jarvis chose to cast the visit in other terms, calling it "a demonstration of his intention to know who his neighbors are."
"I'm going to be standing there right by his side," said Mrs. Jarvis. "And my ward will just be deliriously happy."
For Mr. Clinton's scheduled one-block stroll, Georgia Avenue will be closed off for three blocks around, and a flatbed truck will be brought in to accommodate reporters, photographers and camera crews. On the street today, Secret Service agents with hand-held radios patrolled the area .
But in a neighborhood that has seen its share of disruption -- merchants regularly arm themselves against incursions from open-air drug markets nearby -- the imminent arrival of the President-elect caused little stir today.
 
'He Can Make a Big Change'
 "I voted for him, so I must think good of him," said Shirley W. Webb, a tire shop owner who plans to shake his candidate's hand today. "God has everything in control anyhow, but if he walks in the steps of the Lord, he can make a big change."
Yun Kwon Chong, whose father owns Hamilton Beverage, applauded Mr. Clinton's visit. "He wants to get in touch with the public," he said.
Bernadine Carey was washing her customer's hair and keeping an eye on the soap opera flickering on her black-and-white television when a visitor to her storefront beauty salon asked whether she would be excited to meet the President-elect when he strolls by tomorrow.
"I put it like this," she said, shrugging as she adjusted the flow of warm water. "He's the President, but it's not something to be all bent out of shape about. He's just another man."
Bina Avery and Felix Yeoman are loan analysts for a commercial revitalization office that has, with the help of city and Federal money, financed facade renovations along some of the more tattered areas of Georgia Avenue. They first learned of Mr. Clinton's visit when Secret Service agents knocked on their door first thing this morning.
Mr. Yeoman said he voted for Mr. Clinton because he thought the Republicans were out of touch and that small-business development financing would be more likely to increase under a Democratic administration.
"Even in the last days of the election, the Republican Administration was saying there wasn't a recession just because of a minor increase in the gross national product for the final quarter," said Mr. Yeoman. "They gave the impression that they didn't know people were hurting out there."
But not everyone in Washington is sure that Mr. Clinton's trek into the real city will accomplish all that is necessary.
Courtland Milloy, a columnist for The Washington Post who invited Mr. Clinton to "a ride on the welcome wagon" for a tour of the city, compared the President-elect's visit to Jimmy Carter's inaugural walk down Pennsylvania Avenue or Mikhail S. Gorbachev's impromptu leaps into Washington pedestrian traffic during summit visits.
"I guess it'll be a good gesture," Mr. Milloy said today. "Gorbachev popped out and made a big splash by jumping out and pressing a little flesh, but it's not the same as getting to know people. And you know what happened to him."

HEADLINE: U.S. Says Greek Shipping Lines Are Violating Yugoslav Embargo

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
United States officials said today that companies based in Greece are major violators of the world economic embargo against Yugoslavia and that the Bush Administration has privately complained to the Athens Government about its apparent willingness to tolerate the offenses.
President Bush was to raise the topic today in a meeting with Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis of Greece. Mr. Mitsotakis said later that he had assured Mr. Bush that Greece was complying with the embargo. 
 Mr. Bush and Mr. Mitsotakis met one day after the United Nations approved new sanctions against Serbia and Montenegro, the two republics that now make up Yugoslavia, that were designed in part to discourage violations of the embargo by Greek companies.
Administration experts, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Greek tankers have recently transported 450,000 barrels of oil to Serbia. Some of the tankers unloaded their cargoes in Bulgaria for shipment to Serbia and others unloaded in Montenegro.
As recently as Friday, one official said, a Greek-owned tanker was in the Adriatic seaport of Bar, Montenegro, unloading caustic soda, a critical product in the oil-refining process.
On Friday, the United States delegate to the United Nations, Edward J. Perkins, took the unusual step of publicly identifying one Piraeus, Greece shipping firm, Thita Tankers Company S.A., for violating sanctions in the oil and caustic soda trade.
He said the Thita Triton and Thita Volcano made several deliveries of those products to Bar. Egyptian and Italian tankers also had shipped embargoed products to Bar, he said.
Some officials suspect the Athens Government has not only tolerated the smuggling but encouraged it.
"It is certainly true that Greek ships and Greek companies have been centrally involved in violations of these sanctions," a Congressional expert said in an interview today. "But it's difficult to say the Greek Government is encouraging these shipments with a wink and a nod."
But other officials said the violations of the embargo are so blatant that it is inconceivable the Athens Government is unaware of them.
