HEADLINE: Money Fund, C.D. Yields Are Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit are slightly higher than a week ago at 20 leading banks nationwide but mixed in the New York area, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.
Analysts at The Monitor said that the number of banks raising rates was just slightly larger than those lowering rates. 
 New York-area bank money market rates were down slightly, in contrast to the slight increase at 20 large banks nationwide. And while rates on certificates of deposit were unchanged in New York, they were modestly higher nationwide.
At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills on Monday, average discount rates rose for the sixth consecutive week. The auction is often regarded as the harbinger of how banks will set their deposit rates in the weeks ahead.
The average rate at auction for a three-month bill rose 3 basis points, to 3.13 percent from 3.10 percent, while the six-month bill rose 6 basis points, to 3.37 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
The combined New York area average for yields in the latest week showed the average money market account down a basis point, to 2.77 percent, with three- and six-month C.D.'s unchanged at 2.85 percent and 3.01 percent, respectively.
Outside the New York market, yields at 20 large banks moved higher, with an average money market account up a basis point, to 2.67 percent, and a six-month C.D. up 2 basis points, to 2.96 percent.

HEADLINE: With a Crackle, Religion Enters G.O.P. Meeting

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FONTANA, Wis., Nov. 17

 BODY:
At the close of a gathering here in which the nation's Republican governors spent two days pledging harmony and a "big tent" of inclusion, a testy exchange between two Southern governors today underscored the topic that is at the core of the party's internal struggle: the role of religion.
At a news conference concluding the meeting of the Republican Governors Association, a reporter asked the governors whether they could succeed in holding together a diverse conservative coalition without alienating the religious right. 
 "There's reasonable ground that most us agree on," replied Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina. "And so we don't seek to divide. We may have differences and debate on the individual issues, but not on the general philosophy of this party." He spoke of "the big tent," a term Republicans have used to describe the diverse coalition that formed to elect Ronald Reagan and then President Bush.
But then Gov. Kirk Fordice of Mississippi, a staunch conservative who is opposed to abortion, took issue with the questioner.
 
A 'Christian Nation'
 He said the question "seemed to infer that there is a demise of Christianity in America," adding, "I totally reject that."
Mr. Fordice went on to say: "The United States of America is a Christian nation, which does not in any way infer at any time that religious intolerance or any kind of particular dogma is being forced on anyone else. It just is a simple fact of life in the United States of America."
The Governor also said that "the less we emphasize the Christian religion the further we fall into the abyss of poor character and chaos in the United States of America."
Governor Campbell then strode to the platform and said: "The value base of this country comes from the Judeo-Christian heritage that we have, and that is something we need to realize." He added that a study of history showed that "the foundation of the country" was based on "a Judeo-Christian heritage."
 
Make That 'Judeo-Christian'
 When Mr. Campbell returned to to his spot on the dais next to Mr. Fordice, he said, "I just wanted to add the 'Judeo' part."
Mr. Fordice responded tartly, "If I wanted to do that I would have done it."
The debate came after governors went out of their way during the conference to talk of diversity and sought to publicly shed the image of division that emerged from the Republican National Convention last summer.
 
Beginning in Harmony
 The convention was widely seen as having been controlled by religious conservatives, but the struggle that resulted was set aside for more than two months as Republicans tried to salvage Mr. Bush's re-election hopes. But now that Mr. Bush's fate is sealed, the party's warring factions seem about to resume the battle.
There are three factions: The Christian right, the party's economic conservatives and an emerging group of moderate Republicans. The latter group wants the party to soften its strict social conservatism and find a new appeal for blue-collar Democrats, other conservative Democrats and young people -- the groups that helped form the Reagan coalition in the 1980's.
But until the final news conference today, the governors had shown restraint about allowing the struggle to come into public view.
During the meeting, Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts, who typifies those in the new moderate group, was not ready to directly repudiate the Rev. Pat Robertson, a leader of the Christian right. At the opening session of the meeting, Governor Weld said: "A lot of these pundits are running around saying Pat Robertson's captured the Republican Party. I don't think he's captured the Republican Party. He hasn't captured me. I'll tell you what, I wish him well."
But Mr. Weld added, "Over the next four years that diversity approach is probably a healthy thing for the Republican Party."
Then, in what was probably an indication of the simmering tensions that boiled over today, Mr. Fordice said: "Dr. Pat Robertson is a good friend of mine. He certainly doesn't have control of this party, but he represents Christian people who are rather strong in this country. They feel like they ought to have a voice. And he's a part of our party, and I think he'll continue to be a part of it."

HEADLINE: Senators Tour Hanoi's P.O.W. Closet

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Three Senators and a group of Pentagon officials were allowed today to tour long-secret areas of Vietnam's military headquarters and to rummage through a storeroom of museum artifacts that could hold clues to the fate of Americans missing from the Vietnam War.
The visits were evidence of what Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet of Vietnam described today as his nation's determination to "resolve all aspects of the issue of missing Americans" and to establish full diplomatic and economic ties with the United States. 
 In the dank storeroom in Hanoi's central war museum, Senator John F. Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Select Committee on M.I.A.-P.O.W. affairs, opened a dust-covered wooden closet and found stacks of neatly folded olive green flight suits that, according to the Vietnamese, had been worn by American airmen shot down over North Vietnamese territory.
Defense Department investigators had not been granted access to the storeroom until today, and they appeared startled by Senator Kerry's discovery.
 
Hanoi's 'Enormous Effort'
 At least some of the flight suits bore name tags and, according to investigators, could provide the United States with important evidence in trying to determine the fate of pilots and other airmen who are among the 2,265 Americans still listed as unaccounted for from the Vietnam War.
After touring the museum, Maj. Gen. Thomas G. Needham, who oversees Pentagon teams investigating the fate of missing Americans throughout Indochina, said that Vietnamese cooperation "has markedly increased almost every day." "We've no reason to believe that we're not getting the information we want," he said.
Senator Hank Brown, a Colorado Republican who is a member of the select committee, said today in Hanoi that he detected an "enormous effort by Vietnam to change -- to work toward friendship, to work toward cooperation."
The three Senators -- Mr. Brown, Mr. Kerry and Tom Daschle, a South Dakota Democrat who is also a member of the committee -- are making the panel's last scheduled visit to Vietnam before the committee is to complete a final report and go out of business in January after a 17-month investigation.
 
Tour of the Citadel
 The report is expected to judge the quality of Vietnamese cooperation in resolving the question of Americans missing from the war. The Senators hinted this week that President Bush, as one of his final acts in the White House, will relax a 17-year American trade embargo that has discouraged foreign investments in Vietnam.
Calls by Americans to relax the embargo have accelerated since Vietnam's announcement last month that it would allow American investigators full access to military museums and archives holding information about Americans.
Today's visit to the Hanoi war museum, the Museum of the People's Army, came after the three Senators and a team of Pentagon officials toured the Citadel, a complex of buildings that serves as Vietnam's military headquarters.
Over the years, American intelligence reports gathered from Vietnamese refugees have suggested that American prisoners might have been held in the Citadel long after the end of the Vietnam War. But Senator Kerry said after touring the building that "we found significant information" discounting at least one such report, asserting that a group of about 30 Caucasian men was seen there in 1986.
 
Senator Is Impressed
 Vietnamese officials, hopeful that President Bush will relax and perhaps even lift the economic embargo before he leaves office in January, appeared anxious today to convince the Senators and Pentagon officials that Hanoi was cooperating fully in the search for missing Americans.
Senator Kerry, a decorated Vietnam veteran, said he was very impressed with the Vietnamese efforts.
"I think the cooperation, at least in the couple of of days we've been here, has been as much as we can ask for," he said. "Everything we've asked for has been done."
The Senators also met today with Prime Minister Kiet, who later told reporters that American and Vietnamese officials "understand each other very clearly and well."
Senator Kerry was presented by the museum's director, Col. Pham Duc Dai, with several wartime artifacts and documents, including a handful of Social Security cards and one identification card that had been collected from captured or killed American soldiers.
The Senators were given a blue and gold airman's helmet that, the Vietnamese said, had been worn by Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican who is a member of the select committee and who was a prisoner of war in North Vietnam for more than five years. Inside the helmet were the initials "J. M."
"I would think there must be piles of this stuff elsewhere," Senator Kerry said, pointing to the other wartime relics that were turned over to the American delegation today: items of military clothing, what appeared to be an American pilot's charred log book, a handbook titled "Survival" on American military search and rescue techniques.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Living Down Atari's Ghost

BYLINE: By Adam Bryant

 BODY:
AFTER years of being haunted by the ghost of Atari, a soaring star of the early 1980's that fizzled out, American video game software companies finally appear to be getting some respect on Wall Street.
The two largest publicly traded video game developers -- Acclaim Entertainment Inc. of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Electronic Arts of San Mateo, Calif. -- are garnering most of the attention, and being promoted by many industry analysts as safe and promising. This marks a departure from the historical reading of these companies as volatile, risky plays. 
 "The entertainment software industry is going to be around for a long, long time," said Gary M. Jacobson, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody.
Why the optimism? In broad terms, the video game business is maturing more smoothly than it has in the past. Sales of video game systems based on eight-bit computer technology peaked just after Christmas 1989, and 1990 was a tough year for software developers. But the industry is upgrading to more advanced 16-bit systems.
Sales of these new systems, known as the Sega Genesis and Nintendo's Super NES, are expected to reach 10 million units this year, with an additonal seven or eight million to be sold next year. Electronic Arts and Acclaim are the two largest American third-party software suppliers for these systems.
This growth in hardware systems creates an enormous appetite for games. There are more than 250 new titles coming to market this year, and an equal number or more are expected next year. Both companies have diversified their sources of revenue. And in one sign of the market's maturation, Electronic Arts is using television advertising to pitch its titles for the Sega system.
All of which creates some high expectations that have played on the stock of Acclaim and Electronic Arts in different ways recently. The value of Acclaim's stock, which closed yesterday at $13.50, up 37.5 cents, in over-the-counter trading, has more than doubled since the summer.
Although the company has not been as steady a performer as Electronic Arts, the market nevertheless appears to be signaling that Acclaim's stock deserves to trade at an earnings multiple of more than 20, much closer to that of Electronic Arts' current price-earnings multiple of around 30.
Because of the consistency of Electronics Arts, it has become "the kind of company analysts emblazon on their pillow and hug at night," said Peter L. Keane, an analyst at Interstate/Johnson Lane in Charlotte, N.C.
Electronic Arts' stock, however, has floated too high on the expectations, analysts say, and the stock has subsequently dropped in recent weeks by as much as 16 percent since mid-October. It has rebounded, however, closing yesterday at $31, down 75 cents, in over-the-counter trading. "Both stocks are moving more into equilibrium," Mr. Jacobson said.
The two companies represent two different models of a game software publishing company. Electronic Arts maintains its own staff of software developers, while Acclaim subcontracts development of its games to other companies. And while Acclaim concentrates on licensing such popular movie and television characters as the Simpsons and the Terminator, Electronic Arts develops games that are pegged less to fictional characters. Its library of best sellers include "Chuck Yeager's Air Combat," "Deluxe Paint IV" and "John Madden Football '92."
While most analysts agree that the wind in the sails of these stocks is strong and reliable, it may not be entirely steady. Robert F. Kleiber of Piper, Jaffray Inc. downgraded his recommendation on Electronic Arts on Nov. 2 from "buy" to "accumulate." Although Mr. Kleiber did not change his earnings estimates for Electronic Arts, he did express concern about the current valuations and looming challenges over the next year for Electronic Arts and the industry as a whole.
After the holiday season ends, for example, economic weakness may hamstring sales of game systems early next year. The marketplace for advanced games based on CD-ROM (compact disk-read only memory) technology is going to intensify next year with the introduction of new systems from companies that include a joint venture known as SMSG whose partners include Electronic Arts and Time Warner. "By this time next year, the choice may include as many as eight alternatives," Mr. Kleiber wrote in his most recent report.
CD-ROMS are part of an emerging technology in which compact disks are used to store audio, video, graphics and text. Although the disks hold out enormous potential because of their storage capacity, software game developers are still struggling to fully tap that potential.
Regardless of those challenges, some analysts continue to recommend these stocks aggressively, even high-flying Electronic Arts. "There's lots more upside to the company and the stock," said Steven L. Eskenazi, an analyst with Alex. Brown & Sons in New York who tracks Electronic Arts.

HEADLINE: A Dismayed Historian of the Gallows

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HEADLAND, Ala., Nov. 11

 BODY:
Cornelius Singleton, convicted of the rape and murder of a nun when she went to pray at another sister's grave in a deserted cemetery, is scheduled to be electrocuted by Alabama this month. Few state residents expect executive clemency, least of all Watt Espy, a historian of capital punishment who sees a record tide of executions waiting to sweep the nation in the next decade.
"Most awful," says Mr. Espy, appalled at the very viciousness of the nun's murder, the kind of savagery that makes most Americans favor capital punishment to the point where 2,636 convicts await execution, more than at any one time before. 
 By his accounting, this year's death-house toll will reach 28 with the state's dispatching of Mr. Singleton on Nov. 20, the most in a single year since 1976, when the Supreme Court cleared the way for executions to resume.
This year's executions will fall short of the record 199 set in 1935, a desperate time economically and criminally, Mr. Espy notes. But this year signals an upswing that he estimates will be setting record annual tolls in excess of 300 executions by the turn of the century.
 
'Quiet Blood Bath'
 "And the danger is that you can have a kind of quiet blood bath which the people won't even notice as executions become more common and less newsworthy," said Mr. Espy, a committed opponent of the death penalty who initially favored execution when he began research on it 22 years ago.
"If we executed one a day," he said, "it would take close to nine years to kill those now waiting on death row, and we're adding 200 to 300 a year beyond that."
Time-withered reams of crime magazines and court journals surround Mr. Espy, his computer and his dog here in a ramshackle house in the heart of this rural town in southeastern Alabama, where, at 59, he now devotes his life to uncovering all he can on every execution since colonial times. So far he has documented 18,482 executions since 1608, when George Kendall was shot as a Spanish spy in the Virginia colony.
In contrast to past times of public controversy, Mr. Espy and other critics of executions now foresee an era of routine, footnote capital punishment of historic proportions in which the merits of the issue are less debated and in which retribution rather than deterrence is becoming the main social goal served. This shift is eased by a combination of the abolition of high-profile public execution more than 50 years ago and the application of modern technology in the form of lethal injection.
Of the 36 states that execute convicts, , 22, plus the Federal Government, have adopted lethal injection in recent years as either the sole or optional means of death. While critics note the continuing problems with lethal injection in some states -- 41 minutes of torturous probing for the veins of one doomed felon -- others say that historically, humaneness has never been an overriding factor.
"Study after study now shows retribution is behind the push for capital punishment," said Kica Matos, the research director for the Capital Punishment Project of the NAACP's Legal Defense and Educational Fund.
"What the American people want is some sort of a quick fix in the face of the rise in violence across the nation," Ms. Matos said.
The election of Bill Clinton presents conflicting signals, in her view. On the one hand he has promised judicial appointments rooted in individual quality rather than in conservative-agenda orthodoxy. But as Governor of Arkansas he oversaw executions without apology, including that of a lobotomized convicted murderer. Political specialists say this helped his campaign image as a firm centrist.
"Clinton's impact on the issue will be in the appointment of hundreds of Federal judges across time," Mr. Espy said. He contends that changes in the Supreme Court early in the Clinton Administration might not necessarily mean any immediate shift from an era of high-volume executions that Mr. Espy finds likely, particularly since recent Court rulings pruned the process of time-consuming death row appeals.
 
Viciousness and Despair
 "Who was it said the Supreme Court reads newspapers?" Mr. Espy commented, emphasizing the power of the country's current despair at the viciousness of crime in a nation relatively young and steeped in frontier traditions like liberal gun possession.
The United States is one of only two major industrial nations -- South Africa is the other -- that has not abolished capital punishment. And it is the only one that permits the execution of convicts younger than 18 years of age, 16 being the limit in some jurisdictions.
Mr. Espy documents this history with daily care and without benefit of a research grant. A non-academic who used to sell encyclopedias and cemetery plots, he prefers narrative detail to moralizing, letting not-so-old newspaper accounts ("Black Fiend Hanged/Jerked to Jesus") set the tone of the leering injustice that he contends remains the hallmark of capital punishment.
Mr. Espy feels that some day the nation will pause in the jagged routine of history and be ready for a full-scale debate on capital punishment. "I want to see it based on all the facts, not just emotion," he said. Accordingly, he gathers and savors human shadings above all, talking to the families of victims and perpetrators alike and wincing at the violence and sickness that he, for one, measures as largely unaffected by capital punishment.
"I happened to meet Cornelius Singleton's mother in Mobile," Mr. Espy said. "She's as fine a Christian lady as you could want to meet. And now she's become a victim of crime, just as much as that poor nun's family members and her fellow sisters."

HEADLINE: Nationsbank Is Buying Most of a Chrysler Unit

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Nationsbank, the acquisitive North Carolina banking company whose name reflects its ambitions, announced an agreement yesterday to buy almost all of Chrysler First, a consumer finance subsidiary of the Chrysler Financial Corporation.
For Chrysler, the sale of its consumer finance subsidiary will provide an infusion of cash and reduce by about $4 billion its borrowings in financial markets and from banks. 
 John P. Tierney, chairman of Chrysler Financial, said the company wanted to get out of some of its nonautomobile businesses to focus on financing car buyers and car dealers.
Nationsbank purchased $4 billion of Chrysler First's loans and paid Chrysler an additional premium of about $100 million. The profit to Chrysler, which bought the company in 1985 from the BankAmerica Corporation, was not disclosed.
 
Expansion of Lending
 For Nationsbank, the purchase is a way to expand its consumer lending business quickly and to deploy profitably the surplus of deposits it has accumulated since the purchase of a failed Texas bank several years ago. The bank has also said it wants to shift some of its $28 billion investment in securities into loans, where profit margins are larger.
Hugh L. McColl, Nationsbank's chairman, has often said he wants consumer lending to grow more rapidly, so that it will account for about half the company's loans, up from about 39 percent, or about $27 billion, currently.
The weak economy has slowed consumer lending at many banks. In the three months that ended on Sept. 30, for example, consumer loans at Nationsbank grew by about $305 million, or less than half as much as business loans rose.
Of the $4 billion of loans Nationsbank will purchase from Chrysler, about half are to individuals and half are to retail stores to finance their inventories.
Profits of Chrysler First were not disclosed, but analysts noted that well-run consumer finance companies could earn $1.50 to $2.50 of profit for every $100 of assets, higher than any large banking company. Nationsbank, for example, earned $1.06 on each $100 of assets in the first nine months of this year.
Chrysler First's business will be combined with Nationsbank's existing consumer finance business, which has $500 million in assets and 105 offices in 10 states, and renamed Nationscredit. The company will occupy Chrysler First's headquarters in Allentown, Pa. Robert Major, president of Chrysler First, will continue in that position.
Timothy P. Hartman, chairman of Nationsbank West, will oversee the consumer finance business. He said there would be some consolidation and cost-cutting in absorbing Chrysler First, but that the consumer finance company would remain separate from Nationsbank's branch network.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Global Finnish Issue Sells Well

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Finland received a good reception for its $2 billion bond issue yesterday despite its economic problems at home, traders said. And, for a change, American investors helped another country cover its budget deficit by buying bonds.
The global issue, under which the securities were sold in markets around the world simultaneously, was the first by a sovereign government, traders said. It sold around $900 million of its dollar-denominated five-year notes in the American market. 
 The successful sale of the issue showed that some of the pressure on the corporate bond market has eased recently as the pace of new issues has subsided. From as much as $10 billion a week in September, new issues have slowed, traders said.
 
Demand From Europeans
 James B. Quigley, managing director of the Global Debt Financing Desk at Merrill Lynch, which was a joint manager and the global coordinator for the Finland deal, said the success of the deal was partly the result of demand from Europeans for the securities because of the recent rally of the dollar.
Since the beginning of September the dollar has jumped 14 percent against the German mark and similar amounts against other European currencies. Many analysts say the dollar rally is likely to continue because interest rates are expected to decline further in Europe. And if the American economy begins to rebound at a respectable pace and attract more foreign investment the dollar rally could move even faster.
This makes owning dollar-denominated securities quite attractive because the investor can make a nice profit when the dollars are finally translated back into the home country's currency. In fact, the gains or losses on the price movements of bonds are often swamped by the change in the currency. So even if a European investor expects to lose a little on the five-year note because short-term interest rates might rise further, the currency gain can offset this loss easily.
In the Finish deal, the five-year notes were priced to yield 6.858 percent, which was 82 basis points over the yield for the five-year Treasury note at the time of the sale. In late trading, traders said the spread had narrowed by two to four basis points, another sign the deal went well.
It is hard to measure how much more or less than comparable deals Finland had to pay in yield for the successful deal. Joe Cook, a managing director at J. P. Morgan Securities, which was one of the three joint lead managers of the Finland deal, said Finland paid less yield than its recent alternative borrowings but more than a comparably rated American corporate issuer.
The Finland issue is rated Aa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA+ by Standard & Poor's. A comparable domestic corporate industrial bond with these ratings would have a yield that is about 40 or 50 basis points over the five-year Treasury notes, traders said. But, at the same time, compared with recent bond deals that Finland has done in Europe, the yield paid yesterday was about 10 basis points less.
Mr. Quigley of Merrill Lynch said the Finnish sale was also helped by its size. He said some fund managers buy many foreign issued bonds that are denominated in dollars and called Yankee bonds. Because this was such a large issue, not owning it could hurt a manager's performance compared with a benchmark index of the Yankee bond market. Nomura International was the third joint lead manager of the deal.
In a second $2 billion deal yesterday, the Swedish Government issued three-year bonds denominated in dollars in Europe. It was not available in the United States. The issue was priced to yield 5.636 percent, or 46 basis points over the yield on the three-year Treasury note at the time of the sale. The lead underwriters were Credit Suisse First Boston and J. P Morgan. Mr. Cook said the issue was about half sold.
 
Treasury Prices Rise
 Prices of Government bonds and notes rose moderately in light trading yesterday as the Treasury market got a late day lift from a report that showed department and chain store sales off about 1 percent in the first two weeks of November.
In secondary trading, the price of the 7.625 percent 30-year bond was up 11/32 to yield 7.53 percent, down from 7.56 percent on Monday. The prices of notes from two to ten years were up while their yields fell.
In the auction of one-year Treasury bills, the average discount rate was 3.61 percent, the highest since the 3.93 percent of June 24.

HEADLINE: Witness Saw Accused Killer In Another Crown Hts. Case

BYLINE: By ARNOLD H. LUBASCH

 BODY:
Showing concern for violence in Crown Heights, more than 30 Hasidic women filled a Brooklyn courtroom yesterday to hear somber testimony about the slaying of a neighbor, Phyllis LaPine, who was stabbed to death in her home on Feb. 6.
Quiet weeping could be heard in the spectator section of the small, crowded courtroom as a witness testified about finding Mrs. LaPine's 2-year-old daughter singing a children's song alone in her bedroom as the victim lay dead in a nearby hallway. 
 The witness, Joseph Simpson, a school principal and volunteer with a community ambulance service, said he cradled the child in his arms and shielded her eyes from the body as he took her out of the apartment.
The slaying, which took place in an apparent burglary, is not considered a racial incident. But it heightened tensions because the suspect is black and because racial disturbances broke out in Crown Heights in 1991 when a black child, Gavin Cato, was killed by a car, and a Hasidic man, Yankel Rosenbaum, was stabbed to death.
 
'Nothing, Man'
 In yesterday's session in State Supreme Court, a 16-year-old student identified the defendant, Romane LaFond, as a man he saw running through his backyard near Mrs. LaPine's home on the afternoon of the slaying. Mr. LaFond, 24, is an unemployed handyman who lives in Crown Heights.
The witness, Odino Brown, testified that he looked out his bedroom window because he heard his dog barking outside and that he saw Mr. LaFond in the backyard, which faced Mrs. LaPine's backyard.
Mr. Brown said he went outside, confronted Mr. LaFond and asked him what he wanted.
"He said, 'Nothing, man,' and he jumped over the fence," Mr. Brown testified, noting that a low fence separated his house from the one next door.
Replying to more questions by a prosecutor, Michael F. Vecchione, the witness said the defendant was holding a a 2-by-4 piece of wood in his right hand and that "he had blood on his hand."
A defense lawyer, Samuel Gregory, elicited in cross-examination that Mr. Brown had told the police that the defendant had been wearing a black jacket, light brown sweater and black pants. The defense is expected to present evidence that no blood stains were found on the defendant's clothing.
Mrs. LaPine was stabbed to death when she returned to her home at 680 Lefferts Avenue in Crown Heights after shopping. Considerable blood was found at the scene.
Justice Francis X. Egitto is conducting the trial, which began on Monday.
One of the Hasidic women attending the trial, Liz Zargary, said they intended to come every day "out of respect for Mrs. LaPine."
"It could have happened to any one of us," she said, adding, "We are coming to show our concern for what has happened in our community."
In February, Mrs. LaPine's slaying prompted renewed complaints by Jewish residents in Crown Heights that the police were not providing sufficient protection in the area. The slaying was also followed by an incident in which rocks and bottles were thrown back by Hasidic and black residents of the community.

HEADLINE: Twice Burned: Bronx Store Loses a Last Battle

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
Stanley Bell hunched his shoulders against the morning chill and watched in disbelief last week as a bulldozer's chunky treads noisily crunched over a rough gray patch of broken walls and charred timbers. A gaping hole was the final testament to Belco Distributors, the two-way radio business to which he had devoted four decades of his life in the Tremont section of the Bronx.
It was nearly four months to the day that a searing blaze had burned off the second floor of his electronics store, sending him on a journey of hope and, ultimately, disbelief through the city's bureaucracy.
 
Promises, Promises
 Eager to rebuild, he had won promises of special assistance from city officials and a settlement from his insurance company. But though the insurer had deemed the building salvageable, Mr. Bell says, he was repeatedly stymied in his efforts to get the promised help or the necessary reconstruction permits from the city. Finally, the city declared the building unsafe and tore it down. 
 "I can't get any permits to reconstruct, but they can get everything over in a second," he said, adding that the city had never notified him of the demolition. "I feel my whole life here has been a failure because of this."
Mr. Bell is among half a dozen business owners on a once-vibrant stretch of East Tremont Avenue whose stores were either destroyed or heavily damaged by a five-alarm fire that began accidentally in a trash heap the morning of July 6. In one way or another, his frustrations since then echo those of his neighbors.
City officials say Mr. Bell and some of the others simply expected too much too fast and failed to comply with city rules and deadlines. But the merchants of East Tremont Avenue say they cannot forgive what they see as the hollow promises of city officials, who said they had scheduled the area for extra attention.
Two months ago, when a reporter first visited the block, Jesus Rodriguez, the owner of a hardware store destroyed in the fire, still hoped he would qualify for low-interest city loans. He now says he has abandoned any expectation of government help, even though his creditors are demanding payment from him.
Mr. Bell, who complained then of being caught in a bureaucratic quagmire, said the city's inaction had led him to put his property up for sale in late September. Now, he chafes at the prospect of having to reimburse the city for a demolition he never wanted.
Wallace L. Ford 2d, the Commissioner of the Department of Business Services, said his office was clearing the way for redevelopment, even if the merchants did think there had been no progress.
"There are instances where people expect that just as there was a catastrophic occurrence, there is an ability to rectify matters in a dramatic fashion," he said, adding that his office had helped one property owner obtain a city-owned building as part of a larger plan to rebuild a set of storefronts.
 
Safety Hazards
 Mr. Ford said his office expedited the demolition of Mr. Bell's property and four other burned-out buildings, citing the safety hazards posed by the damaged buildings, at least one of which had asbestos insulation in its plumbing and boiler system.
"This is not a situation of the city just coming in and tearing down a building," Mr. Ford said.
Stanley Bell said his misadventure began after the Department of Buildings issued him a summons to appear in court after declaring the structure unsafe, standard practice after such a fire. Vahe Tiryakian, a spokesman, said Mr. Bell could have prevented the demolition if he had taken steps to secure the building.
Mr. Bell said he and his general contractor tried in vain to obtain the necessary permits to secure the building, remove the asbestos and start construction, but was thwarted by bureaucratic tangles.
He appeared in State Supreme Court on Aug. 25, but was told the hearing -- which could determine whether the building would be razed -- had to be rescheduled because a representative from the Buildings Department was ill. He said he heard nothing further until a former worker called in a panic to say a bulldozer had arrived.
Susan Fuller, an assistant corporation counsel, said a new hearing date was set for Sept. 1 during the August meeting, and a judge ruled to demolish the building at that second hearing. She said there was no need for written notice.
"He lost his opportunity to get into any kind of debate with the court by not following up," she said.
With the demolition done, Mr. Bell is now waiting to see how much he will have to pay for the job. Repeated telephone calls to the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, which handled the job, were not returned.
Francisco Gonzalez, who works for the Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, a branch of the Office of the Bronx Borough President, said that city officials should have streamlined their procedures so the rebuilding process would have been under way no more than 30 days after the fire.
"The city made promises they can help and assist these businesses," said Mr. Gonzalez, who convened a meeting of merchants and officials two weeks after the fire. "We try to facilitate with the city and the city agencies sit on their hands."
A speedier response, he said, could have helped Mr. Bell keep his business in the Bronx as well as sending the message that the survival of small businesses was as worthy of official attention as keeping a large corporation from leaving the city.
Mr. Rodriguez fretted that while he waits for his landlord to rebuild his hardware store, his suppliers are asking him for $35,000 he owes for merchandise that was lost in the fire. They have reduced his line of credit at another hardware store where he is a co-owner.
He is two months behind on his house payments and has put his Jeep up for sale, the same one on whose dashboard he placed the charred street number sign from his store. Mr. Rodriguez said a city official told him he would qualify for a $250,000 loan, but the official denied ever having made such a promise, saying the finances were limited to $50,000 per merchant and that it would have been a disservice to lend Mr. Rodriguez an insufficient amount.
"This is worse than starting over," Mr. Rodriguez said. "When you start from scratch, at least you know where you stand. Here, you don't know about tomorrow."
Nor do the merchants who emerged unscathed by the fire. Mo Stein, the owner of Frank's Sporting Goods, worried that the block could mirror the landscape across the street, where a fire reduced a string of shops to a lot strewn with broken bricks, bulging bags of garbage and a few scurrying rats.
"This could be the death of the block," he said. "The city's inaction creates the biggest problems in the world. Talk about a domino effect."
Across the street, Smitty Smith paused in front of a shuttered bank and craned his neck to look at a row of fluorescent lights that lined the roof.
"When they lit up at night, it was beautiful," he said, as a homeless man swathed in grimy rags tottered in the nearby doorway. "But they don't put them on any more."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar's Recent Rally Stalls While Gold Prices Advance

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar's recent rally stalled yesterday in the absence of fresh economic news.
Gold prices rose. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $334.30 an ounce, up 40 cents from Monday. A late quote from the Republic National Bank said gold rose 90 cents to close at $335.40 an ounce. 
 The dollar has been rising in recent weeks amid reports that indicate the economy is slowly improving. Retail sales, industrial production and the nation's money supply all have perked up in recent days.
"Over all, the dollar is close to the highs we have seen, but there has been little new incentive to take it higher," Craig Asche, a vice president and foreign exchange trader at Salomon Brothers, said.
The dollar has been strengthening against the mark in recent sessions. The mark weakened on Monday after five leading German economists predicted zero growth in western Germany's economy next year, Andrew Hodge, vice president at Bank Brussels Lambert, said.
Mr. Hodge said the dollar failed to break a critical level of about 160.7 marks during the session. The dollar closed at 1.592 marks in late New York trading, up from 1.5915 late Monday.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 124.56 yen from 124.25 yen at Monday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 124.5 yen. At closing in New York, the dollar was quoted at 124.35 yen, down from 124.7 yen on Monday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.5225, from $1.5185 late Monday. In New York, one pound cost $1.522, less expensive than Monday's $1.5245.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.447 Swiss francs, up from 1.4365; 5.3625 French francs, down from 5.3645; 1,358 Italian lire, up from 1,357, and 1.27385 Canadian dollars, up from 1.27125.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Monday, included: 1.5955 German marks, up from 1.592; 1.4508 Swiss francs, up from 1.438; 5.3825 French francs, up from 5.3615; 1.795 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7891; 1,361 Italian lire, up from 1,357, and 1.2747 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2698.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $333.95 an ounce, from $335.75 bid late Monday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $333.90, from $335.25 bid late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.52 an ounce to close at a bid of $334.40.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A Ratings Cut For Prudential

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Standard & Poor's lowered its ratings by a notch yesterday on $3.15 billion of bonds from the Prudential Insurance Company of America, making it more expensive for the biggest insurance company in the United States to borrow money.
The downgrade, to AA+ from the top AAA rating, signifies a higher risk is associated with owning Prudential debt and that means the Newark company may be forced to offer higher interest rates in the future to attract investors. 
 S.& P. said it had stripped Prudential's AAA rating because of the insurer's losses from Hurricane Andrew. Prudential said in September that it had given a subsidiary $900 million to cover greater-than-anticipated claims from victims of the hurricane. Prudential said it expected more than $1 billion of claims and forecast a 1992 loss of $500 million. In addition, S.& P. said it expected Prudential to show as much as $900 million of hurricane-related after-tax losses.
Prudential said the company would have almost $10 billion of capital after paying hurricane-related claims, about the same as in 1991.
Moody's Investors Service said in September that it might cut its Aa1 ratings on Prudential. Prudential lost its Aaa rating from Moody's last January.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
British Air's Net Off 23% In 2d Quarter

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
British Airways reported a decline of 23 percent today in earnings in its second quarter, as a modest gain in operating income was offset by unfavorable exchange rates.
British Airways reported earnings of 112 million, or $170.2 million at current exchange rates, for the quarter that ended on Sept. 30, down from 146 million in the corresponding period in 1991. 
 Income from the 1991 quarter included a one-time gain of 25 million from aircraft sales, while the 1992 results included a charge of 16 million from adverse fluctuations in currency exchange rates. Combined, those items offset a 2.4 percent increase in operating profits in the quarter.
British Airways said its planes carried a larger percentage of passengers during the period. But it said the yield -- the amount earned for each mile a passenger is flown -- was off.
Revenue rose 5.2 percent, to 1.50 billion, or $2.28 billion, for the second quarter.
British Airways' chairman, Lord King, said the results were "not at a level we would like," but noted that the industry over all was in a third straight year of staggering losses.
"While we continue to achieve results that are the envy of our competitors, we, like them, have suffered from the effects of the recession in many of our key markets right around the globe," Mr. King said in a statement.
"Prospects for the second half of the financial year remain uncertain," he said. "Although we continue to experience growth in overall traffic, we do not expect to see an increase in demand for our premium brands until there is sustained economic growth in the major markets which we serve."

British Air-USAir Tie
 LONDON, Nov. 17 (By Bloomberg Business News) -- British Airways will insist on the right to veto financial decisions at USAir as a condition for completing its proposed $750 million investment in the unprofitable United States airline, British Air's chief executive, Colin Marshall, said today.
British Air expects the United States to approve the link with USAir by Dec. 24, Mr. Marshall said. A rejection by the United Sates would "encourage those doubtful about 'open skies' to believe the U.S. doesn't believe in it," he added
Moreover, "the deal is as it stands," and is not subject to possible American demands that British Air give up any veto over some of USAir's financial decisions, Mr. Marshall said. The British airline must have representatives on USAir's board and "couldn't go into an arrangement without broad veto," or with "no influence whatsoever," on USAir's board, he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Running Half-Engine to Save Fuel

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
In the race to develop automobile engines that conserve fuel but provide adequate power, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation has revived an idea that failed a decade ago.
Mitsubishi's new engine automatically switches from four cylinders to two in slow city driving to save fuel, and shifts back to four cylinders when open-road power is needed. 
 The new engine, available only in Japan so far, is the latest product of an aggressive effort by Japanese auto makers to improve the internal combustion engine. Although such efforts could put further pressure on the American auto makers, some experts contend that the new engines will not be suitable for larger American cars and probably will not sell very well anyway.
 
Some Lackluster Results
 Indeed, two new engines introduced by Japanese companies last year have not had that much impact on the market, despite their impressive technology.
Mitsubishi introduced an engine last year that offered a significant improvement in fuel economy by using so-called lean-burn technology. But the engine, offered as an option on the compact Mirage sold only in Japan, has been chosen by only one-half of 1 percent of Mirage buyers.
Honda has had slightly better success with its fuel-efficient VTEC-E engine, introduced last year on some models of the Civic. About 5 percent of the Civic buyers in the United States and Japan have chosen the new engine, a figure that the company says is about what it expected.
Mitsubishi, however, concluded from its experience that consumers were not interested in fuel efficiency alone -- even in Japan, where gasoline costs about three times what it does in the United States.
So Mitsubishi came back with a new approach. Its 1.6-liter engine, capable of 175 horsepower, was introduced last month as an option for Mitsubishi's compact Lancer and Mirage models for sale in Japan. The company said the cars could average more than 37 miles a gallon and when cruising at a steady speed a bit below 40 miles an hour could achieve 61 miles a gallon. The figures come from the standard Japanese mileage test, which differs from that used in the United States.
 
No Decision on U.S. Sales
 Mitsubishi has not yet decided whether to begin selling the engines in the United States. If it does, it will have to come up with new speed and power reference points for switching between two and four cylinders, because the driving habits in the United States, with its many open roads, are far different from those in Japan, with its monumental traffic jams.
An engine cylinder is a chamber in which fuel is burned to power a piston. The concept of varying the number of working cylinders was first tried by General Motors on some 1981-model Cadillacs, which could operate using four, six or eight cylinders. Mitsubishi tried the approach in 1982, offering an engine that could operate on two or four cylinders.
But both efforts were short-lived, mainly because customers just did not respond. Also, the Mitsubishi managing director in charge of passenger car development, Motoo Suzuki, acknowledged that the switch between two and four cylinders was somewhat jerky, with the car suddenly speeding up or slowing down.
But now, Mr. Suzuki said, improved electronic engine controls allow the switch to be made almost imperceptibly. The engine can operate on two cylinders up to a speed of about 60 miles an hour. But if the driver needs power to accelerate quickly, the engine will switch to four cylinders even if the car is traveling at only one mile an hour. The switch is made by hydraulic pressure, activated by an electronic device that senses engine speed.
 
A Savings of 16%
 Mr. Suzuki said the two-cylinder option could lead to a 16 percent improvement in fuel efficiency in typical city driving.
In the quest for efficiency, an approach pursued by Honda, Mitsubishi and Toyota is the lean-burn engine, which mixes more air with the fuel. But lean-burn technology tends to increase pollution by nitrogen oxides and also tends to limit engine power, making it suitable only for the smallest cars. The engine that Mitsubishi introduced a year ago is a lean-burn engine.
Another approach is to vary the timing of the opening and closing of valves that let air and fuel into the cylinder depending on the speed of the engine. The idea is to maximize the amount of air and fuel entering the cylinder.
While such variable valve timing improves the engine's power, it has little effect on fuel consumption. So auto makers are turning to combinations of techniques.
Honda, in its VTEC-E engine combines the valve-timing and lean-burn approaches. Mitsubishi's new engine uses the valve-timing approach for power but instead of lean-burn technology it employs two-cylinder operation to achieve better mileage.
The Mitsubishi engine makes use of high-speed and low-speed cams and rocker arms to control the opening and closing of valves. When the engine is rotating at high speeds, the high-speed mechanisms keep the valves open longer. At slower speeds, the low-speed cam and rocker arm control the valve timing. When little power is needed, specially designed hydraulic pistons disconnect the high- and low-speed cam and rocker arms for two of the four cylinders, leaving them inoperable.
"There's no question that the Japanese have some very clever designs and mechanisms," said David E. Cole, director of the Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation at the University of Michigan. "But others don't have to use that to achieve similar performance gains."
 
Some Differences Noted
 Japanese engines are smaller than American ones, he said, and have trouble generating power at low speeds without using tricks like variable valve timing.
Mr. Cole also said that variable valve timing "adds significantly to the cost of the vehicle." Indeed, Mitsubishi said its new engine with the two-cylinder mode added 170,000 yen, about $1,400, to a car's price.
But the Japanese manufacturers are undeterred. Eventually such technology, they say, will spread to more models of cars and the price will come down. "Such improvements will be accelerated by selling such products in the market," Mr. Suzuki of Mitsubishi said, "even if the volume is small."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "How Mitsubishi's Fuel-Saving Engine Works"
 
Mitsubishi combines a four-cylinder for power on the freeway with two-cylinder engine for fuel, efficiency in city driving. To accomplish this, the engine switches between three modes.
 
Inside the engine
 
High-speed mode above 5,000 engine revolutions per minute (R.P.M.)
 
High-speed mechanism is engaged on all four cylinders.
 
Low-speed mode between 3,400 and 5,000 R.P.M.
 
Low-speed mechanism is engaged on all four cylinders.
 
"Modulated displacement" mode below 3,400 R.P.M.
 
Low-speed mechanism is engaged on only two cylinders.
 
Inside each cylinder
 
As each cam spins, it drives its rocker arm, controlling the opening and closing of the valve. In high-speed mode, for example, the cam spins rapidly, keeping the valve open wider to let in more air for combustion. Switching from one mode to another is done by a hydraulic electronic control.
 
(Sources: Mitsubishi Motors, Automotive News)

HEADLINE: The Pop Life

BYLINE: By Sheila Rule

 BODY:
A Genesis to Suit
The long and the short of marketing the rock group Genesis these days involves, well, "The Shorts" and "The Longs."
In the spirit of having something for everybody, Atlantic Records is releasing "Genesis Live: The Way We Walk" in two separate albums, aimed at two distinct audiences. The newly released "Volume 1: The Shorts" features in-concert versions of hits from the group's last three studio albums, including "Genesis," "Invisible Touch" and "We Can't Dance." "Volume 2: The Longs" is intended to highlight the group's longer, more exploratory numbers, including "Home by the Sea," "Domino" and "Driving the Last Spike," as well as a medley of pieces from the 1970's. To be sold at a discount, the second volume will be released in January and available only through April. 
 The songs on both volumes, Genesis's first live recordings in 10 years, were recorded during the band's stadium tour this year.
"We didn't want to come out with a high-priced album in the middle of these economic times," said Doug Morris, a co-chairman and co-chief executive officer of the Atlantic Group, about the decision against releasing a double-set album. "Secondly, we felt we could appeal to two audiences. One is 'The Shorts' audience, which may start with 14-year-olds who listen to radio and like the hits. The other is the audience that has been with Genesis for years, the adult audience, which is very interested in their eclectic works and longer pieces."
The marketing approach takes advantage of the success of the group -- whose onstage members include Phil Collins, Tony Banks, Mike Rutherford, Daryl Stuermer and Chester Thompson -- in maintaining its traditional base of fans while attracting a new generation of record buyers. "The Shorts" also rides on the coattails of the album "We Can't Dance." Released about a year ago, it has sold more than three million copies in the United States.
"What we're selling is 20 years of emotion," Mr. Morris said. "This is a band that has been around a long time and is very dear to the hearts of a lot of different people."
 
Music for 'Malcolm X'
 To prepare himself for composing the score to Spike Lee's new film, "Malcolm X," which opens across the country today, the trumpeter and composer Terence Blanchard looked at -- or perhaps more accurately, listened to -- a few other movies. (Vincent Canby's review of "Malcolm X" is on page C19.)
"Spike gave me 'Anatomy of a Murder,' which Duke Ellington scored," Mr. Blanchard said. "Spike wanted an orchestra so I went out and got other movies that people suggested. 'Glory' was one I watched a lot."
Mr. Blanchard first collaborated with Mr. Lee on the score of his film "School Daze" in 1988, which led to his contributing to the music of the director's subsequent films, "Do The Right Thing," "Mo' Better Blues" and "Jungle Fever." "I don't start scoring a film until it's just about fully edited, so I can see how the scenes are cut together, where the emphasis is in the scenes," he said. "One thing that's amazing about the process is that I can read the script and get an idea but once I see the scene it can be totally different."
"Malcolm X: The Original Motion Picture Score" (40 Acres and a Mule Musicworks/Columbia) features the Boys Choir of Harlem, the saxophonists Branford Marsalis and Jerry Dodgion, Tarus Mateen on bass, Troy Davis on drums, Sir Roland Hanna on piano and Britt Woodman on trombone. The score, a mix of original jazz and orchestral pieces, represents just one aspect of Mr. Blanchard's participation in the film. He makes his acting debut as the trumpeter and leader of a quartet that backs up an actress playing Billie Holiday. But acting the part required no special creativity, he said.
"That's basically who I am," he said. "I'm a jazz musician. I have a serious passion for music."
That serious passion will be on display evenings from Tuesday through Nov. 29 when Mr. Blanchard plays an engagement at the Village Vanguard in Greenwich Village. He said he would be giving the premiere performances of jazz suite versions of the "Malcolm X" score there.
 
Ya Kid K
 Ya Kid K, who as lead singer of the group Technotronic had pop hits like "Pump Up the Jam" and "Move This," has seen a lot of the world and heard a lot of its music. She was born in Zaire and reared there and in Kenya and in Belgium. Her newly released debut solo album, "One World Nation" (SBK Records), was recorded and mixed in Belgium, the United States and England. It includes rap, African percussion, reggae and a new version of "Move This."
Having been so many places, Ya Kid K, who is 20 years old, says she considers herself a citizen of "the planet earth" and does not like "passports, boundaries or borders." Yet when it comes to the roots of the world's music, she says, all roads lead back to Africa.
"If you mess around with the tempo and listen to the music you'll find that every kind of style of music around today derives from there," said Ya Kid K, adding that "Ya" is a term of respect reserved for older relatives or friends. Her original name is Manuela Barbara Kamosi Maose Djogi.
"So there is nothing that we can't claim," she said of people of the African diaspora. "The whole world is open to us because we started it."

HEADLINE: Meeting South African Wines

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
SINCE early summer, ships with container-loads of South African wine have been docking at American ports and the wines have been showing up in wine shops and restaurants. By the end of the year, about 40,000 cases will have landed here.
With the lifting of trade sanctions against South Africa nearly a year and a half ago, Americans have an opportunity -- and for many it is the first time -- to sample South African wines. 
 Like many other wine regions, South Africa, the ninth-largest wine-producing country in the world, is
A little-known wine region with a unique local grape, pinotage.
adding to the vast global supply of chardonnay and cabernet sauvignon. It also offers a wine made from a grape that is grown exclusively in South Africa, pinotage. The red pinotage wines are easy to like for their gentle fruity complexity and relatively reasonable price.
"A good pinotage should become synonymous with what is distinctive about South African wines," said Andre Shearer, whose company, the Natural Corporation, was among the first to send South African wines to America. Roger Bohmrich, a vice president of Frederick Wildman & Sons, the importer of Kanonkop and Lievland wines from the Stellenbosch district, said that while there are only limited amounts of most South African wines available, there is a good supply of pinotage for the demand. "That's the one you're likely to see in restaurants," he said.
The pinotage grape, developed in 1926, is a hybrid of pinot noir and cinsaut. In South Africa, the cinsaut grape is also known as hermitage, hence the hybridized name, pinotage. Never mind that in France's Rhone Valley, where the cinsaut is extensively cultivated, the wine called hermitage is made from the syrah grape and has nothing to do with cinsaut. Or that Australia's greatest red wine, Grange Hermitage, is made from syrah, not cinsaut.
The pinotage grape was originally intended for blending and for lower-priced bulk wine. "But now the wine makers are learning to treat it like the best cabernet sauvignon or syrah, with excellent results," Mr. Shearer said. "It has its own distinctive style and flavor." There are nearly 100 wineries making wines with pinotage in South Africa today; about half of the wines are blends.
At Boom, a restaurant in SoHo with an international menu and wine list to match, Rocco Ancarola, one of the owners, started serving South African wines as soon as they became available, even pouring them as house wines. "Pinotage is South Africa's claim to fame," he said. "It has body and softness. It surprises people who are unfamiliar with it."
At a tasting of a selection of pinotage wines in New York earlier this year, several South African wine experts, among them Mr. Shearer, John Platter, the country's leading wine authority, and Jabulani Ntshangase (pronounced Chan-GA-say), a native of Soweto who came to New York in 1980 with a business scholarship to Baruch College and now works with Mr. Shearer, discussed the various styles of pinotage.
The tasters preferred the deliciously spicy yet fruity Kanonkop 1990 pinotage. "It's well knit, and I could see it developing for 10 years," Mr. Ntshangase said.
Pinotage can be vinified to have the rich, satisfying complexity and lingering finish of the award-winning Kanonkop, or it can be made in a light and fruity style suggesting Beaujolais, like the Simonsig 1989. "If you like this style of pinotage, we have it in abundance," Mr. Platter said of the Simonsig.
Landskroon pinotage 1989 had the kind of earthy bouquet typical of some pinot noir. The tasters agreed that it was a well-balanced wine with good complexity, but lighter than the Kanonkop. The Bertrams pinotage 1988 was pleasant and easy to drink, while Clos Malverne 1989 was a sturdier wine, with more complexity.
Mr. Shearer predicted that there would eventually be around a dozen pinotage wines on the American market. For around $17 a bottle, the Kanonkop pinotage is the most expensive. Most are $7 to $10.
But selling these wines has not always been as easy as sipping them. Most wine shops that have started carrying South African wines, like Crossroads Wine and Liquor on West 14th Street and Lower Falls Wine Company in Newton, Mass., report no consumer resistance to them. But others are less eager to stock them. "Questions of politics are being raised," Mr. Ntshangase said. "But there is also the quality factor. People who taste the cabernet and pinotage wines and our French-style sauvignon blancs are very receptive."
"I'm putting my political credibility on the line," he added. "But we have to think about the economics of the country as well as the politics."

HEADLINE: Bad Breaks

SERIES: Bill's List: An occasional series commenting on ideas and issues facing the new Clinton Administration.

BYLINE: By Ann Crittenden; Ann Crittenden is author of the forthcoming "Killing the Sacred Cows: Bold Ideas for a New Economy."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Now that the election is over, all we have to do is get the economy moving again, tackle the deficit and add a few much needed domestic programs. All this will take money. But instead of raising taxes, we could consider eliminating a few unproductive tax subsidies that favor corporate debt, foreign investors and long lunches. Here are some suggestions:
* The debtors' subsidy. Right now, a company can deduct all interest payments on debt, even debt incurred buying up its own shares. This means that in effect the Treasury subsidized much of the damaging casino economy of the 1980's. The deduction was originally limited to investment in plant and equipment. If the interest on debt to purchase more than $5 million in stock was no longer deductible, and if companies were no longer able to write-off "goodwill" and similar intangible assets of acquired companies, we would gain $9 billion over five years. 
 * The Puerto Rican subsidy. Drug companies are the principal beneficiaries of the possessions tax credit. The idea was to create jobs in Puerto Rico by giving companies tax credits to set up manufacturing operations there. According to the Congressional Budget Office, repeal of this credit would produce $15 billion in revenue over five years. Do we really need to shelter an industry that charges Americans more for their drugs than consumers are charged anywhere else in the industrialized world?
* The Jacuzzi subsidy. The mortgage interest deduction allows the write-off of interest on mortgages of up to $1 million. Only 19.2 percent of this tax break goes to home owners with incomes below $40,000 (79 percent of taxpayers). If the deduction were capped at 15 percent for home owners with incomes of more than $150,000 (roughly cutting its value in half), the Treasury would save $15 billion a year.
* The advertising subsidy. Companies can write off their annual advertising costs every year. Why not treat some of those expenses as a gradual deduction, since they can contribute to brand recognition that lasts for decades? If 20 percent of the spending for advertising were deducted over four years, the Treasury would raise roughly $18 billion in the first four years, with declining gains after that.
* The Perrier subsidy. Remember the two-martini lunch? Now it's bottled water, but expense-account lunches are still 80 percent deductible. If the deduction were reduced to 50 percent, Federal revenues would rise by $18 billion over five years, and we would discover that the wheels of commerce didn't need that kind of grease.
* The foreigners' subsidy. Interest income earned by foreigners on investments in the U.S. is tax exempt, making the U.S. one of the world's premier tax havens. If a 5 percent tax were imposed on interest earned by foreigners on their U.S. securities, we would gain $11 billion over five years -- even if the tax were waived for those who reported the income to their own governments.
* The speculator subsidy. This isn't a subsidy, but it could cost us a fortune if interest rates go up again. Commercial banks enjoy Federal deposit insurance on money they invest in Treasury securities, which pay higher interest rates than banks pay depositors. But why should we insure deposits that are being used for interest rate speculation? Let's limit the percentage of assets a bank can use to play arbitrage games with insured deposits.
Getting rid of these kinks in the tax code wouldn't hurt the economy. On the contrary, it would allow the Government to invest its tax dollars more productively. Of course, anyone who knows anything about Washington knows that the chances of eliminating subsidies for the folks who write the tax laws are roughly equal to the chances of finding an open suitcase of $100 bills on 34th Street. In other words, it would be a miracle.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Asian AIDS Cases Soon to Pass Africa's

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Nov. 8 special report on AIDS in Asia predicts that reported cases in Asia will multiply in the millions, and the reputation of AIDS as a gay disease will be forgotten. There is, unfortunately, a growing trend to scapegoat gay people as the principal carriers of this disease. 
 Recently, China attributed a jump in AIDS cases to drug addiction, prostitution and homosexuality. A recent gay Asian regional conference held in the Philippines had its conference site changed when the hotel owners realized AIDS was a principal topic. In Japan, where AIDS cases through homosexual transmission is almost double that of heterosexual transmission, new Government pamphlets on human immunodeficiency virus awareness do not directly address the gay population. There is a prevailing notion that AIDS is a result of the gay liberation movement, and any educational materials directed to gays may only increase the AIDS caseload.
The World Health Organization's AIDS surveillance report notes homosexual and bisexual AIDS cases represent 50 percent to 75 percent of the cases in Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, Hong Kong, Malaysia, French Polynesia, New Caledonia and the Philippines.
You speculate that Asian governments have not responded to the AIDS crisis because of fears of offending local standards, of driving away international investors, local denial or plain ignorance of the problem's seriousness. These reasons let many countries off the hook much too easily. Their ruling parties and elites know full well what AIDS is, and their health ministers have attended many world AIDS conferences.
For the less developed and poorer Asian countries, AIDS is inextricably linked to poverty, and if these governments, many of them corrupt, have not addressed basic health issues of their poor before AIDS, there is little reason they will address this disease now. Thailand is the sole exception with its Government backing a successful H.I.V. education program. With more than 35 countries in the region and 25 of these countries reporting H.I.V. and AIDS cases, W.H.O. predicts cumulative AIDS cases in the region will exceed Africa's by the year 2000.
You end by citing how the lingering denial of AIDS in Asian countries will have catastrophic effects on their economies when significant numbers of the work force succumb to the disease. In this global economy, the United States, Japan and Western European nations have significant investments, manufacturing plants and factories in Asia. California alone has a $40 billion yearly trade with Asia.
The economic health and well-being of Asia has profound effects on the Western nations and Japan, and our own denial is exemplified by an absence of sharing resources and experiences in combatting AIDS.
For the second year in a row, the San Francisco AIDS surveillance unit has recorded a decline in the number of reported Asian Pacific Islander AIDS cases, reflecting the same decline as that of the white gay male population. Culturally sensitive and gay-positive educational materials, early intervention and testing and sexual behavior changes have been responsible for this decline. Replicating and sharing these programs in Asia will be one invaluable step in helping to stem an AIDS epidemic there.
 
JOHN L. SILVA
Exec. Dir., Community HIV Project
Gay Asian Pacific Alliance
San Francisco, Nov. 12, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Here's Who First Asked Rock's Big Question

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
It was 1955, there was a revolution on the radio, and five kids from Washington Heights signed up as foot soldiers. Just after the birth of rock-and-roll, they had their moment.
That moment was a simple, tender song called "Why Do Fools Fall in Love?"; the group was Frankie Lymon and the Teen-Agers. For nearly 40 years -- as the song was recorded and rerecorded into the pop music pantheon -- the boy with the sweet soprano and that first blockbuster hit were joined in rock 'n' roll immortality. 
 Yesterday, a bit of revisionist music history was made in a courtroom in lower Manhattan. A Federal jury ruled that two other members of the group had actually first asked the apocalyptic questions posed by the song:
 
Oo-wah oo-wah
Oo-wah oo-wah
Oo-wah oo-wah
Why do fools fall in love?
Why do birds sing so gay?
And lovers await the break of day?
Why do they fall in love?
Frankie Lymon might have had some role, the jury found, but his fellow Teen-Agers -- Jimmy Merchant and Herman Santiago -- were the true and rightful authors.
Now, Mr. Merchant, a cabdriver living in Queens, and Mr. Santiago, who is unemployed and still lives in Washington Heights, stand to collect millions of dollars from those who profited from the song.
"It's been a long, awful struggle that we've been fighting since we were kids," said Mr. Merchant, who is now 52. "Thank God we're alive to see this."
But the struggle is not over. The plaintiffs must go through a second phase of the trial to determine how much they are owed. "I figure there's about $4 million coming to them," said their lawyer, Carl E. Person.
The defense lawyer, Ira Greenberg, said he would ask Judge Naomi Reice Buchwald to reverse the jury's verdict. He would not say if, failing that, his clients would appeal, but he cautioned that the verdict would set a bad precedent by encouraging similar suits years after the fact.
The story of "Why Do Fools Fall in Love?" is a tangled history of music-business chicanery, legal maneuvering and festering resentment, not to mention an earlier courtroom battle over which of Frankie Lymon's three wives was entitled to what was then deemed to be his share of the royalties.
 
Quartet Called the Pre miers-
 It began toward the end of 1955 with a quartet of 15-year-old students at Stitt Junior High in Washington Heights, who called themselves the Premiers. They got a tryout with George Goldner, the sharp-dressing owner of Gee Records, performing a song called "Birds Sing So Gay." Shortly after, Goldner recorded the group and released a record.
What happened in that interval, just a matter of weeks, would haunt Mr. Merchant and Mr. Santiago for 37 years. Another boy from the neighborhood, 13-year-old Frankie Lymon, joined the group and replaced Mr. Santiago as the lead vocalist on the song. The act's name was changed to the Teen-Agers and the song became "Why Do Fools Fall in Love?" And Mr. Lymon and Mr. Goldner, not Mr. Merchant and Mr. Santiago, were named in the copyright as authors.
"Why Do Fools Fall In Love?" soared to the top of the pop charts in early 1956, and the group followed it with an 18-month concert tour. But the members of the band were paid just $1,000 each for their efforts, and Mr. Merchant and Mr. Santiago received no songwriting royalties.
"We were ignorant," Mr. Merchant said. "We did not understand contracts. We didn't know what publishing was. We didn't know about percentages. They said, 'We'll take care of you; the money will be there when you turn 21' and we believed them."
 
Complaints of Intimidation
 Soon, Mr. Merchant recalled, he and Mr. Santiago began to suspect that they had been taken. The singers maintain that when they complained about not being paid, they were intimidated into silence, a pattern that continued over several years when, from time to time, they would raise the issue. Mr. Santiago testified at the trial that a record company executive told him in 1969 that his life would be in danger if he pursued his claim.
Their outrage grew when they realized that Mr. Lymon was receiving songwriting royalties. "Frankie barely did anything on that song," Mr. Merchant said. "It was Herman and me. In the beginning, I was angry at Frankie, but through the years, I began to realize that he was completely manipulated by these people."
Mr. Goldner claimed credit on the premise that the song as actually recorded was substantially different from the song that the Premiers had taken to him. Several second-hand accounts have it that Mr. Goldner put Mr. Lyman's name on the song in order to market it as a schoolboy's love paean to a teacher.
Most of the royalties went to Mr. Goldner and Morris Levy, who was an important promoter and music company owner in the early days of rock-and-roll, and the music companies they owned. In 1964, Mr. Goldner mysteriously signed over the copyright to "Why Do Fools Fall in Love" and other works to Mr. Levy, asserting that he had mistakenly taken songwriting credit that belonged to his colleague.
Mr. Person described the actions of Mr. Goldner and Mr. Levy -- who was convicted years later on two counts of conspiracy to commit extortion -- as "pretty typical of the music world in those days, but very dishonest."
"I don't think the trial was about whether Morris Levy and George Goldner were nice human beings," Mr. Greenberg said. "It was about who wrote the song, and our position was that Merchant and Santiago didn't write the song."
Both Mr. Levy and Mr. Goldner died several years ago. It was the estate of Morris Levy and two companies that he owned, the Big Seven Music Corporation and Roulette Records Inc., that the jury found liable.
Usually, copyright complaints cannot seek royalties from more than three years before the suit was filed. But based on the claim that Mr. Merchant and Mr. Santiago feared the consequences if they took legal action, the jury waived the three-year limit, and found them eligible for royalties they would have collected since 1969, the date of the death threat against them.
Indeed, Mr. Santiago and Mr. Merchant are the sole survivors among the people who created and marketed "Why Do Fools Fall in Love?"
Frankie Lymon left the Teen-Agers in 1957, and the group began a rapid fade into obscurity. The other singers, still teen-agers, began the daily struggle of people who live ordinary lives in the city, while still bitter over what had become of their brief fame. They kept in touch and still occasionally perform together.
Mr. Lymon, after a long struggle with heroin, died of an overdose in 1968 at his grandmother's home in Washington Heights. Another Teen-Ager, Sherman Garnes, died during heart surgery, and a third, Joe Negroni, died of a stroke.
Five years ago, Mr. Santiago and Mr. Merchant began singing together again. They now perform as Frankie Lymon's Teen-Agers, with Louis Lymon taking his late brother's place. "This is what I want to get back to: Making music," Mr. Merchant said.
Because the copyright can be renewed through the year 2030, it can not only make the plaintiffs rich men right away, it can provide a source of income well into their old age.
"That would be very nice," said Mr. Merchant. "I guess it's about time something nice happened to us."
